HEADLINE: FILM; 
Godard in Autumn, Analyzing America

BYLINE:  By STUART KLAWANS 

 BODY:
NIGHTTIME in Paris. People have gathered in a bookshop to hear an American journalist read an eyewitness report of the recent killings in Kosovo. We see that his recitation pains a young Frenchwoman -- because he draws out the r's in "murder."
 "The American accent is awful," she complains, to no one in particular. 
 An older man, standing behind her, retorts: "You asked for the Americans. Now you've got them." 
"I didn't ask," she says.
"And your parents in 1944? Your grandparents in 1918?"
Were this little scene to take place in the average movie, it would be understood, correctly, as a slap in the face of conventional French anti-Americanism. But the exchange is embedded in Jean-Luc Godard's "In Praise of Love" ("Eloge de l'Amour"), opening in New York and Los Angeles on Friday, a film that has been deemed to indulge in that same smug fault.
Reviewing "In Praise of Love" last October when it was shown at the New York Film Festival, A. O. Scott of The New York Times characterized Mr. Godard's attitude toward America as a compound of "slack complacency" and "tinny self-righteousness," as banal as it was unwelcome. (It must be remembered that the mass grave of Lower Manhattan was still smoldering at the time.) A case in point: the episode in which fictional representatives of Steven Spielberg arrogantly negotiate to buy the life stories of an elderly French couple, who were active in the resistance. The critic Kent Jones, writing in Film Comment, said that the sense of anti-Americanism that emerged was particularly objectionable for the lackadaisical hauteur with which it was expressed: "It's as if Godard had an assistant lurking over his shoulder -- 'Sir, we need some material to fill in the space between the blue boat and the man silhouetted against the window.' 'O.K., let's throw in another Spielberg joke.' "
Yes, "In Praise of Love" is reflexively anti-Spielbergian. Whether it's peremptorily anti-American is another question. Mr. Godard makes his characters mouth disparaging comments about America and Americans not once but often, and in ways that can make you wince. The import of those comments, though, may deserve investigation.
A good place to begin, I think, is in Mr. Godard's homemade and magisterial eight-part video series "Histoire(s) du Cinema." As its title suggests, this 1988-98 essay concerns the history of the movies and also the stories told by the movies -- subjects that Mr. Godard introduces by juxtaposing two bygone systems of industrial production: those of MGM and the U.S.S.R. -- "the power of Babylon," as Mr. Godard himself rasps on the soundtrack. Onto the screen comes a view of Lenin's tomb, overlaid with the words "Make me a star."
Fans of Hollywood may reasonably object that Irving Thalberg never set up a gulag. But the comparison, like all good instances of cross-cutting, makes each image reveal something about the other. The Soviets organized their autocratic economy to produce a fiction: the fantasy that a single, benevolent genius guided the workers. Conversely, Hollywood produced its fantasies about stars to conceal a reality: the fact that each studio was an autocratic economy.
The Soviet fiction was finished by the late 1980's, when Mr. Godard made the first chapter of "Histoire(s) du Cinema." The Hollywood fantasy, he thought, ought to have died as well, in 1945, when Europe's concentration camps were opened. At that moment, he says in the video, newsreel photographers were the only filmmakers who did not disgrace themselves. "You don't see close-ups in newsreels. Death is not a movie star."
And yet the Hollywood fantasy outlived the liberation of the death camps -- outlived the studio system too and the efforts of people around the world (including Mr. Godard) to establish a cinema that would do more than tell "stories of sex and death."
Even in 1963, when he was 32 years old and in the first flush of success, Mr. Godard seems to have recognized that Hollywood would roll on. Witness his masterpiece from that year, "Contempt" -- one of film's great stories of sex and death -- in which he put a noticeably Godard-like screenwriter into the unloving hands of an American producer.
To the audience, it is neither surprising nor deplorable that this American is a figure of fun, portrayed by Jack Palance with hilarious self-confidence and an undeniable animal grace. What's inexcusable, in Mr. Godard's terms, is that the screenwriter (Michel Piccoli) betrays his ideal of film art (as embodied by the director Fritz Lang, playing himself), makes a mockery of his political convictions (summed up in his Communist Party card) and drives away his wife, who is represented by no less a personage than Brigitte Bardot. A lightning bolt from Olympus, or its modern-dress equivalent, ultimately destroys the overreaching producer, and the wife as well. But this hardly counts as a triumph for the screenwriter, who has reduced himself to nothing without any such grand stroke.
As a work of critical cinema -- that is, as a movie that tells an engrossing story and at the same time raises questions about how and why the story is told -- "Contempt" makes good on the headiest artistic aspirations of the French New Wave. The film is also an announcement, in advance, of the New Wave's demise -- at least its demise in relation to the kind of Hollywood moviemaking that Mr. Godard dismisses as "cosmetic" in "Histoire(s) du Cinema." You might say, then, that "Contempt" is both critical and self-critical. It analyzes an enormous failure of nerve.
Nearly 40 years later, Mr. Godard, now 71, is still mulling over that failure in his new film. Edgar (Bruno Putzulu), the 30ish would-be artist who mopes his way through "In Praise of Love," is much like the screenwriter in "Contempt," in that he disdains Hollywood's ability to reduce everything to "a story with Julia Roberts." Edgar also resembles the screenwriter in being utterly ineffectual. He leaves projects unfinished. He gets by on financing (or, more bluntly, a handout) from an old family connection. He doesn't even know whether the new work he has in mind -- a project about the phases of love, as experienced by people at different stages of life -- will be a film or a play. On occasion, we see Edgar leafing through an expensively bound notebook full of blank pages. There is no reason to expect that he'll fill any of them.
FINALLY, like the screenwriter in "Contempt," Edgar has a talent for pushing away women. He pursues Berthe (Cecile Camp) for reasons that may be both artistic and romantic and then drops her, as he drops everything. When asked why, Edgar can think of no better response than "She was a letdown."
"No," comes the unanswerable reply. "You're the letdown."
I'd suggest, then, that we shouldn't take Edgar's opinions too literally, either in themselves or as a credo from Mr. Godard. When Edgar criticizes something he calls America, he perhaps does not mean a large and complex nation that has done some good in the world (in 1944, in 1918) but rather is pointing to the world's dominant source of fantasies about stars. It is arguable, but not patently unfair, to say that this America spreads a false universalism -- one that unites the globe in the simplemindedness of commercial entertainment, and all its related products. (Had Mr. Godard confined his example to "The Matrix" and left Spielberg out of it, perhaps all this would be more clear.) On the other hand, Edgar mounts no credible resistance to what he calls America. He is a letdown.
And what about Mr. Godard? How credible is his resistance to the evils of this world?
As "In Praise of Love" reveals, his work has changed in the last dozen years, during what seems to be his autumnal period. The Brechtian signboards have multiplied, to the point that practically every line of dialogue is a quotation from a literary source or a venerable film. The soundtrack, too, has grown more dense, swirling and flowing with a life of its own. Meanwhile, the actors have diminished in importance (no more personalities on the scale of Palance, Piccoli, Bardot). Mr. Godard now treats them as just another set of elements in his editing mix. There's no longer much of a sense that the camera is probing the outside world. What you see and hear seems internal to Mr. Godard.
And what you see and hear is gorgeous: lyrical, heartbreaking, exquisite, sure. "In Praise of Love" gives us the autumnal Mr. Godard performing at the highest level of his art, doing what he knows and loves better than almost anyone. That's his resistance.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bruno Putzulu in Jean-Luc Godard's "In Praise of Love": America is not the only problem. (Manhattan Pictures International)(pg. 7); In "Contempt," Michel Piccoli is a screenwriter who betrays his art. (Brigitte Bardot plays his wife.) (Strand Releasing)(pg. 14)

PERSON: STEVEN SPIELBERG (54%) GODARD, JEAN-LUC; KLAWANS, STUART

TITLE: IN PRAISE OF LOVE (MOVIE)

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Squeezing Yourself Out (for the Company)

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SANTIAGO 

 BODY:
HALFWAY into it, Hugh C. Martin realized that the merger he had initiated to protect his fiber optic company would cost him his job.
 Mr. Martin had joined the company, ONI Systems of San Jose, Calif., as chief executive in 1998, shortly after it was started. By 2000, ONI, a maker of equipment for routing phone calls and computer data, had become one of the fastest-growing companies in Silicon Valley. 
 But last year, an "economic buzz saw" threatened the bandwith industry, he said, and even a cost-cutting drive that cut his own salary to $1 from $295,000 didn't help. So he started looking for a corporate partner.
He soon learned firsthand a business principle akin to the law of physics that says no two bodies can exist at the same time in the same place: When two companies wed, there can be only one surviving boss.
Those who are asked to step aside rarely like to talk publicly about the experience. But now, taking the summer off to sail around Martha's Vineyard with his family and to ponder what to do next, he has agreed to tell about his.
Four years ago, Mr. Martin caught the attention of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm that was one of ONI's original backers. With a track record that included positions as head of desktop engineering at Apple Computer and president of 3DO, a video game start-up, he was brought into Kleiner as an entrepreneur in residence.
Kevin Compton, a partner at Kleiner, then offered him the top job at ONI. "He told me, 'You will work harder than you ever have before in your life, but I have the feeling you will make more money than you can ever imagine,' " recalled Mr. Martin, now 49.
He began by luring optical engineering talent from competitors like Nortel Networks. He also staked out an early claim in a relatively overlooked niche, technology for high-speed video transmission adapted to a more lucrative telecom market.
The company focused on fiber optic gear that brokers data traffic within cities after the data travels between cities. When ONI got into the game, most telecom equipment vendors offered only long-haul products, as carriers rushed to build a national fiber optic infrastructure.
All those fiber optic lines crisscrossing the country, however, were still at the mercy of the copper wires to which they connected upon entering their urban destinations. "If you've got something that runs a million miles an hour that connects to something that runs one mile an hour, then everything runs at one mile an hour," said Mr. Compton, who was also an ONI board member.
So ONI made a play for that missing piece of the network, equipment for local applications. Mr. Martin saw an opportunity "to go build another Cisco" and to focus on customers like SBC Communications and Verizon. By last year, ONI's revenue had increased to $195.7 million and its market share to 25 percent.
That was quite an achievement against rivals like Nortel and Lucent Technologies, yet the industry's recession didn't spare ONI. As orders fell, expenses kept ahead of revenue and ONI never made a profit. Larger carriers started gobbling up the weak and worrying about equipment companies like ONI, asking whether they would still be around in two or three years. These carriers sought more critical mass from vendors offering complete product lines in both long- and short-haul equipment. Competition intensified for fewer equipment deals of greater value.
"SOME of these contracts are worth a billion dollars over four years," Mr. Martin said. "And the risk that we would lose that business, because we weren't this large established broad-product-lane supplier, got high enough that I felt it was important to consider alternatives."
By last December, Mr. Martin decided that the answer was partnership with another midsized company, and he made overtures to the Ciena Corporation of Linthicum, Md. Early discussions of a possible alliance quickly blossomed into merger talks. 
As they progressed, he says, it didn't occur to him that he might soon be out of a job. He focused on saving ONI and persuading employees and shareholders to go along.
Some of them, he said, were thinking like this: "If you have a great product and you are a leading contender for some of these large pieces of business, why on earth would you sell or merge the company?"
His response: "I think Ciena is extremely undervalued right now, and so, going in as part of Ciena, if we go win one of these big deals, our shareholders will see as much appreciation as they would have seen on a stand-alone basis."
Then, as the talks progressed, Ciena officials broke the news to him. "They politely said to me, 'This all makes sense, we are extremely interested in doing the deal, but we don't see a role for you,' " he said.
"It was depressing to me because I really wanted to help integrate our company into that company and then take a leadership role," he added.
Recovering from the news, he realized they were right. Staying would have diluted upper management's authority and confused everybody else, so he bowed to the inevitable.
He even made light of his fate. "Oh, he had a great sense of humor," said Gary Smith, Ciena's chief executive. "He'd say, 'You know, I know there can only be one C.E.O., and Gary got the short straw.' "
Inside, though, he was still smarting. "Here it was my idea," he said. "We are going to glue these two things together and I think it's going to be a huge success. And I have to watch from the sidelines."
An agreement for Ciena to acquire ONI in a stock transaction was reached in February, yet he was still feeling pangs of regret as he dined on crab cakes and Champagne during the signing ceremony in June.
"That was my all-time low point," he said. "It took about a month for me to adjust, reconcile and say 'O.K., I'm going to move on.' "
He remains a consultant to Ciena and owns shares worth about $15 million that he received in exchange for his shares in ONI.
He is upbeat about his prospects. "I will probably eventually start another company, he said. "Now I have a reputation. I can be selective about what I go do."

HEADLINE: A Big Pay Raise Awaits the Next Governor 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
AS Gov. John G. Rowland and Bill Curry, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, vie for the state's top seat in government, what many voters may not realize is that the winner of this fall's election will receive a salary that is nearly 100 percent more than the current pay for the post.
 Starting in January, the state's top elected official will receive $150,000, up from $78,000. In the process, Connecticut's governor will go from being one of the lowest paid in the country to one of the highest paid. 
 The pay hike comes at a time when the state is grappling with budget shortfalls and reductions that have forced places like the University of Connecticut Health Center to freeze managerial salaries. But the chairman of the commission that recommended the governor's raise said it was long overdue. 
"I think that a pay raise to $150,000 from $78,000 is not unseemly given the fact that there has been no raise in 15 years," said Bruce D. Rubenstein, chairman of the Commission on Compensation of Elected State Officials and Judges.
In fact, by private sector standards, the occupant of the governor's office will still be underpaid, according to several compensation experts.
"One hundred fifty thousand today for a chief executive is quite a bargain," said Judith Fischer, managing director of Executive Compensation Advisory Services in Alexandria, Va. "I'm sure if they sat down and worked it out on a per hourly rate it would be a real steal."
The last time the governor had a pay increase was in 1987, according to a report by the compensation commission. The independent commission, which in 2000 recommended a series of salary increases for statewide office holders, found that at the time the governor's salary ranked 42nd in the country.
The new salary will make the governor the fourth highest paid in the country behind New York, California and Illinois, according to "The Book of the States 2002," which is published by the Council of State Governments. 
In fact, since the office has not had a pay increase in so long, many state employees, including members of the governor's staff, have salaries that exceed the governor's, according to the commission.
"While salaries for public officials will never equal those for private-sector administrators with similar responsibilities, the unfavorable relationship of the governor's salary level to those of subordinate managers needs to be addressed," the commission wrote in a report in February 2000.
Why the governor's pay has remained flat for such a long time can be traced to sensitivity to the public's often negative reaction to pay increases for public servants. In fact, when a bill was introduced in 1998, an election year, to increase the pay of legislators and other statewide offices, a raise for the governor was eliminated at the last minute after Mr. Rowland threatened to veto it if it was included.
Consequently, the commission urged the legislature to adopt the pay raises well in advance of the next gubernatorial election to avoid making the subject a political football.
"The commission recommends taking care of this now, well before the beginning of the next campaign for statewide elected officials," the commission wrote. "As we approach the election, the issue of salaries becomes more politically sensitive."
In June 2000, the General Assembly did just that, and not only increased the governor's salary but increased the pay of the lieutenant governor, secretary of the state, treasurer, comptroller and attorney general. The occupants of each of those statewide offices will receive $110,000, starting in January.
Two years later, however, the economy is struggling and some of those raises may seem extravagant at a time when temporary state workers have been told not to come to work and some institutions are considering layoffs.
"Obviously it's a bad time for the governor to get such a big salary increase when so many other people are hurting," said Howard Reiter, a political science professor at the University of Connecticut. "So the timing is not good politically."
But, Mr. Rubenstein noted, there was no way the commission could predict what the economy would look like in 2003.
"We don't have the ability to foresee what the economic situation will be two years after we pass reform legislation," Mr. Rubenstein said. "If we had the ability of hindsight it might have been a different story, but we don't have that ability. We are only human."
But a 92.3 percent raise?
"We are not rewarding anybody's performance," said Mr. Rubenstein, who is a Democrat. "We are not saying that Governor Rowland did a good job at all or a bad job. This has nothing to do with his performance in office. The voters will decide his performance in office. This has to do with the office and not the person in the office."
Others said that the role of the governor, who oversees a $13.2 billion budget and about 52,000 employees, is comparable to the chief executive officers of private companies. If that is the case, then even with the $150,000 salary, he is underpaid.
In fact, under the current salary structure, the governor's pay is just a little more than the average salary for a construction manager or a veterinarian, according to 2000 occupational wage statistics from the state Department of Labor. The salary increase will put the governor in line with an anesthesiologist whose average salary in 2000 was $144,940, according to the Department of Labor.
"That's not very much is it?" said Graef Crystal, a compensation expert in Las Vegas. "If you compare it to the private sector, you couldn't pay the governor enough to do that job."
A chief executive officer of a company with tens of thousands of employees, like the state of Connecticut, would probably make anywhere from $10 million to $15 million a year, Mr. Crystal said. 
"So it's one of those things," he said. "Dig as deep as you can. Pay him as much as you can, because there's no danger of overpaying the bloke."
That said, Mr. Crystal noted that the perks the governor receives, such as a state trooper who drives him, a car and the executive residence, increases the value of his compensation. And, he added, the job does have clout. That is one reason the public has never advocated for large salaries for public servants. 
"So the general perception among the American public is that you can trade money for prestige," he said. "There's a literal trade off there. So if you want to have the Connecticut 1 license plate, the howling motorcycle sirens and all of that stuff, then we don't pay you much."
Mr. Reiter said the prestige is why there will probably never be a dearth of candidates for governor, even though Minnesota Gov. Jesse Ventura said that one reason he opted not to run for re-election was the low pay, which in his state is $120,000.
But Mr. Reiter said that despite a frequent negative public reaction to increasing the pay of public servants, adequate compensation plays a critical role in a democratic government.
"In principle I don't have any problem with higher salaries for public officials because you don't want to create a situation where only wealthy people would be willing to take on those jobs," he said. "It would be a shame where just people with either connections to wealthy individuals or who are wealthy themselves can run for these offices." 
But, Mr. Reiter added, the salaries for public officials will never compete with comparable jobs in the private sector.
"I don't think they should," he said. "You don't want anybody running for public office simply because it's going to line their pockets." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Connecticut's governor will soon go from being one of the lowest paid in the country to one of the highest paid. (Joseph Kugielsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fort Greene; 
Diversity, Culture and Brownstones, Too

BYLINE:  By NANCY BETH JACKSON 

 BODY:
SPIKE LEE has relocated to the Upper East Side and Spike's Joint, his boutique at the corner of South Elliot Place and Lafayette Avenue, is history, but the filmmaker's lens still frames the image of Fort Greene, the Brooklyn neighborhood where he grew up. When he began his career with the 1986 comedy "She's Gotta Have It," he drew upon the world he knew best: the artsy, well-educated, African-American middle class that has thrived in Fort Greene since the mid-19th century.
 "I thought the entire neighborhood would look like it came right out of a Spike Lee film," said Joanna Gonzales, a 29-year-old television producer from Los Angeles, who recently studied Fort Greene in a graduate journalism seminar at Columbia. 
 She imagined an affluent black neighborhood where everyone lived in brownstones. Instead, she discovered racial and economic diversity and a "prevailing sense of racial amity" that intrigues sociologists and attracts middle-class residents from other parts of the city. 
"People move to and remain in Fort Greene because they want to live in a tolerant, relaxed neighborhood, not a homogeneous one that resists strangers," Jan Rosenberg, a Long Island University sociology professor, concluded in a 1998 report on policy development for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Fort Greene, named after Nathanael Greene, a Revolutionary War general who was in charge of building a fort there, has had its ups and downs, but these days it is a hot real estate market. The neighborhood's diversity, proximity to Manhattan, fine 19th-century town houses, relative affordability and cultural life draw young professionals, black and white, who are more likely to work on Wall Street or in law firms than recite poetry at coffeehouses. 
Added into the mix are the French, who have opened bistros, food shops and sidewalk cafes and also come as tourists, guidebooks in hand, after reading items about Fort Greene in the Parisian press. "It's this season's hottest neighborhood in Paris," said the Rev. David Dyson, minister of the Lafayette Presbyterian Church, who heard about the publicity blitz through one of his French parishioners.
On the edge of downtown Brooklyn, Fort Greene is anchored by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Fort Greene Park and the Atlantic Center, a 26-acre retail and housing complex that introduced chain stores like Macy's and Old Navy into a neighborhood of locally owned shops and boutiques. The IRT, BMT and Long Island Rail Road converge under the center, creating what Gov. George E. Pataki called "the busiest transportation hub in Brooklyn" when he recently announced a $200 million project to spruce up the terminal complex. A second shopping mall, to be built above the terminal, has already signed leases with retailers like Victoria's Secret and Gap.
Most of the real estate activity is south and east of Fort Greene Park, the traditional economic divide in the neighborhood, but revitalization is also beginning along Myrtle Avenue, the northern edge of the Fort Greene Historic District, which was designated in 1978.
Some longtime locals fear being priced out; other residents, old and new, fear that development will destroy the vibes that drew them to the neighborhood.
"We joke about it, but this has become the land of the buppies -- black urban professionals," said Ibrahim Abdul-Matin, a 25-year-old whose grandfather came to Fort Greene as an Army lieutenant in World War II. Mr. Abdul-Matin, a science fiction writer and youth programs director at the Prospect Park Alliance, still sees the neighborhood as his muse, but he worries that the Brooklyn Moon, a Fulton Street coffeehouse with legendary Friday night poetry readings, may become just another Villagelike bar.
THE community's history began and almost ended with the 260-acre New York Naval Shipyard on Wallabout Bay. After the Brooklyn Navy Yard, as it is usually called, was commissioned in 1801, craftsmen -- freed slaves and Irish, English and German immigrants -- settled on the adjacent farmlands. Walt Whitman lived in the working-class neighborhood when he edited The Brooklyn Eagle.
By 1840, the shipyard was the largest Navy construction facility in the country. During the Civil War, more than 6,000 craftsmen labored there, with Fort Greene developing as its commercial center. Colored School No. 1 opened at St. Edwards Street and Park Avenue in 1847 for the children of black workers. By 1870, more than half of the blacks in Brooklyn lived in Fort Greene, most of them north of Fort Greene Park.
In the 1850's through 1880's, an elegant neighborhood developed south and east of the park in three- and four-story row houses of brick and brownstone, built by speculators to attract families from Manhattan and beyond. Abolitionists formed the Lafayette Presbyterian Church in 1857, establishing its tradition of activism by offering a forum to speakers like Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman and aiding runaway slaves. 
The church, mirroring the neighborhood's demographics, is now about two-thirds black and one-third white, with a gospel choir that opened the TriBeCa Film Festival this year. Mr. Dyson, a white former union organizer, makes sure the church is a forum on social issues.
"There's great housing stock, trees, a kind of bohemian character and wonderful music, art and theater in the community, but nobody wants another Lincoln Center with everything pulled down," Mr. Dyson said.
World War II brought a significant change to Fort Greene, with many row houses converted into rooming houses and a government housing project built on Myrtle Avenue to accommodate workers. After the war, whites began to desert both public housing and row houses. In 1944, wartime housing was built that later became the public housing complex called the Walt Whitman and Raymond V. Ingersoll Houses, made up of 3,500 units on 38 acres.
The shipyard's decommissioning in 1966 increased white flight. BAM was covered with graffiti, its performing arts spaces turned over to martial arts classes.
Fort Greene descended into urban decay, with one section of its ghetto nicknamed the Jungle. The Pratt Area Community Council was organized in 1964 to improve the quality of life by encouraging homeownership. Slowly, Fort Greene revived as residents and major institutions in the area acted to reclaim the neighborhood. When Mr. Lee established his Forty Acres and a Mule Filmworks in the 1980's, Fort Greene's artistic life was being compared to the Harlem renaissance.
The community spirit is what attracted Nazli Parvisi, an Iranian-born Barnard College graduate who never dreamed of living in Brooklyn until a friend encouraged her to buy in Fort Greene two years ago.
"Fort Greene isn't like Williamsburg, where a whole pack of kids come in and take over the neighborhood," said Ms. Parvisi, 25, an assistant program director at the Social Science Research Council and co-owner of a catering service called the Night Kitchen. "They couldn't do it here even if they wanted to, because the neighborhood has a strong backbone and always has." 
Although she commutes to Midtown Manhattan to work, she finds almost all her social life within walking distance of her apartment. She shops in the African-American designer boutiques on Fulton Street and drops in on Thursday nights at Frank's Lounge to hear Ronnie Youngblood, the saxophonist, deliver rhythm and blues to an audience diverse in age as well as race. Her Manhattan friends are eager to join her in the nightclubs along De Kalb Avenue and in local restaurants that offer African, Cambodian, Middle Eastern, Japanese and European cuisine.
Finding it cheaper to own in Fort Greene than rent in Morningside Heights, she bought a studio in a doorman building south of the park for $93,000. Real estate agents say Fort Greene studios now go for around $130,000. Although still less than in Manhattan, real estate prices have soared.
"One million dollars is the magic number for a town house now," said Dale Smith, a lawyer from the Virgin Islands who has rented in Fort Greene for four years. "I think I'm priced out of the neighborhood already."
He and his wife, Alicia, a University of Pennsylvania law graduate and a full-time mother, recently moved to a brownstone garden duplex when their former landlord decided to put the brownstone in which they rented on the market for $1.25 million.
"The cost of real estate is past outrageous," Mrs. Smith said. "And who wants to spend a million dollars when you can't send your children to school here?"
Public education in Fort Greene ranges from schools with some of the city's lowest test scores to the prestigious Brooklyn Technical High School and the Benjamin Banneker Academy, a two-year-old charter school with 200 students from kindergarten through third grade and 160 more on the waiting list. The Queen of All Saints School, which has kindergarten though eighth grade, had openings only in kindergarten and sixth grade this year and is limited by space to 250 students. Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, where Rudolph W. Giuliani was a graduate, has around 900 students. Such schools draw from beyond the immediate neighborhood.
Newcomers praise the Dillon Child Study Center preschool, staffed by St. Joseph's College master teachers, but they look to Brooklyn Heights or Manhattan private schools for their older children. Long Island University, Polytechnic University and the Pratt Institute also have campuses in Fort Greene or neighboring Clinton Hill.
THOUGH fears about displacement from gentrification continue, the old neighborhood will not go quietly, if at all. 
In January, the Pratt Area Community Council established the Displacement Watch to help residents given 30-day eviction notices by landlords of unregulated town house properties. The council holds weekly meetings for tenants, negotiates with landlords and organizes letter-writing campaigns, prayer vigils and demonstrations.
"A lot of these tenants -- working-class people like nurses and teachers -- are the backbone of the community," said Gabriel Thompson, an organizer for the council. "They remember when they couldn't walk on the streets after 6 p.m. because of the crime and lived through that. They're not saying that they don't like the new restaurants and safer streets, but they want to stay and enjoy some of it."
Mr. Dyson added: "Fort Greene used to be one of Brooklyn's best-kept secrets. But I guess the secret is out."

The A and C trains stop at Lafayette Avenue.GOVERNMENT: City Councilman James Davis (Democrat).CODES: Area, 718; ZIP, 11217, 11238, 11205.LUNGS OF THE CITY: Fort Greene never was much as forts go. Gen. Nathanael Greene hurriedly built Fort Putnam on a hill in the Brooklyn plain in 1776, but the British soon routed the rebels. As another war threatened in 1812, residents dug a few trenches and built some barriers, naming their fortification after General Greene. While editor of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, Walt Whitman called the hill the "lungs of the city" and campaigned for Brooklyn's first park, originally called Washington Park, which was created in 1848 Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, who later designed Central Park, added shady walks and open grassy spaces in 1864 to produce "a somewhat rural character." The Prison Ship Martyrs Monument, a 148-foot-high Doric column designed by McKim, Meade & White and dedicated in 1908, honors the Revolutionary soldiers who died in British prison ships anchored in Wallabout Bay. Richard Wright wrote parts of "Native Son" in Fort Greene Park in the late 1930's, but by the 1970's, few dared even walk through it. The 30-acre park is now again full of activity. Among the activities are tennis courts, playgrounds, concerts and herb identification walks. There is also a Web site at www.fortgreenepark.org. Map of Brooklyn highlights Fort Greene.

HEADLINE: A Water-Wealthy Island Considers Desalination Plants 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
OFFICIALS are considering whether to build desalination plants, the first on Long Island, to deal with a water shortage that forced Shelter Island to truck in drinking water last month after two of its public wells ran dry.
 Arthur R. Williams, the Shelter Island supervisor, said the town government was also weighing running a water pipeline nearly a mile to North Haven to pump water from the Suffolk County Water Authority, or drilling new wells. He said he favors the latter option. 
 "I think we'll find more water," Mr. Williams said. "I'd like to start drilling in the next couple of weeks." 
The water supply for Shelter Island and the rest of Long Island comes from underground aquifers estimated to hold enough freshwater to supply its inhabitants for as long as 450 years. But some coastal areas have experienced an increase in saltwater intrusion, which happens when pumping alters the equilibrium between fresh and salty zones of the aquifer.
Lack of rain has not been a direct factor in the problems on Shelter Island, where lawn watering was banned in April. But drought-related water consumption has contributed to saltwater intrusion elsewhere. It is the reason the Suffolk County Water Authority imposed a six-month moratorium in May on new hookups in the Town of Southold, said Michael Stevenson, the authority's deputy chief executive.
"The moratorium gives us a chance to develop long-range plans," he said. "We have a limited supply of good quality water on the North Fork. The aquifer there is shallow, and it sits on top of saltwater. We don't want to overpump the aquifer because of saltwater intrusion."
Stephen M. Jones, chief executive of the Suffolk County Water Authority, said a desalination plant on the North Fork would need to process about a million gallons a day of brackish water.
"We are seriously considering such a plant," he said. "But it is the most expensive alternative we are exploring. It is far removed economically from the other alternatives -- it's up in the stratosphere."
A desalination plant on Long Island would never exhaust its supply of saltwater. But Mr. Stevenson estimated that desalination would cost about $2 to $2.33 per thousand gallons delivered, compared with the current rate of $1.33 per thousand gallons. And Mr. Jones wondered, "What do we do with all of the salt?"
Cape May, N.J., has two desalination plants that are each comparable to the one under consideration for the North Fork, and officials in Cape May said they were pleased with them.
"In my mind, it's a really good idea," said Carl Behrens, the chief operator of the Cape May plants.
Each of Cape May's plants, supplied by brackish water drawn from 800-foot wells, are designed to desalinate a million gallons daily. The process removes salt and other minerals from the water through reverse osmosis, a process that forces the water through a permeable membrane.
The two plants cost $5 million -- all but $2 million came from state and federal grants -- and began operating in July 1998. And at 22 feet long, 8 feet wide and 16 feet high, they were small enough to be installed in an existing public works building.
"It's not a large facility, and there is nothing to indicate it's a desalination plant," said Luciano V. Corea, Cape May's city administrator. "You could drive right by it."
Mr. Behrens said that the price of desalination has come down considerably in recent years and that the cost should be no more than $1.60 per thousand gallons. As for the salt, it is flushed into nearby Cape Island Creek and from there into the Atlantic, Mr. Corea said. 
As he put it, "What's the problem with putting salty water into salty water?" 
He added that the water pumped from the ground is also checked quarterly for zinc, chromium, lead and other toxic chemicals.
"The tests have determined that we are not affecting the ecosystem," Mr. Corea said.
Christopher F. Smith, marine program director for the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County, said the vast majority of desalination plants in the United States discharge the salt they remove back into surface water.
"All of them have done environmental impact statements regarding that and all indicated that it does not have a harmful impact on the environment because of the dilution ability of the ocean," he said.
Mr. Jones said the Suffolk County Water Authority would soon begin environmental reviews of the alternatives and that he hoped to select one by the end of November so that it could be included in next year's capital budget.
Mr. Stevenson stressed that the authority planned to examine all options. "If bringing icebergs down here were feasible and environmentally friendly, we'd even look at that," he said.
Mr. Jones said the authority must take into consideration a federal proposal to reduce the permissible amount of nitrates in drinking water. A desalination plant would take care of the problem; drilling new local wells might require an additional expenditure for a treatment plant. A third option, piping water to the North Fork from the Pine Barrens 10 miles away, would not require a treatment plant but would involve the construction of the pipeline.
The prolonged hot, dry weather has caused other problems around the Island. Huntington Town, which operates the Dix Hills Water District, said in August that demand from lawn irrigation systems had "reached dangerous levels."
The district has the largest per capita summer use of water in the United States, according to Robert J. Farmer, associate public health engineer for the Suffolk County Department of Health Services.
"The Dix Hills district, which services roughly 8,400 residential properties, has for the past week pumped an average of 17 million gallons per day," the town said in a statement on Aug. 15. "During the winter, the average daily use is 2.5 million gallons."
Such usage forces the water district to tap into its above-ground water tanks, which hold 1.25 million gallons and act as reserves in the event of a fire or when there is unusual demand.
"On Tuesday or Wednesday last week, water levels in the tanks went down to zero," Joseph P. D'Alessandro, the Dix Hills fire chief, said on Aug. 18.
He said that by 9 a.m., water levels in the tanks were generally back to normal but that it was the overnight hours, when many homeowners water their lawns, that he was most concerned about.
The Huntington Town Board has ordered mandatory odd-even lawn-watering restrictions in the water district from May through September. Houses with even-numbered street addresses are permitted to water on even-numbered days and vice-versa.
A Nassau County ordinance adopted in 1987 requires odd-even watering of lawns throughout the county and imposes a $50 fine for violators. It is up to each water district to monitor compliance; the Nassau County Police Department issues the summonses. A spokeswoman for the department said she did not have statistics available on the number of summonses issued.
Although the rules in Huntington Town went into effect last year, the town is enforcing them strictly this year and issued 1,000 warning notices in the last month, said Susan A. Berland, a town board member. 
"When they get the notices, people seem to wake up," she said. "If it's a question of a green lawn or being able to fight a fire, they understand the priorities."
Mr. D'Alessandro said this summer was the worst the department had faced in terms of low water pressure and water levels.
"This is the bottom," he said. "We can't go any lower, or we won't have water."
Donald McKay, a spokesman for Huntington Town, said that in the days after Huntington officials held a news conference to express their concerns, "there was a noticeable decrease in water usage." He attributed the drop to public awareness of the problem, as well as cooler temperatures and rain that finally put green into some lawns.
Sarah J. Meyland of Huntington, executive director of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, a statewide organization, said the combination of a lack of rain and a lowering of the water table due to constant pumping is drying up lakes and streams. 
"Hempstead Lake is now Hempstead mud flats," Ms. Meyland said. "Maybe there are remnants of a lake there, but by and large it's all dried up. That's the lowest level that anyone can recall."
"All surface water bodies on Long Island are fed by groundwater, and as the water table drops, a lot of the lakes and streams dry up or the streams get shorter because there is nothing to feed them," she said. 
At a Suffolk Legislature hearing in early August to discuss the drought, Ms. Meyland argued that the supply of groundwater was not infinite. She said that despite the contention of the Suffolk County Water Authority that the aquifers hold at least 70 trillion gallons of water, enough to last hundreds of years even if it never rained again, she believes only 8 trillion could actually be extracted.
Ms. Meyland said that when you figure that Suffolk and Nassau Counties each pump 69 billion gallons a year, "this notion that you can't pump it dry, that it will last forever, is ridiculous."
Although the latest geologic studies show continued saltwater intrusion on Nassau's North Shore, Ms. Meyland said that for the second year in a row budget constraints had kept Nassau County from contracting with the United States Geological Survey to examine the impact of the drought and the level of the water table.
The National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C., reported that July was the second-driest on Long Island in the center's 108 years of recordkeeping.
On Shelter Island, 25 inches of rain normally falls between October and March, but only 6 or 7 inches fell in the same period in 2001-02, said Mr. Williams, the town supervisor.
He said problems in the West Neck Water District developed at the beginning of August when the district's two older wells dried up and the third was cut back to operate at 60 percent of capacity. But on Aug. 8, the pump in that well broke, leaving the district without water.
The water district called on the Suffolk County Water Authority, which brought in four water trucks that were placed strategically throughout the district. A new water pump was installed on Aug. 9. The Suffolk County Department of Health Services monitored water pumped from that well over the weekend and gave the approval for its use on Aug. 12.
Last month, the Department of Health Services presented a groundwater study that found that the aquifer beneath Shelter Island was only 100 feet deep at its deepest point.
"Below that is saltwater, clay and then saltwater again," Mr. Williams said he was told. "Their engineers firmly believe that our aquifer is isolated and limited. They said it is fragile." 
Ron J. Paulsen, a hydrologist with the Suffolk County Office of Water Resources, said Long Island experienced its worst drought from 1965 through 1968 and that if the present drought continues for another year, it would be comparable to that period.
Mr. Stevenson of the Suffolk County Water Authority said it has mounted a $200,000 advertising campaign to encourage its 355,000 customers to use odd-even lawn watering. He pointed out that in July, the authority pumped a record 12.1 billion gallons of water, eclipsing the 11.3 billion gallons set in July 1999.

HEADLINE: Back to School 2002: Ever More Minds to Feed 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
IF demographers and planners are on the money, Long Island is unlikely to see again an explosion in school-aged children to match the 1960's and 1970's, when enrollment rose through the schoolhouse roof and new schools sprouted like mushrooms.
 The baby boomers who filled those classroom seats are now middle-aged. The era of rapid housing development that brought tens of thousands of children into the schools is over. Population growth has been flat in Nassau and moderate in Suffolk for more than two decades. By 2000, the most recent year for which figures were available, public school enrollment was 247,850 in Suffolk and 202,882 in Nassau, far fewer than the 318,364 enrollment in Suffolk and 321,209 in Nassau in 1972, the peak enrollment year. 
 But a moderate upward trend in public school enrollment has emerged in the last five years, and with students heading back to school this week it appears to be continuing. School administrators say it reflects the Island's surging Hispanic population, a demographic echo of the baby boomer generation and, particularly in Suffolk County, the effects of housing development in the few remaining areas of Long Island not yet built out. 
In school districts and private schools on the East End, officials were also attributing a small part of the upward tick to a continuation of post-9/11 flight from New York City as families took up permanent residence in second homes.
The baby boomer echo was the faintest of the upward pressures but perhaps the most evenly distributed across the two counties. In some school districts, it was seen as adding dozens, or in larger districts, hundreds of extra students in recent years.
School officials in several Suffolk County districts said the far greater enrollment impact came from sharp increases in Hispanic students.
At the East Hampton high school, temporary classrooms have been installed to accommodate a jump in enrollment. Noel McStay, the district superintendent, said Hispanic students now accounted for nearly a quarter of the student body, up from about 7 percent when he arrived in the district nine years ago.
"We're a service-oriented community with a large number of summer residents, and with that comes the need for landscaping and maintenance," he said. Many who hold those jobs are Hispanic. Figures from the Suffolk County Planning Department show the Hispanic population in East Hampton increased from 812 in 1990 to 2,914 in 2000, a 259 percent increase.
School officials will soon ask district residents to approve a multimillion-dollar project to add 20 classrooms, a gym and a cafeteria. The school board was still working out the costs.
In the Hampton Bays school district, J. Bruce McKenna, the superintendent, said Hispanic students were a factor in a recent enrollment surge. "We've been exploding out here for the past two or three years," he said. Enrollment went from 1,370 in 1999 to an anticipated 1,720 this fall, a 26 percent increase. The district will soon ask voters to approve a $40 million to $50 million construction bond.
School officials said they neither know nor inquire whether Hispanic students are in the country legally. "That's not my job and I won't do it," Mr. McStay said. "If a child is brought into East Hampton, it's our job to educate that child."
Mr. McStay said children brought from the city after Sept. 11 were a distant second in spurring enrollment increases.
At the Hampton Day School, a private school in Bridgehampton for pre-school through eighth grade, enrollment and applications were holding steady, said Jim Ferrer, the headmaster.
Mr. Ferrer said that after Sept. 11 the school received telephone calls from anxious parents of children attending schools in New York City. He said about 12 new students enrolled, but that the families of about half of them had since moved back to the city. "We even had a couple that went back last spring," he said.
Real estate professionals in some parts of Long Island said they had seen movements of families with children into their communities after the World Trade Center attack. "That happened immediately after Sept. 11," said Judi Desiderio, vice president of Cook Pony Farm, a real estate company with offices in the Hamptons. "They wanted to be safe and they wanted their kids in schools out here."
But in Southampton, as in East Hampton and Hampton Bays, school officials said they knew of only a trickle of such students. "It was not dramatic," said Josephine DeVincenzi, an assistant to the superintendent in the Southampton school district. She said children of 8 to 10 families leaving the city enrolled. The East End's expanding Hispanic population, she said, was a greater cause of moderate enrollment increases.
Dr. DeVincenzi said her district expected to add 40 to 50 students this year. From 1998 to 2001, enrollment increased from 1,616 to 1,761. As of last week, 1,748 students were enrolled for this school year but more were expected.
In Great Neck, where some real estate agents also noted some buyers and home hunters wanting to leave the city after Sept. 11, the Great Neck public school district said enrollment was only slightly up. The district projects it will enroll 5,975 students this school year, up 43 students from last year. From June 2001 to June 2002, enrollment actually declined slightly.
Alicemarie Bresnihan, the president of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association, said that while enrollment was increasing moderately in many Long Island districts, very little was due to Sept. 11. 
Mrs. Bresnihan said she believed a more common cause was "a turnover of houses as older people moving out of the area are replaced by younger people" with school-aged children.
"Even a moderate increase can be a problem," said Mrs. Bresnihan, a member of the Lynbrook school board for 27 years. "It's not like we're back in the 60's, but it's a problem in terms of needing more teachers, classroom space and services."
From the 1997-1998 school year to the 1999-2000 school year, Suffolk enrollment grew by 10,229 and Nassau enrollment rose by 7,408, state Education Department statistics show. Anecdotal evidence indicates the trend has continued unabated.
Enrollment increases have been largest in districts where housing development has been most pronounced. In the Eastport-South Manor Central High School District, a new high school will open next year to accommodate rising enrollment linked to extensive development, particularly in Eastport. Voters have approved an $88 million bond to finance construction.
Frank J. Carasiti, the superintendent, said enrollment was also growing dramatically in the South Manor and Eastport elementary school districts, which he also heads. In Eastport, he said, enrollment in grades K-6 rose 7 percent over the summer, with more students still expected.
Schools must file final enrollment figures with the state by early next month.
Residential development boosts enrollment far less in East End districts like Southampton, where most new construction is of second homes. In Riverhead, where more new development has been for primary homes and the Hispanic population is also increasing, upward pressure on enrollment is building.
In Farmingville, where Hispanic men wait by the roadside for offers of work as day laborers, the local school district said housing development, not Hispanic students, was behind a projected enrollment increase.
The district, Sachem, had only 21 Mexican students last year, said Mary Bartley, the deputy superintendent. Most of the day laborers are believed to be Mexicans who have entered the United States illegally, but left families at home.
The Sachem district is projecting enrollment at 15,331 this year, up only 1 percent from 15,136 last year. Dr. Bartley said part of the increase was due to an unexpectedly large number of new students coming from Summerfields, a new 440-home development in Holtsville.
James A. Ruck, the district superintendent, said development would continue to push enrollment higher, noting that "we have a considerable amount of open space in our community." The district, which has one of the highest enrollments in the state, includes all or parts of Holbrook, Holtsville, Farmingville, Lake Ronkonkoma, Ronkonkoma, Nesconset, Bohemia, Selden, Centereach and Lake Grove.
The district was uncertain if Hispanic men working in the area would ever bring families and enroll children in the school system. "It's hard to know," said Dr. Bartley. "I would think it's certainly a possibility."
Thomas Conoscenti, a Long Island economist in Nesconset, said it was more a probability. "If they are making money they will eventually move their families here," he said.
Nadia Marin-Molina, executive director of the Workplace Project in Hempstead, said families had already begun arriving. "In Farmingville that's already starting to happen, and it's happening in other places," she said. "As they see there is a labor market here for them, workers are able to stay and bring their families."
Ms. Marin-Molina said she was surprised the Sachem school district was not experiencing a sharper increase in Hispanic students.
She said her group had seen no evidence that Hispanic laborers were bringing their families to Long Island because post-Sept. 11 border restrictions made seasonal visits home too difficult. She said the pattern of home visits had remained the same among the Farmingville workers, with some men going regularly and others not at all.
The Rev. William Brisotti, pastor of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal in Wyandanch, said he knew of Hispanic immigrants who met and married in that community and who were now having children. He said his church recently added a second Spanish mass to accommodate a soaring Hispanic population. "We have droves of kids," he said. "There are also entire families coming here," he said.
Edda Nieves of the Gerald J. Ryan Outreach Center in Wyandanch, said undocumented Hispanics were now more apt to enroll their children in schools. "They are not as afraid as they used to be," she said.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
A Flashy Four-Carom Shot For James and McGreevey

BYLINE:  By Ronald Smothers; Ronald Smothers reports from Newark for The New York Times.

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
On any given day, any one of these events should have been nothing less than a seismic occurrence in Newark and Trenton, a rapid-fire resolution of issues more reminiscent of the settling of scores in the last scene of "The Godfather":
 * Long-suffering supporters of the Newark arena find a new and surer way of financing their prized project, allowing Governor McGreevey to sidestep another skirmish with the Legislature. 
 * The city, faced with a name change for its international airport -- the busiest in the New York area -- gets a reprieve.
* Officials come up with millions of dollars to close a gaping hole in the city's 2002 budget and better insure that future budgets will be balanced. 
* The leasing of the airport to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is extended for 63 years.
Yet the fact that all of the above occurences took place on a single day and were linked to a single transaction -- the airport lease -- seemed to so overload the political circuits that trees could not be distinguished from forests.
It is not an overstatement to say that this is just what happened last week with news of a settlement between Newark and the Port Authority over the airport.
Blame it on the dog days of summer -- when minds wander and the attention is more focused on sun and sand and less on budgets and capital programs. And perhaps Governor McGreevey and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark should be credited for having deftly executed political misdirection plays of the kind that -- had they taken place on the football field and not in a political arena -- would have left everyone wondering who had the ball.
By settling the dispute between Newark and the Port Authority over the airport lease, Newark stands to get a $265 million windfall. About $100 million will go toward plugging a $65 million hole in the city's budget this year, with the remaining amount to help ease the city's long-delayed property tax revaluation.
The remaining $165 million was set aside for economic development purposes, a euphemism that insiders and outsiders alike recognized as money to help pay for the proposed $355 million arena.
The bailout could not have come a minute too soon. The city's budget problems were so acute that last week Moody's Investor Service lowered the city's bond rating, saying that there was a negative outlook for fiscal 2002 and 2003. Mayor James had been threatening to lay off 300 to 400 police officers and firefighters to balance the budget without raising taxes. In the mayor's words -- as he remained closeted with City Council members in a day-long session on the airport lease -- they were facing a fiscal disaster.
But the settlement averted fiscal meltdown and assured the city of at least $65 million a year over the next 60 years, with the possibility that the figure could increase with a rise in airport traffic. Rent for the airport in the previous five years averaged $44 million annually.
As the negotiations with the Port Authority were proceeding, Governor McGreevey revealed that he and Gov. George Pataki of New York -- who together select the people to run the bistate agency -- were thinking about changing the name of Newark's airport to Liberty International in memory of the victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center.
This is where it gets a little tricky. The spokeswoman for Mayor James and the point person on the city's response, Pamela Goldstein, waxed livid, denouncing the proposed change as diminishing the city's profile and stepping on its primacy as owner of the airport.
It seemed as if the mayor was so angry that he would throw his body in front of a 737 until the two governors relented.
Yet the mayor -- famous for his strident boosterism of Newark -- was curiously silent. He hinted softly at some willingness to compromise, but did little else, focused as he was on the negotiations with the Port Authority that were -- at that point -- being joined by Mr. McGreevey.
Suddenly, there were a lot more chips on the table.
When the game was over, there -- unheralded in the 10th paragraph of an 11-paragraph document -- the parties had agreed to change the name of the airport to Newark Liberty International.
Mayor James's hat trick, with an assist from the governor, was completed with the extra $165 million for the arena. For his part, Mr. McGreevey had managed to keep his promise to bring the arena to Newark without having to deal with the balky Legislature and with its opponents in Bergen County, despite his vow to stick with them until a solution was found for the Meadowlands.
"If it was the Governor's goal to remove the arena issue from the Legislature, then this was a masterful move on his part," said one admiring Democrat.
Or as one Republican lawmaker -- a bit chagrined by what appeared to be a seamless coup by the Democratic Governor -- put it, "It all looks pretty real from what I have heard."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Nan Lee, Scott Ito

 BODY:
Yong Nan Lee, the daughter of Lucia Kim of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott Toshio Ito, the son of Yoshiko J. Ito of Altadena, Calif. The Rev. 
In-wham Rheem, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Woo Lae Oak, a restaurant in New York.
 The bride, who is 31 and is known as Nan, is keeping her name. She is the director of fund-raising at the Lawyers Alliance for New York, a nonprofit organization that provides nonlitigation legal services for nonprofit organizations in New York. She graduated from Drew University. Her mother, who is retired, owned Ivy Hill Cleaners, a dry cleaner in Cheltenham, Pa. 
 The bridegroom, 36, is the director of external affairs at Asian Americans for Equality, a nonprofit organization in New York that fosters community and economic development in Chinatown and the Lower East Side. He graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles. His mother is a real estate broker in Pasadena, Calif.
The couple met in the summer of 2000 at a fund-raising event for the Korean American Family Services Center in New York. The bride was the organization's director of fund-raising; the bridegroom was volunteering on the dinner committee.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Cities Find Sisters Abroad

BYLINE:  By SUSAN HODARA 

 BODY:
SHORTLY after Sept. 11, Peter Korn, former city manager of New Rochelle, received a telephone call from Colette Chigneau, deputy mayor of La Rochelle, a port city on the Atlantic coast of France. She expressed concern for what had happened in New York, and inquired about whether anyone from New Rochelle had been lost. Then she invited any children who might need to get away after the tragedy to visit La Rochelle and stay with families there. 
 It was a call that meant a lot to Mr. Korn, and one that reflected the kind of mutually supportive relationship that has been continuing for decades between the two cities bonded as sister cities, and at one time registered with the Washington-based Sister Cities International, but now maintaining the connection on their own. 
 Sister Cities International is the national membership association for sister city, county and state programs in the United States. It was initially an outgrowth of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's People-to-People citizen diplomacy initiative, proposed in 1956 in hopes of diminishing the possibility of future world conflicts. In 1967, Sister Cities International became an independent nonprofit organization, with the goal of fostering global cooperation through international community partnerships. 
Sister Cities International plays a networking role in the creation and support of such relationships, working with citizens, municipal officials and business leaders. Once cities are paired, they can register with Sister Cities for an annual fee, entering into a formal pact signed by each mayor. 
Annual membership fees vary depending on population. They range from $130 for communities with fewer than 5,000 people to $1,100 for those with 5,000 to 500,000 people to $1,235 for those with 500,000 to one million people to $1,440 for those with more than a million people.
There are currently 2,100 communities in 121 countries involved in Sister Cities International partnerships.
"Basically, they're agreeing to further the cause of international friendship," said Cynthia Maka, Sister Cities's regional director for Asia. Sister cities have engaged in exchanges involving health care, environment, arts, education, economic development, trade, public safety and youth issues. In Westchester, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and Yonkers are involved in such relationships. Yonkers's sister city is Ternopil in western Ukraine. Mount Vernon has two sister cities, Yangquan and Shijingshan District, in China. "The result is that people are interacting with people." Ms. Maka said. 
The people of New Rochelle have been interacting with the people of La Rochelle since the late 17th century, when the French Huguenots fled La Rochelle to escape religious persecution and founded New Rochelle in 1688. A relationship between the cities was formalized after World War II through Sister Cities International, but, Mr. Korn said, he found it went back further when he discovered a statue in La Rochelle on a visit there with a group of New Rochelle residents in 2000. 
"In the courtyard of City Hall in La Rochelle is a large statue of a 17th-century La Rochelle mayor," he said. "When we wandered behind it, we found an inscription saying it was a gift from the people of New Rochelle to the citizens of La Rochelle, given in grateful friendship. It was dated 1909."
The present-day friendship between the cities is overseen by Thomas C. Idoni, the mayor of New Rochelle since 1992. Its mission is "to maintain a cultural, social and business partnership so we can learn from each other and help each other's residents," he said. 
"In 1998 to commemorate the tricentennial of the founding of New Rochelle," Mayor Idoni said, "we invited the mayor of La Rochelle and a group of French chefs to New Rochelle for a series of celebrations." 
Several cultural exchanges have taken place, and in 2000, a delegation of 16 New Rochelle residents, led by a councilwoman, Christina Selen, traveled to La Rochelle in an effort to foster economic development. 
"We're trying to establish business relationships between the two cities," Mayor Idoni said. "We're discussing import-export relations with French companies there, particularly in the boating and wine industries." 
La Rochelle businesses are being encouraged to open offices in New Rochelle. "It's a lot less expensive than Manhattan,"Mr. Idoni said, "and it would spur our tourism industry and the growth of our downtown." An effort to export local businesses to France "is still in the incubation phase," he said. 
Besides the economic aspects, personal relationships have emerged. 
"We stay in their homes when we visit," Mayor Idoni said. "We learn their culture, and they learn ours." 
Yonkers residents have also made friends abroad, through its sister city relationship with Ternopil, an area from which many of Yonkers's Ukrainians emigrated. While currently inactive, that relationship began in 1991, when the Yonkers chapter of the international Ukrainian American Youth Association instituted a medical relief fund to deliver much-needed supplies to hospitals in Ukraine. One of the fund's coordinators was the president of the chapter, Dr. Orest Kozicky, a gastroenterologist who practices and lives with his family in Yonkers. 
"During one of our relief missions to Ukraine in 1992, I had the opportunity to meet with the mayor and city council of Ternopil," Dr. Kozicky said. "They expressed an interest in establishing a relationship with Ukrainians in America for the purpose of gaining exposure to western ideas and potential technical and humanitarian assistance." 
The notion of such a connection was embraced by Ukrainian residents in Yonkers and other parts of Westchester. Once the mayor and city council of Yonkers got on board, the relationship was registered with Sister Cities International. 
"Our initial hopes were to offer exchange programs for students, and economic and technical assistance," Dr. Kozicky said. With this in mind, members of the Ternopil City Council traveled to Yonkers in 1994, where, he said, "they were hosted at the Lenoir Mansion, given a tour of the city, and treated to a banquet and traditional Ukrainian dance performances at the Youth Center." 
Meanwhile, relief efforts were continuing, and city of Yonkers won the best humanitarian project award in 1994 at the annual Sister Cities International convention. 
A Ternopil official visited Yonkers in 1997 and met with members of Yonkers commerce commission. The next year, Peter Duda, a Yonkers resident with Ukrainian roots, visited Ternopil and toured several factories. 
"He has since tried to establish an outlet for electric lamps made in Ternopil, but this project has not come to fruition," Dr. Kozicky said. Other projects have met similar fates. "The main reason for the shortcomings of our sister city relationship is the lack of a permanent staff to coordinate the programs," Dr. Kozicky said. "There are many obstacles to overcome in bridging the differences between our economic and technological systems. Without a well-funded staff, many of the best intentions just don't pan out." Medical supplies, he said, continue to be gathered and sent to Ternopil, with the next shipment scheduled for the end of the year. 
The sister city program seems to be working out well in Mount Vernon, which is involved with two different cities in China: Yangquan, an industrial city in north central China, and Shijingshan District, a suburb of Beijing. The first relationship, with Yangquan, dates back to 1994, when Ronald Blackwood, who was mayor then, was approached by a group of Chinese businesspeople who lived and worked in Mount Vernon to discuss opportunities for business development with China. An official invitation from and a trip to Yangquan followed, during which the relationship was formalized.
A second trip to China was made in 1997 by a Mount Vernon group that included current Mayor Ernest D. Davis; Gerrie Post, Mount Vernon's commissioner of planning and community development; and representatives from the technology and business sectors. "We toured factories and schools," Ms. Post said, "and worked on-site to negotiate our second partnership."
She said that Mount Vernon and Shijingshan District are both situated just outside a larger metropolis. 
Air pollution is now a critical concern in China, she said. "We've had visitors from China looking at our automobile inspection and pollution-monitoring systems," she said. "They're talking to a company in Mount Vernon that manufactures these devices about importing them for use in China."
As a result of the strength of Mount Vernon's relationships in China, Mayor Davis said the city was considering developing similar relationships with cities in Italy and Africa. "As the world gets smaller and opportunities get bigger," he said, "Mount Vernon will be poised internationally not to have to go it alone."

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE; 
Off Peak

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY 

 BODY:
MARY JONAS has been taking the bus here about once a week for more than 20 years -- since she was 66.
 "There was Playboy and Atlantis and, really, a lot of versions of Mr. Trump," said Ms. Jonas, who will be celebrating her 90th birthday in a few weeks -- "just about the time they have a new Miss America, though I don't think it will be me." 
 Ms. Jonas comes here from her home in Montclair, usually on the Red and Tan line, but sometimes on special casino buses that she finds out about through newspaper advertisements or leaflets at her recreation center. "There is always some kind of incentive a free lunch, a few bucks back," she said. "But I have noticed there are fewer buses these days."
Age has not dulled her perceptions. The latest statistics from the South Jersey Transportation Authority show that bus traffic to the casino-hotels here has been dwindling in recent years. According to figures made public recently by the authority, 8 million casino patrons will get here by bus this year as against 10 million in 1998.
For now, no one seems to know why fewer people have been taking the bus for several years. Casinos -- which have seen an increase in business this year -- insist they have not been discouraging bus-riding patrons. Most evidence suggests that after the events of last Sept. 11 -- followed by a tightening of the economy -- people began taking less expensive vacations closer to home. And while there have been any number of bus crashes along the Garden State Parkway involving casino patrons -- including one on Christmas Eve in 1998 in which eight people were killed -- there is no evidence linking the two phenomena.
"There has definitely been a steady decline," said Gary Israel, a spokesman for the transportation authority and former marketing executive for several casinos here. "It is difficult to pinpoint one reason, but casino attendance is up otherwise. So you have to figure, to some extent that the casinos have been more successful at attracting drive-in business which, in the end, is more lucrative than bus traffic."
Bus traffic to the casinos tends to be clustered around the hotels near the Atlantic City Expressway. In the first half of this year, Bally's accounted for 12.4 percent of the bus traffic; the Hilton, 10.5 percent; Trump Taj Mahal, 10.4 percent, and Trump Plaza, 10.1 percent.
By comparison, relatively few buses head for the Marina section, whose casinos tend to attract a younger crowd that arrives by car. The Trump Marina draws just 3.1 percent of the bus traffic to the casinos, while Harrah's accounts for only 0.5 percent.
"Let's face it," said Daniel Heneghan, director of communications for the Casino Control Commission, "if the casinos could bring everyone in by car, they would pretty much stop using buses. The drive-ins are the higher-profile people. Even if they don't bet that highly, they still spend more money on food or souvenirs."
Mr. Heneghan pointed out that in 1988, 15 million people came to Atlantic City by bus -- nearly twice as many as this year.
"Still, 8 million is a lot of people," he said. "You have 900 buses coming in a day in a city of 42,000 residents. Where else in the country do you have something like that?"
For their part, the casinos say that they are not intentionally cutting back on bus patrons, and that they are offering the same incentives they have for years. 
"While bus traffic is down, we still encourage it," said Brian Cahill of Park Place Entertainment, which owns Bally's, the Hilton and Caesar's. "The point is to get people to come."
Bobby Hull, the director of operations of Coach USA, which runs several bus lines, including Red and Tan, that originate in New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania, said he had noticed a drop-off in the last year, but he attributed it primarily to the struggling economy.
"We saw it a few months before 9/11," said Mr. Hull. "The stock market went down and people stopped coming by bus. Even though bus patrons may not be big stock owners, they can be on fixed incomes and be worried about the economy."
As for his company, Mr. Hull said his figures for this year showed an 8 percent decrease from 2001 in the number of bus passengers arriving from northern New Jersey, with traffic from Philadelphia off about 10 percent and as much as 15 percent from New York City.
"After 9/11, we had to reroute a lot of buses, particularly in lower Manhattan," he said. "That ridership has never come back."
Contrary to those who think that the casinos tend to hold their noses as they welcome bus passengers, Mr. Hull said he saw a trend in trying to win them back.
"Incentives are higher than I've seen in five or six years," he said. "Right now, some casinos are giving them $15 to $18 back if they ride down from New York, which is about a $25 trip. In Philly, they may get $10 or $12 back after only paying $12."
While Mr. Hull said his company had not cut back on the number of buses operating on fixed schedules, total bus counts -- which include charters and special routes -- have been off considerably for the last couple of years.
According to transportation authority figures, 1,097 buses arrived at the casinos each day in 1999, as against only 897 a day this year. On the other hand, the number of passengers on each bus has held steady, dropping only from 25 in 1999 to 24 today.
Still, as Mr. Heneghan said, "900 buses a day in what is still only a small city is a pretty decent influx of tourists daily, all spending real money."
For people like Ms. Jonas, coming here by bus is still a good deal. "So as long as I can find a bus, Ill be doing my regular thing down here," she said. "And it seems I can always find one."
