HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Thinking Big; 
In New York, Seeking a Grand Vision of Public Works

BYLINE:  By JAMES SANDERS 

 BODY:
EVEN as the world awaits the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, many have begun to question the slow and uncertain pace of the reconstruction process. Certainly, a daunting array of obstacles stand in the way, including complex jurisdictional disputes over who should be in charge and disagreements about the appropriate mix of uses and activities for the development itself.
 Hovering above these issues, however, is a more sweeping and historically significant question: Can New York City, which for more than a century led the world in the construction of major public works only to repudiate the practice some 30 years ago, somehow learn to build on a grand scale again? 
 While in the popular mind New York remains a place of skyscrapers and towering apartment houses -- most, of course, built privately -- the city's innovative tradition of public construction has perhaps been even more crucial to shaping its identity. Indeed, as a modern city, New York was essentially brought into being by one remarkably ambitious public project, the Erie Canal, and then welded together by another, the Brooklyn Bridge. A third, Central Park, became a model and inspiration for every city in America. 
And that was just in the 19th century.
After 1900, New York dazzled the world with one pioneering public-works project after another. In a matter of decades the city built the world's largest subway system, five of the longest suspension bridges ever built, the first underwater vehicular crossing in history (the Holland Tunnel) and the world's first urban arterial highway system. Though technically owned by private companies, the two great railroad stations that arose in these years -- Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station -- were models of public construction, reshaping the city fabric into wondrously intricate urban compositions.
On the eve of World War II, New York awed the nation with a futuristic World's Fair, then, a few years later, started work on America's first land-based international airport, covering more than 4,000 acres. No city on earth could match the energy New York displayed in remaking itself to meet the challenges of modern life -- nor the brilliance, daring and, in most cases, speed with which it carried out that remaking.
But after the war, something changed.
Though the pace of construction continued, the heroism, excitement and romance associated with New York's public efforts gave way to increasing criticism and, a few years later, active opposition. Much of the blame could be laid at the feet of the city's greatest public builder, Robert Moses.
In the decades before 1945, Moses had conceived and executed some of the metropolitan region's most imaginative and stylish public works, including Jones Beach, the Long Island state park and parkway system, the Triborough Bridge and Riverside Park. But in the postwar years he seemed to many to be building for the sake of building, plotting one expressway after another through dense communities and exploiting vast new federal powers and funding sources to level dozens of other neighborhoods for immense yet bland urban renewal projects.
Traditionally, large-scale public construction had meant the wholesale disruption of people's lives and the allocation of immense political and financial resources. But earlier generations of New Yorkers had accepted a calculus that saw the discomfort of those in the path of change -- and the exercise of immense power by a handful of (often) unelected individuals -- as the price of spectacular and innovative public improvements.
By the 1960's, however, that calculus no longer held for an increasing number of New Yorkers. 
For one thing, Moses' postwar projects offered little of the imagination or style that had marked his earlier work. For another, their physical and human cost had grown too high: hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers displaced from their homes, dozens of neighborhoods decimated. Behind it all was a growing suspicion of the very idea of the "master builder" -- especially as embodied by Moses, an increasingly remote and imperious figure.
THE fall from grace began in the early 1960's with the successful community opposition to a pair of unusually destructive projects -- a high-rise housing project slated for Greenwich Village and an eight-lane expressway that would cut across Lower Manhattan.
Soon neighborhoods everywhere rallied behind the ideas presented in the landmark book "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," written by the leader of that opposition effort, a Village resident named Jane Jacobs, who argued persuasively for a small-scale, incremental approach to urban development.
Perhaps the decisive blow came in 1974 with another book, "The Power Broker," Robert A. Caro's monumental biography of Moses himself, which revealed the sometimes brutal and almost always undemocratic means by which New York's master builder wielded his immense power. Yet, for all his criticism, Mr. Caro acknowledged that an autocratic, unelected figure like Moses solved a crucial dilemma for democratic societies: how to build the large public works that were essential to modern urban life but whose daunting time frame and enormous human and economic costs made them anathema to public officials, who fear alienating any segment of the electorate.
In the mid-1970's, as Moses' grand visions were superseded by Ms. Jacobs's localized approach -- more attuned to a generation that, in the wake of Vietnam and Watergate, tended to mistrust "big government" -- New York City overhauled its entire planning process to make the rise of another Robert Moses all but impossible. The autocratic planning of powerful agencies like the Port Authority was replaced by an elaborate community review process that allowed neighborhoods a say in projects that affected their future.
The rise of the environmental movement, meanwhile, gave civic groups another powerful tool against large-scale construction: legal challenges that could tie up projects for years, effectively killing them. 
Such was the case with Westway, the ambitious plan to reclaim five miles of Hudson River waterfront for housing, parks and a submerged highway, whose defeat at the hands of community and environmental advocates in the early 1980's marked the end of the city's last serious attempt at sweeping public planning. (A handful of projects, including Battery Park City and the Third Water Tunnel, begun in the late 1960's at the tail end of the postwar planning era, have taken so long to complete that they are still in construction.)
Though the shift to Ms. Jacobs's community-oriented approach offered a much-needed corrective, it came with a price. The new system made it far easier to reject than approve any large public project -- good, bad or mixed.
It was scarcely surprising, therefore, that in the last three decades New York added almost nothing to its existing inventory of major public projects, a state of affairs that many New Yorkers have judged perfectly acceptable -- despite warnings from groups like the Regional Plan Association that without the will or capacity to carry out major new initiatives, New York may well squander its status as a global city. 
Even so, given its extraordinary heritage of earlier projects, New York seemed able to survive and even thrive without developing a way to build new ones.
But on the morning of Sept. 11, the choice was taken out of the city's hands. 
One way or another, something will have to replace the enormous office, retail and transportation complex represented by the World Trade Center. That new development, whatever its ultimate mix of uses, will by its very nature involve the large-scale public planning that New York once carried out almost routinely. It is no wonder that the effort to get up to speed should be marked by an almost audible grinding of gears.
Yet if there is reason for concern, there is also reason for optimism. In the last few years, as the pendulum has begun to swing back, many planners feel the time has come to attempt a synthesis of the city's older tradition of daring and ambitious public works, and the sense of urbanity and human scale Ms. Jacobs insisted on.
Indeed, a prototype of such a synthesis was suggested by the city's imaginative physical plan for the 2012 Olympics, acknowledged last week by the United States Olympic Committee as a key factor in New York's selection as one of the two finalist cities. 
This proposal was devised by the urban planner Alexander Garvin, who is now the urban design director for the redevelopment effort in Lower Manhattan. If New York can find a way to reconcile its two vastly different planning traditions -- a significant feat in its own right -- the city may again dazzle the world by remaking itself in new and exciting ways.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Where Hands Still Labor

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
 IN this high-tech age of bioengineering, supercomputers, space shuttles and globalized financial markets, the men and women with hands and muscles are still there, laying bricks, sweeping cafeteria floors, making hotel beds. They are the army of manual workers doing the unheralded, largely forgotten jobs that also make the nation go. 
They hammer the nails, trim the meat, clean the sidewalks. There are millions of them, including 327,000 hairdressers, 2 million janitors, 265,000 file clerks, 130,000 messengers, 948,000 housekeepers, 109,000 brick masons, 24,000 hand sewers and 148,000 meat and fish trimmers. In recent years immigrants, men and women from Asia, Africa and Latin America, have filled many of these manual jobs, especially the low-end, lowest-paying positions. "Manual labor is more with us than many people think," said Kate Bronfenbrenner, a professor of labor relations at Cornell. "We will always need people to clean our streets, empty our bedpans and build our buildings. Computers can't do the most fundamental jobs at the core of our economy. There are a lot of dirty jobs, jobs requiring hard physical work, that someone's going to have to do." STEVEN GREENHOUSE

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Terrorism's Toll On the F.B.I.

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
OVER the years, F.B.I. directors have shifted resources to confront the scourge at hand. In the 1970's, Clarence M. Kelley veered away from the fight against Communism and took on organized crime. A decade later, William H. Webster put the emphasis on counterintelligence. William S. Sessions ended his tumultuous tenure with a push against violent crime.
 But when F.B.I. Director Robert S. Mueller III recently announced that the bureau would double his counterterrorism staff, in part by transferring personnel from other areas, the professional group that represents most agents voiced fears that traditional crime-solving would suffer. "Please give us back those bodies," said Nancy L. Savage, president of the F.B.I. Agents Association, which represents about 70 percent of agents. 
 At the same time, criminal justice experts raised concerns that the Federal Bureau of Investigation would become a domestic spy agency authorized to snoop into citizens' affairs even when there is no evidence of illegal activity. That could plunge the bureau back into an era of blackmail and intimidation associated with another director, J. Edgar Hoover, they said.
"Spying on people in order to prevent them from doing undefined harm is what an intelligence agency does," said Philip B. Heymann, a former deputy attorney general in the Clinton administration. "To create an agency that will monitor Americans in no way connected with a foreign government or party, that's a little worrisome."
Taken together, the fears underscore the difficulties confronting Mr. Mueller as he seeks to reshape and reorient a conservative, catch-the-crooks institution to confront an often invisible adversary that has proven its ability to move effectively within United States borders. And those difficulties seem to be mounting after the recent announcement that Dale L. Watson, the F.B.I.'s counterterrorism chief, will retire. No replacement has been named.
The concern about resources is not idle. Even as its duties multiply, the F.B.I. remains a small agency, and it was already stretched thin before Sept. 11.
The proposed shift toward counterterrorism comes at a time when major crime incidents are increasing. According to preliminary F.B.I. data released in June, the nation's crime index -- which measures murder, rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, larceny and motor vehicle theft -- rose by 2 percent last year. Setting aside the data from Sept. 11, which skew the overall results, the F.B.I. reported the largest jumps in murder (3.1 percent), robbery (3.9 percent) and motor vehicle theft (5.9 percent), crimes routinely involving the F.B.I.
Now, the director plans to transfer 518 of its 11,500 agents permanently from traditional crime-fighting duties to the battle against terrorism. This has left some critics wondering whether the bureau is forsaking its role in the drug war and the struggle against violent and white-collar crime. "You've still got a crime problem," Ms. Savage said. "Who's going to address it?" 
In testimony to Congress in June, Mr. Mueller proposed transferring 400 agents from drug investigations, 59 agents from white-collar crimes and another 59 agents from violent crimes. Counternarcotics would thus bear the brunt of the shift. He ordered agents to re-evaluate their involvement in drug cases and, "where possible, and without jeopardizing current investigations, reduce F.B.I. resources."
Virtually no one argues with the need for the bureau to reorganize around the terrorist threat and to bolster disciplines in which the bureau acknowledges it is deficient, like foiling Internet attacks. But F.B.I. experts question whether the bureau should be cannibalizing itself at a time when its federal responsibilities are already so vast and diverse: enforcing 300 federal laws, conducting background checks on cabinet and Supreme Court nominees, training local police and running forensic laboratories.
Ronald Kessler, who has written a history of the bureau, says the F.B.I. should double in size. Now, he notes, the nation's foremost federal crime agency is dwarfed in manpower by the New York City Police Department, which counts about 40,000 officers. Drawing down on existing F.B.I. resources is "a very narrow way of thinking about its potential," he said. "The bottom line is that instead of shifting agents around like this, they should be increasing the size of the F.B.I.," Mr. Kessler said. "Drugs kill more people than terrorists do." 
Dick Thornburgh, who served as attorney general under the first President Bush, recently complained that Congress had heaped too many responsibilities on the F.B.I. Lawmakers, responding to public pressure in recent years, have federalized crimes -- from carjackings to failure to pay child support -- and added to the bureau's burden. With the new emphasis on terrorism, he said, something has to give. Mr. Thornburgh called for handing nonterror crimes back to state and local control.
CONGRESS still must vote on Mr. Mueller's plan. But in practical terms, F.B.I. officials say, the reallocation has begun. Agents are allocating more and more of their workdays to following up on terrorism leads. 
Meanwhile, the Drug Enforcement Administration is girding for additional duties. Asa Hutchinson, the agency's director, has ordered a threat assessment to help determine how to reallocate parts of his $1.8 billion budget. He has 4,600 agents, foreign and domestic, which eclipses the new F.B.I. total of about 1,000 agents that will still be focusing on drugs.
"D.E.A. is going to pick up some of the slack," said Will Glaspy, a spokesman for the agency. "We'd like to work with Congress and the administration to gain additional resources to make sure we fill the holes that are left."
Some law enforcement experts worry more about losing agents who are pursuing white-collar criminals. Recent accounting scandals involving companies from Enron to WorldCom has underscored the need for specialists in detecting fraud, they say.
"The country is in as much danger on the white-collar crime front as it is on the terror front," said Mr. Heymann. "False accounting, false pushing of stocks can do as much damage to the economy as a plane flying into the World Trade Center."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
Resisting the Siren Song of the All-American Muscle Cars

BYLINE:  By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
A neighbor of mine owns one of those 60's-era muscle cars that cause middle-aged men like me to swoon. This cherry-red '66 Chevelle rides high on a racing suspension, propelled by one of the largest engines ever made. The jetlike roar rattles windows and sets off car alarms all along our quiet, tree-lined street.
 Though rare today, cars like this littered the streets when I was a high schooler in the mid-1960's. In fact, they defined what baby-boom men would come to expect from an automobile. In the atmosphere of the time, a car was not quite a car unless punching the accelerator resulted in screaming tires and the landscape blurring around you as the needle on the gas gauge dropped like a stone. 
 The chief executive of Ford Motors, William Ford Jr., is a baby boomer, too. He was clearly remembering hot little numbers from the 60's when he told a management meeting earlier this summer that the American love affair with the car was in danger of dying out. As proof, he noted that Americans no longer write songs about their favorite cars, as they once did.
The death of the California car song is not what you would call a civic tragedy. Those songs deified the largest, heaviest, dirtiest, least fuel-efficient engines in American history. In addition, the songs were primarily about drag racing, which burned off gasoline as though you'd lit a match to it and sometimes ended with the car and its driver wrapped around a tree. Romanticizing this period will not encourage speed-addicted Americans toward the fuel-efficient cars we so desperately need.
The quest for saner cars dates back to the early 1960's, a decade before the oil crisis forced the government to lean on Detroit to produce them. The expansion of the Interstate System fed suburban development, increasing dramatically the number of households that needed at least two cars. Dad drove to work in the two-ton living room on wheels, leaving mom with a smaller, less expensive car for the run to the supermarket.
These mid-sized cars typically got fewer miles per gallon than light trucks do today. The impulse to make them more economical ran afoul of the quest for an "exciting" car aimed at people in their teens and early 20's who would soon make up the majority of the car-buying public.
Enter a young Pontiac car designer named John DeLorean, who was part of the team that placed a very large engine into a modest, mid-sized Pontiac. This hyped-up Pontiac later became the G.T.O. It burned rubber and screamed when you stepped on the gas, and was by any measure too much engine with too little car.
Those of us who reached driving age in this period found ourselves in the equivalent of an arms race in which manufacturers competed to see who could build the fastest, loudest car. My neighbor's cherry-red Chevelle rolled off the General Motors line in my freshman year of high school, a time when, in my blue-collar hometown, the young men drag raced nightly and defined themselves utterly in terms of horsepower.
I could always tell when the school day was ending from the roar of the hot cars that circled the block ceaselessly until the intended passenger was picked up. Then the cars broke orbit and roared away. This scene was played out at a thousand high schools in a thousand towns all over the country. Gas was cheap, so mileage did not matter. The only important statistic was how long it took to accelerate from 0 to 60 m.p.h.
The battle between environmentalists and the car industry over fuel efficiency and pollution standards has its roots in this same statistic. Car manufacturers over the last 20 years have manipulated the law at every turn to increase car size and engine size, and to maintain the fast start. As a result of all this evasion, mileage improvements have been far short of what is possible and emissions reductions have been disappointing. 
American cars are still by and large faster and more muscular than they need to be, especially given that they spend much of their time sitting still in traffic. The challenge that faces us at the moment is how to wean people away from the brute-force hot-rod ethos that Detroit taught us to love in the 60's and coax them toward calmer cars that do not seem as though they are powered by rockets. This will require a change in what Detroit builds, as well as a change in the way it markets what it builds.
Mr. Ford deserves praise for promoting fuel efficiency and clean technology. But he harkened back to the loud and dirty muscle car days recently in a commercial that used footage from the car race movie "Bullitt," in which two brutish cars -- a Ford Mustang and a Dodge Charger -- stage a spectacular chase through the streets of San Francisco. Mr. Ford says in the commercial that he has been accused of having gasoline in his veins and that he could spend the rest of his days behind the wheel of a Mustang with a "throaty V-8" and a great sound system. I know where you're comin' from, Bill. But you can't be Mr. Green and Mr. Hot Wheels at the same time.

HEADLINE: August 25-31; 
Forget About the Strike. Play Ball!

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Suddenly there's no strike.
 Five times before in the tortured history of baseball's labor negotiations players said they were going to strike -- and, by golly, they struck. But today they are playing their games, and they will play them tomorrow and the rest of the month, and some players who are fortunate enough will play games in October, too. 
 "I don't know what this feels like," an official of the Major League Baseball Players Association said on Friday after a new labor agreement was announced. "I might get to like it." 
Players walked out in 1994 and stayed out into the 1995 season. They struck for two days in 1985 and 50 days in 1981. Earlier in the game's labor history players struck: during the last week of spring training in 1980 and the end of spring training and beginning of the season in 1972. 
The focal point of the talks was the twin economic issues of revenue sharing and a luxury tax on payrolls. Over the four years of the agreement, $988 million will be transferred from richer clubs to poorer clubs. The tax will be assessed on portions of payrolls over a designated threshold.
Why didn't the players strike? They always say -- and they mean it -- that they would rather negotiate a peaceful agreement with the owners. Tom Glavine, the brilliant Atlanta Braves pitcher, who is the National League player representative, reiterated that position Friday.
Why was a deal possible this time when it never seemed to be in the past without a walkout?
The owners, said Richard Moss, former general counsel of the players' union, "made no demand to eliminate salary arbitration, no demand for a salary cap, no demand to eliminate free agency by adding requirements."
Said Commissioner Bud Selig: "The deal is sensitive to the concerns that I've raised and others have raised over the years." Murray Chass

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Millionaires on the Wane

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
The number of millionaire households in the United States declined 11 percent last year. Those that remained were less confident about their financial positions and therefore more conservative in their approach to investing, according to a recent survey. 
 "The decline in the equity markets finally caught up with this group of investors," said David Thompson, director of affluent-market research at NFO Financial Services, a division of the NFO WorldGroup, which conducted the survey. "In the early stages of the current bear market, from midyear 2000 to midyear 2001, the number of millionaires basically stayed the same largely due to the strength of their diverse portfolios." 
 But in the 12 months ended in June, the number of millionaire households fell to 3.3 million, from 3.7 million, Mr. Thompson said. 
He said that most people surveyed showed a "startling year-to-year decline" in confidence about their own finances and the economy over the next six months. Nearly two-thirds said they had become more conservative and had become increasingly concerned about preserving wealth rather than increasing it.
The study estimated that households with net worths of $500,000 to $1 million declined only 1 percent from the 3.6 million in 2001. The survey was based on a national sampling of 1,500 households with a net worth of at least $500,000, excluding their principal residence.

Fast Bucks, and Fraud Perils

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
 With the economy and stock market shaky, more people may be looking at less traditional ways to make money. 
But all too often, says the chief postal inspector, Lee Heath, they may find unscrupulous people looking to bilk them of their savings. The United States Postal Inspection Service began a campaign last week to alert the public, specifically the elderly, to the growing danger of fraud. Swindlers may contact people by telephone or e-mail and trick them into sending some sort of payment by mail. The postal agency said it responded to 66,000 mail fraud complaints in 2001. So far this year, there have already been about 68,000. Vivian Marino

A Child Care Solution: Help From Overseas

BYLINE:  By JULIA MEURLING 

 BODY:
As the school year begins, many families are making room in their homes for arriving au pairs, who provide 12 months of child care in exchange for the chance to live and study in the United States. Last year, 11,855 au pairs aged 18 and 26 were placed in families by six federally approved agencies. About the same number are expected this year. 
 Until recently, programs were limited to au pairs from Western Europe, but they now draw a rapidly growing number of participants from Eastern Europe, South America, Asia and Australia. So far this year, the InterExchange agency has placed more au pairs from Eastern European countries like Poland and Slovakia than from Western Europe. JULIA MEURLING

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Baseball Could Learn a Few Things From Australia

BYLINE:  By JUSTIN WOLFERS and ANDREW LEIGH; Justin Wolfers is an assistant professor of economics at Stanford Business School. Andrew Leigh is a fellow with the Malcolm Wiener Center for Social Policy at Harvard. Both are expatriate Australians.

 BODY:
With the threatened baseball strike averted in the bottom of the ninth, fans are relieved but somewhat disillusioned with the national pastime. Is the fierce competition that we enjoy in the ballpark likely to always spill over to negotiations over pay? Or is it simply a reflection of players paying more attention to dollars than sense? 
 A major sports scandal in Australia last week provides an interesting benchmark against which to judge the motivations of American baseball players. 
 Rugby league fans Down Under also had a gut-wrenching week, following revelations that the Sydney-based Bulldogs, a team picked by many to win this year's rugby league championship, had systematically violated the salary cap. The team had funneled player payments through third-party entities and club boosters. It emerged that the club spent nearly a fifth more on player payments than the system allows. 
The players appear to know nothing about these violations, and there is no suggestion of impropriety beyond the team's management. Yet "Doggiegate," as the Australians are calling it, has resulted in the Bulldogs' being stripped of any credit for their successful season to date, and they have been relegated to the bottom of the league. With the finals series only two weeks away, this has also robbed the Bulldogs of any chance of postseason glory. 
The reaction of Australia's rugby league players stands in stark contrast to the position adopted by Major League Baseball players. Bulldogs players, led by their captain, Steve Price, pleaded to take a pay cut to comply with the salary cap, in the hope that it offers them a chance to compete in the postseason.
"It's a shock to us like it is to everybody else," Price said on Aug. 21, claiming ignorance of the player-pay scandal. "Players will take pay cuts if we have to."
The 21-year-old Mark O'Meley agreed. "I just love footy," he said. "I'd be devastated not to play in the finals." He added, "I'd be prepared to take a pay cut to play in the finals."
By contrast, the threatened baseball strike was intended by the players union to maximize only their bargaining power. By waiting until the pennant races and ultimately the World Series were on the line, the players managed to boost their bargaining power at the possible expense of the postseason.
In effect, baseball's stars bet that their fans, who ultimately provide the owners with their profits, care more about the postseason than they do. Having forced the abandonment of the 1994 World Series, we all knew this was no empty threat. And the fact that the owners worked furiously to resolve this dispute by Friday shows that they also understood this.
The response from sports fans in Australia and the United States reveals the very different effects that the two scandals -- player overpayments and the threatened strike -- have had on supporters of the two sports. Bulldogs fans are clearly shocked at the way in which the team's management behaved, but it says something about the innate sense of fair play among Australians that an online poll at the club's Web site found that nearly half of Bulldogs fans surveyed believed that the punishment meted out to the club was fair.
By contrast, baseball's work stoppages seem to have wearied American baseball fans, and although there was a small anti-stoppage protest movement, fans seem resigned to the possibility of further labor strife, and regarded its resolution as an unexpected surprise. While the overpayment scandal led the Bulldogs board to resign en masse, both Bud Selig and Donald Fehr, the two main protagonists from the 1994 baseball strike, continue to lead their respective organizations.
The current Australian scandal also raises some very practical issues for baseball's negotiators.
A primary stumbling block in the baseball negotiations has been the issue of the so-called luxury tax. This tax is in many respects similar to the rugby league salary cap, except that rather than simply banning spending above a certain level, these higher payments are to be taxed so that rich clubs can buy less talent for their dollar.
The overpayment scandal in Australia points to the likelihood of similar infractions in baseball's future. The tough question for those who propose to regulate payments to baseball players is: How would a luxury tax in baseball be enforced? Will Bud Selig be willing to go as far as Australian rugby league officials and ban transgressors from the postseason? Would the players union support his decision, or could enforcing the rules potentially lead to more labor strife?
Even in its darkest hour, Australian rugby league players are showing the sort of sporting passion that American baseball fans yearn for. As Bulldogs Coach Steve Folkes said of his team: "They want to play football. It's not about money. It's about success."
For all its "Field of Dreams" mythology, the mighty dollar remains central to much of modern baseball.
Few have echoed the recent sentiment of one sportsman: "The money, I can deal without. Baseball, I can't." The player? Baseball's $252 million dollar man, Alex Rodriguez.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Sydney-based Bulldogs pleaded to take a pay cut after revelations that the team had violated the salary cap. (Mark Nolan/Getty Images)

HEADLINE: U.S. Rebuked: Slapping the Hand That Fed Free Trade 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 

 BODY:
The United States has always had a love-hate attitude toward free trade, but rarely has the ambivalence been greater than now.
 Having capitulated to demands by steelmakers for steep new tariffs in March, the Bush administration is now rushing to soothe trading partners and steel-consuming companies by excluding hundreds of imported products from the tariffs. 
 Having capitulated to demands from farmers for more than $100 billion in subsidies, the administration is now advocating a plan that would drastically reduce subsidies and farm tariffs around the world.
But perhaps the most startling twist in a tangled relationship came on Friday, when the World Trade Organization in Geneva ruled that the European Union can impose up to $4 billion in penalties on the United States because its tax break for exporters amounts to an illegal subsidy under international law. 
It was by far the biggest trade penalty ever approved, a rebuke that was all the more stinging because it was aimed at a country that routinely lectures the rest of the world on the need to open its markets.
What made the verdict even more striking was that it came from an institution that would not exist if the United States had not pushed relentlessly for its creation.
Conservative critics charged that the panel had eroded American sovereignty and had stepped far outside its authority.
"The whole purpose of the W.T.O. was to lead to the reduction of trade barriers," said Daniel Mitchell, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think-tank in Washington. "For the W.T.O. to start commenting on whether U.S. tax policy is acceptable is a huge expansion of its authority. You have to ask, where does it stop?"
In truth, however, there is little doubt that the international panel was well within its rights. The American negotiators who hammered out the treaty that created the World Trade Organization wanted to make sure that it had the authority to attack all kinds of veiled protectionism: disguised government subsidies, health rules serving only as import barriers, trade preferences for favored countries.
The mantra for American leaders was to create a "rules based" system that would be clear, binding and rigorously adjudicated by what amounted to an international court.
"I remember that we were criticized by the Europeans for having an overly legalistic approach," said Thomas Niles, who was American ambassador to the European Union from 1989 to 1991. "But we were interested in a dispute settlement system where if you won a case you got what you were after."
The United States has gotten what it wanted more than once. In 1997, the W.T.O. vindicated the United States by striking down Europe's ban on beef from cattle injected with growth hormones.
It was an explosive decision for Europe, because the ban reflected a widespread mistrust of artificial hormones. But the W.T.O. ruled that the Europeans had not produced any evidence of health hazards from the beef, and that the ban was therefore an illegal trade barrier.
One of the main reasons President Bush abandoned his free-market principles on both farm subsidies and steel tariffs was that he needed votes in Congress to win approval of trade promotion authority, which allows the administration to negotiate trade deals and submit them to Congress for a simple yes or no vote.
Even then, the House passed the bill by a mere three votes in July.
"There is not a lot of enthusiasm in the United States for trade liberalization," said Gary Hufbauer, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. Mr. Hufbauer, though critical of both the steel tariffs and the new farm subsidies, said President Bush might have made a wise compromise because the narrowly approved trade bill could ultimately open up more trade than the protectionist moves close down.
But what about the immediate future? Is the United States at the mercy of a body it helped create?
At least in part, yes. Some experts argue that the United States needs to learn that many of its own laws and practices fall well short of being a gold standard for openness. 
The World Trade Organization has ruled against the United States in almost every case where it has tried to impose "antidumping" tariffs on steel that was allegedly imported at below its real cost.
The decision this week on taxes was more obscure but involved much bigger money. The international treaties underlying the trade organization prohibit countries from offering tax breaks exclusively to exporters, because that amounts to a government subsidy for exports. 
Both the administration and Congress are now feverishly trying to rewrite the law so they can preserve the tax break without violating international law. But Congress has already made one attempt that the trade group rejected as inadequate.
Though humbling, this may be a necessary learning process.
Americans have become increasingly worried that free trade deals could jeopardize their jobs. But most American trade experts say it would be a mistake to turn away from the new system, because the United States gains more than it loses from free trade.
Even if the United States does lose some big legal disputes, American companies benefit from reliable and enforceable trade rules.
"The United States has won many more cases than it has lost," said Mickey Kantor, who was the United States trade representative from 1993 to 1996 and negotiated the treaty that created the trade organization. "We are much better off with a rules-based trading system, and the W.T.O. has frankly worked very well."

HEADLINE: On Ship of Condos, Life's an Endless Cruise 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: ABOARD THE WORLD, St. John's, Newfoundland, Aug. 31 

 BODY:
Life, they say, is a journey. But who would think to take it on a cruise ship?
 Billed by its Norwegian owners as the world's first and only residence at sea, The World, a 12-deck, 43,000-ton, 644-foot passenger ship, arrived here today -- a floating condominium with apartments, not cabins, ranging in price from more than $2 million to more than $7 million. 
 St. John's is one of 140 ports in 40 countries that the vessel is to visit in its inaugural year, the start of a perpetual circumnavigation of the globe -- a home away from home away from home. 
The World was launched in March, sailing from Oslo, and is scheduled to arrive in New York on Thursday.
Residents are on the average in their middle 50's, and generally self-made, first-generation wealthy. The World is a concept that Howard Hughes would have loved: exile reinvented, a life in comfortable circumstances that cosset but also constantly change, leaving a wake but never a trail. More than a few on board could have been Mr. Hugheses of another generation -- their determined isolation as deep as the mid-Atlantic.
"People that take a risk like this, on a new concept, they're the kind of people I generally like anyway," said Richard Reed, 60, an entrepreneur who has run martial arts schools and a software company selling billing services to health clubs. "I'm not going to sit around and wait for this concept to work itself out -- test a few boats -- there's an urgency factor to it, and it's called age."
The World's accommodations consist of 110 two- to six-bedroom condominium apartments with kitchens, decorated by carriage-trade designers like Nina Campbell of London and Juan Pablo Molyneux of New York. 
There are standard cruise ship amenities like restaurants, a casino and a spa. But there is also a corner store, Fredy's Deli, which sells Rice Krispies, oyster sauce, matzo balls and cake mixes.
Condominium maintenance fees are in the hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, but residents must scrub their own ovens, or pay extra to have them cleaned. The crystal table lamps are bolted to end tables, by regulation. Fireplaces and candles? Forget it. No pets either. 
"We have to get along," said Geoffrey Thompson, 59, a retired advertising executive from Monterey, Calif., when asked about his neighbors on The World. "We share the same backyard." His backyard tilted from side to side in the horizon of his two-bedroom apartment's windows as he spoke, seated on a sedan-sized sofa. "There's more type A personalities on board per capita than anywhere else in the world," Mr. Thompson said. "No passive bones in the body." 
The World was conceived in 1997 by Knut Kloster Jr., a Norwegian cruise ship magnate. The project was the butt of many jokes, even as The World proceeded into construction. Its size was scaled back at the boatyard, because of financing difficulties and concerns that it could not enter the smaller, more exclusive ports it was promising to prospective residents. The World, owned by ResidenSea Ltd., is registered in the Bahamas.
Eighty percent of the apartments, which have 50 year leaseholds -- the ship's expected life span -- have been sold. Plans for a sister ship have been put on hold until The World has sold completely.
Residents can board in any port and are asked, after an extended absence, to give 24-hours' notice. In fairer seas in more attractive locales, the ship expects an average of 340 people in residence, served by its crew of 320. Homeowners are at present 40 percent American, 40 percent European and 20 percent from South Africa, Australia and elsewhere. The ship also books nonresident passengers in its unsold apartments and 88 guest suites.
The apartments on The World are not being sold as investments, because of their expiring leaseholds.
"The clock started ticking the day the ship was delivered," said Jessica Estrada, the on-board sales manager. "It's a depreciating asset. It's a lifestyle, not a way to make money."
Sailing from Iceland to Newfoundland this week, a cold, lonely jog on The World's maiden Atlantic crossing, the oceans were bucking and the 100 passengers, including 15 residents, were the hard-core few. 
Mr. Reed a silver-blond man who said he earned a black belt in martial arts in Korea with Chuck Norris, the action-movie star, was seated in his living room, which he had customized heavily to his own tastes. There was a black leather Harley-Davidson edition of Monopoly on the Chinese-style lacquered coffee table, an electronic Yamaha piano, a Russian impressionist oil painting of a bar scene and a flat-screen wall clock that displayed the earth and its time zones.
"On this side of this line is Wednesday and on the other side is Thursday," Mr. Reed said, pointing to the lit, blue panel. "You're on the move all the time and it's kind of hard to keep track of that."
In fact, several residents on board had trouble identifying the day. 
Mr. Reed stows a telescope in his powder room. "You can't see the stars from land anymore," he said.
Residents are not permitted to claim The World as their primary residence, and must provide an address on land to ResidenSea when purchasing, which a company spokesman cited as proof that the ship is not being used as a tax haven.
Plans for security were not tightened after Sept. 11, though metal scanners are present for embarkation. ResidenSea officials said they would not sell to anyone with a criminal record. The company pays a security concern to perform international credit and criminal background checks on each condominium applicant.
Still, many residents, as if playing a game scheduled by the ship's "enrichment" director, are trying to figure out who among them might be on the lam, and why.
"Everybody's learning everybody's else's bio," Mr. Thompson said. "If the knowledge about somebody only goes back a few years, you kind of go, 'O.K., so where were they before that?' "
Mr. Reed also lives in a gated community, in Scottsdale, Ariz. He said that he never knew any of his neighbors there, a situation far different from life on The World.
"It's 600 by 100 feet -- you're going to run into them," he said. 
Residents like Judy Kreiss, 60, and her husband, Norman Kreiss, 75, say they like the close-quarters' style of life.
"People who come to this life -- married couples -- really have to care about each other," said Mrs. Kreiss, who has been married for 10 years. The longest they have been aboard ship is two months. A framed photograph of one of their five dogs, Shorty, a terrier, sat on a shelf next to them. Shorty lives in San Diego. 
"This isn't a life for people who aren't getting along, and so your neighbors are all people who have good marriages," Mrs. Kreiss said. "It's nice to have that reinforced all the time."
Mr. Thompson's wife, Karyn Planett, a travel writer, works with the ship's residents' committee. She said it was like a co-op board, but with many issues unique to a ship.
The group, which meets monthly, works with the company on the ship's itinerary, for example. Members have insisted on smaller, more interesting ports of call -- at Madagascar and in Londonderry, Ireland -- than short-term paying guests might prefer. But the company's bottom line is keeping the cabins full.
"They are owners of their apartments," said Rene Peter, the general manager on ship. "They don't run the company. They know as well what they bought into -- a certain space on the ship. The rest is all public space." 
The World's developers say it is the precursor of what could become a new niche in the travel industry and in vacation-home real estate. Other residence ship projects that have been reported include the America World City, proposed by the World City Corporation with investors that include Westin Hotels and Resorts, and Freedom Ship, the barge-like craft proposed by Freedom Ship International, which anticipates 40,000 residents living on a 25-story ship. The Freedom Ship filed its business plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the spring. If the ship is approved and built as planned, it will be an $11 billion home with an airport, parks, a hospital, schools and factories. 
With the cruise ship industry trying to recover from Sept. 11 and an industry recession generated late in the 1990's by overbuilding, the pressure to keep The World booked to capacity is strong. ResidenSea, based in Miami, is discounting its passenger fares and is aggressively marketing its empty apartments as rentals, from $1,800 to $5,460 a night.
Ms. Planett said that the residents were realists who understood The World's marketing challenges.
"The company has to be on a sound financial footing or we all suffer," she said. "So we know the reality of their need to fill the guest suites and to have itineraries that are attractive to sell. We like a traveler who buys into the concept, to see the world in a more leisurely pace than the standard cruise ship passenger."
She raised an obvious point, the spray flying past her $3 million apartment as it sailed below the southern tip of Greenland.
"If we're not happy, it's not going to work for anybody," she said. "But how to boycott? Do we do a rent strike? Rent strike to us means we'd be tied up in -- I don't know where. You pick a port."

HEADLINE: Rush to Fill Void in Menopause-Drug Market 

BYLINE:  By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
In the eight weeks since the fed eral government announced that it had halted a study of a popular hormone therapy used by postmenopausal women, doctors say they have been deluged by an ever-growing tide of promotional material for anything and everything that could substitute for Prempro, the drug used in the study. 
 The alternatives run the gamut: prescription drugs that consist of slightly different hormone formulations, nutritional supplements made of herbs and vitamins, soy products said to be natural sources of estrogen, and even what might be termed menopause accessories, such as one company's "cooling comfort towelettes" to wipe the sweat from hot flashes. 
 But many doctors and scientists say they are alarmed by the profusion of Prempro substitutes. The trouble, they say, is that these drugs and supplements have been studied less than Prempro has. Their benefits and risks are simply unknown. 
That is especially true for nutritional supplements. Their advertising receives far less government scrutiny than claims for prescription drugs, which the Food and Drug Administration regulates closely. 
They are also sold without a doctor's guidance. "Everything you've ever heard of is being marketed," said Dr. Wulf Utian, the executive director of the North American Menopause Society, "and it's being marketed to a confused and vulnerable population." 
Prempro, a combination of estrogens and progestin made by Wyeth, has long dominated the menopause market. Until this summer it was used by six million American women, many of whom assumed they would be taking it for a lifetime to protect against some effects of aging, like brittle bones.
But when the federal study, the Women's Health Initiative, found that Prempro carried slight risks (of heart attack, stroke and breast cancer) that outweighed its benefits (a slightly lower risk of colon cancer and hip fracture), the part of the study in which women were taking Prempro was ended. A study in which women take estrogen alone continues. A Wyeth spokesman, Doug Petkus, said sales of Prempro had declined 25 to 30 percent.
Many companies appear to have rushed into the opening. "The Women's Health Initiative Study wasn't out of my fingers before the mailings started coming in," said Dr. Nanette Santoro, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. "It's what you expect in a capitalist economy. You have people with products to sell."
Prempro, like other estrogen replacements, is clearly effective against some symptoms of menopause, including hot flashes and vaginal dryness. Dr. Isaac Schiff, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at the Massachusetts General Hospital, said the government's findings touched off "a mild to severe panic" and left some women desperate for alternatives.
"Now we are seeing the fallout," Dr. Schiff said. "They are saying, 'The hot flashes are killing me,' or 'I don't feel well.' " Some of his patients tell him they have lost energy or a sense of well-being. 
"They are trying to go back on estrogen," Dr. Schiff said. But, he added, "They do not want to go on Prempro."
While the level of marketing for alternative drugs and supplements is impossible to quantify in the short time since the findings about Prempro were reported, Dr. Schiff and others say they have been bombarded with fliers, e-mail promotions and visits from drug salespeople. A similar barrage is going out to patients, in the form of advertisements in newspapers and magazines, in the mail and on the Web.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecolgists has warned its members that it is not necessarily safe to switch women from Prempro to other prescription hormones, adding, "Caution is warranted for different preparations, and their safety should not be assumed in the absence of conclusive data."
But prescription hormones are only part of the picture. Doctors say they are particularly concerned about the promotion of nutritional supplements.
The college of obstetricians, for example, cautions, "The number and sophistication of most studies on alternative therapies, including botanicals, do not meet the current standards of evidence-based recommendations." It adds that " 'natural' does not mean safe or effective," and that "potentially dangerous or lethal drug-herb interactions can occur."
The National Institutes of Health's National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine also cautions women on its Web site, http://nccam.nih.gov/health/alerts/menopause/, about the claims being made for vitamins, herbs and products like soy that contain plant estrogens.
"At this time, there is not enough scientific evidence to determine whether these therapies are beneficial," the Web site says. "In addition, we do not have sufficient information to show whether these therapies are as safe or safer than conventional drugs being used for menopausal symptoms, osteoporosis or heart disease."
Makers of the supplements assert that they are safe and effective. Gayle Engles, education director for the Botanical Council, a nonprofit group that disseminates information on herbal medicines, says that many of the products have been in use for hundreds of years and that some have been tested in scientific studies. 
Still, Dr. Utian, of the menopause society, said that too many companies were sending a message he paraphrased this way: "The Women's Health Initiative has shown the other stuff is garbage, but we have the answer." 
He cited an e-mail promotion with the headline: "Women Search for a Safe Alternative to Hormonal Replacement Therapy. Scientific Research Already Has the Answer." The company, SuperNutrition, says its vitamin and herb combination called Menopause Multiple Blend prevents hot flashes, strengthens bone, protects against heart disease, prevents memory problems and, best of all, is "safe and natural."
Makers of other products also advertise benefits that groups like the National Institutes of Health say are not demonstrated.
Whole World Botanicals advertises a Peruvian herb, maca, asserting that it can relieve symptoms of menopause and even help with "premenstrual syndrome" in younger women. The herb, its maker claims, "contains no plant hormones, unlike soy/genistein and black cohosh."
Zoe Foods says its soy cereals and bars "have helped thousands of women overcome their menopausal symptoms." Another company, SoyToy, claims its soy juicer makes milk from soybeans in 25 minutes. Soy, it says, alleviates symptoms of menopause, increases bone mass and decreases the risk of heart disease.
GlaxoSmithKline, the large drug company best known for its prescription drugs, touts the benefits of another diet supplement, black cohosh, which it markets as Remifemin. The package states that Remifemin is "drug free" and "estrogen free" and that it is good for hot flashes, night sweats, mood swings, irritability and related occasional sleeplessness. A footnote informs consumers, "These statements have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration."
Other companies offer custom blends of actual estrogens and progestins. Individual states, rather than the F.D.A., normally regulate these products as they regulate pharmacies. 
Dr. Schiff, at Massachusetts General, pointed to a flier from one such company, the Women's International Pharmacy, advertising "bio-identical hormones" and "customized prescriptions" and claiming that its product is safer than hormones sold by drug companies. "They have no evidence for that," Dr. Schiff said. 
Makers of prescription estrogens and progestins take a different tack, he said. Because those drugs are regulated by the F.D.A., they may not make unproven claims. 
"I have been bombarded with very subtle ads," Dr. Schiff said. "They can't say their product is safer because they don't have the evidence." Instead, he said, they try an indirect approach: " 'We make product ABC and we don't make the product that was involved in the Women's Health Initiative.' It is like having a bad relative and making sure you don't sit next to them. They are pushing themselves away from the table."
Dr. Marcia L. Stefanick of Stanford University, the principal investigator for the Women's Health Initiative, said some doctors were too quick to say that the risks of Prempro were specific to Prempro but not to other formulations of estrogens and progestins -- or that estrogens from plants were safe because they are "natural." 
The estrogens in Prempro, Dr. Stefanick said, "are as natural to the horse as the phytoestrogens are to the South American yam." As for soy, she asked, "If it is natural to a soy plant, does that make it natural to humans?"

HEADLINE: Season Is Salvaged, but Baseball Still Has Rich Facing the Poor 

BYLINE:  This article was reported by David Leonhardt, Murray Chass, Steven Greenhouse and Richard Sandomir and written by Mr. Leonhardt. 

 BODY:
The schedule said that Major League Baseball would play 15 games today from Toronto to San Diego. History suggested that not a pitch would be thrown and that each big-league ballpark would sit as empty as it does in February.
 But baseball defied history. After haggling for months over complex economic formulas and cold cash, owners and players reached an agreement on Friday that both sides said would give the sport a new lease on the public's imagination. 
 By distributing revenue more equally among teams, the owners argued, the new contract would allow fans in once-passionate baseball towns like Minneapolis and Pittsburgh to believe again that their teams, too, could be consistent winners and contend for a championship. That faith has faded as teams like the Atlanta Braves and the New York Yankees used their wealth to build the best lineups money could buy. 
Whether the negotiators' haggling has solved baseball's problems, however, is far from clear. After all, consider what the contract does not change. The economic might of local television deals will still give some teams like the Yankees and Braves far more money than others.
There is also no guarantee that poorly run teams in small markets will not pocket the new subsidies they will receive from the richest teams, instead of investing in new players or in hanging onto their stars.
At the players' insistence, moreover, the major leagues agreed not to shut down any franchises for the next four years, leaving baseball to cope with the drag of two or three badly struggling teams, most notably the Montreal Expos.
"I think people will see a change in the tide and the direction the game is going in," said Kevin McClatchy, the chief executive and managing general partner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, a team that has endured its share of small-market woes. "But do you solve 30 years of problems with one agreement? No, you don't."
A Pirates fan, Steve Kokal of Plum Borough, Pa., expressed skepticism that the balance of power would shift and improve the fortunes of a team that is headed for a 10th straight losing season. "I don't think the agreement will change anything," he said. "The Yankees will always have too much money and will always pay top dollar for the best players. We get a good player and they're gone because we can't afford to keep them."
Still, McClatchy saw reason for optimism. "We have changed the landscape," he said. "The inequity of payrolls has grown dramatically over the years and I think you will see that change."
If nothing else, baseball is better off today than it was a week ago, simply because everybody knows that pitchers will be trying to get batters out for another two months, and, based on the new contract's length, for another four seasons.
In Chicago today, Wrigley Field will resemble a giant block party for the Midwest, as it does every time the Cubs and St. Louis Cardinals play there. On the West Coast, one of the best pennant races in years will continue with teams in Seattle, Oakland and Anaheim, Calif. Around Phoenix and New York, fans can continue hoping for a rematch of last year's thrilling World Series.
Negotiators made today's games possible by bargaining through the night Thursday and into late morning on Friday. Working primarily with two negotiators from each camp, they shuttled between their offices in Manhattan, exchanging proposals at one long session Thursday night, then two short 20-minute sessions at 4 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. Friday. The final push, which included Commissioner Bud Selig and the union head, Donald Fehr, came in a three-hour session Friday morning.
Still, the bitter relationship between Major League Baseball's owners and players, easily the worst among major sports, has left the business of baseball damaged. Just the prospect of a strike this season seems to have angered fans more than some actual work interruptions did in the past. As the strike deadline approached, fans displayed their frustration with harsh signs at games and complaints on talk radio; on Thursday night in Anaheim, in potentially the last game before a strike, spectators booed the players, threw back balls hit into the stands, and littered the field with debris.
Overall attendance has declined by 5.5 percent this season, and is on a pace to be at its lowest level since 1997. Television ratings for last year's World Series were about half what they were 20 years ago, a far worse decline than the Super Bowl has suffered over the same span.
Indeed, the sport's tenuous hold on many fans' loyalties seemed to have helped push owners and players to reach a new contract without enduring a work stoppage for the first time in 30 years.

The Negotiations
Respect Instead Of Bitterness
If the new labor agreement has in fact ended an era in Major League Baseball history, it is an era that began almost four decades ago. The bitterness that built up over that period left many people surprised, both by the relative calm leading to Friday's strike deadline and the timely resolution of the talks.
"This is a day that many believed would never happen," Selig said after the negotiations ended.
By avoiding a strike even after a strike date had been set, Selig added, "We were able to do what hasn't been done before."
With a few exceptions, both owners and players avoided harsh public criticism of each other. They also agreed fairly quickly to a modest plan for steroid testing that they say will alleviate one the game's biggest on-the-field problems. In the best case, observers say, the talks could be the start of a period in which baseball's owners promote the game by praising their players instead of scoring political points by criticizing them as greedy. 
"I have seen in recent weeks a real effort to reduce the level of rhetoric," said Neal Pilson, the former head of CBS Sports, who runs a consulting business. "This negotiation has been conducted at a much higher level of respect than the last one."
The strategy may seem obvious, given the interest that owners and players share in the game's prosperity. Since the mid-1960's, however, the enmity between players and owners has often overwhelmed everything else in the sport.
Complaining that pensions were too small, two star pitchers -- Jim Bunning, now a United States senator, and Robin Roberts -- began pushing to create a new, more effective union. In 1966, Marvin Miller, an economist with the steelworkers' union, signed on as the players union's executive director, and they slowly began to demand changes.
At first, the players made small requests, like asking for better pitchers' mounds in the Yankee Stadium bullpen and more clubhouse toilets in Cincinnati, said Charles Korr, the author of a recently published history of the players union. By 1972, however, after twice sweetening player pensions, the owners decided that the players did not have the courage to walk out and refused to give in a third time.
That marked the end of any semblance of labor peace. The players promptly showed their resolve, staging a 13-day strike. The owners capitulated, setting a pattern that would largely continue over seven more work interruptions during the next 22 years.
The most important change came in 1975, when an arbitrator gave the players the right to be free agents, who could sign with whichever team they wished when their contracts expired. Until then, baseball had operated with the so-called reserve clause, which bound players to a team unless they were traded, sold or released. That system's harshness, in the face of baseball's success, helped doom the game to labor relations far worse than in any other major sport, experts say. 
The arbitrator's decision set off an explosion in salaries that the owners have tried to restrain in every subsequent contract negotiation -- and that leaves some of them bitter even now.
"That was an outrageous decision," Bowie Kuhn, baseball's commissioner at the time, said in an interview last week.
Since then, the dynamic between the two sides has flipped, with the owners looking to each negotiation as a chance to change the system and roll back player salaries, the players fighting to keep things as they are. "The fans and press asked, 'What do the greedy players want?' " Miller said. "Then, as now, we didn't want more. We just wanted to keep the status quo."
By the mid-1980's the frustrated owners turned to a new tactic: they colluded to keep salaries low, and some of the game's star free agents went unsigned for months. Selig and the owners have consistently called the charges unfounded, but three arbitrators' rulings went against them, and in 1990 the owners agreed to pay the players $280 million as compensation.
Many labor experts say the collusion scandal has dominated the tenor of contract talks ever since. 
"Collusion is the biggest single factor in the recent history of baseball," said Fay Vincent, the former commissioner. "After collusion, Fehr would say, 'How can we trust people who tried to cheat us?' "
That is why Friday's televised settlement announcement seemed significant to many people who have followed the game for years. Fehr and Selig stood together before television cameras and alternated turns at the microphone. At one point, when Selig could not hear a reporter's question, a helpful Fehr whispered it in his ear.

Sharing Revenue
How to Spread The Wealth Around
Even as the labor mistrust grew, however, the game was thriving on the field in a way it never had before.
Attendance soared in the late 1970's and 1980's as free agency helped eliminate the dynasties of earlier eras and spread championships around the league.
During the six years starting in 1981, for instance, six of the American League East's seven teams won the division. The Kansas City Royals, now a prominent cellar dweller, won the 1985 World Series with a $11.8 million payroll, only 23 percent lower than Yankees' top-ranked $15.4 million payroll, said Doug Pappas, the head of the business committee of the Society for American Baseball Research, a fans' group.
More years than not, baseball set attendance records; by 1993, average attendance was 31,000 per game, about two and a half times the number during the 1950's.
But the roots of the game's economic problems were already in the ground -- thanks more to changes in the media business than within baseball itself.
In a deal that took effect in 1989, the MSG Network bought the rights to broadcast Yankees games for 12 years, paying the team a $50 million signing bonus and another $443.5 million through 2000. Nobody had seen anything like it before. 
The initial yearly payments were small, starting at $7.5 million, but they quickly ramped up, rising to $50.7 million in 2000. By last year, only four teams were making more on their local television contracts than the $29.1 million that the Yankees collected from MSG in 1991.
The Yankees have put their television money to better use than any other team, developing home-grown talent and winning four of the last six World Series. But their success, and that of Ted Turner -- who owned both the Atlanta Braves and the cable channel that broadcast Braves games -- spurred cable operators to buy some teams and pay huge sums to others. Fox, owned in part by the News Corporation, has led the way; not only does it own the Los Angeles Dodgers, but it has also nearly blanketed the country with regional Fox Sports Net channels.
The result of all this, according to sports executives, was a quick and sharp widening of the gap between baseball's haves and have-nots.
"That was the defining moment: the growth of regional cable," Neal Pilson said. "Regional cable became more valuable, grew their audiences and teams benefited from that increased flow of money."
The National Football League and the National Basketball Association rely primarily on national television contracts for their media revenue; in turn, those leagues split the money equally between the teams. 
Baseball, by contrast, receives much more of its media money from local broadcasting deals, largely because it plays twice as many regular-season games as basketball and 10 times as many as football.
"Baseball has never understood TV," said Rick Burton, director of the Warsaw Sports Management Center at the University of Oregon. "And into that vacuum stepped people like Ted Turner and George Steinbrenner, who said if you can't take care of yourself nationally, we'll do it regionally."
The size of a local market is not everything, as the players union has frequently noted when arguing against a salary cap, which puts a limit on payrolls. With resources similar to the Yankees', the Los Angeles Dodgers and Boston Red Sox have not appeared in a single World Series in the last decade.
The Seattle Mariners, meanwhile, have found success. They have overcome an undistinguished history -- they did not win more games than they lost until 1991, their 15th year of existence -- to develop both a winning team and a cult following across the Pacific Northwest. Their games on the regional Fox network are seemingly must-watch TV, commanding the highest ratings by far for a major league team. Fox pays the Mariners handsomely -- $37 million last year as part of a new deal -- but reaped the benefits because the franchise invested in the team.
Still, revenue differences have become a central aspect of baseball, and they dominated the recently concluded negotiations.
The Yankees have made the playoffs every year since 1995, and the Braves have won 10 straight division titles (not including the 1994 strike year).
At the same time, the gap between the teams that draw the most fans and those that draw the least has been widening.
Knowing that many fans felt frustrated by the disparity, Selig and the owners turned "competitive balance" into their rallying cry in the negotiations and won a good deal of public support.
In the end, the contract requires all teams to place 34 percent of their net local revenue into an evenly split league pool, and teams with payrolls above a certain threshold, beginning at $117 million next year, will also face a luxury tax stiffer than the current one. 
The agreement that expired this year had similar, although milder, provisions. For most fans, who care little for how players and owners divide their money, the only true test of the new agreement will be whether it does a better job than the previous one of providing competitive balance and allow teams to hold onto their star players.

The Fans
Paying Customers Do Care. Right?
The news that a baseball strike had been averted may have sparked some celebrations across North America, but the feelings are mixed in Pittsburgh, the small-market city where losing and baseball have formed a lasting relationship.
"Go on strike, don't go on strike, I couldn't care less," Ray Sager of nearby New Castle, Pa., said Friday after the agreement was announced. "I don't have nearly the interest in baseball that I used to. It's not a game anymore; it's just about money. This is a small city and that's the problem. How can we compete? We lost Barry Bonds and that ought to tell you everything you need to know. I can't see anything changing."
It has been Kevin McClatchy's job to change that sort of attitude among his team's fans, but he has made little headway. He has been at the controls of the Pirates since 1996 and the team has not had a winning season. At 60-75 entering last night's game at Florida, the Pirates are all but assured their 10th straight losing season. Their problems are many and not all of them have to do with the fact they play in one of the smaller markets in baseball, so McClatchy and his staff are working with limited resources.
There are 334,563 people living in Pittsburgh. According to McClatchy, the team receives about $9 million in local television revenue, and it is drawing 23,380 fans per game this year, its second at PNC Park. With such meager numbers, a team like the Pirates cannot come close to paying for talent what a team like the Yankees does. The 2002 Yankees' opening-day payroll was some $92 million more than the Pirates' payroll. In 1992, the last year the Pirates made the postseason, and a time when the economics of baseball were different, they were outspent by the Yankees by only $5 million.
With a luxury tax and revenue sharing agreed upon by the players and owners, the chasm figures to narrow.
"The deck may still be stacked against us, but with what happened today it will be a lot more in our favor over the next four years than it has been," McClatchy said. "Still, we have to do a good job in all other areas. The Mets and Texas are two teams that spent a lot of money and it hasn't ensured winning seasons. In the long run, though, this will give our team more of a shot."
Kevin Young, the veteran first baseman for the Pirates, said the reality of playing for a small-market team sets in over time.
"When you have that competitive drive throughout your life, it goes well with a team like Pittsburgh," Young said. "You really have that fight in you and always want to be the underdog and you always look forward to upsetting teams."
He added: "But the reality is that it doesn't work. It doesn't happen that way. You do need players who are optimum level to contribute and produce on a regular basis. To get those type players, it costs money."
Young seemed hopeful that this latest collective bargaining agreement will bring about positive change for Pittsburgh.
"Maybe two, three, four years from now, when I'm not playing, I can look back and say this was the day we solidified baseball as the national pastime."
McClatchy speaks passionately about how devoted he is to winning, about how important it was that the season has been salvaged and how baseball is addressing many of its major problems. He realizes the burden is on management to take any new money and use it to improve the team.
"It is important now that the small-market teams spend their money on players and work toward improving the competitive balance," he said.

The Profits
How the Subsidies Will Pay Off
The new agreement will move hundreds of millions of dollars from teams like the Yankees to teams like the Pirates over the next four years. The biggest question that now hangs over baseball, many observers say, is whether the owners receiving money will invest it in the team, or simply use it to increase their profits.
To the great frustration of big-market owners like George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, there is little evidence on the field of the subsidies that small-revenue teams have received as part of the 1996 labor pact. Unable to compete for top free agents, some of the poorer teams have essentially given up, minimizing their payrolls and, according to critics, pocketing their subsidies.
"Going from 60 wins to 80 wins doesn't really pay for itself," said Pappas, of the Society for American Baseball Research.
The new agreement could change the dynamic by vastly increasing the amount of money small-revenue teams will receive. 
The Minnesota Twins and Oakland A's, for example, are both in first place today despite two of the lowest payrolls in baseball. But many of their talented young players will become free agents over the next four years, jeopardizing the kind of talented nucleus around which the Yankees have to built their dynasty. 
In the recent past, many of the teams' best players would have eventually gone elsewhere, just as Jason Giambi, who may be the best hitter in the American League, left the A's at the end of last season for a $17 million average annual contract with the Yankees -- close to half of Oakland's $40.5 million payroll this year. This could be one reason that the Twins and A's are both drawing many fewer fans than they did when their teams won division titles in the 1980's.
With a larger budget, the teams still will not have the choices that the Red Sox or Dodgers do, but they are likely to have a better chance at keeping at least one of their stars even after he files for free agency. 
"I think it will make a significant difference," said Richard G. Sheehan, an economist at the University of Notre Dame who studies sports business, referring to the agreement. Not only will the poorer teams have more money, he said, but the new luxury tax will also prevent the richest teams from offering as many huge contracts as they have.
On the other hand, Mr. Sheehan said, the new deal offers little incentive for less successful small-revenue teams to sign new free agents.
That could leave teams like the Detroit Tigers, Florida Marlins and Tampa Bay Devil Rays deciding to remain in the vicious cycle of losing and bad attendance. And when the owners agreed in last week's talks not to pursue contraction and close any teams over the next four years -- saving union jobs -- they eliminated one solution many analysts find attractive.
In the 1990's, the owners "overexpanded and diluted the product," said Sal Galatioto, a managing director at Lehman Brothers, who advises buyers and sellers of sports franchises. "And it hurts big-market teams, too. If you're a Yankee fan, you'd rather see five more games against the Red Sox than against the Kansas City Royals."
Without contraction, baseball might approve its first franchise relocation in three decades. The Expos are the most likely candidate, and the Washington area, without a team since the Senators left in 1971, is a potential new location for them.
Still, all 30 franchises will exist in some form until at least 2006. They now have to convince people, in both New York and Pittsburgh, that they are worth watching.
