HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
Airlines Trying to Improve Food at 30,000 Feet

BYLINE:  By TANYA MOHN; Readers are invited to send stories about business travel experiences to businesstravel@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
Everybody has heard the horror stories about airline food, post-Sept. 11. It's either inedible or nowhere to be found.
 But try hard enough, and you can feast like a king at 30,000 feet. The surest way to haute cuisine is probably a flight to Europe or Asia on a foreign airline. But don't count out American carriers just yet. While their food might not always rise to Old World gastronomic refinement, it does show inventiveness by appealing to American tastes like the preoccupation with health and the love of speed and efficiency. 
 To sample the cuisine of faraway indigenous cultures, give Air New Zealand a try. Selections like grilled herb marinated venison with mushroom tempura in white soy ginger sesame sauce and sauteed orange roughy with tomato prawn and seasonal vegetables in chardonnay watercress sauce are typical dishes in first and business class.
And Patricia Fraser, a former airline employee in marketing who admits to being a hard sell, has noticed the quality filtering down to economy class. On a recent 14-hour flight from Los Angeles to Sydney on Air New Zealand, she found the food and service "out of this world," and was impressed by the choice of wines and the fact they were poured from full bottles.
Wine lovers will feel at home on Singapore Airlines. It boasts one of the largest wine cellars in the industry, a storehouse in Singapore crammed with many of the 132,000 cases it serves each year. And Anthony Dias Blue, a wine consultant for the airline, says the most exciting wines are not served in first class at all, where older, more established clients are often less daring. "The stuff we pour in Raffles is more interesting," he said, referring to the business class.
If a healthy diet is uppermost in your mind, consider booking a flight with Delta Air Lines. It designed "ideal performance meals" for international BusinessElite travelers a couple of years ago in consultation with Dr. Jack Groppel, a nutritionist and fitness expert known for his work to help athletes achieve high performance.
Those same techniques are applied to meals that will help business travelers, he says. "Food is a very powerful drug" Dr. Groppel said, "with the ability to alter chemistry in an incredible way."
Dopamine, activated by proteins, promotes alertness for those who must work on board, he says, while serotonin in a carbohydrate meal, such as raviolini pasta, promotes calm, allowing the client to rest and be alert upon landing.
It worked for Scott Cushing, a sales manager for ChevronTexaco, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., who was nervous about being fresh for a business meeting after a flight from Atlanta to Paris.
"Typically, I have a hard time sleeping on flights," Mr. Cushing said. But after loading up on penne primavera with vegetables and a pesto alfredo sauce, he said, "I slept, and when I arrived I woke up and was immediately able to get on schedule. It was a total shock. I was thrilled."
Mr. Cushing was so pleased with the results, that he "pirated" a Delta menu for his own use. He has since shared it with fellow business travelers, he says, and follows the concepts no matter what airline he takes.
Some foreign airlines offer organic foods. Swiss Air was the first. Varig, the Brazilian airline, put them on its menus last September for international business and first-class travelers and plans to expand the service to international economy early next year. In polls the airline conducts on its shuttle flights of senior corporate executives, healthy food is consistently rated as a priority, Edward Couto, a Varig executive, said. "We started paying attention to our customers," he said.
Satisfying fliers, never easy, has become harder since Sept. 11, of course, with metal knives banned and meals on some carriers now delivered to planes at fewer points, meaning the food is held longer. 
Even getting the basics right is not easy, said Kelly Yorke, the corporate-executive chef for Midwest Express. "Taste buds are duller at 30,000 feet," she said, so salt and spices are "turned up a notch." And some food has to be tightly wrapped until the last minute, or prepared in special sauces, because it tends to dry out quickly in the cabin air.
Several years ago, Midwest Express's goal was to offer the best coffee of any airline, and Ms. Yorke worked for more than a year to overcome adverse cabin conditions for brewing like high altitudes and air pressure and low humidity, and to find just the right filters for maximizing extraction. 
"It is so easy to produce a bad cup of coffee, and so hard to produce a good one," she said.
Some travelers have found ways to tweak the system. John L. Campo, vice president of postal relations for Pitney Bowes, orders the low-salt or vegetarian meals a day before flying and gets exactly what he wants.
Harvey Schultz, director of Asia-Pacific finance for the McDonald's Corporation, gets similar results by ordering kosher meals on trips to Asia on Singapore Airlines about eight times a year. That carrier takes customized meals one step further through its Book the Cook program that offers more than 20 regional specialties in addition to the regular menu. The program also lets first-class and business-class patrons dine whenever they want.
That is a concept that seems to be catching on. Bob Rosar, a corporate executive chef for Gate Gourmet, one of the two largest airline catering companies, says at least three international carriers offer the eat-when-you-wish option to first-class and business passengers, and one domestic carrier recently considered it.
Peter Jones, a professor at the University of Surrey School of Management in England and an expert on airline food, believes that "customization," or giving passengers a wide choice of foods and letting them order when they want, is the wave of the future. China Southern Airlines recently announced On Demand Dining, an industry first that allows first-class passengers to order absolutely any dish if they call one day in advance, he said. And passengers on many European charters pay for food separately from the ticket, "rather like the railway."
Eventually, technology will allow passengers to book a meal on a mobile phone en route to the airport or on specially designed key pads at the airport, he predicted. "The lead time between ordering and eating will be shorter and shorter," he said.
Meantime, many passengers say airline food in general is improving. "When they do serve a meal, I think the food is getting better and better," said Elise Shumsky-Glier, a sales representative for a distributor of optical and surgical products who flies frequently in both business and economy class. Even on snack-only flights, she said, "the desserts are marvelous." She likes some treats -- like the biscotti she discovered on a Delta flight -- so much that she squirrels away the wrappers and calls the 1-800 number from home. Then, she said, "I order them by the boxful."

HEADLINE: Desperately Seeking Discounters 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich. 

 BODY:
With financial turmoil forcing the nation's major airlines into retreat, reducing or eliminating service to marginal markets to try to cut their costs, smaller airports are fighting hard to lure the low-fare carriers that continue to thrive.
 Smaller cities so value air links as economic development tools that many are spending millions of dollars to expand their operations, even without a promise that one of those airlines, like Southwest and AirTran, will offer service. 
 The campaigns to land these airlines can include everything from billboards to slide shows to guaranteed amounts of business, and they often involve local officials flying to airline headquarters to plead their cases in person.
The lines they join are long: Southwest alone has 115 cities on its consideration list, with dozens more that would like to join the queue. Flint's success in attracting two low-fare airlines already makes it the envy of other communities. 
"Airports across the country are scratching to get one," said Patricia Corfman, the airport's director of marketing. "People say, 'Do you know how lucky you are to have them?' "
Midsize cities covet the carriers because the promise that a low-fare airline can spur economic development is so great. Take, for example, what has happened at Bishop International Airport here.
This industrial city, which lies 80 miles north of Detroit, is itself in such dire straits that Michigan assumed control of civic operations this summer. But its freshly renovated airport is booming, largely because of traffic generated by the two low-fare carriers among the five airlines that fly here.
Only 8,000 passengers a month used the airport at its low ebb a few years ago, but now almost five times that many crowd the terminal, where parking costs just $10 a day and baggage arrives in the lobby. Many of those passengers come from Flint's suburbs, which are flourishing even as the urban core fades.
Airport officials said they hoped that some day, Bishop International would join the ranks of airports in Albany, N.Y.; Providence, R.I.; and Manchester, N.H., that have become successful thanks to low-fare airlines. Officials in Albany figure their airport contributes $635 million to the local economy, compared with $400 million just a few years ago, and Flint-area leaders see a similar effect here.
"It's had a huge impact economically," said Richard E. Hammel, chairman of the Genesee County Board of Commissioners. "There is significant investment in the airport from the carriers."
"People are proud of this airport," he added. "It's one of the things about Flint that is a success story, and there's not a lot of things right now to be positive about."
The airport's biggest carrier has long been Northwest Airlines, which flies from here to its hubs in Detroit and Minneapolis. (Delta Air Lines and Midwest Express Airlines also serve Flint.) But lately, the attention has been on Flint's newest airline, ATA, which began service in July to Midway Airport in Chicago. ATA is already carrying more passengers on its four daily flights than either the airline or airport officials had expected, and ATA plans to add a fifth daily flight.
ATA's arrival, and the presence of AirTran since 1996, have more than offset the departure last year of both Continental Express and US Airways Express, commuter carriers operated by the major airlines whose names they bear.
In retrospect, though, "it was a blessing that US Airways did leave here," said the airport's director, James L. Rice III, because that freed up space to be used by a discounter. US Airways's recent decision to reorganize under bankruptcy protection probably would have caused the airline to quit Flint anyway, Mr. Rice said.
"If a major carrier isn't a viable business, always needing to cut costs or raise prices, then the small town that's relying on it is taking a risk," agreed L. Nick Lacey, executive vice president of Morten Beyer & Associates, an aviation consulting firm in Arlington, Va.
Travelers, meanwhile, celebrate the arrival of the new carriers because of their lower fares. Waiting to board an ATA turboprop last month, John S. Rosenthal, president of Technomics, an automotive supplier, said that he used to pay as much as $1,400 for himself and two colleagues to travel on Northwest from Minneapolis to visit a General Motors plant here.
But on ATA, the total price was less than $900 -- a 35 percent savings and welcome news for Mr. Rosenthal, 38, who is looking to cut his company's travel costs and does not mind downgrading to a propeller plane from a jet.
One reason Flint has been able to attract two low-fare airlines is its location. The airport has a wide market to draw from, stretching north to Bay City, an industrial city on Lake Huron; west to Lansing, the state capital; and south into the suburbs of Detroit. Flint's airport draws 30 percent of its traffic from Oakland County, home to the United States headquarters of DaimlerChrysler, dozens of automotive suppliers and their well-heeled employees.
Mr. Rice stresses such factors when he woos airlines. "You have to prove to them that they can make money here," he said.
The realization that there were alternatives to the big airlines -- and the high prices and infrequent service that they often provided -- struck the small airports only a few years ago. In 1996, only 126 airports actively campaigned for new business, according to figures from the Department of Transportation; a year later, more than 250 were on the prowl.
"For many years, communities thought they were the only ones experiencing the high air fare problem," said Kevin Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporate travel departments and business travelers. "Then they realized, we're not alone -- and we're all in competition with each other."
They also realized they could benefit by giving the full-service airlines a little competition, too. In Buffalo, for example, air fares dropped 36 percent after AirTran began flying there, while passenger levels increased 65 percent, according to a 2001 report by the Transportation Department. Traffic doubled in Greensboro, N.C., once AirTran arrived, while the average fare fell 10 percent.
In Albany, passenger traffic jumped by 300,000 per year, to a record 1.5 million people, since Southwest Airlines began flying there in May 2000. Prices fell by more than 40 percent on average, said the airport's spokesman, Doug Myers.
The airport sparked its own turnaround by deciding to build a 16,000 square foot addition to its terminal to accommodate Southwest -- before the airline committed to start flying there.
Flint went to even greater lengths, adding 52,000 square feet in anticipation of the day when Southwest or JetBlue, which have both shown interest in the airport, might begin service here.
Such moves, however, are a gamble with taxpayers' dollars, said Michael A. Pagano, professor of public administration at the University of Illinois at Chicago. "These regional airports hope that if they can attract one low-fare carrier, another will follow," he said. "If it doesn't work, they can be caught holding a lot of debt."
And there is no guarantee that building terminals will attract airlines. Southwest, for example, has not added a city to its system since last October, when it began service to Norfolk, Va., and said it has no plan to add one at all this year. Instead, it will concentrate on expanding routes among places it already serves.
"We have to spend a lot of time and effort" to start service to a new city, said Richard Sweet, Southwest's executive director of marketing and sales.
Although it has not yet attracted Southwest, the Akron/Canton airport in Ohio has drawn AirTran, along with service by commuter airlines linked to Delta, Northwest, US Airways and United. Except for Northwest, all those parent airlines have hit rocky financial times.
While emphasizing that the airport welcomes all carriers, Kristie VanAuken, the airport's director of marketing, said she would prefer to add another low-fare carrier to Akron. While major airlines provide links to more destinations, the direct flights offered by low-fare carriers attract more new customers to the airport, which will handle about 900,000 passengers this year, up from 400,000 in the mid-1990's.
"Economically, it makes more sense for us to bring in a value carrier that can stimulate traffic," Ms. VanAuken said. The airport aggressively markets itself as a low-cost alternative to flights from Cleveland, an hour's drive away, and Pittsburgh, about two hours distant.
So eager are many communities to attract low-fare carriers that they have persuaded local businesses to pledge to give new airlines a set amount of business during their first years of service. This tactic, called "travel banking," has helped to persuade AirTran to introduce service in eight cities, including Gulfport, Miss.; Tallahassee, Fla.; and Wichita, Kan.
Kevin Healy, AirTran's vice president of marketing, asserted that the cost to corporations and communities of guaranteeing business is more than offset by what happens once AirTran arrives.
"When we enter a market, fares generally drop 50 percent and traffic rises over 100 percent," he said. "It's a win-win situation."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
Before WorldCom, the Funeral Industry Set the Standard for Venality

BYLINE:  By ADAM COHEN 

 BODY:
The high point -- make that the low point -- of "The American Way of Death" is Jessica Mitford's account of a friend's attempt to bury a relative without spending a fortune. When the friend asked for an inexpensive redwood coffin, the funeral home agreed at first. But the salesman called back to say the deceased was too tall, and she had to buy a coffin that cost $100 more. When Ms. Mitford's friend balked, the salesman responded, "Oh, all right, we'll use the redwood one, but we'll have to cut off his feet."
 This summer it feels as if big business is letting us down as never before. But corporate scandals have been a part of American history since the Yazoo land fraud of 1795. Thirty-nine years ago Ms. Mitford exposed one of the most jaw-dropping of all: the great funeral industry scandal of 1963. Her findings, acerbically set forth in her surprise best seller, hold some important lessons for today's reformers. 
 This unlikely scandal was set off by an unlikely crusader. One of six daughters of the Baron of Redesdale, Ms. Mitford left the British aristocracy behind and married Bob Treuhaft, an Oakland trade-union lawyer. From him she learned that when working men died, their hard-won death benefits -- intended to support their widows and children -- invariably ended up in the pockets of unscrupulous undertakers.
On the trail of injustice, Ms. Mitford made undercover visits to funeral parlors and pored over back issues of Casket & Sunnyside -- and the rest is muckraking history. "The American Way of Death" soared to the top of the New York Times best-seller list, and ignited a firestorm. CBS turned it into an hourlong documentary, and newspapers from New York to San Francisco investigated local funeral practices. Ms. Mitford's encounters with shady undertakers and cemetery plot salesmen led her to some conclusions that apply to today's corporate scandals, or most likely soon will: 
1. Never underestimate corporate greed. Before her book came out, funeral directors presented themselves as humble comforters of the bereaved. But Ms. Mitford showed that they charged more to bury 1.7 million Americans a year than universities charged to educate 3.6 million. 
Many observers of today's scandals have been shocked by how far rich people will go to become richer. Bernard Ebbers, who took in more than $46 million at WorldCom, still grabbed nearly a million shares of hot I.P.O. stock, possibly illegally. Martha Stewart, who is worth a good fraction of a billion dollars, took the time to personally trade -- perhaps using insider information -- a few thousand shares of ImClone stock. Having met prosperous businessmen who would threaten to cut off a loved one's feet to make a few more bucks, Ms. Mitford would not have been a bit surprised.
2. Corporate crooks often tell us exactly what they're doing. Much of "The American Way of Death" is simply excerpts from the funeral industry's own publications. (The book "Successful Funeral Management" warned undertakers not to line up coffins by price, since it made it too easy for the grieving family to comparison shop.) So it is with the current scandal, where the most damning evidence is in many cases the wrongdoers' own words. Wall Street analysts issued "buy" recommendations while yukking it up in internal e-mails that the stocks were junk. C.E.O.'s made bullish pronouncements, duping their shareholders and employees, while filling out forms to sell their own stock. When their words are quoted back to them in legal indictments, it will be akin to what Ms. Mitford retorted to funeral directors who complained about her book: She could not see why they were unhappy, since it was "almost entirely given over to expounding their point of view."
3. Sometimes it isn't just the bad apples. President Bush has tried to argue that the misdeeds of Enron, WorldCom and the rest are ethical lapses of a few bad actors, and that the solution is criminal prosecutions. But the point of "The American Way of Death" is that the funeral industry as a whole was corrupt. "This would normally be the place to say . . . 'I am not, of course, speaking of the vast majority of ethical undertakers,' " Ms. Mitford wrote in the foreword. "But the vast majority of ethical undertakers is precisely the subject of this book." The only solution, she insisted -- as reformers today must -- was sweeping reform.
4. Reform comes slowly. For those hoping for meaningful reform now, the funeral experience is sobering. When "The American Way of Death" came out in 1963, the public was outraged. But despite a flood of angry letters, it took the Federal Trade Commission until 1972 to begin an investigation. It was 12 more years before it adopted -- over strenuous industry lobbying -- a rule instituting some of the reforms Ms. Mitford had recommended.
The new rule required funeral homes, but not cemeteries, to itemize services and costs in advance so consumers could decide which they wanted. Still, when Ms. Mitford died in 1996, much of her agenda had been blocked. The Senate held hearings this summer on a bill, to be introduced later this month, that would, among other things, require cemeteries to itemize costs -- just in time for the 40th anniversary of Ms. Mitford's explosive little book.

Consolidated Freightways To File for Bankruptcy
Consolidated Freightways, one of the nation's largest trucking companies, said that it would shut down most of its operations immediately in a move that could result in the loss of at least 12,400 jobs.
 The 73-year-old company made the announcement after talks to secure financing from its banks and other lenders collapsed. It said it would seek bankruptcy protection from creditors. Page C4.

The September Effect on Markets
Analysts say they see little evidence to suggest that stock market indexes are poised to move markedly higher. While there appears less risk that stocks will move through recent lows, recent experience shows that September has not been a month when spirits lifted and markets flourished. Market Place. C6.

Benchmark Indexes Fall Overseas
Stocks in Europe and Asia fell. In London, the benchmark FTSE 100 index lost 46.40 points, or 1.1 percent, falling to 4,180.90. In Japan, the Nikkei 225-stock average slid 1 percent, to 9,521.63, about 100 points above its 18-year low, reached in February. And in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index slid 1.5 percent, to 9,896.98, a 5.1 percent drop in seven days. C8.

Telefonica to Sell Shares in Units
Spain's largest phone company, Telefonica, plans to sell shares in its Admira media unit and the television producer Endemol Entertainment Holding in an effort to reduce losses from a write-down of its European wireless businesses. C8.

Post-Enron Accounting Boot Camp
Many top executives and board members who attended a post-Enron accounting boot camp came away daunted and frustrated by the overwhelming message in almost every lecture: that the legal landscape is shifting and that the liabilities for directors are greater than ever. A1.

Bad Old Days in a Man's World
Liz Perks hung up her spurs as a business traveler nearly two years ago, after 15 years and about 50 countries. When she first started out, women -- who now account for about 40 percent of business travelers -- were a distinct minority. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C6.

U.S. Markets Reopen Today
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. The overseas markets were open. The markets in the United States will reopen today.

HEADLINE: China Struggles To Cut Reliance On MideastOil 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
Alarmed by violence and political volatility in the Middle East, China's leaders are aggressively developing alternatives to oil from the region. But a booming economy and rising sales of cars may propel China, however reluctantly, into the same sticky embrace with Mideast oil producers that the United States, Japan and many other countries have accepted.
 China's transformation from a net exporter of oil as recently as 1993 to a big oil importer has made it more attuned to events in the Middle East. Even as the Bush administration steps up threats to attack Iraq, Baghdad has been wooing the Chinese. Iraq's foreign minister, Naji Sabri, has just met here with Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen and other high-ranking officials, and the Chinese reiterated their opposition to the use or threat of force against Iraq. 
 A report in July by the U.S.-China Security Review Commission, a group created by Congress, warned that China's increasing needs for imported energy had given it an incentive to become closer to countries like Iran, Iraq and Sudan that are accused by the State Department of supporting terrorism. 
A "key driver in China's relations with terrorist-sponsoring governments is its dependence on foreign oil to fuel its economic development," the report said. "This dependency is expected to increase over the coming decade." 
The Chinese are trying to increase the production of oil and natural gas at home and buy more energy from elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, with projects from Australia to Siberia, and from their continental shelf to the deserts of Xinjiang province in the west, Chinese energy company executives and diplomats here said. 
But many Western experts predict that China's energy needs will grow far beyond those reserves and that recent efforts, including the increased use of natural gas, can only slow but not reverse the country's dependence on the Middle East, which now supplies three-fifths of China's oil imports. "They are going to be short such a significant amount of crude that there isn't any choice except to rely more on the Middle East," said David Pietz, a specialist on Chinese energy at Washington State University. 
China accounted for a quarter of the world's growth in oil use over the last decade, during the last several years becoming the fastest-growing consumer of oil. By 2030, according to the International Energy Agency in Paris, it will import as much oil as the United States does now, an eightfold increase over its current import levels. 
"This makes China's energy development critical not only for China but for the world at large," said Robert Priddle, the agency's executive director.
Energy security is a deeply sensitive subject in China, where self-sufficiency was a mantra during Mao Zedong's time. But officials now acknowledge that this is no longer realistic and are publicly worrying about the implications of this. 
Rising dependence on imports, "will dramatically increase the supply-side risks of petroleum resources," China's minister for state land and resources, Tian Fengshan, said in a rare statement on the subject in July, "and that will damage the country's capacity to ensure its oil resources as well as economic and political security." 
China's rising energy consumption also threatens to make it a huge contributor to global warming, by burning more fossil fuels.
In the late 1990's, even as its economy grew, China had actually reduced its emissions of the gases blamed for global warming -- mainly by switching factories and homes from coal to cleaner-burning oil and natural gas, and by moving to less energy-intensive industries like the production of consumer electronics and clothing instead of steel. But emissions appear to be increasing again, with coal consumption rising 5.4 percent last year while the use of oil and natural gas also rose. 
Growth in Chinese oil consumption has accelerated mainly because of a large-scale transition, still in its early stages, away from bicycles and mass transit and toward private automobiles. Car sales jumped 40 percent in the first seven months of this year compared with the similar period of 2001, although part of the gain reflected the increased affordability of cars as China's entry into the World Trade Organization forced it to reduce tariffs and increase import quotas. 
In the mid-1990's, state-owned Chinese companies purchased oil fields in Iraq and the Sudan, although international sanctions on Iraq have limited the development of the fields there and Sudanese civil war has periodically slowed production. 
More recently, China has been pursuing supplies of energy that are as reliable as possible, which usually means as far as possible from the Middle East. While some of the recent flurry of deals were in the works before last September's attacks, the Chinese have lent extra impetus to them lately. 
On July 4, a consortium of domestic and foreign energy companies announced that it would spend $3.3 billion to develop gas fields in western China and $5.2 billion for a pipeline to carry the gas across the country to Shanghai. On Aug. 8, China concluded an agreement with Australia to buy $11 billion to $13 billion worth of liquefied natural gas over 25 years for Guangdong province, China's most prosperous region in the south, and said it had begun exclusive talks with Indonesia to buy $8 billion to $10 billion of liquefied natural gas for Fujian province. 
Mark Qiu, the chief financial officer of Cnooc Ltd., a Chinese offshore drilling company, said in an interview here that planning was already under way to double Guangdong's purchases, by buying more gas from Australia or some other country, and possibly to double Fujian's purchases as well. Cnooc also bought half a dozen oil fields in Indonesia early this year and announced plans a week ago to pay $320 million for a 5 percent stake in the Northwest Shelf gas fields of Australia; it is negotiating to buy a stake in Indonesia's gas fields, too. 
Energy company executives here said that China is also exploring ways to buy more energy from Siberia. An oil pipeline is already being built from near Lake Baikal in Siberia to a giant Chinese refinery in Daqing in northeastern China, and a joint Russian-Chinese study is under way to build a gas pipeline, as well, to Daqing or Beijing from the Lake Baikal area, they said. 
The Chinese also invited Gazprom, the giant Russian energy company, to join a consortium developing the gas fields in western China, in a possible prelude to having the trans-China pipeline carry gas to Shanghai from far larger gas fields across the border in western Siberia. 
The Chinese military remains especially leery of energy dependence on the country's northern neighbor, Russia, according to a new paper on Chinese energy from the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London. The fear of such dependence on a nominal Communist ally took hold after severe border clashes in the 1960's, and has persisted over the years, first as reformist leaders in Moscow relaxed Marxist-Leninist precepts and then with the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. 
Deals are taking place in the context of a radically changed energy industry. In the name of deregulation, China has swung from a heavily bureaucratic, centrally planned economy to one having remarkably little energy policy planning at all.
China abolished its energy ministry in 1993, after years of bureaucratic struggles that pitted it against the coal, electricity and oil-refining industries, which were each their own ministries as well. But with the conversion of many of these para-industries into state-controlled, for-profit companies late in 1998, the result has been a near-absence of coordination. 
Another result has been an emphasis on energy production instead of conservation. Chinese gasoline prices now rank with those in the United States as among the lowest in the world for oil-importing countries, and are a third of retail prices in Europe, where steep taxes push the price to $4 a gallon or more to discourage gasoline use. The National People's Congress, China's Parliament, has been discussing the imposition of steep gasoline taxes here for two years, but has taken no action. 
The State Development Planning Commission is now setting China's energy policy on everything from pipeline routes to liquefied natural gas contracts with foreign nations. But the commission's energy staff numbers fewer than 20 people, who are hard pressed to address all the issues before them, said Xavier Chen, the China program manager at the International Energy Administration; the government's Energy Research Institute employs several dozen more. By comparison, the United States Energy Department has 16,000 employees, of whom at least 400 are involved in some way in the policy-making process, and hundreds more administer regulations.
While China's three main state-controlled, but publicly traded, energy companies -- PetroChina, Sinopec and Cnooc -- are aggressively exploring in China itself, executives at multinational companies are skeptical that they will find a lot of oil, although the executives see some potential for additional gas discoveries. 
"In terms of oil exploration and development, it is fairly mature," said Tan Ek Kia, the Beijing-based chairman of Shell's subsidiaries in northeast Asia.

HEADLINE: Tarnish Anew From Race for Mayor 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Not long ago, the District of Columbia was in danger of losing its reputation as the un-Chicago: the city that does not work. To the surprise of locals and visitors, potholes were filled and budgets were balanced. When people talked about the city's drug problem, they were not referring to the mayor's crack pipe.
 Now, thanks to the 2002 mayoral campaign, Washington's reputation for ineptitude may again be secure. After Washingtonians go to the polls on Sept. 10, it could take a week to count the votes, because neither of the leading candidates had the foresight to get his name on the ballot. Penmanship will be crucial as election officials try to distinguish which write-in votes are for "Williams" and which are for "Willie" or "Wilson." 
 The two leading candidates are Anthony A. Williams, the technocratic mayor thrown off the ballot for submitting thousands of fake signatures on his petition, and Willie F. Wilson, a populist Baptist minister who has been the spiritual counselor of Marion S. Barry, the former mayor who served 16 years in office and six months in prison. (The prison term, for using drugs, was between Mr. Barry's third and fourth terms as mayor.) When Mr. Barry campaigned with Mr. Wilson last week, it was not clear whether the endorsement would help or hurt Mr. Wilson. 
Mr. Williams, who became known for his bow ties and strait-laced demeanor when he was Washington's chief financial officer under Mr. Barry in the 1990's, won the mayor's race after Mr. Barry decided not to seek re-election in 1998. Mr. Williams was widely credited for improving city services, and he eliminated the deficits that had prompted Congress to strip Mr. Barry of much power.
Mr. Williams's re-election seemed assured until the discovery of the fake signatures (many in the same handwriting and using the names of prominent nonresidents like Martha Stewart and Tony Blair). Though the latest poll shows Mr. Williams far ahead of Mr. Wilson, the mayor is campaigning aggressively. While he exhorts voters to "do the write thing," campaign workers are preparing to hand out pencils and inked rubber stamps on election day.
"By all rights Tony Williams should be steaming to victory almost by acclamation, and instead his fate rests on punctuation," said David Axelrod, a Democratic political consultant from Chicago who has worked on mayoral races around the country, including Mr. Williams's 1998 campaign.
"It's a stunning development," Mr. Axelrod said, "but the truth is, my experience, he was always more interested in governing than in the mechanics of politics. That's a strength as a mayor, but it's a weakness in this situation. Almost any mayor has a political infrastructure that deals with basic housekeeping issues like petition gathering. He's just never built it, and at this point he doesn't need me to tell him it was a mistake."
Why does not Washington, like Chicago, have a mayor who can deliver services as well as collect signatures? One obvious answer is that for most of its history it had no chance to develop a political machine anything like Chicago's. Until the city was granted home rule in the 1970's, members of Congress controlled power and dispensed patronage.
"Most people from the outside are appalled by what they hear about the District of Columbia politics," said Dorothy Brizill, the executive director of DCWatch, a watchdog group that helped expose the fraudulent signatures in Mr. Williams's petition. "But most of them don't realize that it wasn't until 1974 that we elected our own mayor and City Council. Politically, Washington is like a developing country. We have not developed a political culture or a system to nurture leaders. We have difficulty, quite frankly, making the government run."
Washington's version of a political machine took shape in the 1960's and 1970's, a time of street protests, riots and Great Society programs. Garbage collection was not high on the urban agenda. Community group leaders and advocates, most notably Mr. Barry, came to power and used federal dollars to expand the city government and provide their allies in churches and community groups with money for ambitious programs.
"The vision in the 1970's was to make Washington the black city on a hill, a place more egalitarian, more caring, more open to black cultural expression," said Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington and author of "The Future Once Happened Here," a study comparing urban politics in New York, Washington and Los Angeles that was published in 1997. "Marion Barry promoted those utopian visions even while he was running the city into the ground. Mayor Williams wants to make it a conventionally successful city instead of an expression of black liberation, and that's not acceptable to the followers of Barry who still believe in the city on the hill."
In the campaign, Mr. Williams has tried to rebut accusations that he is not "black enough" and that he favored white neighborhoods at the expense of Anacostia, the low-income and predominantly black neighborhood where Mr. Wilson's church is.
Although supporters of Mr. Williams produce statistics showing how much he has done for Anacostia, some concede that he has offended some residents there by seeming remote and high-handed. The way he shut down a public hospital infuriated many residents and has become one of Mr. Wilson's chief campaign issues.
Mr. Wilson, who decided to enter the race after Mr. Williams's name was taken off the ballot, is well known for political activism and for counseling Mr. Barry, one of the 7,000 members of his church. In his campaign, he has promised an ambitious array of social programs and adopted a slogan of "take a stand for all of Washington."
Mr. Wilson's critics accuse him of having been divisive in the past by allying himself with Louis Farrakhan and the leaders of a black nationalist school. One of his more quoted remarks was made in a boycott of a Chinese restaurant in 1987, when he told reporters that he was a forgiving man. "If we hadn't forgiven him," Mr. Wilson said, referring to the restaurant owner, "we would have cut his head off and rolled it down the street."
Mr. Williams led Mr. Wilson citywide by roughly a four-to-one ratio in a Washington Post poll published on Sunday, and Mr. Williams was ahead two to one even in Mr. Wilson's neighborhood. With many voters still undecided, the possibility of a relatively close and racially polarized outcome remains. That could complicate the next mayor's job.
Whatever the result, Dr. Siegel said, voters can console themselves with one enduring fact of Washington: there is only so much damage any mayor can do.
"Washington's economic future is largely assured no matter who wins," he said. "It's guaranteed by massive, endless subsidies from the federal government. Imagine how irresponsible politicians in New York could be if they didn't have to worry about Wall Street leaving. In Washington, they can indulge their fantasies because there's no accountability. No matter what the next mayor does, the federal government isn't going anywhere."

Wilson, campaigning for mayor of Washington last week, has promised an ambitious array of social programs. (Photographs by Susana Rabb for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Americas: Colombia: Exports Surge 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Colombian exports rose 3.3 percent in July on surging oil sales abroad, the government's statistics agency said. 
Total exports increased to $1.04 billion in July from $1.01 billion in the month last year, with the United States holding its position as the largest single recipient of Colombian goods as it bought more than 40 percent of the total. Sales of oil and its derivatives, the country's largest export, surged 18 percent to $272 million in the month. Coal, the second-biggest export, brought in $55.4 million, a drop of 21 percent from the same month last year. Coffee sales abroad fell 7.3 percent to $51.9 million.

HEADLINE: In Cuomo's Record as HUD Chief, Bold Steps and Missteps 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Late in 2000, as Andrew M. Cuomo neared the end of his tenure as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, he ordered the agency to print 30,000 copies of a report about his years in office. This was no spartan government printing. It ran 150 pages and included a narrated compact disc and 19 photographs of Mr. Cuomo alongside such notables as Shimon Peres of Israel and Sarah Jessica Parker of "Sex and the City." 
 For Mr. Cuomo, the report summed up his most important battles and brightest achievements at HUD, the bloated bureaucracy he claimed to have transformed from a picture of waste, fraud and abuse into a model of government service. 
 But for Mr. Cuomo's critics, the $688,000 report, released just weeks before the end of the Clinton administration, symbolized how Mr. Cuomo attempted to use HUD as a springboard for his campaign to be governor of New York, which started just nine days after leaving Washington. 
In the leadup to the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, Mr. Cuomo has focused on his work at HUD in practically every campaign speech and television commercial. Besides claiming to have reinvented HUD, he paints his administration as a golden age for housing.
"We took this big old government that nobody could make work and we transformed it," Mr. Cuomo said in a recent debate with H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and his opponent in the Democratic primary for governor. Mr. Cuomo boasted that during his administration HUD created more jobs, built more housing for the elderly, and fought harder against housing discrimination than anyone had done before. "I'm a can-do Democrat," he said, "and I believe we can do more and make Albany work better."
But there is another side to Mr. Cuomo's record at HUD, as even he acknowledged during the debate with Mr. McCall. Housing advocates say his initiatives were never free of political ambition. At times, that worked to the advantage of a particular program or issue, with Mr. Cuomo pushing hard and taking risks to achieve political goals. 
"I wouldn't want to see someone appointed secretary of HUD who wasn't ambitious," said John E. Taylor, president of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, an urban advocacy group that worked closely with HUD during the Cuomo years. "Massive problems require ambitious personalities."
But sometimes Mr. Cuomo's political drive was seen to work against the department's core mission of providing housing, with his introducing ambitious and well-publicized initiatives that later stalled.
"His goal was to improve the department because housing was the business he was in prior to coming to HUD," said Denise B. Muha, executive director of the National Leased Housing Association, which represents groups involved in federally assisted rental housing. "But his goal also was to run for office in New York. There was no one who didn't know that." 
Mr. Cuomo came to HUD as an assistant secretary in 1993, with a background in politics (working for his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo) and in housing. When he was in his 20's he built apartments for the homeless through a nonprofit group he founded, Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, or H.E.L.P. The group offered an approach to homelessness that combined housing with education, job training, help with substance abuse and mental health services. 
It was an approach that Mr. Cuomo later used to much praise at HUD.

A Department Evolves
 In 1997, he became HUD secretary, taking over a $30 billion department that top Republicans, and even Vice President Al Gore, considered expendable.
It helped that he served during a period of startling economic prosperity. Working with a mostly unfriendly Congress, he broke a logjam on reauthorization of thousands of rental housing subsidies, wrangled successively bigger budgets out of Congress, and pushed the department to become more aggressive on homelessness, tripling the amount of federal money to address the problem. 
Mr. Cuomo speaks of himself as having brought a different approach to government, and has boasted in his campaign of reorganizing HUD so successfully that the department was removed from the General Accounting Office's list of agencies considered "high-risk" because of management deficiencies.
That claim is only partially true. The accounting office did remove two HUD programs, development and community planning, from its watch list.
But two others -- single-family mortgage insurance and rental housing assistance -- remain on the list because of "significant weaknesses." And in January 2001, as Mr. Cuomo's tenure ended, the G.A.O. found that HUD still needed to shore up two important areas, human capital and financial management systems.
While his programs for the homeless were praised, other efforts were picked apart by angry community leaders and housing advocates, and the inspector general for HUD put out a stream of negative reports. 
One of the most controversial efforts was the 203k federal housing rehabilitation program, in which dishonest appraisers, real estate brokers and mortgage lenders acquired 500 buildings but never did the repairs and in some cases sold them to unsuspecting buyers, devastating parts of Brooklyn and Harlem. 

Kiosks and Controversies
 Some of the accomplishments Mr. Cuomo claims -- such as the reform of public housing -- involve programs that existed before he became secretary and cannot fairly be credited solely to him. 
But two programs -- HUD kiosks and the Officer Next Door program -- stand out as signature Cuomo initiatives, wholly conceived and executed during his tenure.
Though comparatively small in budget and modest in scope, they capture both the spirit and energy of the Cuomo years as well as their controversies and setbacks.
Tucked into an alcove in the Peter W. Rodino Federal Building on Broad Street in Newark, next to the automated teller machine and the Federal Express automated depot, is a machine resembling a large red jukebox. Anyone passing by could easily mistake it for another A.T.M.
During the Cuomo years, 106 of the boxes, called HUD kiosks, were placed in federal buildings and commercial spaces around the country. The on-screen information includes federally owned houses for sale and the location of nearby shelters for the homeless. Sixteen of the kiosks are inside HUD storefronts, which are in HUD buildings or commercial spaces.
The storefronts and kiosks were intended to serve as national models of more responsive government, a sharp reflection of Mr. Cuomo's attempt to reorganize the department, streamline its operations and generally make it more accountable to the needy people it is supposed to serve. 
"What Cuomo was arguing throughout his term was that as long as the public saw HUD as a failed agency, at best in league with the bad guys running buildings that were running the community down, you couldn't expect people to work with HUD to improve neighborhoods," said William C. Apgar, a senior scholar at the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University who was assistant secretary of HUD under Mr. Cuomo. "The kiosks helped cast HUD in a different light." 
But when the office of the inspector general for HUD audited the $8.5 million storefront and kiosk program in March 2000, it concluded that the effort was poorly thought out, used infrequently by the public and largely a waste of taxpayer money. HUD has little if any measurable evidence that the expenditures for storefront and kiosk operations have benefited HUD customers, the audit concluded. 
Many specialists working at street level in the cities, where housing can be a life-and-death issue, scorned the kiosks. "The whole thing was kind of insane," said Ira J. Rheingold, executive director of the National Association of Consumer Advocates. He said he worked across the street from a kiosk in Chicago for five years and never saw it used.
"It just shows the disconnect between Washington and what goes on in the real world," he said. 
Jonathan J. Cowan, Mr. Cuomo's former chief of staff at HUD, said the kiosks won awards for innovation in government because of the way they enhanced public access to government. He said the inspector general's audit was politically motivated, as were audits of other HUD programs during Mr. Cuomo's tenure. 
To further improve access to the public, HUD storefronts were staffed by a new cadre of housing professionals called community builders, who were supposed to reach out to the needy.
But the builders, some from within HUD and others from outside, were widely seen as little more than advance political troops for Mr. Cuomo.
"It was not a worthwhile endeavor or a productive program," said Timothy G. Kaiser, executive director of the Public Housing Authorities Directors Association, who was a member of the advisory board of the community builders program. 
The inspector general's office criticized the community builder program and recommended that it be scrapped. Earlier this year, Mr. Cuomo's successor at HUD, Mel Martinez, eliminated the entire program.
Mr. Martinez is also weighing whether to shut down the storefronts and kiosks. Like the kiosks, the Officer Next Door program showed how Mr. Cuomo used his housing experience. It also showed how good ideas can trip over the reality of housing.
Under the program, law enforcement officers qualified for a 50 percent reduction in the price of a Federal Housing Administration loan-foreclosed property. In exchange, the officer agreed to live in the house for three years, stabilizing distressed neighborhoods. It typified Mr. Cuomo's approach to building communities, not just houses. 
"The theory was good," said Peter Dreier, a professor of urban policy at Occidental College and former director of housing for the City of Boston, "but it was hard to avoid scandals."
From the outset, some police officers used the government subsidy to buy properties in what were supposed to be distressed areas but were not. Some purchased multifamily buildings and rented out all the apartments, living elsewhere in violation of their contracts. 
In June 2001, the inspector general's office found serious abuses in 23 of 108 audited transactions, and indications that as many as one in four participants had violated the rules. By the time the program was shut down for several months in 2001, a nationwide investigation had found about 200 instances of abuse. Two dozen officers were indicted on charges of cheating the government. 
Mr. Cowan, Mr. Cuomo's former chief of staff, said the number of abuses was small when compared with the 3,800 homes sold to officers up to that time. "It's a big testament that the program is still around," he said. 
Since the program was reinitiated, an additional 2,200 properties have been sold to officers without any abuses being reported. But officials in the four cities audited in 2001 -- Miami, Memphis, Springfield, Mass., and Manassas, Va. -- say their police have stopped participating. In Memphis, city officials have set up their own program using municipal funds. 
"We decided to change the focus because it was somewhat tainted," said Robert Lipscomb, director of the Memphis Housing Authority, which administers the local program. "It is a very sound concept, but we didn't have good enough controls in place."

Policy and P.R.
 That same statement can be made of other Cuomo initiatives, housing experts say. From the effort to pay cash for guns turned in to public housing authorities, to the threat to use the authorities to sue gun manufacturers, some of his ideas made better public relations than housing policy. 
Throughout Mr. Cuomo's tenure, press releases streamed out of his office. He also traveled so extensively that Kit Bond, a Republican senator from Missouri who was a frequent critic, kept track of the secretary's itinerary.
And the glossy reports kept coming. The last one was completed in early 2001 and distributed days before Mr. Cuomo left office.
This time, Republicans complained so loudly that distribution was halted and the remaining reports were carted off to HUD's basement. A department spokesman says they are being recycled with other HUD documents.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Andrew M. Cuomo, at work on a Habitat for Humanity home in 1997, has made his HUD tenure a cornerstone of his campaign for governor. (Associated Press)(pg. B5); Andrew M. Cuomo has claimed credit for transforming HUD. (Associated Press)(pg. B1)

HEADLINE: World Briefing Haiti: Criticism From Rights Panel 

BYLINE:  By David Gonzalez

 BODY:
 The government has failed to stop the country's slide into lawlessness and social turmoil, a report by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has concluded. 
The commission, part of the Organzation of American States, said courts were influenced by the government and armed gangs broke the law with impunity and likened the economic, health and social problems to serious rights violations. Foreign donors have suspended direct aid to the government until it resolves an electoral dispute. The Organization of American States, under pressure from Caribbean nations alarmed by Haiti's unrelenting poverty, is expected this week to consider a resolution that would unblock the aid. David Gonzalez (NYT)

HEADLINE: Who'd Want to Govern New York State? 

BYLINE:  By Gerald Benjamin; Gerald Benjamin is the dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the State University of New York at New Paltz.

DATELINE: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. 

 BODY:
With one week left before the Democratic primary for governor, Carl McCall and Andrew Cuomo are vying to govern a state that may face the biggest fiscal crisis in its history. The pesky potential of third-party candidacies notwithstanding, New York's incumbent Republican governor, George Pataki, remains far ahead in opinion polls. His leadership after the attack on New York City a year ago, though not unflawed, created a measure of good will in the state's Democratic heartland. Mr. Pataki's "Southern strategy" -- a focus on the city and especially on its growing cadre of Hispanic voters -- is classic for an incumbent Republican and promises major electoral dividends. Equally important, the governor has plenty of money left to spend to bring his message home.
 Both Mr. McCall's candidacy and Mr. Cuomo's follow established patterns in New York politics. Like Malcolm Wilson, Hugh Carey and Mario Cuomo before him, Carl McCall is reaching for the top after a long career in elective office. He is relinquishing the office of comptroller, one of the most financially powerful elected state offices in the country, to seek the governorship. 
 Andrew Cuomo, like Averell Harriman, Nelson Rockefeller and Lewis Lehrman before him, is offering himself as leader of the out-of-power party without having held elective office. They were rich. He is famous: the son of a former governor, he was a member of Bill Clinton's cabinet and married a Kennedy. 
A race against an incumbent is always risky, but this Democratic contest has from the beginning been driven by reasons of personal timing rather than a pressing agenda that would captivate voters.
Mr. McCall is in his mid-60's; his run this year seems a now-or-never matter. Mr. Cuomo, a much younger man, might have waited. But there is no benefit to waiting if you want to be governor in New York. The state has no term limit for the chief executive (as do 39 others) and thus no guarantee of a shot at an open seat at a predictable date. And incumbent New York governors do stay on longer.
Thomas Dewey and Mario Cuomo served three four-year terms, Nelson Rockefeller three and part of a fourth term. There have been only two races since World War II in which there was no incumbent on the gubernatorial ballot. One of these was in 1982, although campaigns were launched well before the candidates learned that the sitting governor, Hugh Carey, would not run. Mario Cuomo was elected; Andrew Cuomo ran the campaign.
Unlike many other states, there are few other statewide elected offices in New York to use as a perch to wait out an incumbent governor. Besides, incumbents in those offices also tend to serve multiple terms. 
Incumbent Republican governor notwithstanding, the political numbers in New York offer plenty of encouragement to Democratic gubernatorial hopefuls. There are more than two million more Democrats than Republicans enrolled in the state. It was an anti-Cuomo vote that first elected George Pataki governor. Even then, the total vote on the Democratic line in 1994 exceeded that on the Republican; Mr. Pataki's third-party endorsements carried him in.
The challenge for Democrats is to expand the electorate and get their potential vote to the polls. It is no accident that the state constitution, written by Republicans, requires that governors in New York be elected in non-presidential years. Turning out voters is much harder without the stimulus of a presidential election. It's tough even in these uncertain economic times, with a massive fiscal crisis looming that may be as bad or worse for the state and New York City than that in 1975. Here, in time honored New York fashion, Democrats are complicit. Members of the Democratic Assembly have joined with the governor and the Republican Senate to paper over the crisis until all are safely reelected.
The fiscal mess we face ought to be the theme of this election. But it's hard to win an election by talking up and planning for a fiscal crisis; you don't gain friends by proposing less spending or more taxes.
Neither Mr. Cuomo nor Mr. McCall has found a mobilizing theme with this or any other issue. Instead, Mr. Cuomo runs as an outsider and a reformer. But a Cuomo married to a Kennedy is not credible as an outsider, and serious reform of state government seems an impossible dream -- even if Mr. Cuomo talks about it passionately. Mr. McCall, part of whose job as comptroller has been to serve as in-house critic of state government, has a record of proposing fiscal and budgetary reforms. But he has found little response from voters on this subject, and has focused on primarily on education -- everybody's issue.
There is one theme in this election that has nothing to do with issues, and that is the question of race and ethnicity. Andrew Cuomo's campaign seems to have little ethnic appeal. Perhaps this is because he can achieve no "first"; his father has already been there. On the other hand, if Carl McCall wins in the primary he will be the first major-party African-American nominee for governor of New York, offering New Yorkers a chance to make history. For that reason alone, his nomination is likely to increase turnout among black voters. Though the primary race seems oddly quixotic, it still holds a compelling logic for each candidate. Given the fiscal crisis New York faces, the general election is likely to produce the captain of a sinking ship.

HEADLINE: In Colorado Race, 2002 Looks a Lot Like 1996 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Aug. 30 

 BODY:
To highlight his support for environmental protections, Tom Strickland recently took his campaign as Democratic challenger for the Senate to the top of Gray's Peak, one of the highest mountains in Colorado.
 But reaching the summit, Mr. Strickland found that others had beaten him to it. Waiting were a half-dozen giggling supporters of the Republican incumbent, Senator Wayne Allard, with their own campaign signs. 
 It was a rare moment of amusement in an otherwise nasty rematch of 1996, when Mr. Allard won an open seat by five percentage points. More often this year, the tone has been set by weeks of television attack commercials that link one or the other candidate to corporate scandals rocking the national economy.
For now, more than two months before the election, it remains uncertain whether Colorado voters are much interested in who might have done what. Both camps insist that the issue is Exhibit A for why the opponent should not be elected, and the two candidates continue to hammer away at each other for real or perceived acts of irresponsibility.
Yet for Democrats, who are trying to tie Republicans to corporate shenanigans in campaigns all across the country in a year in which a single seat determines control of the Senate, the strategy in Colorado has worked about as well as Mr. Strickland's climbing expedition.
Recent independent statewide polls have shown Mr. Allard holding a modest but steady lead, with the only good news for Mr. Strickland being that Mr. Allard's support remains under 50 percent with about a fifth of respondents undecided. About 36 percent of Colorado voters are registered as Republican and 30 percent as Democrats; 34 percent are unaffiliated. 
"I don't think Strickland can survive if he is not within eight points, at four or five, right after Labor Day," said Floyd Ciruli, whose firm conducted a poll in mid-July that showed Mr. Allard leading Mr. Strickland by 46 percent to 37 percent, with negligible support for third-party party candidates. "Unless he can close, it's going to be tougher for him to get money in a year money is tight."
A poll conducted two weeks ago by The Rocky Mountain News had Mr. Allard in front by 42 percent to 34 percent.
On the stump, Mr. Allard, 58, speaks proudly of his annual visits to all 64 Colorado counties, his humble roots as a veterinarian and state lawmaker and his efforts in the Senate to improve the quality of life in Colorado through support for land preservation and environmental cleanups. Never mind that he voted for oil exploration in Alaska. He calls himself a more experienced candidate than he was in 1996, as he said in an interview this week, and "a more electable-type person" than Mr. Strickland. 
Mr. Strickland, 50, favors broader access to health care, higher tax deductions for college tuition and more vigorous prosecution of white-collar crime. He said he had a better financed campaign than he had six years ago and positions that were more in sync with mainstream Coloradans than those of Mr. Allard. 
Yet true to the tenor of recent television advertisements, each man is just as eager to blast the other as unsuitable for the Senate because of ties to big telecommunications companies under criminal investigation -- Mr. Allard to Qwest, Mr. Strickland to Global Crossing. 
The barrage began with a mid-summer commercial in which Mr. Allard took credit for strong opposition in the Senate to corporate wrongdoing. The Strickland camp quickly objected, saying Mr. Allard had been lax on the matter and only mentioned it in the heat of a tight race and growing public disgust with misbehaving executives.
Mr. Strickland criticized Mr. Allard for joining a dozen other senators in asking the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2000 to delay stricter accounting standards that might have reduced the financial damage at companies like Enron. Mr. Strickland called the request "a complete betrayal of public trust."
He also accused Mr. Allard of promoting a merger in 1999 of US West of Denver and Qwest, also of Denver, rather than with Global Crossing, which is based in Bermuda. Over the years, Qwest has been one of Mr. Allard's largest campaign contributors.
But Mr. Allard has found Mr. Strickland an easy target for response. In commercials and interviews, he has characterized Mr. Strickland as a "multimillionaire-lawyer-lobbyist" who lobbied for Global Crossing and made $25,000 through a Global Crossing stock offer a day before the offer was made public.
He also blames Mr. Strickland for the dark tone of the race, saying, "It has gone negative very early, and I'm not happy about that."
Both candidates have offered plausible explanations for every accusation, and the explanations, too, have endured attacks from the other side.
By November, however, the outcome of the election could depend less on arguments of economic stewardship than on voter registration and turnout, even in a state hard hit by the sagging economy through layoffs and loss of savings.
Among the major races in Colorado this year, five of the seven House seats are considered safe, and Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican, has a huge lead over his Democratic challenger, Rollie Heath.
E. Scott Adler, a professor of political science at the University of Colorado, said that whichever party could generate more interest in the two competitive House races, the Fourth Congressional District and the new Seventh, could provide a strong boost for its Senate candidate.
"Because of the voter registration, it's really going to be tough on Strickland," Mr. Adler said. "He's the one who really needs the turnout. To me, that makes him a real long shot, and for Democrats, that's a pity. Allard this year was beatable."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tom Strickland, left, is trying to persuade Colorado voters that he should replace Senator Wayne Allard, a Republican. Mr. Strickland, a Democrat, lost to Mr. Allard by five percentage points in a bitter race in 1996. (Photographs by Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Compromise Brings Accord on Renewable Energy Closer 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
The first of 100 world leaders who are to address the environmental summit meeting here issued strong criticism today of rich polluting nations -- the United States chief among them -- for refusing to ratify a treaty intended to prevent the devastating effects of climate change.
 But despite the pointed remarks from the leaders of France, Britain and other nations about the treaty, known as the Kyoto Protocol, American officials succeeded tonight in winning an important concession. 
 A plan for converting world energy production from fossil fuels to solar and wind power and other renewable energy sources no longer contains a commitment to ensuring that such sources account for 15 percent of world energy output by 2010.
Officials said delegates were close to final agreement on the plan, now that the provision has been dropped. 
Yvon Slingenberg, a senior member of the European Union's delegation, expressed disappointment that the United States and other countries had refused to embrace the targets for renewable energy.
"We would have preferred to have a target and we would have preferred to have a timeline," Ms. Slingenberg said. "This was not possible. We tried until the very end. At a certain stage there is a point of exhaustion."
Environmentalists, too, were critical, saying the United States, which has opposed targets and timetables, had repeatedly watered down the text. "It's a shameful abrogation by governments who should be delivering on protection of climate, on protection of air quality," said Kate Hampton, international coordinator of Friends of the Earth, an advocacy group.
The United States says it prefers concrete action to target dates that might ultimately prove meaningless. In getting the time frame eliminated, it found allies in developing countries, as well as Japan and Australia.
Paula Dobriansky, under secretary of state for global affairs, defended the Bush administration's position, saying, "The document clearly highlights the need to increase access to modern energy services and signals the valuable role renewable energy will play in the future."
During the course of the meeting, the administration has acceded to other proposals, agreeing for example on efforts to halve the number of people without sanitation by 2015 and to reduce the loss of endangered plants and animals by 2010. 
But the concessions have not quieted the discontent among America's allies, who argue that as the world's most powerful nation, the United States should do more to protect the environment. "Our house is burning down and we're blind to it," President Jacques Chirac of France said in his speech here today. "The earth and humankind are in danger, and we're all responsible. It's time to open our eyes."
"Climate warming is still reversible," Mr. Chirac asserted. "Heavy would be the responsibility of those who refused to fight it."
In his speech, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said leaders could not afford to allow poverty and environmental degradation to continue unchecked. "Kyoto is right; it should be ratified by all of us," he said. "The consequences of inaction on these issues are not unknown. They are calculable. Poverty and environmental degradation, if unchecked, spell catastrophe for our world. That is clear."
In speechmaking today, several leaders took the opportunity to weigh in on their own specific issues concerning the environment, politics and one another.
President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela called for the creation of a global fund to ease poverty. President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda urged rich countries to open their markets to products from poor countries.
Mr. Chirac called for an international solidarity tax on items like airline tickets and health products that would create a pool of money to help developing nations.
And President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe received rousing applause from his fellow heads of state when he told Mr. Blair to stop interfering with his land redistribution program.
Mr. Mugabe, saying sustainable development was not possible without land reform, said: "Blair, keep your England. Let me keep my Zimbabwe."
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who is representing the United States in the absence of President Bush, will take his five minutes at the podium on Wednesday, officials say.
American officials dismissed the criticisms made today, saying most delegations had responded positively to American contributions to the summit meeting's action plan.
John F. Turner, assistant secretary of state for oceans and international environmental and scientific affairs, said he was pleased with the commitments that had been made. He pointed to agreements on sanitation, improved governance and a deal to restore depleted fisheries, where possible, by 2015.
As for global warming, Mr. Turner reiterated Washington's position. Mr. Bush asserted in rejecting the Kyoto treaty that it was unfair that the accord did not bind developing nations, especially China and India, that are also major emitters of gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.
"We're strong supporters of the compromise on climate change," Mr. Turner said. "We have our sovereign choice to pursue another path." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, left, and President Jacques Chirac of France at a news conference during the world summit conference on sustainable development in Johannesburg. Both criticized the United States for refusing to ratify the Kyoto treaty on global climate change. (Joao Silva for The New York Times); President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe listening to a speech at the meeting. When his turn to speak came, he defended his land policy. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: A Bit Ambiguously, Russia Backs Iraq Over U.S. Threat 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
The Iraqi foreign minister, Naji Sabri alHadithi, stopped here briefly today, seeking renewed support from a generally sympathetic Kremlin against the threat of an American effort to remove Saddam Hussein from power. He got it, but not as unambiguously as he might have liked. 
 After meeting with Mr. Sabri al-Hadithi, the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, at a news conference with the Iraqi, repeated the Kremlin's position that military action against Iraq "would seriously undermine the already difficult situation in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East" and make prospects for a permanent settlement of the region's problems even more remote. 
 Mr. Ivanov also said Russia hoped the United Nations Security Council would not be asked to approve military action against Iraq, "so there will be no need for a Russian veto." 
"We are closely analyzing statements made by Washington to the effect that there is no alternative to a military solution," Mr. Ivanov said. "We have not found a single solid argument in those statements to the effect that Iraq poses a threat to U.S. national security. These statements are political." 
Mr. Ivanov's other statements today were slightly more circumspect. In a speech at the Moscow State Institute of Foreign Relations earlier today, he endorsed the notion of taking "pre-emptive measures" against global problems, including international terrorism, but only through the United Nations or other alliances. 
He said countering terrorism had become the central problem since Sept. 11. President Bush has couched his campaign for the removal of President Hussein as a pre-emptive strike against a regime building weapons of mass destruction. 
Mr. Ivanov also applauded statements today by Iraq's deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, indicating that readmitting United Nations weapons inspectors to Iraq was "still under consideration." Mr. Aziz, in Johannesburg for the world summit meeting on the environment, said he hoped to meet Secretary General Kofi Annan to discuss options for ending the crisis. 
There was little else in Mr. Ivanov's remarks today to suggest that Russia's longstanding view of the Iraqi situation has changed. 
Russia has sought for years to bring about a political solution to the standoff between Iraq and the United States, mostly with proposals under which weapons inspectors might return to Iraq after a four-year absence. In return, the United Nations would eventually end economic sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. 
But Iraq so far has rejected all Russian overtures. While Russia has steadily opposed American military action to end the stalemate, it has insisted that Mr. Hussein readmit arms inspectors and meet other conditions the United Nations has imposed for lifting the sanctions. 
In his remarks today, Mr. Ivanov did not disavow reports that Russian officials in Washington have met with Iraqi opposition leaders who are bent on deposing Mr. Hussein, though both he and Mr. Sabri al-Hadithi took pains to dismiss the importance of those meetings. 
"That was an ordinary event which, we think, was artifically blown out of all proportion by certain mass media," Mr. Ivanov said. "As every diplomat knows, one has to maintain contacts with the other party in order to have broad and objective information. But this in no way indicates any adjustment of Russia's policy line on Iraqi settlement." 
Mr. Sabri al-Hadithi called the exiled Iraqi opposition leaders tools of American and British intelligence and said the meeting had no impact on Iraq's relations with Russia. 
In fact, while Russia is opposed in principle to unilateral action against Iraq, politicians here have openly suggested that Russia's stake is economic, and that it has little interest in preserving Mr. Hussein's rule if he can be removed in an internationally acceptable manner. 
There was no indication today that Russia and Iraq were on the verge of a new trade agreement. Iraqi officials had suggested that their country was on the verge of signing a deal to purchase $40 billion or more in Russian goods over the next decade, a figure Russia's Foreign Ministry quickly disavowed. 
Russian officials have said they are working on a "framework accord" for expanding trade, but only within the confines of existing United Nations sanctions.
