HEADLINE: Passing The Buck 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Somewhere I read about a conference on optimal economic planning, some years before the fall of Communism. The Soviet delegate declared that his planning agency always did the best it could under the circumstances. Hence, Soviet planning was always optimal.
 The man from Gosplan would have gotten along fine with Alan Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan disclaims any responsibility for the immense market bubble that inflated on his watch: his policy was right, he says, because he did the best he could. 
 In his keynote speech at last week's Jackson Hole conference, Mr. Greenspan offered two excuses. First, he claimed that it wasn't absolutely clear, even during the manic market run-up of 1999, that something was amiss: "it was very difficult to definitively identify a bubble until after the fact -- that is, when its bursting confirmed its existence." Second, he claimed that the Fed couldn't have done anything anyway. "Is there some policy that can at least limit the size of a bubble and, hence, its destructive fallout? . . . the answer appears to be no."
I wasn't alone in finding this speech disturbingly evasive. As The Financial Times noted, policy makers always have to act on limited information: "The burden of proof for a central bank should not be absolute certainty." The editorial also reminded readers that while Mr. Greenspan may now portray himself as skeptical but powerless during the bubble years, at the time many saw him as a cheerleader. "The Fed chairman . . . may well have contributed to the explosion of exuberance in the late 1990's with his increasingly bullish observations."
Moreover, there is evidence that Mr. Greenspan actually knew better. In September 1996, at a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, he told his colleagues, "I recognize that there is a stock market bubble problem at this point." And he had a solution: "We do have the possibility of . . . increasing margin requirements. I guarantee that if you want to get rid of the bubble, whatever it is, that will do it." 
Yet he never did increase margin requirements, that is, require investors to put up more cash when buying stocks. Indeed, aside from giving one speech about irrational exuberance, followed by a small rise in the Fed funds rate, Mr. Greenspan did nothing at all. He now says he could not have done more, but how does he know when he never even tried? What really happened, one suspects, was that in early 1997 Mr. Greenspan discovered that his tentative efforts to deflate the emerging bubble made investors furious, and lost his nerve. 
Worse, he then began giving ever more euphoric speeches about the wonders of the new economy. Surely he must have known that these speeches were interpreted by investors as a retraction of his own previous warning, as a signal that soaring stock prices were justified after all.
Still, what's most important about Mr. Greenspan's defensiveness is not what it says about the past, but what it implies about the future.
You see, Mr. Greenspan is the only economic policy maker we have. Fiscal policy is effectively off the table, partly because of long-run deficits worsened by Mr. Greenspan's own bad advice. Funny how he wasn't sure that Nasdaq 5,000 was a bubble, but believed that 10-year surplus projections were reliable enough to justify a huge tax cut. In any case, serious fiscal action is ruled out by the Bush administration's relentless opportunism; every proposal for short-run economic stimulus turns into an attempt to lock in permanent tax cuts for corporations and the wealthy. So if the recovery continues to lose momentum, it's up to the Fed to take matters in hand.
Yet Mr. Greenspan's remarks reinforce a worry I've had for the past few months: that Fed officials will respond to continuing economic weakness not with action but with excuses. 
We've seen the process all too clearly in Japan. First officials at the Bank of Japan denied that they had any responsibility to fight economic stagnation; their mandate, they said, was solely to ensure price stability. Then, as inflation gave way to deflation, even price stability was no longer their business. In other words, rather than risk trying to solve Japan's problems and failing, the bank has repeatedly redefined its mission so that it doesn't even have to try. 
I never thought the Fed would go down the same path. But after listening to Mr. Greenspan explain why he couldn'ta and shouldn'ta, I'm starting to wonder.

HEADLINE: America's Failed Frontier 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

DATELINE: TAYLOR, Neb. 

 BODY:
It's time for us to acknowledge one of America's greatest mistakes, a 140-year-old scheme that has failed at a cost of trillions of dollars, countless lives and immeasurable heartbreak: the settlement of the Great Plains. 
 The plains, which have overtaken places like Appalachia to become by far the poorest part of the country, represent a monumental failure in American history. To understand more I came here to Loup County, officially the poorest county in the United States, with a per capita income of $6,600 (New York County, or Manhattan, is the nation's richest, at $90,900). 
 In fairness, Loup doesn't look poor, and it's so rich in warmth, community spirit and old-fashioned friendliness that it's just about impossible for a stranger to pay for a meal here. The tiny school, the only one in the county, has student lockers with no locks; and outside, students' cars are not only unlocked, but the keys are left in the ignition. 
Yet Stewart Switzer, a 17-year-old senior, says that if he could go back in a time capsule and talk to his great-great-grandpa when he was settling here a century ago, his message would be: Don't stop here. Keep on going.
It might have been sage advice. Loup County's population peaked at 2,188 in 1910, but now it's down to 600. It lost its only grocery store in August, and with people fleeing, an average house in Taylor, the county seat (population 180), goes for just $6,000. 
As my colleague Timothy Egan noted in a brilliant article about the Great Plains in The Times last year, more than 60 percent of the counties in the region lost population in the last decade. In North Dakota, 47 of 53 counties lost population, and at this rate it'll eventually have to merge again with South Dakota to create a single state of Dakota.
This vast region in the middle of America, more than five times the size of California, now meets the 19th-century definition of frontier, with six or fewer people per square mile. Instead of the frontier closing, as Frederick Jackson Turner declared a century ago, it is expanding, and we may look back on large-scale settlement of the Plains as a fluke, a temporary domination now receding again.
The aridity of the Great Plains is partly to blame for the failed land development here, but fault also lies in the vapidity of American farm programs -- which President Bush and Congress are now expanding. It was, after all, a web of subsidies and government land promotion schemes that lured people to the Great Plains in the first place. 
President Bush signed a $180 billion farm bill this year, with the backing of many Democrats as well as Republicans, after a gutless surrender to lobbyists for wealthy farmers. But the program will actually aggravate rural distress.
Subsidies do nothing to help hard-working ranchers here, because the money overwhelmingly goes to crop farmers rather than livestock owners. Worse, much of the money goes to the most prosperous families (47 percent of commodity payments go to farmers whose household income is more than $135,000), who use the cash to buy up more land. Subsidies thus accelerate the consolidation of farms that is already depopulating rural areas.
Tom McNeil, a genial 66-year-old cowboy, has a sprawling 5,000-acre ranch that a few generations ago would have supported many homesteading families. But now, with just a horse and a pickup -- and even after two heart bypasses and a heart transplant -- the tireless Mr. McNeil ranches the land singlehanded.
I thought that was something, and then he took me to a next-door neighbor (six miles away) who pretty much on his own ranches 12,000 acres. 
Farm policy's focus needs to shift to rural business development, to help people find new sources of income. For example, a fourth-generation cattle ranching family here hopes to survive on its land by opening a cozy lodge so that tourists can come to hunt, fish or help with the branding (www.calamusoutfitters.com). 
President Bush's support for agricultural welfare (with considerable Democratic backing) contradicts every value he stands for and reflects a complete capitulation to a calculus of vote-buying. America's rural policy today is about where Soviet industry was in the 1980's: the leadership knows that its policies have utterly failed but lacks the courage to reform them.

HEADLINE: White House Memo; 
A Silence That Coolidge Would Envy

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: NEVILLE ISLAND, Pa., Sept 2 

 BODY:
President Bush is well practiced at strategic reticence: his normal affability and Texas backslapping can be flipped off instantly when he is not in the mood to answer questions, or when he senses that unscripted comments could make a politically uncomfortable moment even worse.
 But as the summer has drawn to a close, Mr. Bush has nurtured silences that even Calvin Coolidge would envy. Ensconced on his ranch last week, he kept reporters at bay and let Vice President Dick Cheney do all the talking about the administration's thinking on Iraq. When he emerged for obligatory events, like campaign appearances last week in Oklahoma and Arkansas or today's talk here at a Labor Day picnic with the carpenter's union (a favorite because last year it split with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a Democratic ally), Mr. Bush has stuck closely to last spring's well-worn scripts about chasing down Al Qaeda and getting Congress to pass his energy and domestic security bills. 
 So what are his thoughts about the national security advisers from his father's administration who have taken to the airwaves and op-ed pages, suggesting that he may be making a huge mistake by careening toward a confrontation with Iraq without the support of allies or Arab nations? Mr. Bush has avoided the question, and the inevitable follow-ups about whether his Republican critics are speaking for his father or Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. (The critics deny it.)
How about the estimates last week that federal deficits are likely to deepen throughout the Bush presidency? The president who a few months ago confidently predicted that deficits would be shallow and brief has not talked about it.
The sharp rebukes delivered by federal courts over how the administration has dealt with deportation hearings and Americans caught up in the terrorism roundups? The president, a spokesman said in Texas, has not voiced an opinion.
White House aides say there is nothing unusual going on: like most other vacationing Americans, Mr. Bush was trying desperately to eke out a few last moments of relaxation, a difficult enough task for a man who starts each morning with the C.I.A. and F.B.I.'s threat assessments.
But as a confidant of the president said the other day, "this hasn't been the most pleasant summer" on the ranch. Mr. Bush, his friend said, "doesn't sound like a man eager" to get back to what promises to be a tough fall, what with wrangling with the Senate, a frenetic campaign schedule for the midterm elections and continuing arguments with the allies on issues like the environment and Iraq.
Presidential moods are difficult to measure from a distance, of course, and reporters always whine that they hear too little from the presidential lips. Officially, the White House says Mr. Bush "looks forward to getting back to business." 
But there is no question this has been a summer of mounting discontents. Like the economy, the battle against terrorism Mr. Bush talked about today seems to be moving sideways. While he appeared relaxed as he shook hands today at the invitation-only picnic outside Pittsburgh, the easy laugh Mr. Bush displayed a year ago this week at an off-the-record barbecue with reporters has not been heard by the press corps for some time.
Mr. Bush declined to hold a similar event this year, perhaps wisely, choosing to entertain volunteers and locals instead. Nor did he show up at the Coffee Station, his town's meeting place, which features prominently in his speeches as a place where he stays in touch with real America. He has stayed far from reporters in his last public appearances.
Perhaps Mr. Bush does not want to let on about his thoughts until Sept. 11, when he is will lead the day of national reflection and commemoration. Perhaps he is thinking about all the wrangling ahead with a Democratic Senate that is blocking major elements of his agenda.
But some of his aides concede that something else is at work. All the questioning of his Iraq policy -- by his father's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, the man who saved the Florida recount for Mr. Bush -- has stung.
"First, this is a president who doesn't like policy issues and fissures in his own team being aired in public," a senior official said over the weekend.
The most withering assessment came just as Mr. Bush was corralling the presidential dogs, Spot and Barney, to make the trip back to Washington. (Barney seemed particularly reluctant to leave his Texas freedoms and had to be carried aboard Air Force One.)
As they flew back, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a lifelong Republican and for a time the elder Mr. Bush's secretary of state, was on the NBC program "Meet the Press" suggesting that the Bush team's problems might be explained by inexperience, and asking why Mr. Cheney had not backed up his accusations that Iraq was on the verge of obtaining nuclear weapons. 
"If we are so clear in our own minds that this is a real danger, why can't we convince our NATO allies of that fact?" Mr. Eagleburger asked. He added, "There is a disconnect here, and I don't understand it."
One of the mysteries of the last week of August is why Mr. Cheney was doing all the talking on the tough issues, while Mr. Bush avoided any mention of Iraq. Instead, the president stuck to a standard menu of education reform, the need for energy and domestic security legislation, and a vow to go after any executives who are "cooking the books."
One theory was that Mr. Cheney was testing the international waters. Mr. Bush has learned the advantages of keeping his options open until the last moment, and it is easier to call back a vice president's lines than it is to call back a president's.
Another theory, denied by the White House, was that Mr. Cheney was subtly pushing his boss. The vice president's position that going through the United Nations for further inspections of suspected weapons sites is a dangerous waste of time seemed to contrast with General Powell's public insistence that the United States needs to do so to build an international consensus. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, who said reporters were making "much ado about no difference," added that "Iraq changes positions on whether they'll let the inspectors back in more often that Saddam Hussein changes bunkers."
And would Mr. Bush break out of his own bunker and perhaps have a news conference upon his return to Washington? "Point noted," Mr. Fleischer said. "Nothing is planned. We'll let you know."

HEADLINE: Policy Makers Hone Debate: When to Hold, When to Fold 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Sept. 1 

 BODY:
If the central bankers, government officials and economists who gathered here this weekend for the Federal Reserve's annual retreat agreed on anything, it was that policy has little success when used to fine tune the economy.
 Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, took the notion of policy impotence a step further, asserting that there was nothing the central bank could reasonably do to avert or deflate a stock market bubble. 
 Yet the policy makers here also seemed to have an uneasy feeling that they will increasingly be called upon to deal with complex domestic and international issues that will demand activist, imaginative steps on their part. In a crisis, they concluded, their reluctance to put even their limited powers to work will be swept away by an imperative to use monetary and fiscal policy more aggressively than ever. 
The dissonance between action and inaction reflected a collision of two developments over the years.
One is the growing, though still much-debated, thought that interest rate policy is best focused on fighting inflation rather than on stimulating economic growth. A close corollary is that government tax and spending policy is too tangled up in politics to be timely and effective in dealing with an economy's cyclical ups and downs.
The other development is the experience of Japan. Neither fiscal nor monetary policy has succeeded in bringing Japan's economy, the world's second largest, out of its decade-long slump, and yet the need for new policy initiatives to prevent a complete meltdown is growing more urgent. The possibility that the United States, like Japan, could be at risk of a deflationary spiral that defies traditional policy remedies was assumed, if largely left unspoken, here.
The questions over fiscal policy were captured in a discussion over a paper presented by Alan J. Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley.
Mr. Auerbach's main conclusion was that discretionary fiscal policy -- meaning political choices over taxes and spending -- "has effects, but leaves us with little evidence that these effects have provided a significant contribution to economic stabilization, if they have in fact worked in the right direction at all."
In other words, attempts by governments to address economic weakness have not proved to be a good way of smoothing out the business cycle.
Martin Feldstein, a Harvard professor who is the president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, agreed with Mr. Auerbach's findings, saying they confirmed what has become conventional wisdom among many economists. But Mr. Feldstein told the conference that there should be an exception: when a country faces a deflationary spiral of the sort dogging Japan.
In such a case, Mr. Feldstein said, governments should use fiscal policy in a way that increases incentives for consumers to spend and businesses to invest without increasing the government's budget deficit. In Japan's case, he prescribed a plan in which the government would gradually increase, for several years, the value added tax applied to all goods and services and simultaneously reduce income tax rates. Such a plan would encourage consumers to buy now before the price went up and would not cost the government any revenue.
At the same time, Mr. Feldstein said, Japan could stimulate business investment by enacting a big investment tax credit and offset it by an increase in the corporate income tax rate. The investment credit would gradually decline over time, and the corporate income tax would fall, giving companies an incentive to invest sooner rather than later, again without worsening the budget deficit.
Mr. Feldstein said an aggressive fiscal policy would be vital in such a case because the effectiveness of monetary policy would be limited. He criticized the current thinking within the Federal Reserve about how a central bank should respond to the threat of deflation, defined as a generalized decline in prices.
Within the Fed, there is considerable support for the idea that a central bank should cut interest rates aggressively if signs of deflation emerge, even if rates are already low or even if they are approaching zero. Mr. Feldstein said that using such a "hyperexpansive" interest rate policy could inflate a bubble in stocks and other assets and that popping a bubble could well destabilize the economy.
"An excessively easy monetary policy is a dangerous tool," he said.
Other economists said Mr. Feldstein's concern about an asset-price bubble seemed out of place when discussing an economy whose main problem is declining prices and demand. And they debated, without reaching a consensus, a number of other ideas for dealing with a situation like Japan's.
One of the most provocative ideas was put on the table by Lars E. O. Svensson of Princeton, who proposed what amounted to a big but temporary currency devaluation as a way to encourage prices and demand to rise. His idea was widely criticized; Michael Mussa, a former chief economist for the International Monetary Fund who is now with the Institute of International Economics, noted that the fund's articles of confederation expressly forbid devaluations for the purpose of increasing international competitiveness.
Mr. Svensson also ignited a heated debate by proposing that central banks explicitly acknowledge how much their inflation-fighting policies are costing the economy in lost output and jobs.
His idea was a new twist on the old debate about whether central banks should focus exclusively on price stability or should also seek maximum economic growth. It won some support from other economists who said that central banks are always after maximum economic growth even if they cannot openly acknowledge it in the face of pressure from markets, which can severely punish any perceived lack of inflation-fighting willpower.
But his idea was mostly criticized either as unworkable, since no one has a clear idea of what an economy's maximum sustainable growth rate really is, or unwise because it would inevitably distract from a central bank's inflation fighting role.
Hanging over the conference were the question of what policy makers could do to deal with stock market bubbles and Mr. Greenspan's conclusion that the answer is not much.
"There was a sense of frustration that we couldn't deal better with the asset price bubble," said Laurence H. Meyer, who was a Fed governor through most of the Wall Street boom. "But I don't think anybody has come up with a strategy that people feel would have gotten the job done."
To criticism by economists here like Henry Kaufman that Mr. Greenspan could have done more to keep stock prices in check by making a public argument that Wall Street had pushed itself to irrational levels, Mr. Meyer said central bankers could not use their positions to destroy wealth.
"That's a politically untenable situation for a central bank to be in," he said.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
What Failed in TV Pilots Brings Laughs in a Club

BYLINE:  By Marc Weingarten

 BODY:
"Last week we had a 100 share of people watching TV in a nightclub," the comedian Beth Lapidus told a packed crowd at Moomba in West Hollywood, a halogen-and-red-velvet nightclub where Jeff Goldblum has a weekly jazz piano gig and Rosanna Arquette's brother Alexis is host of a karaoke night. But there will be no hipster posturing tonight, just videos of television shows that never made it to prime time.
 "The Other Network," a weekly series in which failed pilots are screened for Moomba patrons, is a runaway hit. Ms. Lapidus, who founded the Los Angeles comedy group Uncabaret with her husband, Greg Miller, is the creator and host of "The Other Network," and it's a fascinating peek inside the harsh world of television pilots, where many are picked, but few are chosen. 
 The four main and two smaller networks produce roughly 130 pilots every season, of which about 35 pass muster. An overwhelming percentage are comedy pilots. With a potential motherlode of syndication revenue awaiting the lucky producer who is graced with a "Seinfeld"-like hit, the successful sitcom is a holy grail for comedy writers and stand-up comedians who think they have stumbled onto the premise that just might click.
Most failed pilots are seen only by the family of their creators and the executives who rejected them, which is why "The Other Network" is such a revelation.
On this night something called "The Lemur," featuring the stand-up comic Greg Behrendt as an obnoxious drive-time D.J. and Moon Zappa as his long-suffering sidekick, gets big laughs. It's a knowing, uncanny parody, but Mr. Behrendt says in prescreening introduction that Comedy Central did not pick it up as a series because a focus group did not think the comic was joking. "It was the lowest-tested show for Comedy Central ever," Mr. Behrendt told the crowd without a hint of irony.
The pilots in "The Other Network" hardly adhere to the usual sitcom template. Jack Black and Ben Stiller's show, "Heat Vision and Jack," is a bizarre amalgam of "The Twilight Zone," "Second City TV" and "The Six Million Dollar Man." "Next!," a would-be Fox series produced by Bob Odenkirk, is a sketch show that whipsaws from gag to gag. Judd Apatow's "North Hollywood" features Judge Reinhold playing "Judge Reinhold, struggling actor."
Ms. Lapidus's Uncabaret has been a finishing school for many creators of "The Other Network" show. "For the creators of these pilots," she said, "there's always the hope that you're going to be the one show that will provide the authentic voice on the air. They're doing the work they really want to do, going for that little piece of the market that will get it. Some of the shows aren't wholly successful, but they're really interesting experiments."
The behind-the-scenes narratives for failed pilots of "The Other Network" are strikingly similar. Virtually all of the show creators introduce their shows as great notions that were watered down by benighted executives too timid to go out on a limb. Cynthia Greenberg, a writer who collaborated with Judy Toll on a snappy workplace sitcom called "Me and My Needs," almost sounded contrite when she told the Moomba crowd, "Judy didn't want a workplace."
"The network will find an original voice, and then some of their notes will start to dilute that voice," Ms. Greenberg said the day after the screening. "I just think it's always amazing when executives risk trusting the vision of a writer they know is good. Look at the people who had strong visions of what they wanted, like Larry David or David Kelley. They had a lot more room to make their own choices."
To hear participants in "The Other Network" tell it, focus groups are the most pernicious momentum killers. If a network is interested in a pilot, they corral a random group of viewers into a screening room and hand each of them a box with a dial on it that measures their response to every aspect of the show. If a pilot tests poorly, chances are it has reached the end of its development road.
"Testing is dumb," Mr. Odenkirk said. " 'The Wayne Brady Show' tested amazingly, and it didn't last a season. Something like 'Seinfeld' wouldn't test well, but it had somewhere to go. So many shows the networks produce are hot for one run and burn out. You think we're going to see a fifth season of 'The Osbournes'?"
Mr. Apatow called the pilot process "an insane system."
"There's always a set of questions," he said. "Will women like it? What about older people? Will kids be offended? Are the characters likable? That's why the networks didn't want 'The Sopranos': it broke all the rules of likability." He said there was pressure to find actors who were both good-looking and hilarious. "It's the 'Friends' mind-set," he said. "But the truth is, most funny people look like Jack Klugman."
Despite the frustration and incessant head-knocking, these television writers say they will continue to make pilots in the hope that one kernel of an idea will blossom into a thriving franchise. Mr. Odenkirk remains ready to pitch the network on something else. Mr. Apatow is also fiddling around with some ideas. "I'm always up for trying again," he said. "It's really fun, until the moment you're unemployed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Greg Behrendt, left, and Mike Gandolfi introduce their pilot, "The Lemur," at Moomba in West Hollywood. (Misha Erwitt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japanese Shares Fall 3.2% to a 19-Year Low 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
The main Japanese stock index plunged 3.2 percent today, reaching a 19-year low and reawakening fears that Japan is about to be swept by another banking crisis.
 With American markets closed for the Labor Day holiday on Monday, Japanese analysts, investors and money managers seemed to be taking their cues today from mounting evidence that Japan's mild recovery may halt or reverse if the American economy falters again. 
 Figures released by the Japanese government last week confirmed that Japan's economy remains highly dependent on exports for the meager growth it has managed recently. Any slackening of demand in the United States for Japanese goods could throw Japan back into recession. And the signals from the United States have not been very promising. 
Japanese banks are very vulnerable to slides in the stock market because they hold huge portfolios of stocks and depend on them for much of their capital. In the past, the banks had great leeway in deciding how to value the stocks on their books, and could ignore short-term market swings; the portfolios were useful in generating capital gains on appreciated stocks to cushion profits. 
The banks needed that cushion because their fundamental business, making loans, has been weak for years. Interest rates are near zero, demand for loans is falling, and despite growing write-offs, the mountain of nonperforming loans keeps growing.
But new laws require the banks to revalue their portfolios using market prices at the end of each fiscal half-year. The next deadline comes Sept. 30. If the markets keep sliding for the next few weeks, the banks may face an ugly reckoning when they close their books for the half-year.
The twin worries -- over the economy and the financial system -- have further undermined an already bearish stock market. The Nikkei 225 index has fallen for seven consecutive sessions and given up more than 8 percent of its value since Aug. 26, closing today at 9,217.04, a level not seen since Nov. 7, 1983.
Big exporters like Sony and Matsushita Electric Industrial, the country's two consumer electronics giants, have been hit hard. So, too, have been the banks' own stocks. Mizuho Holdings, the largest bank group, fell more than 9 percent today; its nearest rival, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, fell 8 percent, and Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial fell 7 percent.
Japan's banks and insurers typically hold large blocks of stock in many of their clients, a practice long used to cement business relationships. But as the economy soured in the 1990's, the banks sold many of these holdings to generate profits when their lending business could not. Most of those unrealized gains have now been used up or overtaken by falling stock prices.
"Every time the index falls, it hurts the banks," said Tim Marrable, a bank analyst at Indo Suez Securities in Tokyo. "The upshot is their portfolios are all out of cushion and they are all under water."
Japanese investors have often in the past looked to the government to take steps to prop up the market, but the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, said today that his ministry had no plans for special measures now.
Mizuho Holdings also came under intense criticism today from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government. The city governor, Shintaro Ishihara, threatened to shift some of its 1.7 trillion yen ($14.39 billion) in deposits to rivals, including Citibank, if Mizuho does not improve service to the city's residents and businesses.
Mizuho Holdings was created in April through a merger of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Fuji Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan. The merged company was immediately troubled by a multitude of computer failures and other integration problems that angered retail customers and cost corporate clients millions of dollars.
Mr. Marrable of Indo Suez said he did not think the Tokyo government's threat was idle posturing. The comments by Governor Ishihara surprised analysts because he is regarded as an ardent nationalist. 
But he also has a history of combative relations with the banks. Two years ago, he tried to impose a tax on the largest banks' revenue based on their size, arguing that the banks were not paying their fair share because of the paper losses they were recording. His effort was ultimately defeated in a court challenge.

HEADLINE: How To Boil Four-Star Water 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY

DATELINE: YOUNTVILLE, Calif., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
The joke was going to be that in order to get into the French Laundry I had to get a job there. And like a lot of wisecracks, this one contained more than a kernel of truth. Despite what one reads about the dot-com debacle, the Silicon Valley money that helped transform this one-time mining, timber and prune growing region into a viticultural wonderland still seems immune from what most Americans would consider economic reality. For the moment, at any rate, there is no apparent shortage of lotus eaters willing to spend the $300 or so that dinner for two can easily cost at Thomas Keller's celebrated Yountville restaurant. 
 "We have to say no, unfortunately, a lot of the time," a waiter explained to a customer last week. "But we do have a waiting list, and I encourage people to put their names down, because you never know when something will open up." 
 It never does. At least, it hasn't for me in the eight summers that I have migrated to this valley, visiting generous friends. I have tried pulling strings to snag a French Laundry reservation, worn out the redial button, and driven often past the restaurant's modest fieldstone building, once a brothel, with longing in my heart. But mostly my pals and I just grilled food at home. 
Then, a friend alerted me to L'Ecole des Chefs, a program that allows what its originator, Annie Jacquet-Bentley, refers to as "passionate cooks" to spend time as stagiers, or apprentices, in the kitchens of world-class chefs like Guy Savoy, Daniel Boulud and Mr. Keller. Founded in 1999, the program was soon folded into the upscale Relais & Chateaux syndicate. The affiliation added scores of chefs to the roster, so that now passionate and prosperous amateur cooks can hone their skills with one of nearly 100 professionals in 17 countries throughout North and South America, Europe, Asia and Africa.
Pros do this all the time, of course. Kitchen hierarchies are notoriously medieval in their structure. Novices serve time as scullery serfs as they work toward the privilege of trailing a pastry chef or a garde-manger; seasoned workers perform unpaid drudgery in return for what amounts to a stove-side master class. Students at what is now called L'Ecole des Chefs Relais Gourmands bypass the usual flying skillets and backbreaking hours slicing carrots for the stockpot, though, and invert the occupational formula entirely by paying for a chance to be, pardon the expression, a fly on the wall.
And they pay richly. The fee for two days in Mr. Keller's kitchen was $1,400. This was subject to approval of my application, and exclusive of other requirements like black chef's pants, black shoes with nonskid soles, and a tool list that read like the armamentarium for a battle of the Iron Chefs. 
I applied. I was accepted. I drove to Yountville on a recent August day when the temperature hovered near 100 degrees. I was handed a French chef's coat, a French blue apron, and hugely to my surprise, was immediately put to work. 
Of the several ways to interpret this article's opening sentence, the one that surprised me was philosophical. As a perk of my expensive internship, I did eventually get into the French Laundry. I did unexpectedly find myself inducted into an echelon of customers that the restaurant's reservation book terms PX's (interior code for V.I.P.'s). I did dine on an extraordinary improvised multicourse meal that is Mr. Keller's customary way of rewarding favored regulars for their patronage. 
But I also got into the French Laundry in another sense altogether, one that had to do with Mr. Keller's intensity of focus, his relationship to the market, to techniques of cooking, serving, sanitation, management and also, ultimately, to finesse. 
What I did not do is learn very much about how to cook. The printed schedule for my abbreviated "stage" (most interns spend five days at the restaurant) was efficiently broken down into increments of about an hour. 
On paper, Day 1 was dedicated to visiting a local purveyor with the chef de cuisine, Eric Ziebold; preparing pasta with a commissaire, Donald Gonzales; and getting an introduction to sauce making and the organization of ingredients and tools that, in classic French cuisine, is called mise en place. On paper, Day 2 would see me learning rudiments of pastry making with the pastry chef, Sebastien Rouxel; doing a stint trimming meats with the butcher, Ryan Fancher; learning fish butchery with another chef, Jonathan Benno; and arranging canapes with Jonas Lundgren, a chef de partie. 
Some of these things occurred. Some did not. The reasons were fluky and as subject to whims of temperament as is anything that happens in a professional kitchen. I found myself being conducted deeply into the arcana of meat preparation by an enthusiastic Mr. Fancher. The fish butcher, on the other hand, barely gave me the time of day.
In no particular order and to no very evident purpose, I accumulated a hodgepodge of culinary lore. Waste nothing. Wash as you go. Trim the sinews on steak by stroking the knife in smooth arcs. Prick the inner membrane of a rabbit kidney with your thumbnail and it will slip away as easily as a silk sock. Use the dull edge of a blade to squeegee fish you plan to saute with its flesh on and it will cook evenly all the way through. Salt water for vegetables until it tastes like the ocean. The secret ingredient of a restaurant kitchen is a good supply of C-fold paper towels. 
I was destined to be surprised about tools at the French Laundry, since the technology in use there is little more complex than what you would find in many kitchens at home. And the kitchen itself, while white-tiled and gleaming, is a good deal smaller, at roughly 600 square feet, than the culinary luxury liners that are the norm in certain neighborhoods of New York. 
Except for an ice cream maker the size of a Chevy transmission and an electric fish poacher resembling a Lilliputian sitz bath, there were few fancy gadgets. The one that seemed to excite Mr. Keller most was a Raytek MiniTemp -- a gizmo that digitally reads surface temperature and that resembles a toy gun. 
"Isn't that great?" he asked on Tuesday, as he zapped the contents of a refrigerator drawer. "When the food inspectors come in and start saying, 'It's too cold, it's too hot,' you can just show them this." He grinned.
Hanging above the threshold to Mr. Keller's kitchen is an enamel sign with a dictionary definition of a favored word. "Finesse," it reads. "Refinement and delicacy of performance, execution or artisanship." It is no secret that Mr. Keller was not always renowned for his finesse, and that his highly pitched scale of standards was often expressed with performances not notable for their delicacy. "I don't explode anymore," he once told a reporter. "I let it out in different ways."
That was in 1996, two years after Mr. Keller first assembled nearly 50 limited partners and the $1.2 million it took to purchase the original French Laundry from its longtime owners, Don and Sally Schmidt. Mr. Keller's French Laundry was the culmination of a journey that began at the Palm Beach Yacht Club in the South Florida restaurants where his mother was a dining room manager, and where -- according to a well-burnished legend -- he stepped in to replace a chef who quit without notice, and learned to broil a lobster tail by consulting with his older brother, Joseph, who was already a cook, on the phone.
Since that time the trajectory of this chef with no formal training has carried him to New York, where he worked at the Polo restaurant under Patrice Boely, to stages at Michelin-starred restaurants in France, to a stellar but doomed stint as the chef at Rakel in Manhattan, and to his 1997 award from the James Beard Foundation as the Outstanding American Chef.
Nowadays, the French Laundry is a global destination, a conglomerate that extends to an award-winning cookbook now in its 13th printing and to Bouchon, Mr. Keller's bistro-style restaurant down the road. And it will soon include a boulangerie, an inn and spa in Yountville designed by the architect Antoine Predock, and an as-yet unnamed restaurant set to have its debut at the AOL Time Warner building when it opens in New York. 
French Laundry, the diffusing empire, seemed pretty remote on the days I spent there, when Mr. Keller's focus was like a tightly focused arc of white light. The atmosphere of near silence in the French Laundry kitchen has often been noted. Yet that hardly conveys a level of concentration that probably wouldn't feel out of place at Livermore lab. From the vantage of the small garden, where diners can peer through the kitchen windows, everything seems evenly paced and mellow. Why would it not? There are, after all, just 62 seats and rarely more than 90 people being fed on a busy night. 
Yet distributed among those people, on a variety of tasting, a la carte and improvised menus, are as many as 900 separate dishes, composed of ingredients from 300 purveyors, and rendered over a day whose two culinary shifts end at 2 a.m. and begin again at 5:30 a.m. 
There are 102 styles of plates at the French Laundry. There are 83 people on staff. There are preparations that, while theoretically familiar to anyone with a smattering of training in classic French cuisine, have been tweaked and pushed well beyond the limits of rote. 
The pepper confetti, for instance, that Mr. Keller uses as a garnish -- sparingly enough to save it from seeming like an anachronism left over from the first wave of California cuisine -- is created by first flaying red, green and yellow bell peppers, and then slicing their lobes to the thinness of onion skin. The slices are then julienned and laid on trays to dry slowly on shelves suspended above the 800-degree stovetops. The resulting flakes are not much larger than grains of the fleur de sel that Mr. Keller favors; so delicate, in fact, that they make actual paper confetti seem crude. 
It is in a weirdly accreted blur of details like this that I passed my two days in the French Laundry kitchen, being handed along from one worker to the next, from cold room to front room, from stations where a pastry chef merrily blasted creme brulees with a propane torch to the cold-room shelf where a butcher shouldered aside boxes of calfs' feet to make room for a tub of some marmoreal reduction made from the head of a pig. 
At a certain point, I, too, began to feel like a reduction. It happened while the canape chef was attempting to explain a contraption used to snap the dome off an egg.
The egg would eventually be emptied of its contents, sterilized and then refilled with a white truffle custard. The custard would be thinly glazed with another truffle sauce. The egg would be set in a cup and ornamented with a papery oblong potato chip. The chip, in turn, would have a single strand of chive embedded at its translucent center; how, I never learned. 
That almost everything in Mr. Keller's kitchen was similarly considered, recast and rendered as an essence of itself, made a certain kind of sense, given an anonymous quotation that he keeps on the clipboard hanging above his desk. "If we did all of the things we are capable of doing," it reads, "we would literally astound ourselves."
As I observed Mr. Keller ranging around his kitchen, trimming the bright flesh of a red snapper, tweaking spears of baby leeks on a plate of salad until the arrangement pleased his eye, the lesson of his process began to come clear. Like all good lessons, it seemed both too simple and, ultimately, profound enough to justify the price of admission. It was this: Think about the food.

What You'll Need
THE French Laundry asks interns from L'Ecole des Chefs to bring the following.
2 pairs black chef pants
1 pair black shoes, with nonskid soles
1 French knife
1 paring knife
1 slicer
1 serrated knife
1 palette knife
1 peeler
1 timer
2 pairs of scissors (heavy duty and all purpose)
1 pair of fish tweezers
Assorted saucing spoons

Who, Where And How Much
THROUGH L'Ecole des Chefs Relais Gourmands, amateur cooks can serve as interns to nearly 100 chefs in 17 countries.
The following are among the participating chefs.
DANIEL BOULUD -- Daniel, New York.
LUDOVIC LEFEBVRE -- L'Orangerie, Los Angeles.

GUY SAVOY -- Restaurant Guy Savoy, Paris.
MICHEL TROISGROS -- La Maison Troisgros, Roanne, France.
KIYOMI MIKUNI -- Mikuni, Tokyo.
Information on internships is available at www.ecoledeschefs.com or (212) 856-0115. A five-day internship costs $1,900 to $2,600, and a two-day program costs $1,100 to $1,400. Lodging is available at some restaurants that are part of Relais & Chateaux properties.

HEADLINE: Ah, Sweet Mysteries Of Trenton, She's Got 'Em 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
As backdrops for best sellers go, this is an unlikely city. The architecture ranges from state office buildings that seem Soviet inspired to dilapidated old Victorians and row houses. The downtown nightspots can be counted on the fingers of one hand, the hotels on one lonely finger. The city empties out at 5 past 5, as the bureaucrats make a beeline for the suburbs. There is not even a movie theater or a mall worth walking into.
 But with her eight comic crime novels featuring the bumbling, big-haired bounty hunter Stephanie Plum, Janet Evanovich has made herself Trenton's de facto poet laureate, turning a colorless state capital into the kind of place that thousands of her readers actually want to visit, and that no resident would ever want to leave. 
 It would not be too much of a stretch to say that the Plum series, which began in 1994 with "One for the Money," has elevated Ms. Evanovich, a onetime romance writer, into the whodunit pantheon alongside Sue Grafton and Sara Paretsky, Robert B. Parker and Carl Hiaasen. Each of her last three books had its debut on the New York Times best-seller list at the No. 1 position, and the latest, "Hard Eight" (St. Martin's Press), has sold 500,000 copies since June. 
It would not be too much of a stretch, either, to say that Ms. Evanovich has done more for Trenton's reputation than anyone since George Washington rode over here in a boat. Boston's literary presence is far bigger than the Spenser novels, of course, and Chicago would not be a lesser place had V. I. Warshawsky never been dreamed up.
"We have people who come in all the time asking for mysteries set in specific places, like New York, Paris, London, Venice, you name it," said Tom Cushman, manager of Murder Ink, a specialty bookshop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "But we've yet to have anyone ask for a mystery set in Trenton."
This is a city that shows its bruises, after all: a 7.5-square-mile patch of concrete where the state doglegs around a bend in the Delaware River, where factories once spewed smoke and churned out rubber, wire and Lenox china until the big industries fled half a century ago, leaving the dwindling working-class population with a hollow shell of an economy, persistent poverty and a steady supply of crime.
But in Ms. Evanovich's hands, Trenton becomes a tight-knit home where for all the crime, residents could not feel safer, since everyone knows your business, your neighbors watch your back, and even your grandmother carries a gun; where the food is too good to resist, the men are too hot to resist and excitement is always just a fugitive-recovery assignment away.
The most visible reminder of Trenton's manufacturing might is the neon motto on a bridge: "Trenton Makes, the World Takes." Today that is just a cruel joke. Even Ms. Evanovich, 59, arguably the city's biggest claim to fame these days, isn't a product of Trenton. She grew up in South River, a small suburb three exits up the New Jersey Turnpike and only became familiar with Trenton when visiting her father at St. Francis Hospital, in the city's old-line Italian neighborhood of Chambersburg.
A pastry shop first lured Ms. Evanovich up the street from the hospital, and soon she was exploring the neighborhood further, tasting food, asking questions and looking into windows. What she found -- and what she portrays in her books -- is not all that different from what she had experienced as a girl, she said on a recent visit here.
"No kid was ever snatched off a bike when I was growing up, because everyone was watching," she said. "And I understand how a funeral parlor can be a social center. We didn't have a country club, but we did have two really good funeral parlors. Rezem's did the best makeup. Four or five nights out of the week the ladies would come over to my aunt's house. They'd go over the obits and decide which ones to go to."
A stylized, slightly anachronistic Chambersburg -- a place she has largely imagined but could not have invented -- provides the center stage for Ms. Evanovich's elaborate plotting. Her supporting characters seem cast from the sitcom mold: Lula the sidekick, a trigger-happy, very-big-boned ex-prostitute who loves to eat but does not take to being called fat; Grandma Mazur, who crashes funerals and occasionally overturns open coffins; Joe Morelli, the police detective with whom Stephanie enjoys a lust-hate relationship; and Ranger, a seemingly superhuman bounty hunter and bedmate who mysteriously appears and disappears like the wind.
As for Stephanie herself, Ms. Evanovich, drawing on her long experience with romance heroines, has wisely dreamed up a gumshoe any reader could love, or at least understand. Stephanie Plum is a woman in her 30's with a pet hamster, a pocketbook full of makeup and mace, and a dangerous array of irrepressible appetites and impulses: for men, for clothes and cars, for doughnuts and Tastykakes, for getting into trouble, and even -- dare she admit it? -- for her mother's pot roasts and pies. 
"She's a very average person," Ms. Evanovich said. "We all know who she is. We could go out and eat pizza with her. Yet she has this tenacity to succeed."
Ms. Evanovich's reviews have consistently been as strong as her sales. A typical notice for "Hard Eight" came in The San Francisco Chronicle, where a reviewer called it "most emphatically not Raymond Chandler but, like his work, a piece of finely crafted prose." A critic in The Washington Post called the book a guilty pleasure, saying, "Just when the slapstick tires you, there's a wonderful laugh, a smart one-liner, a tart bit of dialogue, a nice turn on your expectations."
Mr. Cushman of Mystery Ink said: "Of the female mystery writers, she is definitely the funniest one going these days -- one that we not only sell a ton of but that we can wholeheartedly recommend. And a lot of times those do not necessarily coincide."
Ms. Evanovich and Trenton have quite happily adopted each other, to tell from the love fest that ensues when she shows her face in town, which invariably means vodka fettucini at Marsilio's and cookies from the Italian People's Bakery.
In her books, Trenton cops seem unable to solve any crimes on their own and instead use Stephanie as the ultimate decoy, piecing together cases by picking up the pieces she sends flying. But no offense is taken at police headquarters, where Ms. Evanovich was given a three-hour tour on her most recent visit.
Two lieutenants, Robert Szejner and Joe Juniak, both of whom make cameos in the Plum novels, squired Ms. Evanovich from the bail counter and the holding tank to the basement police academy to even the motor pool, where one of the mechanics, Craig Chapman, asked for Ms. Evanovich's autograph. 
"On account of her, my wife's reading now," Mr. Chapman said. "She's a crossing guard and got hit by a car. She was so bored, but her girlfriend gave her the first book. She read the first eight in a week. Now she's waiting for the next one."
In the detective bureau, Capt. Robert Tedder pointed out that the real murder rate in Trenton was only 15 or 20 a year, a far cry from the body count in her novels. Yet he obligingly revealed that the night before, a body had been found at the new Marriott, the city's only hotel.
Perhaps it was a good omen, given Ms. Evanovich's arrival in town, someone said. "We think its an overdose," Captain Tedder said, letting a smile slip out. "But we're not ruling anything out."
Ms. Evanovich understands why Trenton police officers and Chambersburg restaurateurs get a kick out of her books. And she banks on it. "People in Jersey have a sense of humor about themselves, and they just love the attention," she said.
But she has had to take precautions, for example by changing the names of Trenton streets, to protect the innocent from having their lawns trampled. "My fans do go," Ms. Evanovich said. "They'll take vacations and walk around and look for the places in the books."
Her growing following is forcing other precautions as well. The Trenton Marriott was nearly the scene of a disaster in June, when 3,000 people mobbed a book signing that Ms. Evanovich thought would draw perhaps 1,000. She spent five hours scrawling her name. Next year, she said, she may rent Trenton's minor-league hockey arena.
Ms. Evanovich, who will add a Christmas-season Stephanie Plum novella to her schedule of a book a year, has a simple explanation for why the series is taking off among readers far afield from the New Jersey watershed. "It's very, very much about middle America," she said. "It's this little ethnic community in the Burg, mostly Italian, a little Hungarian. But I'm getting letters from people all over: Are you sure Stephanie isn't Jewish?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Janet Evanovich in Trenton, the setting of her Stephanie Plum mystery novels. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Brazil Builds Up Its Trade-Talks Team 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: BRASILIA 

 BODY:
Until recently, Brazil's trade negotiators would compare themselves, only half-jokingly, to their 1998 national soccer squad, which lost the World Cup to France when no worthy replacement could be found for the injured star striker Ronaldo.
 "Unless you have substitutes who are up to the mark, you risk losing the match," said Roberto Giannetti da Fonseca, who recently stepped down as head of Brazil's chamber of foreign trade. 
 "Our trade negotiations were in the hands of very few experts -- say half a dozen," Mr. Giannetti said. "Holidays, illness, a wedding, a death in the family, anything could virtually halt an important round of talks." 
This year though, Brazil clinched a historic fifth World Cup victory. And Mr. Giannetti says his country is also "on the way to forming a winning squad of negotiators."
Brazil is going to need them.
Slumbering for decades behind a high wall of import tariffs, Brazil, South America's economic giant, has unilaterally opened its market over the last decade and is now negotiating major trade accords on three fronts: with the United States, to form the Free Trade Area of the Americas; with the European Union, as de facto leader of South America's trade bloc, Mercosur; and, multilaterally, in the World Trade Organization.
Traditionally a closed economy thanks to its continental size and abundant natural resources, Brazil still exports less than 10 percent of its gross domestic product and, though it is among the world's top 10 economies, accounts for less than 1 percent of global trade.
But the recent devaluation of its currency, the real, has made the country much more competitive, especially in agribusiness. The country currently runs the world's biggest agricultural trade surplus, totaling $20 billion a year.
"Brazil is being pushed toward becoming a world trade player," said Marcos Jank, a professor in Sao Paulo and a consultant at the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington. "By opening its economy, Brazil weakened its balance of payments and must now aim for a more or less constant trade surplus."
In the last five years, Brazil unilaterally lowered import tariffs to an average of 14 percent, from 55 percent, Mr. Jank said.
Echoing all four candidates in October's presidential elections, who say Brazil's Achilles' heel is its chronic trade deficit, Mr. Jank predicted that "any further opening will be negotiated, and I believe negotiated firmly."
"Tariffs will only fall from 14 percent to zero if Brazil gets something in return, and that is access to others' markets," he said.
The question is whether Brazil can negotiate such access.
"Brazil is at an unprecedented point in its history that will be crucial for the country's future," said Lytha Spindola, secretary of foreign trade at the Ministry for Development, Industry and Foreign Trade. "We are negotiating with almost the whole world."
Brazil recently signed a bilateral trade pact with Mexico, which it sees as a model for negotiating access to United States and Canadian markets, and it sealed an accord on textiles with the European Union.
But the major bargaining is still to come. In November, Brazil will join the United States as co-president of the coordinating committee in the negotiations to get a Free Trade Area of the Americas, stretching from Alaska to Argentina, in place by 2005. And parallel negotiations between the European Union and Mercosur should also start producing results. 
Meanwhile, to provide the "half a dozen" negotiators Mr. Giannetti referred to with backup and to create a pool of future front-line diplomats, Ms. Spindola has recruited 180 foreign-trade analysts in the last two years and an additional 95 are due to join the ministry soon.
The recruits, all recent graduates, start out by gathering statistics, studying investment regulations, intellectual property rights and antidumping legislation.
"It's a new discipline that never existed before," Ms. Spindola said. "They learn on the job by supporting negotiators in the field, and after two or three years they're ready to negotiate themselves."
As times are hard and Brazil does not have a lot of money to throw at the problem, the new posts have been culled from other governmental bodies like those dealing with coffee, sugar and alcohol that are now considered largely obsolete.
When their training is over, they are assigned to negotiating teams under Ms. Spindola's command or at the foreign or agriculture ministries.
"It's still very few people, compared to the rest of the world," said Ms. Spindola. 
Brazil's negotiating team might be small, but it has already shown itself capable of getting results, sometimes against the odds and particularly on the multilateral battleground of the W.T.O.
Last year, Brazil finally won a five-year dispute with Canada over export subsidies to their regional jet manufacturers, Embraer of Brazil and Bombardier of Canada.
This month, Brazil filed two complaints at the W.T.O. against United States subsidies to its cotton farmers and against European Union subsidies to its sugar industry, and has already won support from Argentina, Australia, Thailand and several African nations.
Even without subsidies, cotton is one of the fastest growing sectors of Brazilian agribusiness, and the country has been the world's largest sugar producer for years.
The Foreign Ministry has set up an office to deal solely with such complaints and trade disputes, while the Agriculture Ministry has created a Department for International Trade Negotiations.
"In agriculture, Brazil is already a world player," said Pedro Camargo Neto, the department's head. "Brazil must lead the way for South America in the F.T.A.A. negotiations, and our biggest challenge will be to get all types of agricultural export subsidies abolished at the W.T.O."
Although not numerous, Brazil's negotiators were not merely "quixotic dreamers," he said.
"We must not compare our team with how many people Brussels or Washington have," he said. "We must compare what we have now with what we had in the past, and, looking at it that way, it's obvious to me that we're headed in the right direction."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brazil, with crops like coffee, above, and sugar, currently runs the world's biggest agricultural trade surplus, totaling $20 billion a year. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
The DowTakes Another Beating, Falling 355 Points

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged yesterday on a report that showed that manufacturing remained quite weak, fueling concerns about the already sluggish economic recovery.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 4.2 percent for its worst single day since the period immediately after Sept. 11. 
 The two other major indexes fell at least 3.9 percent, pulled lower by sharp drops in Citigroup, down 10.3 percent; General Motors, off 4.8 percent; Exxon Mobil, down 5.2 percent; General Electric, off 5.6 percent; Microsoft, down 4.2 percent; and Intel, off 4.9 percent. All 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average were down, as were 482 of those in the S.& P. 500.
All three indexes are above their levels when the overall market hit a five-year low in July. But Nasdaq is within 58 points of its low, and the S.& P. 500 is below 900 for the first time in four weeks. 
The market's decline on the first trading day in September is not an auspicious beginning to the fall season. September has been the worst month for the Dow. The index has fallen sharply in September in the last three years, and September is the only month in which it has posted a negative return on average.
The Dow and the Nasdaq composite index finished August in the red for the fifth consecutive month of losses. It was the first decline of that length for the Dow since 1981 and the first for the Nasdaq since 1984.
"The market still has a lot of speculation built into it," said Richard Bernstein, the United States equity strategist at Merrill Lynch. He warned that he did not think the market had reached a bottom.
Investors who are playing the market's volatility, trying to profit on the rallies and the slumps, are the driving force in the market, he said. "The dominant theme in the market is momentum," he said, "momentum up and momentum down."
But as stocks fell yesterday, bonds rallied and interest rates fell sharply, which could be good news. Lower interest rates encourage borrowing and could allow many homeowners to refinance their mortgages, giving them extra cash to spend. In late afternoon trading, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was at 3.96 percent. Except for a brief intraday trading dip below 4 percent in mid-August, the yield has not been this low on a security with a 10-year maturity since the early 1960's.
Since the stock market reached its five-year low, investors have digested conflicting news on the outlook for the economy and, in turn, corporate earnings. Some analysts have argued that the market is attractive because stocks are undervalued, while others still worry about how high prices are relative to earnings. 
"I think mixed signals are the inescapable reality in a modest recovery, but that can be especially disappointing to anyone who is hoping to return to the boom times of the 1990's," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y.
Mr. Barbera said that he did not expect the economy to fall into a second, or double-dip, recession. Economists and analysts generally contend that the last recession ended late last year.
But there is more and more talk of what is called a growth recession. This is a period when the economy is growing, but the pace is so slow that unemployment can still rise and the economy has the feel of a recession. There was such a period after the end of the 1991-92 recession, when President Bush's father was president. Although the recession officially ended in March 1992, the Dow did not get into a steady upward trend until the next year.
In positive news, figures released last week showed that orders for durable goods shot higher in July while consumers increased their spending by 1 percent, also a big surge.
Consumer confidence, however, declined. The report yesterday from the Institute for Supply Management was another negative. The institute's factory index stayed at 50.5 in August, though Wall Street analysts had predicted the index would rise to 51.8 percent.
To David J. Greenlaw, chief United States fixed-income economist at Morgan Stanley, the report seemed even weaker than the overall numbers indicated. "Technically, with the composite index above 50, the manufacturing expansion continued in August," he said. "But with orders down and only 8 out of 20 industries reporting growth, down from 12 in July and 15 in June, the recovery that started in February is clearly faltering badly."
He also noted that manufacturers are "anxious about second-half sales" and worried about the decline in both business and consumer confidence.
At the close, the Dow was down 355.45 points, or 4.1 percent, at 8,308.05. The Nasdaq dropped 51.01 points, or 3.9 percent, to 1,263.84. The S.& P. 500 index fell 38.05 points, or 4.2 percent, to 878.02. It was the biggest drop since a 4.9 percent decline last Sept. 17 when the markets reopened after the attacks.
Citigroup fell in part because Michael L. Mayo, an analyst at Prudential Securities, downgraded the stock to sell from a rating of hold. He said that he expected earnings to be weaker than expected and that Citigroup still faced big potential losses from lawsuits in connection with its Enron and WorldCom business.
The recent performance of stocks that tend to rise and fall with the economy reflects indecision about the outlook. Investors expect these stocks, including companies like International Paper, Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Sears, Roebuck and Caterpillar, to rally when the economy begins to turn up. Morgan Stanley's so-called cyclical stock index tried to rally in July, but failed. It rallied in August and is now heading lower again. Yesterday, the index was down 3.7 percent.
In the bond market, the yield on the Treasury's two-year note, which is often sensitive to expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut, fell to 1.98 percent, from 2.15 percent on Friday. This is still above its historic low of 1.89 percent in early August.
In what may have been another blow to investors, Federal Reserve officials have indicated that they do not think that another cut in their benchmark short-term interest rate is necessary to assure that the economic recovery continues.
Even after Fed policy makers left rates unchanged at their Aug. 13 meeting, some hope remained for a rate cut at the September meeting. Recent comments from Fed officials have damped those expectations. The weak manufacturing data released yesterday, however, revived somewhat the expectations of a September cut. Expectations of a rate cut could grow if the August employment data that is released on Friday shows the economy is weaker than expected.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Tries to Block Sale of Hershey 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 3 

 BODY:
The state went to court today to try to block any move to sell Hershey Foods by the charitable trust that controls it, warning that such a deal could lead to huge layoffs in Hershey, Pa. 
 Lawyers for the $5.9 billion Hershey Trust Company, which benefits a school for disadvantaged children, argued that the state lacked the authority to stop a sale. 
 The trust controls 77 percent of the shareholder votes of Hershey Foods and 31 percent of its common stock. In July it announced that it had ordered company executives to seek bids for Hershey. Analysts say the price could be as high as $15 billion. 
Attorney General Mike Fisher sued to block any sale, contending that the loss of jobs and tax revenue could devastate the Hershey area, where about 6,200 people work for the company.
Judge Warren G. Morgan met briefly with lawyers after adjourning the hearing, but did not immediately rule on Mr. Fisher's request for a temporary injunction.
During the hearing, the former chief executive of Hershey, Richard A. Zimmerman, testified for the state, saying any buyer would cut spending to make up for the cost of the purchase. "There's no doubt in my mind there would be some massive changes," he said.
Jack Stover, a lawyer for the trust and for its sole beneficiary, the Milton Hershey School, argued that the attorney general had no authority to interfere.
Mr. Stover said the trust was pursuing a sale because it needed to diversify its holdings. Nearly 59 percent of the trust's holdings are in Hershey Foods stock.
James Bailey, an investment adviser to the trustees, testified that the trust's portfolio "is twice as risky as the typical portfolio of a college or university."
Mr. Fisher, who attended the hearing but did not argue the case, said he expected a ruling later this week on the temporary injunction.
Shares of Hershey fell 15 cents, to $75.60.

HEADLINE: Working-Class Students Go to Boarding School 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
They are hard-working black and Hispanic parents who have high hopes for their daughters. They have tried, often in vain, to keep their daughters from the distractions of sitcoms, the telephone and the hustle and bustle of the streets. So when words came that their daughters had been chosen to enroll in a boarding school in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, at virtually no charge, these parents jumped at the chance.
 "Boarding school in the 'hood," said Lashawn Hamilton, a token-booth worker whose daughter received a scholarship to the school. "That's good. That's good. That's good." 
 This fall, Catherine McAuley High School, a 60-year-old Catholic girls' school in a working-class section of Brooklyn, will begin enrolling 20 boarding students, whose room and board and education will be financed by a nonprofit organization. The aim is to insulate the students from the attractions of society and improve their chances of entering four-year colleges.
Boarding schools are a rarity in New York City. While some of the prestigious private schools were boarding schools at the turn of the century, all but one have become day schools.
"There are so many affluent people living in New York City, and they are the ones sending their children to the city's private schools," said Victoria Goldman, co-author of "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools and Selective Public Schools," a popular book among city parents. "Their homes are close by. Their kids don't need to board."
Still, some educators believe that a boarding school environment would help children from neighborhoods brimming with distractions and from homes lacking stability because of divorce or unemployment.
"As much as we can do for them during school," said Joseph Viteritti, a professor of education policy at New York University, "children from low-income families don't have the same support that middle-class children get at home. Their parents might need to work a second job."
"The network of support boarding schools provide will help these students to focus on their schoolwork," he added, "so they will not be hanging out on the street corners in the afternoons. It will provide them with a structure."
And structure defines the new boarding school program. 
The students will get up at 6:45 every day and go to bed at 11. In between, every minute will be accounted for; the girls will attend school, take dance and self-defense classes in their dormitory gym and prepare for meals. Two house parents will supervise the girls 24 hours a day, and the ratio of students to residential parents will be kept at 10 to 1, even as the program expands. 
No visitors will be allowed, and no trips outside the building permitted. The girls will return home every weekend.
Barbara Welles, whose previous jobs involved raising money to help disadvantaged children, founded the Anchor Program, which is financing the boarding program. Ms. Welles said the boarding high school she attended in Massachusetts had sheltered her from the discord at her Chicago home when she was a teenager. 
"I know what it's like to have a lot going on at your home," she said. "I saw first-hand what a difference boarding schools could make. It's hard to see it and not do something about it."
Friendly with Wall Street investment bankers because of her previous positions, Ms. Welles raised $1.2 million for the Anchor Program among prominent figures in the financial world. 
Last year, Ms. Welles approached guidance counselors in some of the city's lowest-performing school districts and asked them to recommend students for the boarding program. The students filled out an application and were interviewed, and successful applicants will be supported by the program until they graduate.
It will cost $12,000 to provide room and board for each student for nine months. Catherine McAuley High, picked by Ms. Welles from nine schools that had expressed interest in the boarding program, will not earn a profit from housing the teenagers, but it welcomes the tuition dollars brought in by the new students, paid for largely by Anchor. 
Ms. Welles plans to expand the boarding program at Catherine McAuley to 60 girls in a couple of years, and she intends to create similar programs at other private schools. Though Catherine McAuley is a parochial school, the Roman Catholic Church is not otherwise involved in the Anchor Program.
The dormitory at Catherine McAuley, a modest but cheery brick building in a neighborhood of neat row houses, does not resemble the buildings at Andover, the alma mater of the Bushes, or Choate, which John F. Kennedy attended. Still, the twin-sized bed covered with floral-print sheets and the spotless mirror and sink in each room impressed the girls, who attended an orientation session with their parents on a recent Sunday.
The students will move into the dormitory, a former convent, tomorrow. Classes begin on Monday. 
The parents seemed far more concerned about the imminent departure of their children than the students themselves. At the orientation, the parents bombarded the residential counselors with questions: "What will happen when my child gets sick?" and the like. 
While the parents were nearby, the girls seemed to echo their views, but as soon as the school principal led the parents to a separate meeting, Monique Robinson, a freshman, blurted out: "I am gonna be away from home! That's the best part!" 
All the girls laughed and started clapping. Jaquoya Williams, a junior from Harlem, said she would rather not return home on weekends. "I want to go to somewhere like China," she said.
The girls worried about the length of the skirts that are part of their school uniforms (too long) and the mandatory evening study sessions (also too long), and asked questions quite different from their parents'.
"Can I listen to the Walkman during the study hours?" Jaquoya asked a counselor. "I just cannot study in complete silence." (Answer: no.)
When the time came to pick a single or double room, Monique seemed less certain about her new independence. She decided to ask for a double.
"Because I know the first night," she said with an impish grin, "I am gonna be scared, and I want to be scared with somebody."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anissa Brathwaite, left, and her sister Kaye checking dormitory rooms at Catherine McAuley High School, in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, during a recent orientation day for a new boarding program. (Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Manufacturers Reduce Output As Orders Fall 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
Manufacturing stalled in August, a report released today by the Institute for Supply Management showed, as orders declined for the first time in nine months and production slowed.
 The drop in new orders "signals a warning," said Norbert Ore, head of the institute's survey of manufacturers and director of purchasing at the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. "We've lost a lot of momentum." 
 The factory index held at 50.5 last month, lower than expected and below the average of 53.8 for the first seven months of this year.
"What little manufacturing we have seems to come from consumer demand," said Richard Yamarone, chief economist at Argus Research in New York. "Until businesses begin to invest, we can't expect to see robust manufacturing."
The institute's new-orders index fell to 49.7, the first contraction since November 2001, from 50.4 in July. The orders index had risen as high as 65.3 in March, as companies responded to signs that the economy was rebounding from recession. The production index slipped to 55.6 in August from 55.7.
August was the seventh month that the factory index has held above 50, the dividing line between expansion and contraction among manufacturers. The institute says that an index reading of 42.7 is consistent with the break between expansion and contraction over all in the gross domestic product.
That means that the August reading "is consistent with G.D.P. growth of 2.5 to 3 percent," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
Before the report, the median of 48 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey was for a reading of 51.8.
The institute, based in Tempe, Ariz., surveys more than 400 companies in 20 industries.
Its index of inventories rose to 45.2 from 41.8, indicating that stockpiles of unsold goods were being run down at a slower pace. The employment index rose to 45.8 from 45, suggesting that manufacturers were still restrained in hiring.
A gauge of prices paid by manufacturers for materials and supplies fell to 61.5 last month from 68.3.
A separate survey yesterday showed that layoff announcements rose 46 percent in August from July. Businesses outlined plans to eliminate 118,067 jobs, compared with 80,966 in July and 140,019 in August 2001, according to an outplacement firm, Challenger, Gray & Christmas.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Bertelsmann to Drop Mostof a Book Unit

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
Bertelsmann confirmed plans today to abandon the bulk of its online bookselling service, BOL.
 The company said it was exploring a "variety of possible withdrawal scenarios" from BOL's businesses in Germany, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Sweden. 
 Executives said those options ranged from a sale to a management-led buyout to shutting them down.
Bertelsmann said it would retain BOL's joint venture in Italy and its operations in China.
It also said it had no immediate plans to dispose of its 36.2 percent stake in Barnesandnoble.com, the American online bookseller, or of BeMusic, the direct marketing arm of the Bertelsmann Music Group.
Bertelsmann also announced today that its first-half profit was lifted by the sale of the company's largest investment in the Web, its stake in America Online.
The company said its net income more than doubled in the first six months, to 1.63 billion euros ($1.6 billion), largely because of the proceeds of the sale of its remaining shares in AOL. 
But Bertelsmann is still struggling through the advertising recession. It said its sales fell to 8.83 billion euros ($8.65 billion), from 9.29 billion euros ($9.1 billion), because of lower ad revenue.
