HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
A Suburb Finds That Outlying Development Is Hurting Its Downtown

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, Wash. 

 BODY:
This is the story of identical twin buildings born 14 years apart.
 Here in Vancouver, a community just across the Columbia River from Portland, Ore., job growth is stagnant and real estate development can be a zero-sum game played by two competing economic forces. 
 "For years, Vancouver has been viewed as a bedroom community of Portland, and they're trying to make their own identity," said Terry S. Shanley, managing director of the Portland office of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate services firm. "But they're caught in the same national economy that everybody is." 
The city is spending tens of millions of dollars to draw development downtown, but Westfield Shoppingtown, also known as the Vancouver Mall, situated five miles northeast, is pulling development away. For the moment, the mall is winning, and the evidence is the impending delivery of Parkway Plaza 4, the long-gestating twin of Parkway Plaza 3.
The two Parkway buildings were conceived in 1988, when a developer named Gregory L. Specht secured entitlements and design approvals from Clark County to raise two more 50,000-square-foot buildings in an office complex near the mall, about five miles from downtown.
Mr. Specht built Parkway Plaza 3, a curved red brick structure with stripes of tinted glass, in 1989. Every so often since then, he has looked over from Parkway Plaza 3, where tenants pay an average of $20 a square foot annually, at the empty corner lot next door that was intended for Parkway Plaza 4 but remains overgrown with weeds.
By Mr. Specht's reckoning it would cost $175 a square foot, or around $8.8 million, to build Parkway Plaza 4, and tenants would have to be willing to pay $24 a square foot to generate a decent return for the developer and his financiers.
"I'm a bit surprised that anyone would want to take Parkway Plaza 4, because you'd have to get $24, and we're only getting $20 next door," Mr. Specht said.
But someone does want to take it.
Dennis Pavlina works right around the corner, where his wife runs the Management Group, a company that operates residential properties. His own company is called the Gold Medal Group, and it has some experience building multifamily housing units.
Mr. Pavlina started in the business as a construction laborer. "I didn't want to have to work with my hands and my back every day of my life," he said, so he began buying distressed properties where there might be demand for apartment buildings. He and his wife "decided that I would put them up and she would manage them." 
He has never developed an office building like this before, but that empty field around the corner was almost teasing him. It was only after he put in an offer to buy the land earlier this year that Mr. Pavlina discovered that much of the early work had been done for him.
The county had approved a master site plan for the area, including many of the specifications for Parkway Plaza 4, some 14 years ago, before Vancouver annexed the area to capture the tax revenues from the shopping mall. 
So after what Mr. Pavlina describes as -- literally -- five minutes of negotiating with a landowner named Graham Bryce, Mr. Pavlina bought the 2.2 acres next to Parkway Plaza 3 for $925,000 in April, planning to follow all the original specifications for Parkway Plaza 4 laid out 14 years ago.
"We had to," Mr. Pavlina said. "That's where the value is."
To complement the entitlements and design approvals, Mr. Pavlina has obtained a grading permit, allowing him to start preparing the land for construction, and he has applied for building permits. Because the city left the approvals in place with a grandfather clause when it annexed the property from the county, Mr. Pavlina thinks that he can complete the project for only $7 million. And that he can get $24 a square foot from tenants by marketing this building as the newest thing in the little Vancouver Mall submarket (or sub-submarket, if you ask some brokers who consider Vancouver itself a suburb of Portland).
While modest, Mr. Pavlina's debut is the only office development under way in Vancouver. As economic incentives, a popular shopping mall and an old building permit long relegated to oblivion have trumped more than $18 million in city spending to attract development downtown.
Downtown, the city has built a four-level $12 million subterranean parking garage with 850 spaces. It has also spent more than $2 million to rejuvenate Esther Short Park and more than $4 million to provide parking for the West Coast Bank Building, an office building completed last year that tests the city's vertical horizon at five stories.
The underground parking garage was intended to serve a $100 million multiuse project by VanDevCo, a limited liability corporation formed by a developer called the Belbadi Group of the United Arab Emirates. So far, the group has built the first two of four buildings, containing market rate rental apartments, but no work is being done on the second two, planned to hold condominiums and retail stores as well as 160,000 square feet of office space.. The parking garage is complete and open for business.
"The city in the meantime has to own and operate it, so it's not going to be profitable until the office space is up and occupied," said H. Roger Qualman, executive vice president of Norris, Beggs & Simpson, a brokerage firm here that is affiliated with the international commercial real estate services firm NAI.
The chamber of commerce and the city are trying to create a business improvement district to attract retailers to the traditional center of Vancouver, in the bend of the Columbia River where Lewis and Clark landed and the Hudson's Bay Company operated a trading post until the United States pushed the British farther north. Mr. Qualman said that the area near the shopping mall, with relatively inexpensive land values and abundant surface parking, presented a significant challenge to that effort.
On the downtown streets, the colorful banners promoting Vancouver do little to brighten the dilapidated record store and the dark tavern with a window for walk-up service.
Attracting development is "hard to do in an older downtown that's been allowed to deteriorate," Mr. Qualman said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Sept. 4 about commercial real estate in Vancouver, Wash., referred incorrectly to two residential buildings and an underground parking garage that are part of a downtown project. While the buildings are substantially completed, they are not yet occupied. The garage is scheduled to open in March; it is not already in use.

HEADLINE: REGIONAL MARKET: The Bronx; 
From Graffiti to High Hopes for a Desolate Area

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Paul Travis recalls that the thought first struck him as he was driving along the Major Deegan Expressway and glanced at a graffiti-scarred warehouse: despite the look of the building and the ones next to it, the site -- in a Bronx neighborhood that is technically part of Manhattan -- could be a prime retail location.
 In the two and a half years since then, Mr. Travis, a principal of Kingsbridge Associates, a Manhattan development company, bought not only the warehouse, which was formerly used by Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center to store medical records, but also five smaller adjacent commercial structures. 
 The plan is to replace all six buildings with a 230,000-square-foot retail center, including a Target department store, on 9.45 sloping acres alongside the Harlem River and adjacent to the Major Deegan Expressway and West 225th Street, which becomes West Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx. 
"If you look at the boroughs, the West Bronx and Upper Manhattan is the single most underserved area for retailers and commercial uses," Mr. Travis said. "It's a totally unmet market."
The site, he added, is near mass transit stations as well as major roadways, and 350,000 people with median household incomes of $53,000 live within a mile and a half of it.
Construction of the $80 million development in the Marble Hill neighborhood is expected to begin in November and finish by spring 2004. It will include three one- and two-story buildings and house up to 16 stores, all with separate entrances facing West 225th Street, as well as a small amount of office space. 
The Target store, with 120,000 square feet, will anchor the complex. The other tenants, including one restaurant, will occupy spaces ranging from 2,500 to 35,000 square feet. There will be parking for 809 cars.
The Target store will be the first outlet in the Bronx for the Minneapolis-based chain, which has two stores in Queens and will open one in Brooklyn in October. Douglas Kline, a spokesman for Target, would not comment on the planned Bronx store, saying only that his company's policy was not to discuss a store until "often after construction has begun."
The Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrion Jr., confirmed, however, that Target was the anchor. He said the overall project, which was reviewed by Community Board 7 in the Bronx, had been "received relatively well" by residents. 
"There will be some impact," Mr. Carrion added, referring to traffic. "But in the end the pluses outweigh the minuses." He said the project would also generate 600 retail jobs.
Walther G. Delgado, executive director of the nonprofit Audubon Partnership for Economic Development of Manhattan, which serves Marble Hill, added that the project would "help spark a renewal of the desolate area." 
Faith Hope Consolo, vice chairman of Garrick-Aug, the Manhattan retail brokerage firm, said that having as strong a tenant as Target would be important to the development's success.
The neighborhood's commercial district is centered on Broadway, which has such chains as Stop & Shop and Loehmann's, the clothing retailer. Both are on the northern end of the Broadway shopping area. 
Mr. Travis said, and Mr. Delgado agreed, that the proposed center, designed by Greenberg Farrow Architecture of Manhattan, would anchor Broadway's southern end. The added hope, both men said, is that it will encourage people to remain in the area to shop rather than go to Westchester County or New Jersey. 
Financing is coming from the developer's own equity, a loan from North Fork Bank and the tenants. 
Though Mr. Travis would not disclose rents, he said they would be competitive. Ms. Consolo said annual rents for stores in the area now average $20 to $30 a square foot and could go to $40 to $50 a square foot when the project is completed.
Building on the site involves several challenges that added four months to the construction schedule and 10 percent to the cost, said Jeffrey M. Brown. He is president of the Manhattan company bearing his name that will construct the project.
For example, because the site is along the river and because century-old sewers run beneath it, some 1,300 piles must be driven to support the structure.
Other challenges included cleaning the site of contaminants and the existing buildings of asbestos, a process that has been completed.
Technically, part of the new shopping center will be in Manhattan. The Marble Hill neighborhood is geographically in the Bronx, but through a twist of history it is politically still part of Manhattan. The twist was the filling in of the former Spuyten Duyvil Creek after the digging of the Harlem River Ship Canal in 1895, a process that detached Marble Hill from the rest of Manhattan and connected it to the mainland.

HEADLINE: Zambian Leader Defends Ban On Genetically Altered Foods 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
The president of Zambia said today that his country, which is inching toward famine, would continue to refuse relief food that may be genetically modified, calling such food "poison" and saying it is "intrinsically dangerous."
 Speaking to journalists at the United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development here in South Africa's biggest city, President Levy Mwanawasa said the desperate plight of his nation would not drive him to disregard his better judgment and accept genetically modified food. 
 "I'm not prepared to accept that we should use our people as guinea pigs," Mr. Mwanawasa said. 
Zambia and five other countries in southern Africa are critically short of corn, the staple in the region, and the World Food Program is carrying out a relief operation for more than 13 million people.
The food agency is already feeding just over a million Zambians, and agency officials predict that the number will approach 2.5 million by the end of the year.
Much of the aid being earmarked for the region is from the United States, where crops genetically engineered for better production are widely grown and the foods produced from them are widely consumed.
The United States says that it is donating the same food Americans eat and that in any case, it has nothing else to offer. 
Last week, the head of the Agency for International Development visited Zambia to urge the government to distribute the American food already in the country and accept the additional supplies headed there. This week, the world food agency's director, James T. Morris, is flying into the region, seeking to allay the hungry countries' concerns.
Genetically modified foods, which entered American commercial markets in the mid-1990's, have been the subject of intense international debate among environmental activists and consumer advocates, particularly in European Union countries.
Critics say such foods have not been sufficiently tested. Regulators in the United States, along with many scientists, counter that extensive studies already carried out have not found any reason to believe that the products are not safe to eat.
But along with fearing possible health effects, critics have said that planting genetically modified seeds could threaten the diversity of a country's plant and animal life. In Zambia's case, that could complicate and perhaps even jeopardize trade with the European Union. 
Such food is grown and eaten in parts of the union, but the union has generally been more circumspect. It mandates, for instance, that genetically modified foods be labeled. 
With its limited capacity for scientific food analysis, Zambia, now nominally free of genetically modified food, would not be able to keep modified crops separate if it did introduce them.
Lesotho, Malawi and Swaziland have accepted the modified food. Mozambique and Zimbabwe have insisted that corn be milled before being distributed, to eliminate any risk that genetically engineered seeds could cross-pollinate with naturally occurring seeds.
But President Mwanawasa and his agriculture minister say that even if the corn were milled, too many questions remain unanswered, namely whether eating such food poses health risks. "We may be poor and experiencing severe food shortages," Mr. Mwanawasa said, "but we aren't ready to expose our people to ill-defined risks."
At the invitation of the United States, a team of Zambian scientists will be visiting to meet with American experts on genetically modified organisms, said Mr. Mwanawasa, who added that he remained "open to conclusive scientific evidence."

HEADLINE: Candidates' Ads Responding to Public Insecurity 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 27 

 BODY:
With the approach of the first major elections since last year's terrorist attacks, candidates are responding to a sense of public insecurity with commercials that try to inspire confidence in their character and their ability to handle a crisis.
 Republicans and Democrats running for Congress, for governor and for local offices are trying to soothe voters with what are essentially comfort-food advertisements in which they offer reassurances for anxious people in a troubled economy and a turbulent world. 
 Almost none of the commercials raise the terrorist attacks overtly; consultants deem that too frightening and too inflammatory. Few even mention Sept. 11. Instead, in somber tones, often with a flag in the background, the candidates are taking perennial issues -- the economy, health care, Social Security -- and subtly reframing them. With words like "protect" and "preserve," they emphasize their character traits and values -- experience and level-headedness, strength and caring -- as symbols for their dependability in uncertain times. 
If candidates cannot quite guarantee "homeland" security, they are offering what Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant, calls "close to home" security.
"In this uneasy environment," Ms. Gorlin said, "candidates have come to talk about security as Social Security, pension security, the security of knowing that if you're laid off in Iowa, at least your children will have health coverage, the security that comes with prescription drug coverage, the security of knowing that white-collar criminals who threaten their employees' jobs and retirements will be severely punished."
Here in Iowa, a radio advertisement promises that Representative Jim Leach, a Republican who says he is preoccupied with the powder keg in the Middle East, will not "play politics with America's future."
In Mississippi, a commercial for Representative Ronnie Shows, a Democrat, offers stability on a bedrock issue. "He believes your Social Security should be a sure thing and not stock-market roulette," his advertisement says.
In Delaware, in one of the few overt references to Sept. 11, Ray Clatworthy, a Republican candidate for Senate, tells radio listeners he is a graduate of the Naval Academy, flew fighter jets in the Marines and wants "to make sure that we are a vigilant nation, that we're a strong nation and that we win this war on terrorism."
Darryl Roberts, a Democrat in Oklahoma who spent 30 years in the Marine Corps, rolls all these ideas into one, saying in one commercial that voters "deserve a congressman with the military experience to protect Tinker and Fort Sill and the determination to improve public schools and health care."
The perceived gold standard of security, of course, is in New York, where former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who gained international stature with his command of his city under siege, is appearing in commercials for Gov. George E. Pataki.
The former mayor praises Mr. Pataki for "giving us a sense of purpose that we didn't have before." No need to say before what.
Representative Thomas M. Davis III, the Virginia Republican who heads his party's House campaign committee, said he would deploy Mr. Giuliani, in dozens of districts, saying his endorsement was "the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval."
"Many races in the past have been based on hope versus fear," said Stuart Stevens, Republican consultant and media adviser to George W. Bush in 2000. "This year, it's anxiety versus reassurance."
Donny Deutsch, chief executive of the Deutsch advertising agency in New York, said consumers, whether searching for a product or a politician, want the same thing -- "comfort and security."
"Nobody wants snide or in your face," Mr. Deutsch said. "People want safe, sure, back to basics." He cited with approval a new black-and-white Sears advertisement that evokes scenes from the 1950's and conveys endurance and reliability.
While candidates are shying from a direct link with Sept. 11, interest groups are exploiting it. The Sierra Club, for one, is running commercials about the danger of relying on foreign oil and urging the auto industry to promote better fuel efficiency.
"We ask our young men and women to sacrifice their safety and perhaps their lives to fight the war against terrorism," former Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska and a decorated Vietnam veteran, says in a Sierra Club advertisement. "Surely we can do something here at home to help." 
An anti-immigration group called Californians for Population Stabilization is running a commercial that says: "It's time for Congress to halt mass immigration until the I.N.S. can tell a terrorist from a tourist. If we don't, who knows where terrorists will strike next." An image of the Diablo Canyon Power Plant comes on the screen.
Such images are perceived as too hot for individual candidates. 
Ms. Gorlin said that in the past candidates would advertise their position on issues as a way to convey their values. Now, she said, candidates are promoting their values -- their solidity, their ability to understand the problems of regular people, their distaste for corporate crooks -- as a proxy for where they stand on issues. As a result, experience is promoted more now than it was a few short years ago when the rallying cry was for term limits.
The emergence of this kind of advertising results partly from the fact that candidates generally want to sound positive as they begin their campaigns. But also, with the Sept. 11 anniversary looming, they want to sound in sync with the national mood.
Experts cautioned that while the underlying theme of security might be useful in establishing a candidate's values, it may give way closer to Election Day, Nov. 5, to more traditional attacks.
"There is still a tremendous skepticism about either party's ability to offer much in the way of real solace and comfort," said Carter Eskew, a Democratic consultant who worked for Al Gore in 2000. "It will remain to be seen whether 'security' is a redefinition of the landscape or whether, when it runs its course, candidates will revert to the traditional 'I'm better than the other guy.' "
But for now, many candidates are speaking to voters' vulnerability on issues across the board and putting aside negativity and harsh attacks.
"The American people are not in the mood to be entertained," said David Axelrod, a Democratic consultant based in Chicago. "They're very sober and serious and concerned about real problems and they want people to address those problems without varnish."
Here in Iowa, the candidates are doing just that. Mr. Leach, a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, is more internationalist in his approach. He is disturbed over the Bush administration's inclination to invade Iraq, and he says his constituents are, too.
"There is deep concern at the idea of our intervening without being attacked and concern that the repercussions in the Muslim world could be absolutely gigantic and that we would be precipitating the clash of civilizations," he said.
His Democratic opponent, Dr. Julie Thomas, a pediatrician, is offering a more personal kind of security. Her commercials show her treating patients, and she uses comforting language, offering protection not just for voters' health but "protection against corporate fraud like Enron."
Being a doctor, she said, gives her a natural advantage when talking about security. "People do trust their physicians for good advice and for solving problems," Dr. Thomas said.

HEADLINE: Free-Market Upheaval Grinds Mexico's Middle Class 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
By Mexican standards, Alvaro Alvarez and Alma Amarillas are a solid middle-class couple. But in the 20 years they have worked to build a stable life for themselves and their children, the economic ground beneath them has never stopped shaking. 
 She works double shifts as a public school teacher and administrator. He has quit teaching to work as a personnel manager for the government. Together they make about $24,000 a year. But they have little more to show for their life's labor than the roof over their heads. 
 They have not been able to save a penny. They spend more than half their monthly income on their mortgage. Their safety net is a credit card with a $300 limit. And they have diminishing hope that their two daughters will live better than they do. 
"We live day to day," Ms. Amarillas said. "We never know when there will be a new crisis. I panic when the girls get a fever or the car sounds funny. 
"I don't think much anymore about how our situation will improve," she added. "I worry more about how it could get worse." 
It has been two decades since Mexico committed itself to free-market reforms aimed at propelling this country into the developed world. The North American Free Trade Agreement, considered the centerpiece of the new Mexican philosophy, has generated a quarter trillion dollars in cross-border trade with the United States. The treaty helped turn a closed, inefficient economy dominated by state-owned companies into one that was flooded by foreign investment and driven by foreign competition. 
But government statistics show that economic liberalization has done little to close the huge divide between the privileged few and the poor, and left the middle class worse off than before. Battered by a series of severe recessions, teachers and engineers, nurses and small-business men, all find themselves swinging above and below the poverty line with the rise and fall of the peso, interest rates and the unemployment rate. 
According to a recent government report, in the year 2000 half the Mexican population lived on about $4 a day, with scarcity shifting along with the population from rural regions to cities. Some 10 percent of Mexicans at the top of the income pyramid controlled close to 40 percent of the nation's wealth. 
Meanwhile, the 35 percent of Mexico's population that lives in the middle -- with average earnings of about $1,000 a month -- spirals slowly downward.
The economist Rogelio Ramirez de la O said that in the 1970's, when Mexico's population was 50 million people and the country had begun to enjoy the benefits of an oil boom, some 60 percent of Mexicans were middle and working class. Their numbers and buying power have declined "dramatically" since then, Mr. Ramirez said.
"The promises of economic modernization have not been fulfilled," he added, and Mexico's middle class "now has less buying power than a generation ago." 
The development of a middle class was a shining achievement of the Mexican revolution, said the historian Lorenzo Meyer. Incubated in a closed economy that was driven by state-owned monopolies, the middle class grew steadily from the 1920's to the 1970's. Faced with declining economic efficiency and a mounting public debt, successive presidents opened Mexico's protected economy, igniting an industrial revolution that turned the country into one of the world's leading exporters.
In an effort to reduce its external debt, the government simultaneously slashed spending for higher education, transportation and health care -- all traditional pillars of middle-class life. 
"The idea of Mexico as a middle-class country is a delusion," Mr. Meyer said. "This is a country of extremes."
It is not a unique predicament in Latin America, a region that has long suffered some of the greatest inequalities of wealth in the world. However, it seems a sorry outcome for a nation that adopted the economic tenets of globalization as gospel. It is particularly bitter for the middle class, the very people who powered the rise of President Vicente Fox, whose election two years ago brought down the dictatorial 71-year regime of the Institutional Revolutionary Party.
In addition to advocating the expansion of Nafta, Mr. Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive, also promoted a more even distribution of wealth. He promised to create more than a million new jobs a year, increase government spending on education and health care and make low-interest loans available to small and medium-sized businesses. 
In his state of the union address on Sunday, Mr. Fox highlighted how his sound fiscal policies had helped keep the country afloat, while Mexico's neighbors to the south had become mired in crises that have crushed their middle classes. The Mexican peso is strong, inflation is projected to decline to 4 percent annually and levels of foreign investment have remained stable. A government welfare program started by Mr. Fox's predecessor, Ernesto Zedillo, has been renamed and expanded to include more than two million new families. 
"We have achieved change without violence, without crisis, with great economic stability," Mr. Fox said in a conversation with foreign correspondents last week. "That is very important." 
Still, the benefits of the nation's current economic stability have yet to ripple through a Mexican society that increasingly measures itself by North American standards. More than a million jobs have been lost since Mr. Fox was inaugurated, many of them in manufacturing. Congress has blocked or watered down Mr. Fox's tax and energy plans, aimed at increasing government funds for social programs and at increasing the supply of electricity to keep up with soaring demand.
Several new plans for stimulating economic growth in 250 of the poorest regions of Mexico, including infrastructure projects and micro-loans that help peasants start homespun businesses, have just come off the government's drawing board. A survey in Mexico City found that only 30 percent of small and medium-sized businesses used banks for financing because of high interest rates and stringent terms. 
The financial roller-coaster ride of Salvador Jimenez, a college-educated accountant, is typical. Mr. Jimenez decided to go into business for himself nine years ago, and then nearly lost his shoe store at the end of 1994 when the peso was devalued by 50 percent and the principal of his business loan doubled.
With contributions from his family, Mr. Jimenez, 39, has managed to pay off his debt. His store is back in the black, but earns profits of only about $800 a month. To make ends meet, the single father of 13-year-old twin boys does accounting work for all his neighbors. And his former wife, a lawyer in Chicago, regularly sends money. 
"The middle class is falling, falling, falling," he said. "We need help. We need credit." 
A government demographer, Rodolfo Tuiran, referred to the 1980's and 1990's as "lost decades," and said the Mexican middle class responded to the cycles of crisis by sending women and children to work and by incorporating members of their extended families into their households. 
An increasing number of middle-class men and women have joined the exodus of Mexican immigrants to the United States, Mr. Tuiran said, with one out of 17 professionals abandoning the country in the last two decades. 
"That is a significant loss of human capital," he said. "It is an expression of the growing gap between the expectations people have for access to higher education and careers, and the realities of our country, which is not opening sufficient opportunities."

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: IN HIS OWN WORDS/Donald H. Rumsfeld; 
'The American People Have Got the Staying Power for This'

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview with Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Secretary of Defense, reflecting on events since the Sept. 11 attacks. Except for some remarks that were not intended for quotation, the full interview is online at nytimes.com.

Q -- Mr. Secretary, since you came into this office the phrase asymmetrical threat has now entered the popular vernacular in a way that it wouldn't have otherwise.

A -- I don't like it. I wish I knew an alternative. I wish I knew a better way of saying "weapons of mass destruction." And if I had some time, I'd sit down and think about it. . . .

Q -- Speaking about Al Qaeda and terror networks. In some ways they're a virtual enemy, in that they have leaders and they have budgets and they have command-and-control and they can wreak terrible damage and they're like a country with an army -- but they don't have a country, they don't have headquarters -- they are a virtual enemy.
 What you do in this building, what the military does, is completely real and solid. What are some of the new things you think this building and this military have to learn to do to fight an enemy that's a virtual enemy? 

A -- The first thing it has to do, as always, is to acknowledge the fact. Once having done that, recognize that in addition to the other things that it always has done, or needs to do, for deterrence and defense, those things haven't disappeared; we also have to begin to develop the ability to live in the world that you've described.
You do that by recognizing that the world's changed, understanding the ways it's changed and the way those changes disadvantage you as a country, and then providing leadership in this institution so that down through the building and the establishment, there is an understanding that we need to organize, train and equip to live in that world. 
Business as usual won't do it. 
There are a lot of implications of that change, and one of them is the need for being swift on your feet, and big institutions aren't swift on their feet. They're ponderous and clumsy and slow, powerful over time, but not deft.
One thing about the world you described is that it learns every day. It goes to school on you. It watches how you're behaving and then alters and adjusts at relatively little cost, relatively little time, relatively little training to those incremental changes we make in how we do things. 
And our changes tend to be slower, more costly and visible. Their changes can be cheaper, quicker, and for a period -- a longer period than in our case -- but for a period, invisible. So there is that advantage as well as the obvious advantage that the attacker has against the defender. . . .

Q -- Another very important thing -- I know our time is running short -- that came up yesterday, your frustration with the focus on Iraq. Putting aside the newspaper's view of that, but you think it detracts from looking at the broader picture, the global war on terror, weapons of mass destruction.
It's an interesting role in which you cast yourself. As defense secretary, we've talked before how you try to describe the financial and economic impact of war and peace to the countries with whom you negotiate. You seem to also be -- I don't know what the word is -- the beacon for trying to keep America focused on this long picture, the bigger threat. Not Iraq, but everything else that's out there.
That must be a hard job because most of America was not affected by 9/11 except emotionally, psychologically. You were a teenager in World War II. You remember a time of shortages and curfews and all that. That doesn't exist in America now. So how can you keep this country better focused on this long war?

A -- Well, you're right, I do feel it's part of my responsibility to do that.
And as I've said so often, it's your in-box that tends to distract you. And to the extent you spent all day working on your in-box instead of fashioning an out-box that then others read and react off of, then you're reactive and your decisions are ad hoc and therefore random.
Unless you have a longer perspective in a leadership post and plant some standards way down the road, so that the daily in-box items can be tested against those things, you're going to be like the fellow in the sailboat where the rudder doesn't work. You're just going to be milling around.
Unless you have a direction and some speed and you're under way, you can't calibrate your direction. No one can get it right perfectly the first time. You need to set a direction and then you need to calibrate it. If you don't have any steerageway, you're not going forward, you can't calibrate it. 
And if you haven't developed a longer-term view, every one of your daily decisions -- you can do your very best to take them the best you can, but they'll be random because they've not been tested against something.
So my biggest task and problem is to push away the immediate and force myself to address the important, and to try to look down the road and see that we do have a direction, that we do have steerageway, that we can then adjust and calibrate as we learn every day, and goodness knows, I hope we learn every day.

Q -- One more question on the way ahead. Many of the issues that are confronting you now are the same issues from last summer -- which are budgets, force structure, procurement, weapon systems, that sort of thing.
Elsewhere in the administration, people have said the '04 budget is really the last Bush budget before the campaign season starts for him. How will that affect what you do as secretary of defense in this building, with one more clean shot at a defense budget? 

A -- It makes it very important, there's no question. The '04-'09 budget is -- we have been here long enough to have put our people in place, which was not true last year. We have been here long enough to have turned over enough rocks to get a sense of where the problems are. We've not been here long enough to have intervened in all these two- and three- and four-year cycles that exist around here.
But we have been able to identify a series of studies that needed to be done and some cross-cutting looks at things.
I think that we've got work going on that, in probably half to three-quarters of the instances, we probably will have the study done or far enough along that it should inform the process that takes place from August, September, October, November around here and benefit those decisions.
A couple of things. The other things will have to be, like a lot of things in life, 60, 70, 80 percent decisions, where you've got about 60, 70, 80 percent of the information you think you need, and it's going to take one or two or three years to find the last 20 percent, and therefore you bite the bullet and go. 
I think that we'll undoubtedly make investments, for example, that will improve our intelligence capability and improve our ability to interact with the rest of the intelligence community and the C.I.A., but I don't think it will -- we've not gotten a new person in place i.e., an under secretary of defense that will take a look at all the intelligence. . . . 
One thing we're talking about that could conceivably help -- and I think is interesting that it doesn't exist -- is joint ConOps, a concept of operation that's joint.
If you had that it would inform the process of establishing requirements. If you establish requirements out of the services and then the CINC's commanders opine on requirements, and they are coming from separate perspectives, it will undoubtedly produce a more difficult process and decisions that would be different than if you did it a different way. 
The different way would be, maybe, to decide that you're going to have a joint concept of operations for several models of how to do the kinds of things you might need to do, and get agreement on that, and have that determine requirements. And it's interesting that in the year 2002, that doesn't exist.
Whether we'll be able to do that, how fast we'll be able to do that, whether it will be sufficiently useful the first time that you try to do it, is a question that remains before us. 
But my hope is that between now and a year from now, that we will have done that, and that the budget that we're building a year from this fall will be informed by a process like that, where you would have had extensive involvement by CINC's as well as service chiefs, and force up on the table a set of issues that otherwise don't get forced up.
Just like . . . the Defense Planning Guidance forced up the issues of how you begin to balance risks: war risks, against personnel risks, against transformation risks, against modernization risks. 
People were able to go out and trade off among those things but not between those things -- they could trade off within a category. And in life, tradeoffs are okay, but they tend to be more power- or political-based -- I don't mean politics, I mean a judgment or a tradeoff that's based on something other than a substantive look at what is needed could conceivably end up where, well, the Army gets this, the Marines get that, the Navy gets this and the Air Force gets that. 
That's not the way one ought to be deciding how things ought to be taken care of out there, and what kinds of things we're going to need. But as you well know, that's tended to be the history of this building.
So we have got a lot going on and I think ---- You said I sounded frustrated on the Iraq question. I'm not frustrated. What I'm trying to do is to get people's eyes up on what I think to be the big issue that needs to be talked about, and is going to help inform a lot of issues, a lot of people's ways of thinking about things and looking at things.

Q -- But the default mode of any democracy is peace. Americans, as you know, bless them all, don't want to be at war, they want to relax. So it's a challenge.

A -- Sure it is. My impression is that the American people have got the staying power for this. You look at what we did during the cold war: Generation after generation, from 1950, took money they would prefer to spend on other things, invested into the defense establishment, put troops overseas.
A lot of people think they were left there after World War II. They weren't left there. They were brought home and sent back, and troops were put there because they needed a deterrent and they needed a defense capability and because leadership stuck at it, and from Truman on, provided the kind of leadership that was needed, and not just in our country but in European countries. . . . 
In country after country, leaders kind of rose to the top and persuaded and informed the American people so that they gained the support necessary to make investments, in a time of peace, to make investments that would enable us to defend if necessary -- but preferably deter -- against a very serious, persistent, expansionist, powerful threat that was not visible, that wasn't there every minute, that people wanted to debate against as to whether it even existed, and the American people had the staying power. And they will this time.
My hope is that they'll have it because of the fact that the need is there and that democratic people, free people, have a pretty good center of gravity. The other way they'll have it, is if we're punctuated periodically with additional terrorist attacks that remind us that we do have an obligation to ourselves and our system and our friends and allies around the world to behave responsibly.

HEADLINE: Broad Accord Reached at Global Environment Meeting 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Wednesday, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
After a week of intensive negotiations, diplomats here at the World Summit on Sustainable Development arrived at a plan early this morning that is intended to reduce poverty and preserve the earth's natural resources.
 The breakthrough came after diplomats worked late into the night on Tuesday to resolve a dispute over language in the conference's plan on health care for women. 
 Also on Tuesday, Russia announced that it would ratify the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty intended to ease global warming -- a move virtually ensuring that the treaty would go into effect despite its rejection by the United States.
Canada wanted the words "in conformity with human rights and fundamental freedoms" linked to health care to avoid condoning practices like female genital mutilation. Representatives of developing countries initially opposed the language, but backed down this morning. 
"We're very pleased," Kelly Morgan, a spokeswoman for the Canadian delegation, said. "We are finished."
The plan is meant to set the global agenda for coming years. It calls on nations to reduce by half the number of poor people who lack sanitation by 2015; to commit to the sound management of chemicals with the goal of minimizing their adverse effects on health and nature by 2020; and to reduce significantly by 2010 the number of animals and plants having endangered status.
The plan calls for the reduction of agricultural subsidies in wealthy countries, which, poor nations say, protect farmers in the United States and Europe from competition. It also urges nations to promote renewable energy sources like solar and wind power as well as to expand access to energy services by the poor.
Officials from the United States and the United Nations praised the document, but it was sharply assailed by environmentalists and advocates for the poor, who complained that wealthy countries had weakened the language.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell flew in late on Tuesday and will make a speech here today.
The United States, along with Canada, Japan and oil-producing countries, blocked an effort by the European Union to set a target and a timetable for the conversion from oil and gas to renewable sources of energy. The Europeans had sought a commitment to ensuring that renewable energy sources would account for 15 percent of the world's total energy production by 2010. But American officials opposed the target, saying they preferred concrete action to goals that might ultimately prove meaningless.
In the end, the nations agreed to promote an increase in renewable energy, but rejected the specific target and time frame, officials said.
The United States praised the plan and the negotiations that preceded it. "It's a message of hope to impoverished areas of the world," said John F. Turner, assistant secretary of state for oceans and international environmental and scientific affairs. "I think it builds an excellent framework for going forward." 
But Brooks Yeager of the World Wildlife Fund said most environmentalists were disappointed. "We're particularly disappointed at the outcome of the energy discussions," he said.
The secretary general of the conference, Nitin Desai, emphasized that leaders had succeeded in finding common ground in difficult discussions. But he, too, acknowledged that the plan was weaker than many hoped. "In some areas," he said, "I wish we could have done more." 
Russia's decision was hailed as a step forward in the struggle to prevent the droughts, floods and agricultural disruptions many experts think is caused by climate change.
Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov said Russia planned to ratify the Kyoto treaty "in the very near future." Diplomats said they expected ratification by the end of the year.
The treaty would set the first binding restrictions on releases of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases by industrial nations.
Officials also said they hoped Russia's decision would put more pressure on President Bush, who angered many leaders last year when he rejected the accord. But Mr. Bush maintains that it could harm the American economy and that it is unfair because the required emissions cuts apply only to industrial powers, not to fast-growing developing countries like China and India.
Among treaty supporters, Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada pledged to push his Parliament to ratify the treaty by the end of the year.
Environmentalists said they thought Russia was waiting to ratify the treaty in an effort to win concessions in other areas, like increased financial aid or compensation for maintaining vast forests that emit carbon dioxide.
China announced today that it had ratified the treaty, but American officials said that did not change their position. As it now stands, the Kyoto accord does not require China to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.

HEADLINE: Cheap Power Gone, Montana Is to Vote on Buying Dams 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: ENNIS, Mont., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Even with little population growth and a lack of high-wage jobs, Montana could always count on a few good things. There was cheap electricity, thanks to a power company with the personality of a rich, domineering uncle, and there were river trout that could make people forget their troubles in a hurry.
 The trout are still here. But the cheap power and the company that delivered it are gone. Now many people here say Montana has lost what little economic self-determination it had, and they blame one of the few new economic notions that did find a home here, briefly, in the 1990's: deregulation. 
 In a populist campaign reminiscent of old battles against Eastern railroads and California copper barons, Montanans are to vote this fall on a measure that could lead to a public takeover of 12 hydroelectric dams owned by out-of-state corporations. The proposal, Initiative 145, would set in motion a process by which the state might buy the dams, through either negotiation with the owners or condemnation. 
Opponents say the proposal would amount to brazen property confiscation that would do little to ease high power rates. But it is those escalating utility bills, in a state that consistently ranks among the nation's poorest, that are driving the campaign to take over electric power.
The push to buy the dams of Montana is part of a broader reaction to the energy and telecom deals that were hatched on Wall Street and changed the face of utilities that in some states had been enduring institutions. When companies like Enron and WorldCom expanded by buying one utility after another, their customers were mere observers. Now, in the aftermath of those companies' collapse, and with electricity bills moving steadily higher, the public in far-flung American towns is clamoring for a say.
Sold as a way to bring choice and lower utility bills, power deregulation is now about as welcome as drought, at least in the West. The debacle of California's experiment, which may end up costing the state as much as $30 billion and has led to criminal inquiries into alleged price manipulation, looms large as Californians try to return to a regulated market.
But other states are backing away as well. On Aug. 27, the Arizona Corporation Commission, which regulates that state's utilities, voted unanimously to halt a six-year drive toward deregulated electricity. The commission, whose vote keeps some of the state's major power providers from divesting themselves of their generating plants, said deregulation could expose consumers to market manipulation and price gouging.
Portland, Ore., meanwhile, is moving ahead with a plan to acquire, perhaps through condemnation, Portland General Electric, a utility owned by the bankrupt Enron Corporation. The utility, with 742,000 customers, infuriated many of them with a 40 percent rate increase last fall. Portland city officials say that if the utility were publicly run, it could offer energy at much lower prices.
Deregulation can still work, supporters say, if it is set up properly. But that is a hard sell in Montana, where people like to feel a personal connection to the institutions that govern their lives.
From his house above the backed-up Madison River near this little tourist town in far southern Montana, James Bond can see water become electricity as it courses through a small dam. Mr. Bond, a veterinarian, wonders if that power is going out of state while his utility bills go up.
"When I can see the dam from my house and I can't get the power from that dam," he said, "it doesn't make a whole lot of sense."
The dam here used to be owned by the Montana Power Company, once the state's dominant corporation. In earlier incarnations, Montana Power was part of a conglomerate that ran mines, timber operations and newspapers, and had an iron grip on political power under the big sky.
That sway over the Statehouse was still evident when, at the end of the 1997 legislative session, Montana Power, looking to get out of the stodgy, regulated utility business, pushed through a deregulation bill, which made its assets more attractive to prospective buyers. The company said the public would benefit, with lower costs and more consumer choices. 
The Legislature, made up mostly of farmers, ranchers and small-business owners, approved the measure with little hesitation. "The dining, the free drinks, the contributions -- it all paid off when Montana Power called in its chips," said Hal Harper, a former speaker of the Montana House, who has been both a Republican and a Democrat but is now out of politics. "We're stuck with the bill."
Montana Power sold its generating plants to the PPL Corporation of Allentown, Pa., a company that sells power in more than 40 states and numerous countries. The once-thriving Montana Power Company got into the Internet service provider business, becoming Touch America, and has nearly collapsed with the implosion of the telecom industry, losing more than 90 percent of its market value.
The first shock of deregulation here was felt by business. In a fourth year of increases, power prices soared to unheard-of levels in 2001. Paper companies, mines and other industries that provide some of Montana's few good-paying jobs began to close or lay off workers because they could not afford to pay their electricity bills.
For residential consumers, whom the deregulation law shielded from the first four years of price jumps, bills started to go up this summer, and will rise again next summer.
Owners of the dams, backed by some union officials and the leaders of the Republican-controlled state government, are challenging the initiative in court while raising nearly $1 million to build a political campaign against it. That sum is huge in a state like Montana, where the cost of advertising is low, and where supporters of the initiative expect to have little money.
The raw emotion of the issue has already made its way into court filings. "The prospect of some Montana residents having to choose between heating and eating is not so unrealistic," Jim Reynolds, a lawyer for a group called Dam Cheap Power, wrote in support of allowing voters to have their say.
The dams' owners -- in addition to PPL, a Spokane company named Avista could lose a dam -- are leaving nothing to chance. In focus groups, they have found that people are very upset over deregulation but also do not like the idea of government's condemning private property, said Aidan Myhre, a spokeswoman for Taxpayers Against Initiative 145.
"Property rights works in our favor, but deregulation is just not popular," Ms. Myhre said. She said her side would argue that the state could not run power plants efficiently and that Montana could not sit on the sidelines of global business.
"We live in a global environment, and Montana is not this little cell that can determine its own destiny," she said. "Besides, there is no guarantee that if the state were to take over the dams, they could offer lower prices."
Though few polls yet give a good indication of where the electorate stands, Ms. Myhre said the dams' owners would have to "educate people."
A yes vote would not automatically lead to state purchase of the dams. It would set up a commission to determine whether it made sense for the state to buy the dams and run them. If so, the state would either negotiate to buy them or condemn them and pay market value for them. Revenue bonds of as much as $500 million would finance the acquisition. 
The initiative's supporters cite the Montana Constitution, which says all rivers in the state are to be used for the benefit of Montanans.
"A river running downhill -- there's no cheaper power in the world, because there are no fuel costs," said State Senator Ken Toole, a Democrat who is a leader of the buy-the-dams campaign. "We have this in our backyard. Yet we went from some of the cheapest power rates in the nation to some of the highest."

GRAPHIC: Photo: This dam at Thompson Falls, Mont., is among those the state may buy if voters approve a ballot initiative. (Tim Thompson for The New York Times)(pg. A16)

HEADLINE: And Now There Are Two 

 BODY:
Andrew Cuomo's withdrawal from the Democratic primary for governor of New York was a moment of drama in a contest that had otherwise sorely lacked pizazz. Bill Clinton brought down the house by assuring everyone at Mr. Cuomo's press conference that he, Mr. Clinton, was the only person on the stage whose political career was over. (The line worked so well that he repeated it.) Representative Charles Rangel, who was furious when Mr. Cuomo tried to stand in the way of Carl McCall's becoming the state's first black Democratic governor, was all smiles. And Mr. Cuomo himself, who had appeared to be cruising toward a career-ending political defeat on primary day, salvaged his future options. 
 That leaves the voters with two major-party choices this fall, and plenty of time for a vigorous contest between Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, and Gov. George Pataki. Mr. McCall is going to have to campaign hard against Mr. Pataki, the current front-runner, and both men need to answer tough questions about the state's future. 
 At the top of that list is what to do about the Potemkin budget. Anybody with even a modest understanding of state finances realizes that the current financial plan is a house of cards, built on a huge and growing gap in revenues. Nobody in Albany, especially Comptroller McCall and Governor Pataki, should be allowed to get away with this charade. Both need to declare what they would do next year, when the state budget gap could stretch to $7 billion. Each candidate needs to go on record and answer how -- specifically -- he would pay this huge public bill. Whose favorite program will be cut -- specifically? Will he borrow even more and thus eat into the state's extremely shaky bond rating? Will those promised tax cuts be delayed or even ditched altogether? Voters should demand a no-surprises rule from these contenders.
Both candidates will also have to do more than talk about campaign finance reform. Mr. Pataki and Mr. McCall show little remorse about harvesting money by the truckloads, much of it from private interests that want their say in Albany. Mr. Pataki announced a campaign finance reform plan on the last day of the legislative session in 1999. He reaped the credit, then let the whole idea lie fallow. Mr. McCall has promised to push for such reforms but has himself accepted funds from people who have connections to his comptroller's office. Neither side is showing any real leadership or courage on this issue.
Mr. Pataki must answer for the delay in reforming the Rockefeller drug laws that lock addicts into long mandatory sentences, and he must explain the failure to increase the minimum wage. Mr. McCall will have to assure voters that he can find a way to improve the upstate economy at the same time he matches Mr. Pataki's environmental record. The rebuilding of downtown Manhattan deserves more focus on the emotional and financial needs of the city, not merely today but in the decades to come.
The departing Mr. Cuomo says he intends to continue speaking out about the dysfunctional state of the political culture in Albany. We hope he keeps his word. Mr. Cuomo deserves credit for raising this issue in the campaign. No politician could do a greater service to New York than in spreading unease through the ever-complacent ranks of state government.

HEADLINE: Canada Central Bank Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Citing uncertain prospects for the American economy and turbulent financial markets, the Bank of Canada said today that it would leave its key overnight interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent after three consecutive increases since April.
 The bank said that while "stronger-than-expected growth in domestic demand in Canada continues," prospects for growth in the United States -- where 85 percent of Canada's exports go -- and other major economies "appear to have weakened somewhat." 
 The Bank of Canada has plenty of company. The Reserve Bank of Australia said today that it would leave its overnight rate at 4.75 percent for a third consecutive month after quarter-point increases in May and June. Australia's economy grew a slower-than-expected 0.6 percent in the second quarter from the previous three months and retail sales fell in July. 
The Bank of England is expected to announce on Thursday that it will keep its key rate, the repo rate, at 4 percent, for the ninth straight month. Last month, the European Central Bank left its benchmark minimum refinancing bid rate at 3.25 percent for the ninth consecutive month; the Bank of Japan has left its monetary policy unchanged, holding rates at close to zero for a year and a half; and the United States Federal Reserve has kept its federal funds rate at 1.75 percent, where it has been since December.
Canada's economy remains buoyant. Gross domestic product expanded at an inflation-adjusted annual rate of 4.3 percent in the second quarter and 6.2 percent in the first, the strongest first-half growth of any industrial nation. By comparison, the United States posted a 1.1 percent growth rate in the second quarter.
Avery Shenfeld, senior economist at CIBC World Markets in Toronto, ascribed Canada's relatively sturdy performance to its heavier dependence on the automotive and energy industries, both of which have grown strongly this year. The troubled technology and telecommunications industries make up a smaller component of the economy in Canada than in the United States.
Fearing that strong growth would unleash new inflationary pressures, the Bank of Canada moved its overnight rate up by a quarter percentage point at each of the previous three policy settings. Though it held the rate steady this time, it said today that if the economy continued to expand, further interest rate increases would be necessary to maintain the bank's inflation target of 2 percent. The bank's next monetary policy statement is scheduled for Oct. 16.
Mr. Shenfeld said today's decision to leave rates unchanged showed that the central bank "is more willing to recognize that Canada is not an island in the world economy."
Edward Carmichael, chief economist at J. P. Morgan Canada, wrote in a report today that second-quarter growth was propelled by inventory building. Growth in the third quarter is likely to be slower as domestic demand and exports slacken, Mr. Carmichael said.

HEADLINE: ABB to Sell Its Finance Unit to G.E. for $2.3 Billion 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
ABB said today that it had agreed to sell most of its financing unit to General Electric for $2.3 billion in cash.
 The Zurich-based ABB, a Swiss-Swedish builder of heavy machinery and electric power systems, is selling assets to pay off debt as it grapples with slumping demand for its products and mounting costs of asbestos-related lawsuits. The company has suffered a series of embarrassments in the last year, including a narrowly averted financial crisis and a public dispute with two former senior executives over their large retirement pay packages. 
 Jorgen Centerman, the chief executive, said the sale today was in line with a strategy of focusing on the power and automation businesses and shoring up the balance sheet by disposing of other assets. All the proceeds will go to retire debts, reducing the company's total to $2.9 billion from $5.2 billion at the end of June.
The acquisition will allow G.E., through its commercial finance subsidiary, to expand its toehold in the European structured-finance market. G.E. will take over loans, leases and other financial assets with a face value of $3.8 billion; it will also assume $1.2 billion in liabilities. Together, the two financing businesses operate in 100 countries and employ 150,000 people.
"ABB is one of the foremost European players in structured finance," said Cornelius Wijtvliet of F. van Lanschot Bankiers. "It will give G.E. a stronger grip on Europe."
Excluded from the deal are ABB Export Bank, an aircraft leasing company and ABB's 35 percent stake in the Swedish Export Credit Corporation. ABB said today that it was in talks to sell them, too, along with about $200 million in real estate.
ABB will also retain control of about $900 million in leasing assets related to its power and automation businesses, representing about 15 percent of its structured finance unit. And ABB will keep a financial advisory subsidiary that serves customers for its industrial projects.
Investors applauded ABB's efforts to get its finances in order. Its shares rose more than 13 percent in Swiss trading, to 8.65 Swiss francs ($5.88). G.E.'s shares rose 24 cents, to $28.70.
ABB has had a rough year, including deteriorating operating results, a sliding share price and management defections. Percy Barnevik, the longtime chairman, who supervised the merger that created ABB and was later frequently compared to John F. Welch Jr. of G.E., resigned in November after an uproar over $140 million in pension benefits -- an extraordinary figure by European standards -- that were awarded to Mr. Barnevik and another executive. 
The company lost $691 million in 2001, its first losing year, and posted a further $13 million loss in the second quarter of 2002, largely because of asbestos-related liability claims in the United States. The claims stem from industrial boilers made in the 1970's by Combustion Engineering, which was later bought by ABB. Though ABB eventually sold the company again, it retained responsibility for the liabilities.
Investors grew so concerned about ABB's prospects that willing buyers could not be found for an issue of the company's unsecured short-term notes, known as commercial paper, prompting Mr. Centerman to warn in March that ABB faced a cash squeeze.
ABB made it through that crisis by issuing bonds instead, but soon put the financing division up for sale.
G.E. took advantage of ABB's distress and drove a favorable bargain, analysts said. "G.E. knows these businesses very well," said Mark Demos of Fifth Third Investment Advisors. "And G.E. was in a better negotiating position than ABB."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
In a City of Foreshadowing

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
"HE who is last had best laugh," wrote Gore Vidal of Romulus Augustus, the last ruler of imperial Rome. In the 18th century, as the sun set on yet another Italian empire, the Venetians lived by this comic-apocalyptic code.
 Not all of them carried on as gaudily as Casanova, the era's most colorful figure. Unspeakable misery befell prisoners held in secret chambers within the Palace of the Doges. But the spirit of Carnivale, still celebrated in Venice each February, was the era's presiding cast of mind. 
 That genius lives on at Ca' Rezzonico, Venice's sumptuous museum of 18th-century art and life. Though the palazzo's rich residents have long since disappeared, the harlequins remain, or at least Giandomenico Tiepolo's lively renderings of them. Ca' Rezzonico is now a gallery of ghosts, haunted by cavorting pulcinellas, stragglers from the glittering parties for which the house was built. 
Closed for renovations for more than a decade, the museum re-opened last year without much fanfare. Some belated trumpets, please. Those headed to Venice this month for the Eighth International Architecture Exhibition at the Biennale should not pass up the chance to visit this giant reliquary of a maritime power in its years of decline. A few may get a shock of recognition from the parallels between that era's restless pursuit of pleasure and our own. And the jewel of the Ca' Rezzonico's collection must on no account be missed: a panoramic fresco by Tiepolo titled "Il Mondo Nuovo" ("The New World").
The mural was painted by Tiepolo for his own mainland villa in the 1790's. In this surprisingly modern painting, Tiepolo depicts a cross section of Venetian society lining up for a magic lantern show of glass slides painted with North American views. A hazy, fluid background suggests distant horizons.
It is startling for an American, two centuries later, to gaze back at a crowd of Venetians straining to peer ahead toward us. Their Old World is collapsing. Our Mondo Nuovo beckons. Looking at the painting now, it may occur to some viewers that the situation is reversed. Exhausted by a long cold war and disoriented by its aftermath, some Americans now gaze across the Atlantic for tips on surviving triumphal success.
Though the 1,000-year-old Venetian Republic did not formally expire until 1797, the city's golden age had passed long before work began on the Ca' Rezzonnico. The expense of protecting its Mediterranean empire from the Turks was ruinous. The value of maintaining the empire had declined with the opening of new trade routes to the south and east.
As revenues from foreign trade shriveled, Venice turned in on itself to keep up opulent appearances. Casino gambling was perhaps the most publicly conspicuous of its schemes. A more genteel form of income derived from the marketing of patrician prestige. Arrivistes could buy their way into the Golden Book, official honor roll of the city's most illustrious families.
The Rezzonicos, a Genoese banking family, entered the rolls in 1687 at a cost of 100,000 ducats paid directly to the Venetian treasury. Completed in 1756, their house is a tribute to the rise in their social position. But half a century after moving in, the Rezzonicos had faded from history, impoverished by the cost of maintaining the house in the style to which it had become accustomed.
The Rezzonicos were not the first to be overextended by this imposing palazzo Broke-coco. They acquired the property in 1751 from the Bons, patricians of ancient lineage who were driven into bankruptcy by construction costs well before the house was finished. The house is thus the work of two Baroque masters: Baldassarre Longhena, architect of the magnificent Church of the Salute, who began it in 1649, and Giorgio Massari, who finished it 100 years later.
But its classical design can be seen as a symptom of Venetian decline. In the city's mightiest years, Venetian architects built in a Gothic style fused with Byzantine intricacy. The Venetian Gothic style reflected the city's view of itself as the "third Rome," an imperial lineage inherited, along with much military plunder, from Constantinople. Turning its back on the Italian mainland, Venice faced eastward across the sea.
The Renaissance, which came late to Venice, signified a major readjustment in the city's identity. As its control over the eastern Mediterranean waned, Venice recast itself in a Western image. The Baroque, the agitated style of rejuvenated, papal Rome, saw Venice through to its merry 18th-century end.
Ca' Rezzonico is as much house as museum, despite the grandeur with which the occupants lived. It is not a showplace for artistic masterworks, unless you rank lifestyle as an art. The displays are varied, ranging from an apothecary shop to chairs of such overwhelming sculptural ambition that their use as functional objects defies the imagination.
Come prepared for neck strain: the museum's most imposing artworks are the ceiling frescoes in the major rooms. Frescoes by Giandomenico Tiepolo's more celebrated father, Giambattista , depict the rise of the Rezzonicos with overblown metaphors. One, in the Nuptial Allegory Room, celebrates the family's alliance by marriage with the Savorgnans, a venerable Venetian dynasty. In the Throne Room, the figure of Merit holds the Golden Book: amid a celestial panorama of chariots and clouds, the party-crasher is transformed into the gatekeeper.
A gallery devoted to the work of Pietro Longhi presents Venice on a less exalted plane. Longhi's subject is the city's daily life, especially as it was enacted within the domestic interior. Painted in small scale, and displayed salon style on the walls, these richly human scenes absorb the visitor more deeply into 18th-century Venice than the palace itself. How much more extraordinary the city's watery reflections must have been in the days before electric light!
The Ca' Rezzonico's restoration is a pet project of Franca Coin, president of the Venice International Foundation, a group that supports the official civic museums of Venice. With her husband, Piergiorgio, of the Coin department store empire, Ms. Coin resides in another fabled palace on the Grand Canal, Palazzo Barbaro, where Henry James often stayed. James wrote "The Aspern Papers" in the house, and it inspired the palazzo in "The Wings of the Dove." The present owner is, James might say, "magnificent." Her passions range from the rebuilding of La Fenice opera house to welcoming young American artists and architects in town for the Biennale.
Giandomenico Tiepolo's frescoes have been restored with additional funding from the American organization Save Venice. In them, he satirizes the society his official commissions glorify. Dancing couples tippy-toe back and forth, trapped within their vast stupidity and the contraction of their place in a world of widening horizons.
Those horizons are the subject of Tiepolo's "Il Mondo Nuovo." With its pastel colors and flatness of surface, the painting looks surprisingly modern -- as if Tiepolo has not merely gazed at the distance but crossed over into it in his imagination. He reached the New World well over a century before Alex Katz was born. In this painting, Ca' Rezzonico offers a vista far more profound than the particular pleasures of architecture, painting and the manners of an age. We see here a critical pivot in urban history: how a city's end feeds into a new beginning.
Tiepolo's fresco foretells characteristics of our world. It depicts the concept of mass spectacle, for example, along with its power to cut across traditional distinctions of social class. In addition, it shows the hypnotic lure of the image. In contrast to the passion for authenticity that fueled the retrieval of St. Mark's remains from the Holy Lands and their interment in the basilica, the magic lantern beckons people into the sensory field of simulation.
Above all, perhaps, "Il Mondo Nuovo" illustrates the larger meaning of its title. People are lining up not merely to behold images of the New World, but to enter into the mythological world of the New. The novel. The next big thing. The painting looks toward the future of Venice itself: the creative international showcase that the city has become.
This weekend, for example, a cosmopolitan audience will be lining up for the opening day of the 2002 Venice Architecture Biennale, the world's foremost event of its kind. (The show runs from Sunday to Nov. 3; www.labiennale.org for information.) Titled "Next," this year's edition of the Biennale features sketches and models of buildings now on the drawing boards or under construction around the world. Though the emphasis is on the pragmatic side of building, "Next" will nonetheless showcase ideas, images and simulations, a selective and imaginary vision of a world to come. Beyond that, the exhibition crystallizes a global development already under way: the recasting of older urban centers within a cosmopolitan framework.
There presently exists no livelier forum for the exchange of ideas on the changing relationships between cities in the era of economic globalization. Nor does any other city's architectural heritage crystallize more perfectly the cosmopolitan idea than Venice itself. Ruskin recognized this when he called the Doges' Palace "the central building of the world" for its fusion of architectural influences from northern and southern Europe and the Orient. Today, the city occupies a pivotal position in the West as an international platform for urban visions.
Venice hasn't made a bad show of things since Napoleon took over, actually. It has spent the succeeding two centuries triumphing over its own political and economic demise. In the 19th century, the city was spiritual home to Romantics everywhere. It devoted the 20th century to Proust, fabulous parties and the most advanced developments in art, architecture and film.
A backwater in the industrial age, Venice has entered the 21st century way ahead of its time, as industrial cities now try to remake themselves as centers of cultural production. Who's got the last laugh now?
