HEADLINE: Here's to Working Less, and Living More 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Why Americans Should Rest" (Op-Ed, Sept. 2), Juliet Schor describes the phenomenon of the overworked American and how the combination of Sept. 11, the economy and corporate scandals may make this a perfect time to re-evaluate our workaholic work ethic. 
 This is indeed true, and what it will require is a paradigm shift. 
Employees need to demand more time away from work as a priority factor to staying with an employer. 
Employers need to buy in to the concept that more vacation time is a prerequisite to a productive work force.
There is already a framework for this type of change. A decade ago, employees demanded child care at work as a prerequisite to working after having children. Employers realized that the only way to keep trained, productive employees was to offer child care. Everyone benefited, and they will again. 

LINDA KUPFER
Rockville, Md., Sept. 2, 2002

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Profit Down 

BYLINE:  By Paul Meller (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Poor weather in Europe and logistical problems in the United States and Russia hit first-half earnings at the Belgian brewer Interbrew, the company said. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization fell 12 percent, compared with the first six months of 2001. 
A legal dispute with the Mexican drinks distributor Fomento Economico Mexicano has held up the integration of the recently acquired German beer Beck into Interbrew's brand lineup in the United States. Meanwhile, the Belgian company's Russian brewer Sun has lost market share by failing to switch to plastic bottles from its unpopular glass ones quickly enough. The chief executive, Hugo Powell, said that apart from these problems the first-half results were pleasing. Second-half results will suffer from the continued poor weather in Europe, he said. Brewing operations in the Czech Republic were halted by the severe flooding in August. He said it was too early to estimate the impact of the floods on sales. Paul Meller (NYT)

HEADLINE: Financing Ends Some Doubts About Qwest 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Clearing away concerns that it could be forced into bankruptcy before the end of the year, Qwest Communications International announced arrangements yesterday with bankers to borrow $750 million and extend by two years a $3.39 billion credit line that was scheduled to expire next May.
 As expected, Qwest's lenders also relaxed requirements on how profitable Qwest has to be each quarter to avoid a default on the credit line. 
 The $750 million loan was obtained by QwestDex, the company's phone directory subsidiary, and must be repaid when Qwest completes its previously announced deal to sell QwestDex for $7.05 billion to a group of financiers. 
"Coupled with the pending sale of QwestDex, these actions announced today and the cash flow from our operations should provide us with enough funding for the next several years and put any liquidity concerns behind us," Oren Shaffer, Qwest's vice chairman and chief financial officer, said in a written statement.
Qwest is the dominant local phone carrier in 14 Western states and a provider of long-distance phone and data services in other regions. Some skeptics warned yesterday that none of the maneuvering addressed Qwest's long-term chances of dealing with its $26.3 billion debt load.
"This is a short-term reprieve," said Scott Cleland, an analyst at the Precursor Group in Washington. "It just means they'll be weaker when they do go into bankruptcy."
In addition to its financial woes, Qwest faces criminal and regulatory investigations of its accounting. Analysts say it will need favorable settlements, cost-cutting, more asset sales and a strong rebound in business to avoid bankruptcy.
Qwest is paying a stiff premium of 3.5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the Libor rate, an international benchmark interest rate, to extend its credit line and relax covenants that set requirements for minimum earnings before interest, depreciation, taxes and amortization, or Ebitda.
Those covenants required Qwest to earn enough that debts did not exceed 4.25 times Ebitda in the current quarter or 4 times Ebitda by the end of the year. With its business deteriorating, Qwest had warned that it might violate the covenants this quarter and, at any rate, most analysts had assumed the tougher year-end requirement was out of reach.
The agreements announced today allow debts to rise to a maximum of six times Ebitda. But the banks took steps to minimize their exposure in extending the credit line. It must be paid down to $2 billion when the first part of the QwestDex sale is completed, which is expected before the end of this year. It must be reduced to $1.25 billion when the second phase of the sale closes, which will be next year if all goes smoothly.
Qwest's battered stock and bonds had been strengthening recently in anticipation of the agreements, which were announced after the markets closed yesterday. Qwest's shares closed at $3.60, up 34 cents, or 10.4 percent yesterday. They rose as high as $3.89 in after-hours trading.

HEADLINE: As Schools Open in New York, Mayor Sits Front and Center 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
More than a million New York City students will return today to a school system now in the hands of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a chancellor who serves at his pleasure, with new and potentially powerful tools to bring about change.
 The biggest cloud looming over the system is Mr. Bloomberg's plan to cut $378 million from the schools budget of nearly $12 billion, starting with $100 million this month. But Mr. Bloomberg and Joel I. Klein, the new chancellor, have promised that the cuts will not affect instruction and other student services, saying they will come from the central and district administrative budgets. 
 Mr. Klein submitted a list of proposed cuts to City Hall yesterday, and though it was not made public, several officials said the cuts did not appear to affect classrooms. In fact, the officials said, the initial cuts might be closer to $65 million because of unanticipated savings from the summer school program, among other things.
"Student-related services are being kept sacrosanct," said Steven Sanders, chairman of the State Assembly's education committee. "There is a very clear directive that is going out from the chancellor to the superintendents that no cuts of any kind can be realized from those areas."
Mr. Bloomberg clearly has more of an interest than previous mayors in protecting classroom budgets, because schools are now his responsibility and he has asked that his term as mayor be judged by how much they improve.
But like many of his predecessors, Mr. Bloomberg has complained bitterly about administrative waste in the school system. He and Mr. Klein are expected to study the system's budget intensely this year in hopes of pinpointing needless spending.
Budget worries aside, the school year is starting on an unusually calm note, in part because of a contract agreement that raised teacher salaries as much as 22 percent. The raises, combined with the flagging economy, prompted thousands of state-certified teachers to apply for jobs here, easing a teacher shortage that made for chaotic school openings in recent years.
In exchange for raises, the city's 80,000 teachers have agreed to work 100 extra minutes a week, devoting half of that time to training and half to working with students. As a result, the school day will start 20 minutes earlier this year, a change that the Education Department was trying to communicate to parents until the last minute yesterday with automated phone calls and public service announcements.
Mr. Bloomberg would have preferred that all the extra time be used for instruction, but even under the compromise he reached with the teachers' union, students should be in class for the equivalent of four extra days a year.
In another change, the Justice Department has approved a plan to strip community school boards of their role in hiring the superintendents who oversee instruction in the city's 32 school districts. Mr. Bloomberg got the Legislature to sign off on the change in June, saying that if he controlled the school system, he and his chancellor should have the sole power to hire and fire superintendents. Until now, the chancellor had to choose from lists submitted by the local boards, which have been criticized as politically motivated and sometimes corrupt.
Mr. Klein used his new power for the first time yesterday, appointing a superintendent for Harlem's District 5. Although the local school board had recommended several candidates, Mr. Klein chose someone else: Dennis Pradier, a deputy superintendent in the chancellor's district of low-performing schools.
Mr. Klein has not set an instructional agenda, though he said in a meeting with reporters on Tuesday that his tenure should be judged by "what I do in terms of performance of students in the schools." 
His deputy for teaching and learning, Diana Lam, will not start for a few weeks, as she is wrapping up business in Providence, R.I., where she has been the schools superintendent since 1999. Schools in Providence and San Antonio, where Ms. Lam worked in the early 1990's, improved under her tenure, and she will be under pressure to raise test scores here. Mr. Klein clearly has faith in her abilities: he is paying her $250,000 a year, $82,000 more than his other deputies and as much as Mr. Klein himself is earning.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: PERSPECTIVES/Gerhard Schroder; 
'No One Has a Clear Idea About What the Effects Would Be'

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, reflecting on events since Sept. 11. The interview was conducted in German and translated by The New York Times. 

Q Did Sept. 11 really change the world, or is that just an American way of looking at it?

A First of all, it is understandable that the reaction in America, which for the first time was attacked on its own territory, was more intense than in the rest of the world. But it was also interesting for me to observe how much it affected the Germans, for example, and others as well. The large demonstration in Berlin by 200,000 or 300,000 people was in fact a spontaneous expression of sympathy and solidarity. And I also experienced it much closer to home -- if I may be permitted to say so -- since my wife had once lived not far away, on the Upper West Side. . . .
 I believe it not only changed America, but also the world, in two ways: first, it was astounding how fast and how impressively this international coalition came into being. One said that the offer of support was a self-evident duty as a friend. And Germany agreed to break with tradition in deploying military forces outside Europe. 
But that is only one side of it. I think the other side is that changes have taken place because the analysis of the threat had to be changed. That is to say, in the past, countries or alliances felt themselves threatened by other countries or alliances. That was, after all, the classic confrontation in the cold war. What happened in New York and Washington -- this attack on the two cities and on the people in them -- has shown that there is a privatized form of war, waged by terrorist organizations, and that we have to defend ourselves against this using appropriate means, including military means.
So I believe two things have changed. First there is the question: who is threatening the civilized world? Not only countries, but also forms of privatized violence that never used to exist in this form. And the second remarkable thing is the unity at the United Nations, rallying an international coalition against terror. It is important to keep the awareness of both alive. . . . 
I asked myself why the attack on New York affected so many people in the world in such a special way. I think the answer has to do with the special importance that this city has always had for all those who were forced to or wanted to leave their own country. New York is thus a symbol of asylum. This was very much the case during the Nazi period in Germany. . . .

Q Your new defense minister, Peter Struck, said there was no threat to Germany from Saddam Hussein, and Condi Rice, of course, said the whole world was threatened.

A I think the truth lies somewhere in the middle. There is no question that dictators represent a threat. And the crucial question is: what can they do and what would they like to do to realize their threats? The problem with Saddam is making up our minds what scope for political and military action he has. Politically, he has none, unless one forces the Arab world into solidarity with him. Militarily, I believe it is hard to judge.
In my view, the threat may be overestimated by people like Ms. Rice, and underestimated by others. That is why I was one of those who were disappointed that a change of objectives took place as regards the treatment of Saddam Hussein. I think that we -- all of us, together -- had isolated him politically, and that there was a real opportunity of using diplomatic and economic pressure to get the inspectors admitted to the country again. The moment the debate in the United States put an end to the objective of exerting every possible kind of pressure to get the inspectors readmitted to the country so that we could discover what the real situation was, and not have to rely on surmises or intelligence reports -- the moment this objective was changed, the real problem began. 
How can you exert pressure on someone by saying to them: Even if you accede to our demands, we will destroy you? I think that was a change of strategy in the United States -- whatever the explanation may be -- a change that made things difficult for others, including ourselves.
That is one thing. The other thing is consultations. In the past it was always said: Before we do anything, we will consult with our principal allies -- at least with those who take an active, very active part in the fight against international terrorism. But consultation cannot mean that I get a phone call two hours in advance only to be told, "We're going in." Consultation among grown-up nations has to mean not just consultation about the how and the when, but also about the whether.

Q Do you believe that Cheney speaks for President Bush?

A I am not qualified to say. The problem is that he has or seems to have committed himself so strongly that it is hard to imagine how he can climb down. And that is the real problem, that not only I have, but that all of us in Europe have. I think that a mistake has been made. It may be understandable in terms of domestic politics, but it has, of course, made things much more difficult for all those who were in agreement with the original objective of exerting pressure to have the inspectors admitted to the country.
After Sept. 11, the situation was quite different. We were among those whose military participation was likely to be requested, and we were all agreed there would be military action. And in that situation, where there is a need for secrecy, for the element of surprise, it is enough to be notified of the start of the operation just ahead of CNN or The New York Times. 
The essential point is that everyone agrees on the question of whether something is going to happen. If we agree about that, we can then form different opinions, so to speak, about questions of when and how. That is the vital difference from Sept. 11. It was because I was inwardly convinced and had also been consulted that I said at the time: This thing has to be done, and I am going to force it through even if I have to call a vote of confidence, for the situation was not easy in Germany, especially with that coalition. 
And that is why it is just not good enough if I learn from the American press about a speech which clearly states: We are going to do it, no matter what the world or our allies think. That is no way to treat others.
But there is another question that must be answered. According to my information, no one has a really clear idea of the political order that would follow in the Middle East. And such an idea is needed. No one has a clear idea about what the effects would be in the moderate Arab countries or what new political order might emerge after a military intervention in Iraq. 
What I find particularly worrying, incidentally, is that there is so little discussion of the economic consequences for the world economy. . . . 
There is another point I consider important. Germany is at present, after the United States, the second-largest provider of troops for international missions. We have almost 10,000 soldiers in the Balkans, involved in Enduring Freedom, and in Afghanistan. In 1998 we spent 170 million euros on international missions. This year it will be around 2 billion euros. I only mention this to make clear that no one can criticize us for lacking international solidarity. That is the one thing.
The other thing is that I was in Kabul and took a very close look at the situation. Germany is contributing a great deal to the international security force, perhaps more than any other country. I don't want to be unjust to the others, but I think this estimate is not far out. My concern is that we have not even begun to achieve in Afghanistan anything that could be called nation-building. Yet if that is not succeeding before the eyes of the whole world, what advantage are the masses in the third world going to see in the restoration of a country to the civilized world? 
What I mean to say is, we have to prove that a return to the civilized community of nations brings a prosperity dividend. And many people are watching what is happening in Afghanistan. We are deeply committed there, and that is why I say: Before we have made any progress there, before we have proved to the disenfranchised masses in the third world that it is worth their while to return to the Western fold, to the civilized world, I would say that military interventions -- in whatever terms they may be justified -- tend to be counterproductive for the international coalition against terror.

Q I first understood you to say, no unilateral action in Iraq. Then later you seemed to say Germany will not participate in an attack or help pay for one no matter what the U.N. says. Which is it?

A Let me begin by saying that without a U.N. Security Council mandate, our Constitution would not permit any form of participation. That is quite clear.
But the other arguments that I have cited against an intervention are so important that I would also be against such an intervention if -- for whatever reasons and in whatever form -- the Security Council of the United Nations were to say "Yes," which I cannot imagine happening in the present situation. 
I have attempted to make clear that it is not just formal considerations that induce me to say that this is the wrong way. I have told you about what harm we would do to the international coalition against terror. I have attempted to make clear that we must prove before the eyes of the world, in Afghanistan and elsewhere, that participation in the struggle against terror will also bring a peace dividend, and I know of no one who has a real concept for a new order in the Middle East which could shape the region afterward. These are for me weighty arguments that lead me to say: Of course it is important for Germany what resolutions the United Nations adopt, but these arguments -- these three -- they remain my own, the ones that make me say: Hands off. Especially because, as I said before, the evidence appears to be highly dubious. . . .

Q This administration is making lots of difficulties for its friends. Do you think that Sept. 11 has changed America in a way that isn't a good way?

A . . . I would like to answer that question with another: what is the duty of a friend in such a situation? It is the duty of friends to show solidarity, but also to use this tried and true solidarity to bring rational arguments into the political debate. The duty of friends is not just to agree with everything, but to say: We disagree on this point. . . .

Q The nasty view is, you're in a tough campaign and you want to run against Bush, against America, for "peace," and change the subject from unemployment.

A . . . I would never treat this issue as a matter of tactics, because the consequences would catch up with me later. We will win in Germany, and then I will have to stick by this decision, and I know what that means. In this sense it was not a tactical variant in the election campaign. . . .

ON THE WEB
This interview is the second of a series in which national and world figures reflect on the terrorist attacks and their effect on a year of public life and policy. The articles and full interviews are online at nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: China's Leader Won't Hold On, Anonymous Author Says 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Despite rampant speculation to the contrary, a new account of Beijing's secretive politics says that China's leader, Jiang Zemin, has decided to give up all of his top posts and that the country will have its first orderly political succession over the coming six months. 
 According to the account, which claims to draw on high-level insider documents and discussions, an intense campaign this year promoting Mr. Jiang's "theory" of a modernized Communism embracing capitalists, interpreted by many analysts as an attempt by Mr. Jiang to cling to power, is intended to give him an honorable retirement and secure his legacy. 
 The account, by an anonymous Chinese author, is being published in the United States. It has been scrutinized by a leading American expert on Chinese politics, Andrew J. Nathan of Columbia University, who calls it highly credible, though impossible to verify fully. 
The unusually detailed account of maneuvers inside the "black box" of Beijing politics comes from a Chinese man who has lived for several years in the United States and who says that well-placed insiders gave him the party's secret dossiers, evaluating dozens of candidates for leading positions. 
He says he has maintained contact with his party sources during recent weeks as final preparations are made for the 16th Communist Party Congress on Nov. 8, and offers a precise and consistent view of the jostling at the top.
Under the pseudonym of Zong Hairen -- he fears reprisals against himself or his sources -- he has combined excerpts from the personnel reports with his account of insider maneuvers in a Chinese-language book called "Disidai," or "The Fourth Generation," to be published this fall by the New York-based Mirror Books.
The report says that trial balloons this year suggesting that Mr. Jiang, 76, should retain one or more of his top offices failed to win the support of other senior leaders. It says Mr. Jiang will step down as Communist Party chief in November and as China's president next March, handing power to the 59-year-old heir apparent, Hu Jintao.
The report asserts that Mr. Jiang's advisers have convinced him that in the interests of party unity and his own legacy he must also sign over to Mr. Hu his third title, chairman of the Central Military Commission. 
That transfer, the report says, is to take place during the meeting of Parliament next March, and Mr. Jiang is unlikely to wield major informal power in the years that follow, contradicting a common view here that Mr. Jiang is angling to keep the military title to prolong his influence.
While the new account offers what some say is a credible account of recent politics, it is unlikely to convince all the experts, who have expressed widely varied interpretations of Mr. Jiang's intentions.
Just today, the Communist Party departments of organization and propaganda issued a major notice to all party units throughout the country, instructing members to carefully study a new book of Mr. Jiang's writings, the official New China News Agency reported.
This campaign may, as the anonymous book author suggests, be preparing the ground for Mr. Jiang's smooth retirement. But some experts here think it signifies Mr. Jiang's muscle and his intent to remain an assertive player.
The author provides startling and previously unreported details of the Machiavellian struggle for power in the period since 1989, when Mr. Jiang was installed as party leader after the trauma of the bloody Tiananmen Square crackdown.
He asserts that for a time in 1992, Deng Xiaoping, then China's de facto leader, discussed toppling Mr. Jiang and Prime Minister Li Peng for their failure to press China's economic opening, which Deng saw as vital. 
According to that account, Deng even briefly bruited the notion of restoring Zhao Ziyang to senior office. Mr. Zhao was deposed as party chief in 1989 because he showed too much sympathy for the democracy protests at Tiananmen Square.
The dismissals were sidetracked, the author says, by Mr. Jiang's masterly aide, Zeng Qinghong, who helped Mr. Jiang jump belatedly onto the "reform" bandwagon and convinced Deng that a greater threat lay in the accumulating power of two related army generals, who were later purged. Mr. Zhao remains defiant and under house arrest today.
An English-language description of the "Zong" book and his version of political developments has been prepared by Mr. Nathan and by Bruce Gilley, a journalist and biographer of Mr. Jiang. Their version will be published this fall as "China's New Rulers: The Inside Files," by The New York Review of Books Press. Excerpts are being published in forthcoming issues of The New York Review of Books.
In an interview, Mr. Nathan acknowledged that many assertions could not be independently verified.
But he said that the anonymous writer's track record of informed articles and an earlier book, the rich and plausible detail of the new report and extensive discussions had convinced him and Mr. Gilley that the documents and the author's high-level access were genuine.
Mr. Nathan played a similar role early last year as an editor of "The Tiananmen Papers" (Public Affairs), described as a collection of internal documents surrounding the 1989 crackdown and compiled by a different pseudonymous Chinese author.
Mr. Nathan said he remained puzzled by the motives of the insiders who leaked the secret documents to the author. The materials -- describing the work records, climb to power and excerpts from internal speeches of Politburo candidates -- did not seem to convey any political agenda on the part of the leakers, who were taking a severe risk.
The anonymous author, through whom all the information has in effect been filtered, has in previous works shown a strong dislike for Mr. Jiang and Mr. Li but appears intent in the new book to describe the talents as well as policy leanings of the coming generation of leaders.
The account portrays China's next leaders as highly competent men who have advanced largely on merit and are "determined modernizers, intent on integrating China's economy with the world and on maintaining good relations with the United States," according to an advance copy of The New York Review of Books.
At the same time, Mr. Nathan and Mr. Gilley write, "This is a group of men who believe in authoritarian rule as a precondition for pushing their country through the turbulent passage to modernization."
According to the Chinese author's account, the future membership of the Politburo standing committee was largely determined months ago or earlier. The standing committee, which runs the party and the country, now includes seven men, most of whom are to retire because they are older than 70.
Mr. Hu will rank first, followed by Li Ruihan, 68, who is also to become the head of Parliament. Wen Jiabao, 60, will be named prime minister as well as a standing committee member. Others on the committee will include Wu Bangguo, who is now a deputy prime minister; Luo Gan, the hard-line director of law and security, and Mr. Zeng, the Jiang protege and party organizer.
Still undetermined in recent weeks, the author says, is whether one, two or three other men will join the standing committee, possibly including an under-50 leader like the governor of Fujian or Henan Province.
The report describes Mr. Zeng's skillful role in building Mr. Jiang's power. Mr. Zeng is credited with engineering the purge of Jiang rivals over the last decade, including the former Beijing party secretary Chen Xitong, who was jailed for corruption, and Qiao Shi, the Parliament leader who was eased out in a surprise move in 1997.
Many experts have described Mr. Zeng as a proxy for Mr. Jiang, but the author says Mr. Zeng appears ready to take his own place. He is reported as personally urging Mr. Jiang to retire now, arguing that an effort to hold office would open a Pandora's box as other aged leaders asserted themselves.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Devotion to free-market, laissez-faire dogma makes for ineffectual policy.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick, who teaches at Cooper Union, is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. His new book, "Why Economies Grow," will be published by Basic Books in October. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
IN a widely cited speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo., last week, Alan Greenspan tried to defend his failure to tame the 1990's stock market bubble. The Federal Reserve chairman said raising interest rates would have caused too much damage to the economy. He said raising margin requirements would not have mattered, although senior Wall Street hands like the economist and consultant Henry Kaufman had long urged him to do so.
 But most telling, Mr. Greenspan said Fed officials could not know when stocks were too high. Maybe the market, even when violating all sorts of historical precedents, was just right. 
 Such thinking is all too representative of the undue faith in the magic of markets that characterizes today's policy making. 
Mr. Greenspan was quick to help the market when it was too low. During the Asian financial crisis in 1997, the fear that the financial system might collapse weighed heavily in his decision to cut rates sharply. 
But when stocks were in a bubble and the political pressure was to keep the good times rolling, he consistently retreated to his deepest belief that the markets were basically efficient and should not be interfered with. A few economists have even asserted that stock bubbles are entirely rational. 
A highly respected mainstream economist has issued one of the strongest criticisms yet of such thinking. George Akerlof, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, won the 2001 Nobel in economic science, with Joseph Stiglitz and Michael Spence.
In his Nobel acceptance speech, reprinted in the June issue of The American Economic Review, Mr. Akerlof uses behavioral economics to criticize oversimplified laissez-faire theories. 
Such theories depend greatly on one assumption: that buyers and sellers are rational and seek to maximize their own incomes and profits. These economists, perhaps best represented by the work of the so-called new classical economists, whose home base is the University of Chicago, conclude that stocks are almost always sensibly priced. They also conclude that unemployment cannot be reduced without creating inflation, people save enough on their own, regulations that limit the international flow of capital are anathema, and even monetary policy has little or no consequence.
Mr. Akerlof argues, however, that market bubbles can exist and should be kept under control; that unemployment can often be pushed lower by government without generating inflation; that people will not save enough on their own; and that liberalized global capital flows have been damaging. He argues that monetary and fiscal policies do matter in creating jobs and raising incomes.
The starting point for Mr. Akerlof and his colleagues is to make the central assumption of economics realistic. People are often not rational, maybe even most of the time. Consider investors in stocks. Keynes implied long ago in his "General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money," Mr. Akerlof notes, that investors are subject to fads and fashions.
Behavioral economists have developed a lot of evidence to support this idea. For example, Robert Shiller of Yale has carefully shown that stock prices are much more volatile than corporate profits and dividends. 
An important conclusion is that when stock prices are historically far out of line with profits, there is a good chance that it is a bubble, not a "new economy" of ever-higher profits, as Mr. Greenspan often suggested in the 1990's.
Similarly, new classical economists argue that markets are so efficient that unemployment is largely voluntary. For the most part, they say, people who are out of work can find jobs if they are willing to work for less. Government cannot really help them.
Mr. Akerlof argues that in real life, businesses often pay more than the market wage to retain good workers, bolster morale or create incentives to work harder. Thus, jobs are actually rationed, and many job seekers are shut out.
Mr. Akerlof argues that behavioral economics also casts doubt on the related assertion that there is a unique natural rate of unemployment. If policy makers push the jobless rate lower, the argument is that inflation will inevitably accelerate. Mr. Akerlof believes that when one considers the way people really act, this is just plain wrong. As Keynes asserted, monetary and fiscal stimulus can produce more jobs and higher incomes that will not be undermined by higher inflation.
As for savings, much economic theory argues that people save rationally over their lifetimes for retirement. But behavioral economists show that people systematically procrastinate -- they spend today and plan to save tomorrow.
This may seem obvious. But consider how far Social Security privatization has gotten, based largely on the new classical view of rational human behavior. Proponents argue that if people are deprived of Social Security as a safety net, almost all of them will save adequately for retirement, no matter their level of income. There is no basis in human observation or economic history for this conclusion. For many people, especially with lower incomes, saving is very difficult. 
The strength of behavioral economics is that it is based largely on actual observation of human behavior, not pure theory. "In the spirit of Keynes," Mr. Akerlof writes, "behavioral macroeconomists are rebuilding the microfoundations that were sacked by the new classical economists."
To be fair, economists from other schools of thought, including post-Keynesians, structural economists and gender economists, have tried to explain the same observations with other interesting theories, and they deserve more of a hearing.
But Mr. Akerlof and his colleagues have attacked today's conventional wisdom, which dominates the halls of power, on the basis of its own assumptions and values. Mr. Akerlof's side, I believe, is winning this battle of ideas. The battle for power may be another matter. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York on a wild day in April 2000. The conventional wisdom among policy makers seems to be that markets should not be tampered with. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: As Deadline Nears, Congress Slogs in a Fiscal Quagmire 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Senator Robert C. Byrd, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, says he cannot quite explain it. The House is tied in knots as well.
 Less than a month before an Oct. 1 deadline, Congress has passed exactly zero of the 13 required spending bills. The Senate, for the first time in years, has not even adopted a budget. Lawmakers blame one another and the White House, while the White House holds Congress accountable. 
 Combined with an intensely politicized climate on Capitol Hill, the fiscal failures are adding up to what one aide described as a "train wreck" that has the potential to throw Congress and the executive branch into turmoil for months.
"It is probably as bad as I have ever seen it," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, about the state of Congressional spending and budget affairs.
No one is talking about a reprise of the government shutdown of 1995, but if factions in Congress cannot bridge differences between themselves and the White House over spending priorities, federal agencies are very likely to be held hostage to a series of stop-gap spending bills. Without a budget and the rules that go with it, the door could be opened to a flurry of sticky Senate legislative fights.
Some lawmakers say the press of urgent business, including legislation relating to the terrorist attacks and corporate accountability, have left them little time to deal with the annual spending bills that finance the government.
The debate is occurring after the Congressional Budget Office last week predicted that the government, faced with a stagnant economy and the need to absorb the costs of a fight against terrorism and last year's tax cuts, will run large deficits through 2005. But at the center of the current stalemate is a difference of $9 billion to $13 billion in spending out of a total of more than $750 billion.
To the administration, that is an amount worth contesting on the grounds it will contribute to spiraling spending in coming years. "Just that $9 billion to $13 billion compounds to $200 billion over 10 years," said Amy Call, a spokeswoman for the Office of Management and Budget.
But to Democrats and even some Republicans on Capitol Hill, the amount is evidence that the battle is more about politics, as the Bush administration, worried about a return to deficits on its watch, tries to show it can get tough on spending.
"He is trying to find some high ground on spending when the differences are trivial," said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, the chairman of the Budget Committee, referring to the president. "We have gone from massive surpluses to massive deficits, and he wants to have some way to say it is not his fault."
The budget picture grew even more complicated today when the White House proposed about $1 billion in new spending on AIDS initiatives, airport security and Middle East relief, reviving part of a $5 billion package the president blocked last month. House Appropriations Committee members said they would have to accommodate that and some other new spending sought by the White House within already constrained limits.
"They go out and give a speech and slap us around while they are quietly sending up these requests," said one Republican staff member on the House appropriations panel. "It is a tad frustrating."
Senate Republican leaders attribute the backlog to failure by Democratic leaders to get serious about appropriations measures earlier in the summer and the inability to get a budget passed.
"I think we should have focused on appropriations bills back in May or June, like I tried to," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader. Congress rarely adopts all its spending bills by the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30, but experts on Capitol Hill say it has been quite a while since it was in this predicament. The House has passed five appropriations measures, the Senate three. None have been reconciled in House-Senate negotiations.
In an effort to speed things up, the Senate today began interspersing appropriations bills with its continuing debate over the homeland security department, bringing the Interior Department bill to the floor. But scant progress was made. The House Appropriations Committee is expected to consider two bills this week, one of them in subcommittee.
The slow pace already has some suggesting that Congress might take care of most of its spending matters in a large bill known as a continuing resolution that would maintain spending at current levels unless a spending bill has been passed. The continuing resolution could last until a lame-duck session after the elections in November or into next year.
But any delay also brings politics back into the equation since control of Congress could change with the November results, perhaps putting Democrats in control in the House or Republicans in the Senate.
Mr. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said he was not yet ready to call for a continuing resolution. "I don't want that," he said. "We have a month here." He also accused the president of playing politics with the spending process. "I think we ought to quit the kid's stuff and work together," he said. 
In the House, the appropriations process is also squeezed between conservative Republicans trying to reduce spending and Democrats and moderate Republicans who favor increases in some areas. 
The House adopted a budget figure of $759 billion for the fiscal year 2002-2003, which starts on Oct. 1. While the Senate has not adopted a budget plan, it is using a target of $768 billion. The White House says the figure is actually $772 billion. Mr. Conrad, who fell one vote short earlier this summer in trying to get a budget plan adopted, says he believes he can still pass one before the start of the fiscal year. 
If not, budget rules that require 60 votes for some tax and spending measures would disappear. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, has already said he might try again to eliminate the estate tax, which drew 54 votes earlier this year but not the 60 required at the time.
"We have to do something," said a Senate aide, worried about the implications of not passing a budget.

HEADLINE: Busy Being an Icon, Giuliani Keeps Political Future Alive 

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
A horse farm in Goshen, Ky. -- 700 acres of bluegrass and thoroughbreds, interrupted by a swimming pool, a bathhouse and a stately 19th-century home -- that kind of horse farm. And here is Rudy Giuliani of New York on a torrid summer day in his customary suit and tie, his shoulders in that heavy slump, clapping the shoulders and shaking the hands of 200 people who have donated up to $15,000 a couple to the Kentucky Republican Party to meet him.
 When he speaks he begins with his familiar Godfather imitation, draws a few quizzical looks when he refers to HBO's Tony Soprano, shares his secret of leadership ("You have to know what you believe"). Truth be known, Mr. Giuliani, ending a 14-hour swing through two Southern states, is not at his most eloquent. 
 But it doesn't matter.
He is engulfed in thunderous applause anyway, from dazzled Kentuckians who confess they know little about his politics, even, some of them, whether he is a real Republican. Nor do they care. They have come to meet the Mayor of America and they are not disappointed. 
"He's a hero," said a merchant of animal feed from Cold Spring, Ky. "We don't have that many of them left."
Rudolph W. Giuliani, improbable icon from New York. Cheered at the All-Star Game, acclaimed at the MTV Video Music Awards, even said (unverifiably) to be on the short list for this year's Nobel Peace Prize, getting a higher approval rating than the president -- legacies of his powerful leadership in his city's darkest hour.
He was calm, direct and purposeful through the crisis of Sept. 11 and beyond, in reassuring control when nobody else was. And his bravura performance transformed him, overshadowing everything else -- his feuds with other politicians, his confrontations with black elected officials, his bitter scoldings of museum officials, his stubborn boycott of the United States Open and the tennis stadium his predecessor had helped build.
That and all the rest are footnotes for now. In fine print.
Before, he was the tough, I'll-do-it-my-way mayor, credited by fans with taming New York by cutting crime and the welfare rolls. But he went about what he saw almost as a mission so contentiously that by his eighth year, even fans had grown weary and were ready for term limits to move him on.
Then came Sept. 11, and now Mr. Giuliani can contemplate an unspecified political future that he could not have dreamed of before. And he is earning typically $100,000 a speech on the lecture circuit, running his own company, publishing a book next month on leadership, solidifying his Republican bona fides as he crisscrosses the country speaking and fund-raising for Republican candidates from California to North Carolina. 
"Mayor, many people think that with your level of popularity you're crazy to walk away from politics," a reporter asked in the Raleigh, N.C., airport during his recent Southern swing. "How's your health and are you done?"
Elizabeth Dole, candidate for Senate from North Carolina, stared. Mr. Giuliani roared. "How's my health and am I done? I'm very healthy, fully recovered from prostate cancer. And I'm not done, just in a transition period."
But after the memories of Sept. 11 start to fade, after the book tour is over and the lecture invitations aren't as frequent, and the midterm elections are over, does Mr. Giuliani move beyond celebrity if he runs for office himself, in a party several degrees to his right? Or is he stuck, however benevolent the vise, and merely taking abundant advantage of his new status while it lasts?
Put another way: Is this the beginning? Or the end?

Time to Make Money
Mr. Giuliani smiles at the speculation that he could break out of the infamous dead end that is New York City politics and be the first former mayor of New York to go on to higher office since 1868. He's heard it all, some from his own ambitious advisers: that maybe he'll run for governor. Or vice president. Even president, post-Bush. If he doesn't try for mayor again.
The 58-year-old former mayor is neither discouraging nor revealing.
"I thought and still think that I probably would like to run for office again, but it would be some years in the future. I needed time in the private sector, for practical reasons, to make money," said Mr. Giuliani, who reached a $6.8 million divorce settlement from Donna Hanover, his wife of 18 years, in July. "Maybe it's my personality. I like to do different things," he added, "to get a different perspective."
Right now that perspective looks out from a spacious office on Times Square, a glass-enclosed room filled with many photos of his children -- Andrew, 16, and Caroline, 13 -- and even more photos of his companion, Judith Nathan, a managing director of Changing Our World Inc., which helps nonprofit groups raise money.
The views from the office, in the headquarters building of Ernst & Young, the accounting firm and an investor in Giuliani Partners, are spectacular. The former mayor can see east, west and north -- but not south, toward City Hall and the void left by the destruction of the World Trade Center.
The past, though, is never far away. In many ways, Mr. Giuliani brought it with him. He put together a company whose partners and associates are drawn almost entirely from his inner circle at City Hall. His lawyers, communications director, trusted advisers -- they were with him then and still are now.
"He demands a sense of loyalty," said Bernard B. Kerik, the former police commissioner, now affiliated with Giuliani Partners, advising clients on security. "He surrounds himself with people who are close to him and competent. If you're not going to be loyal, you've got to go."
His close associates are still very careful about what they say, even reserved about matters of such great sensitivity as how the former mayor spends his free time (at the opera, eating at Italian restaurants, going to the movies with Ms. Nathan).
Though very much a public figure, he insists on shielding much of his life from public scrutiny, just as he did as mayor, on controlling the world around him, just as he did as mayor. He does not make his schedules public except selectively -- a reporter is advised to consult the Web to learn more than is provided in answer to a request. And he surrounds his public speaking with secrecy.
He closes most of his paid speeches to news coverage, as Colin L. Powell did when he was on the lecture circuit: why pay to hear a speech if it's on the evening news?
And Mr. Giuliani, whose candor has always been a political attribute, continues to be direct. He acknowledges that he is making political trips in part to stay politically visible, readily agrees that having close advisers around him means he has the makings of a campaign staff. Was that part of his thinking in setting up Giuliani Partners? "Maybe," he said. "I can't say the most prominent part. I know I have this very strong feeling of wanting to keep the team together."
This afternoon in his office, and in other chats on the road, Mr. Giuliani was relaxed, the customary tension nowhere to be found, and given to a small talk about his passion for golf, his children and Ms. Nathan, a constant presence in his life.
The thought occurred that he could afford to be relaxed now, freed of public responsibility. He doesn't have to defend a decision, is no longer the fierce Republican taming a Democratic town.
Not that he objected to the role. Before his interviewer even got around to asking what he missed about being mayor, he volunteered the answer: his call-in radio show and town hall meetings, where he dealt directly with the public. And his daily news conferences, where the impatient mayor did not hesitate to insult reporters if he found their questions wanting.
"Nobody believes it but it's true," he said of his press nostalgia. "For me it was like going to court every day. It was a good discipline. It kept me on my toes."
And in the headlines. Mayor Giuliani, with the City Hall press corps at his beck and call, could make news on a whim. Today, if he has something to say he has to find a way, as he did recently by writing a Time magazine essay reiterating his preference for building a Sept. 11 memorial on the entire disaster site. His successor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, favors a smaller memorial, with some of the land going to other purposes.
The former mayor made his case with reserve, though.

Whither a New Rudy
Dare one suggest a new Rudy? There have been other new Rudys -- inevitably short-lived. "Sometimes I think I've changed, sometimes I think I haven't," he said. "I know I've learned a lot about myself, what's important in life."
An old friend, Peter J. Powers, said it's a matter of emphasis.
"A cancer diagnosis and 9/11 gave him a glimpse of his own mortality," Mr. Powers said. "If anything is going to show you you'd better enjoy your life, that you'd better think about what's worth getting exercised about, it's a combination of those two things. It did change him. But it didn't totally morph him."
In fact, a lot has stayed fundamentally the same. Mr. Giuliani still has many of the trappings of office, including a large city-provided security detail for himself, his children and Ms. Nathan, and a small entourage when he travels.
He is accompanied by at least one political adviser on most trips -- Bruce J. Teitelbaum, his former political adviser, or Anthony V. Carbonetti, his former chief of staff. Both are in the new business, described as a consulting-investing company. It is advising Purdue Pharma, the company that makes the pain reliever OxyContin, on security.
Detailed insights into Giuliani Partners are hard to come by. Presumably, Mr. Giuliani will be more forthcoming if he runs for office.
His associates do not doubt that he is speaking for more than money. They theorize that he could succeed Dick Cheney as Mr. Bush's running mate in 2004 if the president needs Northeast and industrial states.
Others who are not Giuliani fans theorize that the Bush administration would not risk aligning with the independent former mayor for a bagful of electoral votes.
For now, White House advisers say only complimentary things about the former mayor, and Mr. Giuliani returns the favor. He will not be caught saying anything critical about the president, or anybody else, for that matter. 
Although Mr. Bloomberg has reversed many of his policies, Mr. Giuliani has expressed dissent only about plans for the trade center memorial. He does not bridle when reminded of his failed attempt to extend his term by three months last year -- "Things probably turned out best."
When asked about seeing Mr. Bloomberg change his policies -- cancel plans for new baseball stadiums, for instance -- Mr. Giuliani says he will not carp from the sidelines and thinks his successor is doing fine: "He's being himself, which he should be."
Mr. Giuliani seems eager to appear philosophical even about criticisms of his record, from his failure to get control of education to a report by an independent consultant that cited critical difficulties with radio communications and poor coordination between the former mayor's prized Fire and Police Departments on Sept. 11.
"I think there is no question errors were made; you can't do a complex task without making errors," Mr. Giuliani said. "But I think if someone were to look at it fairly, they would say it was run about as well as you could expect human beings to run it, given the realities of what was going on."
He expected criticism, he added. "I'm quite confident, given the results, people can put it in the proper context, meaning the results of so many people saved, of the city coming out of it the way it did."
That display of tolerance is the most surprising change in the man. Even in his last days as mayor, when he removed his files and papers from City Hall, he led others to see him, still, as the control-bound man he ever was. Perhaps now that he is no longer able to control the city, he is working at controlling himself, recognizing that while New Yorkers like their politicians tough, most of America prefers them affable.
Or maybe starting over -- being divorced, out of the pressure cooker of City Hall and obviously happy with Ms. Nathan -- is enough to relax the Giuliani scowl.
The couple is finalizing details on a new Manhattan apartment, living in a Midtown hotel in the meantime. Weekends are spent on the links, on courses from Westchester to New Jersey, or at Ms. Nathan's condominium in Southampton. Their future? "Judith and I are going to be together forever."
His friend Howard Koeppel, a car dealer, said: "She loves him very much and he loves her. I don't think you could live with him for 10 minutes, but she really worships him. He's not the easiest person in the world. That's just the way he is and that's why we all love Rudy. He takes no prisoners. But he's lovable."
The old Rudy still rankles in some quarters. Edward I. Koch, an ally-turned-enemy, argues that Mr. Giuliani's reputation will ultimately suffer from the budget and homeless problems he left behind, questions raised about the city's emergency preparedness, and his temperament: "He was mean before he was mayor, mean after and will be the rest of his life."

9/11 Self-Promotion
Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, accuses Mr. Giuliani of turning last year's horror into a self-promoting industry. "He has marketed this very successfully, the only man in America to turn it into an industry," Mr. Ferrer said.
Others have quietly complained that Mr. Giuliani's agent, Brad Grey, co-produced the HBO special about Sept. 11, which starred the former mayor and featured several members of his administration and Ms. Nathan.
Mr. Giuliani, who wanted the film made before memories faded, said he was sensitive about not exploiting the tragedy, delaying publication of his book until after the anniversary, donating some fees to charity, making many unpaid appearances. "But Sept. 11 was part of my life," he said. "I can't take it out of my life."
The disaster is not so much the focus of his speeches and civic appearances, as a touchstone.
Speaking to graduating seniors in Shanksville, Pa., where the fourth hijacked plane crashed on Sept. 11, he said America was attacked for its democratic ideals.
"We believe that you have the right to be a Protestant, a Catholic, a Jew, a Muslim, or any combination or different set of beliefs within those groups or any group that you want to belong to or not belong to," he told the students. "You decide how you want to communicate with God or not. That's what binds us together as Americans. And that's why we were attacked."
He advised the graduating seniors: "Don't be afraid. All of those terrorists combined can't invade us and take us over. We're too big, we're too strong, we're too powerful. And we're too confident of who we are."
The last time Mr. Giuliani ventured out of town to campaign for Republicans, in 1998, he turned few heads.
At the time, a dismissive William Kristol said: "What's his message? It has to be more than I'm a moderate, I play well in New York and I'm a terrific mayor.' "
Mr. Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, now offers a different opinion: 9/11 changed everything. "Rudy was a good mayor who wasn't going anywhere and had personal problems. Now he's a national hero." Mr. Kristol is hardly running him for president. "But it's a different country since 9/11. A certain toughness, patriotic toughness, not culture war-related, but a patriotic toughness, has become a more central criterion."
Democrats scoff. "His positions on social issues would be anathema to Republicans around the country," said one national Democratic leader. Many Republicans agree, citing likely opposition to the Giuliani brand of Republicanism from their party's influential right flank, especially the religious right and champions of so-called family values.
Difficult to overcome. Maybe impossible? Paul Weyrich, a leading conservative activist, isn't so sure: "He has greatly helped himself, not only by displaying the leadership he did post-9/11, but also he has been willing to go campaign for a whole host of people whom he doesn't agree with, and that is very unusual on the part of liberal Republicans."
"He had a couple of obstacles -- his pro-abortion positions and being for gay rights," Mr. Weyrich continued. "Those were two things which the conservative movement really couldn't swallow. Now all of a sudden I'm hearing, 'Well, if he'll be fair to us, perhaps we could swallow it.' I'm very surprised."

Untested in National G.O.P.
The former mayor has not tested his viability in his party. He does not speak about social issues, or political ones for that matter, unless asked. His speeches are not about Iraq, or the economy. He offers no solutions for the Middle East. He does not emphasize his positions out of town in favor of abortion rights, gay rights and gun control. He does not have to. Political figures out of office can pick their shots.
If he became a candidate, that would change. Mr. Giuliani argues that Republicans are more prepared to listen to his positions today than they used to be. "There is more of a voice today for the idea that there should be a broad range of opinion in the Republican Party on choice and on gay rights," he said. "I think it's still a debate. I don't think the answer to the question is obvious: Can a Republican who is pro-choice and pro-gay rights, because that is the way it would be viewed, succeed nationally? I don't know. I think more of a chance now than there would have been five or six years ago."
Perhaps they are. Or perhaps the former mayor is this year's celebrity fund-raising draw.
"He's the hottest political property we have outside the president," said Tom Davis, chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee. Besides campaigning for Mrs. Dole, Mr. Giuliani has helped Bill Simon Jr., candidate for governor in California; Senator Susan Collins in Maine; Gov. George E. Pataki of New York; Representative Anne M. Northup of Kentucky; and many others.
Asked if he was uncomfortable supporting candidates who differed with him on everything from abortion rights to gun control, he said no: "A big tent means there are going to be disagreements."
Mr. Giuliani still has $2.5 million left in a fund he created for his failed Senate candidacy two years ago, and is accumulating those many political debts around the country.
Will Mr. Giuliani's iconic status last? That is one of the many ifs about his future. Another is his health. Given a diagnosis of prostate cancer two years ago, he says he is cancer-free and fine now, other than enduring occasional infections, a legacy of the radiation treatments. But even as he keeps to a schedule that would exhaust a younger person, he seems to tire a bit sooner and takes frequent breaks.
Sometimes, there comes a note of fatalism. "A year ago I got prostate cancer and then there was Sept. 11, so I no longer plan the future too much," he said on Canadian television in July. Yet, he quickly added, "But probably I will be back in politics."
It sounds like a safe prediction.
He is, after all, a former mayor of New York who one sultry summer day finds himself standing under a tent in Goshen, Ky., ending a chicken-dinner speech with a tribute to the Bronx Bombers. And commanding a standing ovation from an audience of beaming folks from bluegrass country who might not have turned up a year ago. If he'd even been invited.
A funny business, politics.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: PERSPECTIVES; 
German Leader's Warning: War Plan Is a Huge Mistake

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 1 

 BODY:
Gerhard Schroder, the German chancellor, believes that the Bush administration is making a terrible mistake in planning a war against Iraq, and he is not afraid to say so.
 A new war in the Middle East, he says bluntly, would put at risk all that has been gained so far in the unfinished battle against Al Qaeda. 
 The arguments against a war with Iraq are so strong, he said, that he would oppose one even if the Security Council approved.
After the Sept. 11 attacks, Germany offered "unconditional solidarity" and support to the United States as "a self-evident duty, as a friend," he said in an interview at his home here. Fighting Iraq, which he regards as entirely separate from fighting Al Qaeda, could shatter that unity. 
"I think it would be a big mistake if this feeling of needing one another should be destroyed by excessively unilateral actions," he said.
Consultation is important, he said, "but consultation cannot mean that I get a phone call two hours in advance only to be told, 'We're going in.' "
"Consultation among grown-up nations has to mean not just consultation about the how and the when, but also about the whether," he said.
Mr. Schroder is in the midst of a fierce election campaign that some say has influenced his stand, a suggestion he denied. "We will win in Germany, and then I will have to stick by this decision, and I know what that means," the chancellor, a Social Democrat, said.
His stand on Iraq is a departure for Germany, traditionally a staunch ally at moments of crisis. Many Germans feel indebted to the United States for helping shape modern Germany and are uneasy about charting an independent course on issues of such gravity.
Mr. Schroder made time in his garden to reflect on the events of Sept. 11, their impact on America's relations with its allies and the talk of war with Iraq.
Recalling Sept. 11, he praised President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell for their skill in quickly rallying an international coalition against terror. With the terrorist strikes, he said, the world understood it was facing "a privatized form of war, waged by terrorist organizations," that must be fought "using appropriate means, including military means."
Informal, sometimes smoking a cigar, Mr. Schroder emphasized Germany's close ties to the United States and its people. He and his wife, Doris, were greatly moved by the Sept. 11 attacks. His wife talks of living in America again, but Mr. Schroder has his eyes set first on the Sept. 22 election.
His stance on Iraq has appealed to those Germans who oppose war and are skeptical of Bush administration assertions that Iraq must be overthrown, not simply contained.
Senior officials in Washington are angry at his presumption that the American debate over Iraq is finished and his failure to give his closest ally the benefit of the doubt. They believe he is damaging the alliance for electoral advantage and is running against America. 
But Mr. Schroder believes that his policy is prudent and coherent. He insists that the goal must be to pressure Saddam Hussein to allow weapons inspectors unconditional access -- not to go to war regardless to overthrow Mr. Hussein, as Vice President Dick Cheney has suggested.
Mr. Schroder threw up his hands. "How can you exert pressure on someone by saying to them, 'Even if you accede to our demands, we will destroy you'?" he asked. "I think that was a change of strategy in the United States -- whatever the explanation may be -- a change that made things difficult for others, including ourselves." 
Referring to Mr. Cheney, Mr. Schroder said: "The problem is that he has or seems to have committed himself so strongly that it is hard to imagine how he can climb down. And that is the real problem, that not only I have, but that all of us in Europe have."
Mr. Schroder emphasized that he had put his own job on the line when he pushed his Social Democratic and Green coalition to vote for German deployment of troops in the war against Al Qaeda, and said it was his duty to do so. Germany, he noted, has some 10,000 troops serving abroad, second only to the United States, in Afghanistan, the Middle East and the Balkans -- so "no one can criticize us for lacking international solidarity."
But Iraq is different, he insists, and he said he resented finding out first from the media about the Cheney speech. Because he was prepared to call a vote of confidence on Afghanistan, he said, "it is just not good enough if I learn from the American press about a speech which clearly states, 'We are going to do it, no matter what the world or our allies think.' That is no way to treat others."
Mr. Schroder said he had seen no new evidence indicating that the military danger from Iraq had increased, and so questions the administration's urgency. He says he believes "no one has a really clear idea of the political order that would follow in the Middle East" or of the effects of a war on the stability of moderate Arab states, or the cohesion of the antiterror coalition. There has been little discussion, he says, of the economic consequences, in particular the price of oil, for the rest of the world.
The war against Osama bin Laden is not finished, he said. "My concern," he said, "is that we have not even begun to achieve in Afghanistan anything that could be called nation-building." 
Germany cares what resolutions the United Nations adopts, Mr. Schroder said. But the harm to the coalition, the lack of a concept for a new Middle East and the need to succeed in Afghanistan trump everything else for him. "These arguments," he said, "make me say, 'Hands off' " -- especially, he added, since the evidence of an increased threat from Iraq "appears to be highly dubious."
Sept. 11 made Americans more determined on the issue of terrorism, he said, but did not change the American democracy or the ability to conduct a strong debate on issues like Iraq.
Sept. 11 had an enormous impact on the Germans, too, he said. "The large demonstration in Berlin by 200,000 or 300,000 people was in fact a spontaneous expression of sympathy and solidarity. And I also experienced it much closer to home -- if I may be permitted to say so -- since my wife had once lived not far away, on the Upper West Side."
New York also has special meaning to the world as a place of refuge for those forced to leave their own country, Mr. Schroder said, adding: "New York is thus a symbol of asylum. This was very much the case during the Nazi period in Germany, and this gives New York a very special importance."
He knows Washington is angry with him, but he thinks officials misunderstand what real friends he and Germany remain. "What is the duty of a friend in such a situation?" he asked. "The duty of friends is not just to agree with everything, but to say, 'We disagree on this point.' That is what I believe to be the duty of friends in relations between individuals, just as it is in relations between nations, if one happens to disagree. And on this point" -- Iraq -- "we disagree, or I disagree."
He says he did what he thought was right when he put his job on the line to send troops to Afghanistan, "and now I am again doing what I think to be right," he said. "It is something that has to be done, and one has to have the strength to do it if one holds this office."

HEADLINE: Disease Hits Firs and Redwoods, Posing Risk of Economic Damage 

BYLINE:  By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

 BODY:
Douglas fir, one of the nation's most economically important timber species, and California's coast redwood are infected with the fast-spreading new disease known as sudden oak death syndrome, scientists reported yesterday.
 The researchers emphasized that they still did not know what impact the disease would have on the long-term health of redwood and Douglas fir forests. So far, the disease, which has killed tens of thousands of oak trees in California, has been found in Douglas fir only in saplings in Sonoma County. 
 But the potential for a major economic impact is already clear. Within a few days, regulators said, both species will be added to the official list of susceptible species, making these two important trees subject to the evolving state and federal quarantine regulations intended to stop the spread of this still poorly understood disease. 
"We were stunned," said Dr. David Rizzo, plant pathologist at the University of California at Davis who led the study with Dr. Matteo Garbelotto, a forest pathologist at the Berkeley campus. "Douglas fir goes up into British Columbia, so this is a big deal."
Mark Stanley, chairman of the California oak mortality task force, a coalition of government agencies, nonprofit groups and other private organizations, said that regulators and task force members hoped to mitigate the impact on the forestry industry, perhaps by regulating the movement of only parts of Douglas fir and redwood trees.
Current federal regulations include the requirement that all host species harvested from infected areas have all bark removed and left on site and be accompanied by a certificate before being transported between states. 
Harvests of Douglas fir, a major timber and Christmas tree species, are worth more than a billion dollars each year in the United States. Douglas fir is the dominant tree of the Pacific Northwest, giving the forests of the region their distinctive evergreen canopy. Redwood, also valued as timber, produces bark that is widely sold for landscaping in gardens.
In response to the new results, Gov. Gray Davis of California yesterday sent President Bush a letter requesting $10 million in federal money to fight the disease. "The implications of this disease are enormous, including a major change in the environment and landscape of California, severe economic dislocation, and an increase in fire danger," the letter said. 
The disease is caused by the microscopic organism known as Phytophthora ramorum, part of a group funguslike organisms known as water molds. Discovered in California in 1995, and thought by most scientists to be a foreign, invasive species, the disease is a close relative of the pathogen that caused Ireland's potato blight and another species that has wiped out vast swaths of forest in western Australia.
Quarantined regions include 12 counties in California and one nine-square-mile patch in Oregon.
Researchers found Douglas fir and redwood trees infected with the pathogen in the wild earlier this year, but they only recently completed tests showing that healthy seedlings and saplings could be infected in the laboratory by the disease.
Researchers still do not know whether large, mature Douglas fir or redwood trees can be infected or killed by the disease.
The symptoms of infected trees of different species range from death, in oaks, to small spots on leaves in bay trees. It remains to be seen how severely Douglas firs and redwoods will react to the infections. In the field, researchers found that the disease killed the growing branchtips of infected, Douglas fir saplings. The disease also killed young sprouts at the base of infected redwoods and killed the needles of the tree.
Meanwhile, as the disease appears to hop from species to species, infecting a total of 17 known plant species in California so far, researchers are left scrambling to find ways of containing the ever-increasing and often unexpected sources of infection, including yard and park clippings.
"The Bay Area alone generates a million tons of green waste a year," Dr. Rizzo said. 
Because the disease is thriving there, Dr. Garbelotto said he had been studying whether composting can be trusted to kill the pathogen or whether these excesses of yard waste will need careful tracking as well. He said he was even working on how to dry bay leaves for cooking so that they could not spread the disease to other plants.
No cure is known for the disease, and Dr. Garbelotto and colleagues are conducting experiments to find possible preventives that can be applied to a forest. In Australia, where a relative of sudden oak death has reduced vast forests to grass and shrublands, managers have found great success with aerial sprays of preventive chemicals. But researchers say that sprays would not be feasible in places like the heavily populated Bay Area or Muir Woods, a tourist attraction of redwood trees just across the Golden Gate Bridge. 
"There are more people in Muir Woods on a Saturday afternoon," said Dr. Rizzo, "than in these sites in a year in Australia."
In Oregon, the region known to be infected is near Brookings, by the California border, and only in a species known as the tanoak, one of the hardest hit of trees in California. Given the small area, Oregon's researchers are actually trying to eradicate the disease from their state by burning diseased trees.
"There's no good precedent for getting rid of a disease like this," said Alan Kanaskie, forest pathologist for the Oregon Department of Forestry. "If there's a precedent, it's that eradication fails. But maybe we can at least delay its spread."

More Tourists in New York, But They Spend Less
Despite the troubled economy and the World Trade Center attack, slightly more Americans visited New York City in 2001 than in 2000, tourism officials said. But that news was muted by the fact that domestic visitors spent nearly 10 percent less in the city last year than in 2000. B1

Pay Raises for Police
A state arbitration panel has awarded the city's 24,000 police officers raises totaling 11.75 percent for the last two years, ending a bitter and protracted contract dispute between a dispirited force that felt it deserved more for its sacrifices and a city that said it could afford no large increases. Liberal Party Fights to Survive
Raymond B. Harding is orchestrating the survival of the Liberal Party, a 58-year-old uniquely New York institution. Critics who see the party as nothing but a throwback patronage mill welcome the prospect that the Liberals will fail to get the needed 50,000 votes to retain the ballot line in statewide elections. Pataki, did not stand a chance against a newly united Democratic Party.
