HEADLINE: Is There Life for Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Without Martha? 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS and TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Since its inception, the fortunes of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have been entwined with the image of its founder, Martha Stewart. Now, as legal troubles continue to swirl around Ms. Stewart and her ImClone trades, some analysts are envisioning a future for the public company without Ms. Stewart at the helm and suggesting that could even help. 
 Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has been looking for a chief executive to possibly succeed Ms. Stewart, a person who was briefed on the matter reiterated yesterday after the search was reported by The New York Times. 
 The company's board denied yesterday that it was involved in such a search. In a statement, the board said it "felt it appropriate to categorically deny the report contained in today's New York Times that any search for a new chief executive has been initiated." 
The statement also said that the board "actively monitors the business needs of the company on an ongoing basis as well as in relation to the investigations involving Martha Stewart personally." Shares in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia closed yesterday at $7.80, up 15 cents. 
The likelihood of a diminished role for Ms. Stewart was first suggested by the company itself before it began trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 1999. The company's prospectus, which warned investors that "business would be adversely affected if Martha Stewart's public image or reputation were to be tarnished," announced a strategy of reducing its dependence on its founder. The prospectus went on to describe the company as "increasingly focused on team-based content development," and pointed out how Ms. Stewart had all but ceased to appear on the cover of her own magazine, where she was once a fixture. 
"We believe that a reduction in our dependence on Martha Stewart personally and a better balance of personality and brand will provide additional brand durability, increased growth opportunities and a broader recognition of a new generation of Martha Stewart Living experts," the prospectus stated.
Some analysts are now suggesting it is time to accelerate that process. 
"It would be a step toward putting distance between Martha, ImClone and the company," said Laura Richardson, a principal in equity research at Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston. "And it would be a step toward a turnaround in the company's earnings and stock performance."
A company spokeswoman said its plans to evolve its identity were on schedule, "according to a longstanding plan, and are not deviating from it." The stock price, the spokeswoman said, "will ultimately track the fundamentals of the business."
Ms. Richardson also said the company faced serious questions about its fate as a Kmart supplier, at a time when Kmart remains in Chapter 11 bankruptcy and sales are declining in its stores. A spokeswoman for Ms. Stewart would not comment on the Kmart business. 
One analyst, Kathleen Heaney of Brean Murray in Manhattan, said it was time for the company to move to improve its situation. The share price has been battered, earnings for the current quarter are expected to be less than half what were forecast, and company executives have offered no guidance beyond the end of this month about its fortunes.
Some of the problems stem from a weak economy, but most of them have been attributed to fallout from three investigations into Ms. Stewart's sale of nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems, the biotechnology company founded by her friend Samuel D. Waksal. Dr. Waksal was indicted last month on charges of insider trading, bank fraud, forgery and destroying records to obstruct a federal inquiry. Ms. Stewart has not been charged with any crime.
Ms. Heaney called Ms. Stewart's possible departure a "nonevent." The company, she said, "is full of people," including Sharon Patrick, the chief operating officer, who have experience with the products and lifestyle the company promotes. 
Away from the boardroom, the company has already made some efforts to reduced its reliance on Ms. Stewart. In its redesign of its magazine, Martha Stewart Living, which will begin with the October issue, the company has highlighted three executives with columns and features focused on them, not Ms. Stewart. And its catalog, Martha By Mail, is being renamed Martha Stewart: The Catalog for Living. A spokeswoman for Ms. Stewart said that both changes had been planned for some time.
And in a conference call with investors and analysts in late July, Ms. Stewart said that one of her biggest accomplishments was creating a company in which there were hundreds of talented people focusing on the products and lifestyle promoted through her publications and shows.
The question provoked by companies like Ms. Stewart's is whether they can enjoy success once separated from their founders.
"Hey, I'm sitting here wearing a Chanel suit and she's been dead for, what, 40 years," Ms. Heaney said. "She's gone but the perception of quality remains. Martha's still alive, she just may remove herself from the day-to-day business to concentrate on the big picture."

HEADLINE: McCall, Minus One Opponent, Pokes Fun at Another 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall may as well have been wearing a party hat with his suit and tie yesterday.
 Part mischief-maker, part leader of the flock, he sauntered down the campaign trail on the day after driving his rival, Andrew M. Cuomo, to an early surrender in the race for the Democratic nomination for governor. 
 Standing with a knot of local politicians at a community center in Buffalo, Mr. McCall said that his presumptive opponent in the general election, Gov. George E. Pataki, did not stand a chance against a newly united Democratic Party. 
"When they see all the support, they're going to do what the guy did yesterday," Mr. McCall said, waving his long expressive arms at his comrades. "George Pataki is going to withdraw before this is over with."
Mr. McCall was so pleased with the idea that he repeated it when a reporter implied that Mr. Cuomo could have saved him precious time and money by dropping out earlier. "Just think how much George Pataki could save me if he were to pull out now," he retorted, to laughter. "It's these 11-hour exits that bother me."
But that was as close as he came to taking a swipe at his former opponent, whom he repeatedly acknowledged and thanked during a two-city victory lap to Buffalo and Albany. 
On Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo, facing a near-certain loss and a faltering campaign, fell cleanly onto his sword in a political maneuver that had been encouraged by both Mr. Cuomo's enemies and his supporters, including former President Bill Clinton. 
Although Mr. Cuomo's capitulation drew the spotlight, the moment was a sweet one for McCall supporters, who were angered when Mr. Cuomo, who had never before run for office, first decided to challenge Mr. McCall -- the state comptroller, the party favorite and the first black man with a viable shot at becoming governor. 
Mr. Cuomo declared on Tuesday that in the next morning he would "set out to work with Carl McCall and Democrats all across this state." But he spent the next 24 hours or so on the national media circuit, appearing on "Charlie Rose" and "Donahue" and, his spokesman said, "making thank-you calls."
Mr. McCall, as the presumptive winner of the Sept. 10 primary, now faces a formidable opponent in Governor Pataki, a popular incumbent and an energetic campaigner with a treasury about nine times larger than Mr. McCall's.
But yesterday was not a day to dwell on the negative. 
It was a day to embrace former Cuomo supporters wearing blue and red McCall stickers, to announce that former President Clinton was planning a fund-raising effort for the campaign, and to stand on the steps of the State Capitol in Albany as Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, called Mr. McCall "a man of style and grace and wisdom" and many other pleasant things.
Not that Mr. McCall abandoned his usual caution. "There are some of you out there who believe today we should just run up the steps and take over right now," he said, motioning at the Capitol behind him. "But let me tell you, we have to go through two steps before we do that," he continued, admonishing people to go to the polls on Tuesday. Mr. Cuomo's name and that of his chosen partner, Charlie King, who withdrew from the race for lieutenant governor, will remain on the primary ballot.
It is not yet clear what will happen to Mr. Cuomo's campaign war chest, although a Cuomo spokesman, Peter Ragone, said that when the campaign's debts were settled the money would be closer to $1 million than the $3.3 million recorded in the last campaign finance reports.
Mr. McCall held a fund-raising event at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan last night.
Earlier, in Albany, Mr. McCall stuck to his usual script, although he riffed to an audience more responsive than usual. 
"All the people of the State of New York know that George Pataki has failed us," Mr. McCall said. "He has failed our children. He has embraced the concept that says that our children are only entitled to an eighth-grade education." At that, the audience booed, and Mr. McCall intoned, "That's what he said!"
He also announced that if elected, Dennis Mehiel, a successful businessman running for lieutenant governor in an alliance with Mr. McCall, would lead the state economic development program. Mr. McCall denouncedthe governor's record on the upstate economy, saying that if it were a separate state, upstate New York would rank last in job creation.
Sandy Treadwell, the chairman of the State Republican Party, appeared at the Capitol rally to defend the governor, saying he had created 160,000 jobs upstate in his eight years in office. Mr. Treadwell criticized Mr. McCall for failing to invest more of the state pension fund in New York businesses.
But privately, top Republicans said that Mr. McCall would be a tougher opponent than Mr. Cuomo would have been. Mr. McCall, they said, was better liked and would be better able to hold together the traditional Democratic coalition of minority and union voters that Governor Pataki has courted.
If Mr. Cuomo had won the primary, they said, they would have linked him to his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and the economic woes of the early and mid-1990's.
That is the same argument that Roger Stone, Tom Golisano's chief strategist, has made for months. "If Cuomo had been the nominee, a lot of the Democratic vote would have been up for grabs in November, and Pataki, the liberal, would have picked up most of it," Mr. Stone said yesterday. "Cuomo losing now is a substantial loss for Pataki and a substantial win for Tom."

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Carl McCall visited the Capitol yesterday, jubilant at the withdrawal of his opponent for the Democratic nomination, Andrew M. Cuomo. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES; 
Flag-Bearer Of Fine Silver

BYLINE:  By Wendy Moonan

 BODY:
Michael James was 18 when he bought his first piece of antique Georg Jensen silver. "I had never heard of Georg Jensen when I bought the four-piece 'Blossom' tea set," said Mr. James, an Englishman who began selling antique silver as a teenager. "I'd never seen anything that amazing and different in my life. Everything else looked rehashed."
 Jensen, the Danish silver company, was founded in 1904, and by the 1920's it had shops all over the world: "In New York, Buenos Aires, Paris, London, Stockholm and Berlin," said Mr. James, co-managing director of the Silver Fund, dealers in vintage Jensen silver. "By the 1950's, Jensen had a shop on the Queen Mary, the Concorde of its day. The Jensen name has always carried an assumption of quality. The silver was always made in the most expensive way possible." 
 In the 1980's Mr. James decided to specialize in antique Jensen silver and kept buying. His timing proved fortunate. "Silver prices were depressed after the Bunker Hunt boom," he said, referring to the attempt in 1980 by Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas oilman, and his family to inflate the price of silver by accumulating large amounts. Then the bubble burst. 
To cater to the demand for vintage Jensen silver, Mr. James and Alastair Crawford, another veteran English dealer in antique silver, put together a group of investors in 1995 to form the Silver Fund. They amassed an inventory of 50,000 antique Jensen pieces, including estate flatware, jewelry and holloware. They opened a small shop in London and started selling estate Jensen silver at American fairs like the Palm Beach International Art and Antiques Fair and the Modernism show at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. In 1996 the Englishmen created thesilverfund.com, a surprisingly successful Web site.
"All of our best clients buy on the Internet," Mr. James said. "You have to have a brand people trust. Think of it this way: if you were going to buy a tie online, you would buy an Hermes tie because you can trust the quality. There is safety in the brand. It's the same with Jensen."
Now his business has expanded again. Six months after opening their first United States store, at 1001 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, in Manhattan, they moved their London shop. Last week they opened the new, three-floor Silver Fund store at 1 Duke of York Street at the corner of Jermyn Street in the St. James's neighborhood of the West End.
The Silver Fund is now the single largest source in the world for vintage Jensen silver, Mr. James said. "We are also the largest buyer," he said. "We buy estates. We buy from other dealers. We buy at Sotheby's and Christie's." It is the choice for people as fashionable as Karl Lagerfeld and as powerful as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
There is a lot of antique Jensen silver in existence, about $800 million worth of it, Mr. James estimated. He calculated the volume in sheer manpower hours. "In the 1930's the firm probably had some 200 silversmiths," he said. "In its heyday in the 1950's it employed 250. Now it has 12."
At one time Jensen made 33 flatware patterns, 23 of which are no longer produced, and about 1,200 holloware items: bowls, candelabra, pitchers, tea sets, trays, vases, wine coolers, covered fish platters and more. Like Georg Jensen jewelry, many holloware pieces were embellished with semiprecious stones like amber, amethyst, garnet, lapis lazuli, malachite, opal and quartz.
Within a given flatware pattern, like the ever popular "Acorn," Jensen created as many as 272 separate pieces: serving pieces, fish knives and forks, ice cream spoons, you name it. One full set is on display in Copenhagen in the small Jensen museum next to the shop selling products made by Royal Scandinavia, the current parent of Georg Jensen.
Why would people buy vintage Jensen flatware when they could order a brand new set at the Jensen shop in New York? "We are 40 to 50 percent cheaper, and we have more selection," Mr. James said. The Silver Fund also has a bridal and gift registry.
Jensen silver comes in three distinct styles: Art Nouveau, Art Deco and Modern. Georg Jensen himself was a follower of the Art Nouveau movement. His signature motif, the cluster of grapes, is part of his repertory of forms from nature, including berries, leaves and fauna, which he combined with lightly hammered plain surfaces.
Over the years before his death in 1935, Jensen hired a series of talented designers who were allowed to go their own ways. The most noteworthy include Harald Nielsen (1892-1977), the young brother of Jensen's third wife, Johanne Nielsen; Count Sigvard Bernadotte (1907-2002), the second son of Gustav VI of Sweden, who was known for his classic geometric shapes, especially cylinders, spheres and streamlining elements; and Henning Koppel (1918-1981), a radical modernist whose unadorned biomorphic designs have become icons of their time and are in great demand.
In the end Jensen's greatest talent may have been his ability to find and nurture other talents. Jensen did not lead an easy life and did not die a happy man despite his success and recognition.
The son of a blacksmith, Jensen grew up in a poor family in the little industrial town of Raavad, north of Copenhagen. He always called it "a paradise on earth," fondly remembering its powerful oaks, towering beeches and blue clay, which he used to sculpture human figures. As a boy, he was sent to work at a foundry to help support his parents and seven siblings.
When he was 14, his family moved to Copenhagen, and he apprenticed with a goldsmith. In his spare time, he took drawing, geometry, engraving and modeling courses. He decided to become a sculptor.
"It was an improbable ambition for a working-class young man," Mr. James said. "Jensen was driven to realize his dream. He passed the entrance examination of the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts and joined its sculpture class in 1887."
After graduating in 1892 he made art pottery. Nothing sold. He married and had two children, but after his wife died he decided he had better return to his old craft, metalsmithing, to support the family. He designed and made silver jewelry.
Finally in 1904 he opened his own shop in Copenhagen. Soon he had 60 people working for him. His designs were a success; his business skills were not.
"He struggled most of his life," Mr. James said. "He always needed new investors."
His life was also filled with personal sorrow. He lost three wives, Mr. James said. He also lost control of his company. In 1925 Jensen left the company and moved to Paris to start a new workshop. It didn't work. The next year he was back in Copenhagen. He agreed to become the company's artistic director, a role that was fairly limited, though he continued to design for the company until he died. Today he is recognized for his immense creativity and productivity, especially outside his native country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the Henning Koppel designs for Georg Jensen from the 1950's. (The Silver Fund)

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Bennington, Vt.

BYLINE:  By DAVID A. KELLY 

 BODY:
BENNINGTON is one of those places where people brag that everything is close. In 45 minutes, said T. J. Carmody, the cheerful proprietor of Carmody's Tavern, an Irish-style pub on Main Street, "I can be in Williamstown for the theater festival" or "up in the mountains skiing." Brenda Jones, the owner of Brenda Jones Realty, said one big advantage is that an international airport is only 40 miles away, in Albany. Even the Chamber of Commerce is quick to point out what's elsewhere, within 50 or 60 miles: 12 ski areas; outlet stores in Manchester, Vt.; and concerts at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in New York and Tanglewood in the Berkshires.
 Then what is in little Bennington, a town of 15,000 enclosing downtown Bennington; the adjacent picturesque, picket-fenced hamlet of Old Bennington; and the village of North Bennington? 
 For a symbolic answer, take a long look through rolling fields and over covered bridges and steeples, to the hilltop where the artsy and experimental Bennington College, populated largely by urbanites, has set its modernist buildings. This is still the postcard Vermont that nurtured Robert Frost, who is buried in Old Bennington, and inspired Grandma Moses. The native Vermonter who grew up driving the back roads and inner-tubing in the Walloomsac River can still be found. But there has been an urban intrusion. With your pancakes and maple syrup, you can get an espresso.

Workaday Town With a Past
Bennington venerates its past. Its most prominent landmark is the 306-foot Battle Monument, on Monument Hill on the north side of Old Bennington, commemorating the Battle of Bennington in 1777, won by the Americans. The Bennington Potter's Yard, a 50-year-old factory and outlet store, builds on the industrial developments of the 18th and early 19th centuries, when water power from the Walloomsac made Bennington a mill town and the center of much of the nation's pottery making.
The Bennington Museum on West Main Street has pottery, American glass and what it says is the largest public display of Grandma Moses paintings anywhere. Hemmings Motor News, a bible for collectors of antique cars, has offices on West Main Street, with an antique filling station and a collection of private cars available for public viewing.
Today, Bennington is struggling for a new economic balance. Batteries and automotive parts are still made here, but many manufacturers have left. Farming still supports some residents, and tourism is increasingly important.
Vermont Route 9 is Main Street in Bennington, and it intersects with U.S. Route 7 at downtown's commercial four corners. A new bypass is expected to be completed in two years; until then, a tractor-trailer or two may interfere with easy progress. There are art galleries, clothing shops and a cozy bookstore -- just don't expect to find them all open in the evening. Besides Carmody's, which serves pasta and sandwiches along with the Guinness, there are Mexican, Chinese and vegetarian restaurants and Sonny's Blue Benn Diner, a local institution.
So far, Bennington has few national chain stores and restaurants. Nancy Woltman, originally from the Bronx and now the owner of Panache, a clothing and jewelry boutique on Main Street, sees independent shops like hers as contributors to the relaxed atmosphere. "I go to New York on buying trips for clothing, and I love the sense of peace I get when I come back," she said. The rural quiet also suits some celebrities: Norman Lear, the television producer, has a house in the Bennington area, as does the writer Jamaica Kincaid.
The river that powered the mills is now used for kayaking, canoeing and inner-tubing. Bicycle tours and mountain biking are popular, and there is an access point for the Appalachian Trail four miles from downtown.

Buying In
The average price of a house in the Bennington area is about $150,000, and the market is active, with some spillover from hot markets in Manchester and Williamstown, Mass.
Second-home seekers will find stately older houses from the 18th and 19th centuries and a variety of newer dwellings. A house dating from 1785, with a modern addition and six bedrooms, was for sale in Old Bennington this week for $595,000. A two-bedroom condominium in a clapboard-faced building was offered for $69,000. In the countryside, old Vermont farmhouses come up for sale now and then, but more common is an offering like the eight-room Cape on 1.8 acres for $259,000.

Getting There
Bennington is 190 miles northeast of Manhattan. Take the New York State Thruway to Albany and exit at Route 787 north. Follow Route 787 for 8.6 miles to the exit for New York Route 7 east. Drive right across the state line, where the road becomes Vermont Route 9, and into Bennington.

GRAPHIC: Photo: VERMONT GOTHIC -- The Bennington Battle Monument provides an idyllic Vermont view. Below is a comfortable town that is in touch with its roots. (Will Waldron for The New York Times) Map of Vermont highlighting Bennington.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Hawaii's Little Chunk of Open Road

BYLINE:  By MICHELE KAYAL 

 BODY:
YOU can drive up 13,796 feet in a morning -- probably the fastest climb by road anywhere -- on the island of Hawaii. That afternoon, you can be back at sea level, watching liquid-hot magma spilling into the Pacific. And if you choose to keep moving, by nightfall you can be cruising past the orchards, ranches and plantations that are still an economic mainstay of the Big Island, as it is known.
 A drive of less than 500 miles, roughly around the island's perimeter with some inland loops, ricochets among vast contrasts: from the chilly, sometimes snowy summit of Mauna Kea to the fire of Kilauea, the active volcano; through black lava deserts and dewy rain forests; past tourist attractions and abandoned sugar cane fields grown up with weeds. 
 This is compact touring, but when drivers in Hawaii long for miles of open road, the Big Island is the best they can get. 
Hawaii's Interstate highways are a tease: 52 miles of pavement (all on Oahu) and none that can take you to another state. Only the Big Island -- about the size of Connecticut and nearly twice as large as the five other major islands combined -- is big enough to sustain a respectable trip by automobile. Because so much of the island is still rural, there are long stretches where traffic is sparse and the driving is relaxed and easy.
Routes 11 and 19, the major roads, are mostly well paved and have two lanes. The rural landscape, once heavily given over to sugar cane, has changed since the last mills closed in the 90's, forcing the island to try new crops and learn new ways.
Charlene Cowan, a macadamia grower near Naalehu, says she hopes for a future similar to the development of the Napa Valley, with visitors taking leisurely trips and sampling exotic tropical foods where they are produced. (She is pioneering the idea, running a bed-and-breakfast and giving her guests tours of her orchards.)
For most who visit the Big Island, the spectacular scenery comes first. On the upward drive west from Hilo to Mauna Kea, about 30 miles away, meticulous tropical gardens along the Saddle Road give way to scrub, then heaps of flinty lava rubble. Then comes the summit road, a largely unpaved, curving climb that challenges both a four-wheel-drive truck and its passengers. At the visitors' center at 9,000 feet, a bag of potato chips strains in the thin air as if it were an inflatable pillow.
On the narrow, rocky rumble to the top, the gray cooked terrain and rolling red dunes conjure the Moon. But once at the peak, if the day is clear and the oxygen-starved brain can take it in, the reward is a view across the island and the sea, with sunlight glinting off the domes of the 12 astronomical observatories on Mauna Kea itself and Maui's signature volcano, Haleakala, seeming almost nearby.
Back along the highway, south of Hilo, is the lava show at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. The spectacle has turned up a notch since May, said Don Swanson, a park geologist, when a new flow began and spilled close to a road. Rivers of fire cascade down the mountainside, 2,100 degrees of molten rock. Hundreds of hikers at a time tramp across recently hardened, graphite-sheened surfaces, some still warm to the touch, to the plume of pink-tinted steam where the flow meets the ocean.
Kilauea has been erupting since 1983; in just the last few weeks, this converging flow has added about nine acres to the Big Island. Just outside the park, Volcano Village, a flower-filled town in a tropical rain forest, offers several good places to stay.
A few miles farther south, Route 11 goes through the Kau Desert, a huge expanse of chunky black volcanic debris. The settlements beyond it, in the island's southern horn, grew up in the 19th century in rich volcanic soil where sugar cane flourished -- bare-bones company towns to serve the sugar workers, for whom the pay was low and luxuries meager. Hidden away near one of these towns, Pahala, is the bright red, green and gold Wood Valley Buddhist Temple. It was built a century ago by Japanese immigrants who came to cut cane but is now tied to the Buddhism of Tibet.
The dirt road leading to it winds through fallow fields shaggy with weeds and random, self-sown cane and opens to a tropical glen. "The Dalai Lama has been here twice," said Maile Yamanaka, a temple volunteer. It is, as she put it, "his home in Hawaii."
Naalehu springs into sight, promoting its claim to fame on numerous signs: "Southernmost community in the U.S.A." It's enough to persuade tourists to stop and maybe buy some taro-flavored Portuguese sweet bread. This is the town where Ms. Cowan has her macadamia trees, and she is one of many growers.
Macadamias are common in this part of the island, along with other expanding crops, like coffee and medicinal herbs, replacing the old, monotonous vistas of cane fields. There are cattle, too -- brown steers dotting the hillsides, and dairy cows lying about in pens. Ms. Cowan says there are 5,500 farms in the entire state, with about two-thirds of them on the Big Island.
A road off the main highway goes to a barren black lava plain and a fishing village called Milolii that is home mostly to native islanders. Everyone here is family, said Kaimi Kaupiko, a University of Hawaii student who sometimes works in his parents' general store in the village, and it was only about 20 years ago that they switched from outrigger canoes to motorboats. Some villagers work at tourist hotels farther north; some own macadamia or coffee farms. But mostly, he says, they still fish.
Route 11 morphs into Route 19 on its way up the western, or leeward coast, and moist roads branch off it into the mountains to the Mayberry-style villages that make up Kona coffee country. Clusters of coffee beans hang from trees that line the roadside, and signs urge visitors to stop at the farms for a tour and a sample. On the other side of this route, are the tourists. In Kailua, families and teenagers stroll along a sea wall, eat at the Hard Rock Cafe and snap up refrigerator magnets and T-shirts. Tourism now makes up about half of the island's economy. 
Out of sight farther north are the five-star resorts, private golf courses and gated communities of the wealthy. 
The island's famous cowboys can be found near Waimea, where Route 19 passes after turning inland into the undulating velvet hills. Cattle graze on every slope.
And then there is the last curving leg of the trip, back south toward Hilo along the Hamakua Coast, where it rains 130 inches a year. The highway dodges in and out of impossibly green gulches, and in spots one wrong move on a sharp curve could send a car plunging hundreds of feet to the ocean below. Much of this coastal road traces what used to be a railway, built to haul sugar. It stopped service in 1946, after a tsunami destroyed many of its bridges. Now the people work in Kona hotels miles away or grow exotic crops like orchids or rambutan, a tropical fruit, or, on one farm, vanilla.
The Hawaiian Vanilla Company, in Paauilo, produces the only vanilla commercially grown in the United States. It has nearly 10,000 vanilla plants, a type of climbing orchid grown in greenhouses. The vines are thick, green and twisting, and it is the celadon-colored flower that actually produces the bean.
When James Reddekopp Sr., the operations manager, slices open a bean -- which looks like a tiny, swollen Japanese eggplant before it is dried -- and peels back its chocolate-brown husk, it reveals a sensuous black must, full of tiny gold flecks. Those are "purest vanillin," he said.
He added, with enthusiasm, "That's going to drive Madagascar nuts!" He is convinced that Hawaii's bean has a milder aroma and can beat its competition from Madagascar or Tahiti.
Like Ms. Cowan, with her agritourism, Mr. Reddekopp and his son, James Jr., who started the company, are pioneers, part of the changing face of the Big Island. And like her, they believe in their notion of what will ultimately help take all of Hawaii to a new verdure and prosperity.
"My vision of this state," he said, looking out over the neat rows of plants, "is wherever you saw sugar cane and pineapple, you'll see vanilla beans."

IF YOU RENT
Book Ahead and Read the Fine Print
Car rentals are big business on the Big Island, for both the familiar national rental agencies and local companies. It is a good idea to reserve well in advance.
Many companies offer four-wheel-drive vehicles but restrict where they can be driven. That puts the partly unpaved summit road at Mauna Kea off limits. Many agencies also rule out drives to places like the lovely Waipio Valley, reachable only by a clifflike road. To visit these remote spots, it may be necessary to park the car and go by bus or van or on foot. If you do rent from a company that allows a drive up Mauna Kea, read the rental contract carefully. Some have big insurance deductibles. 
Prices vary, but a full-size sedan generally rents for $45 to $50 a day, not including taxes, and a four-wheel-drive truck or sport utility vehicle for $80 to $130.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 3473 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
From Photos to Relics, Remembering the Unforgettable

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
In the days after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last September, some people lamented that art was frivolous or pointless in the face of such horrors. But that didn't stop anyone from turning to art for comfort -- or from making it, either. 
 Even before the predictions that irony would die, materialism would end and television would turn serious had faded, the "pointless" point of view regarding art drowned in a flood of diverse, aesthetically oriented visual activity. Coping was the overused word, but also a very real explanation. People needed to look at things that reflected their loss, and they often made them themselves. 
 Within 48 hours of the attacks, a vibrant form of participatory folk art was, if not born, then taken to new, often glorious extremes in the shrines that sprang up all around the city. Exhibitions of videotapes and photographs, many of them by amateur photographers, proliferated -- most notably in the "Here Is New York" exhibition in a Prince Street storefront in SoHo. People began planning memorial quilts and trauma-oriented art programs. Artists returned to their studios, sometimes working without electricity in loft buildings that were once in the towers' shadows. 
For the first anniversary of the attacks, scores of exhibitions and screenings have been organized in museums, galleries, libraries and the lobbies of office buildings. Many, but not all, display art made in reaction to or in commemoration of the attacks -- by children, quilters and photographers, as well as by people who make art on a full-time basis. Some shows are already open; others cannot be seen until Tuesday or Wednesday. 
It seems irrelevant right now to consider whether any of this work is commensurate with the loss. Much of it isn't, but some definitely is. If these shows run the gamut in quality, there is comfort and clarity, whether emotional or aesthetic, to be gained from all of them. And they all affirm that the will toward visual expression is hard-wired into human nature.

Baruch College
"In Memory: The Art of Afterward," an exhibition at the Sidney Mishkin Gallery at Baruch College, is a useful reminder that contemporary artists from around the globe have tried to respond to trauma in life-affirming ways, and with immense stylistic diversity. The show, organized by the Legacy Project, a New York-based organization that studies artistic responses to the effects of violence, includes work made during the last four decades by artists from 16 countries. 
They commemorate specific historic traumas, including American slavery (Betty Saar) and the killings of Armenians by Turkish soldiers in World War I (Samia Barsamian), as well as broader occurrences like displacement or the deaths of loved ones. The show is a mix of the familiar and the less known, of maudlin and good work.
Good includes a small, dynamic wood maquette relief from Frank Stella's "Polish Village" series and "Martial Law V" by the Japanese painter Shigeo Ishii (1933-1962). Mr. Ishii's work, made during the American occupation of Japan, depicts a sharp-edged urban canyon full of hovering, spinning black spheres.
Another of the show's surprises is "Painting With Flying Houses" (1975) by Oscar Rabine, a Russian living in Paris; it is a dark, robust reprise of Chagall and Kandinsky.

New-York Historical Society
Commemorative visual gestures take many forms, but the three primary -- not always separate, of course -- seem to be artifacts (or relics), documentaries and art. They are all in evidence at the New-York Historical Society, beginning in its Great Hall with displays of a street shrine, some artifacts and 15 photographs of ground zero by David Margules, a photographer for The New York Post. 
But the main event here is a sequence of three photography exhibitions and a spherical panorama of New York City that together create an extremely moving progression of emotional and visual perspectives. 
First comes "Twin Towers Remembered," a selection from the many photographs that Camilo Jose Vergara made of the World Trade Center during what was, in essence, a 30-year love affair with the buildings. Recording their existence from construction to destruction, from all angles, in all kinds of weather, these images celebrate the towers as icons of power and glamour -- glinting in the sun, being saluted by tugboats, dominating Lower Manhattan.
But they also show the sheer variety and extent of the buildings' visibility. Whether looming large or barely visible in the distance, they were landmarks in locales throughout the region, from the marshes of Jamaica Bay to the broken-down docks of Newark. Mr. Vergara had his camera with him on Sept. 11, and later returned to some of his favorite viewpoints to photograph New York without the towers, and these pictures are also included. 
While images of ground zero might logically follow Mr. Vergara's, the second exhibition focuses instead on the people who came to see it. "Pilgrimage: Looking at Ground Zero" consists of 30 photographs taken by Kevin Bubriski during five visits to New York toward the end of last year.
These large black-and-white images have none of the randomness of expression or movement associated with street photography. Their caught-in-the-headlights intensity conveys an incredible range of human response that is neither forced nor disguised. Pilgrims are seekers, and Mr. Bubriski's pictures show people in the moment of finding what they sought, a deeper, more literal understanding of the destruction of the attacks. 
"Beyond Ground Zero: The Forensic Science of Disaster Recovery," an exhibition of color photographs by the photojournalist Richard Press, takes another view of the aftermath of the attacks, with images of the New York City medical examiner's office and the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island in the months since last September.
Accompanied by explanatory labels, they show the refrigerated trucks, each with its own American flag and potted flowers, where human remains were temporarily stored; rows of frost-covered vials containing tissue samples; a single tooth in a test tube; and workers examining chunks of debris on a conveyor belt. Their combination of blunt factuality and implicit tenderness has an undeniable power. 
With "In the Light of Memory: A Spherical Panorama From the South Tower of the World Trade Center," the progression of shifting perspectives comes to a close with an exhilarating yet painful moment of illusion created by the painter Christopher Evans.
This time, we see the world as it looked from the public concourse of the South Tower, a view that will never be seen again. It is painted with wonderful precision and restraint on a sphere that seems as light and smooth as a balloon shot through with the late-afternoon sun. (Jan Van Eyck must be Mr. Evans's favorite artist.)
Everything is there: the rivers, the harbor, the lesser skyscrapers of Manhattan, the afternoon sun, the expanses of New Jersey, Staten Island and Long Island stretching toward the curved horizons, and, finally, the big striated plane of the North Tower. For one second, it is as if Sept. 11, 2001, never happened. 
The final element in the historical society's 9/11 presentation is a well-chosen sampling of the many films and videos that have been made about the attacks and their aftermath, including Bryan Kortis and Steven Mudrick's "WTC: Uncut," which will have its premiere on Tuesday. Other substantial film and video programs are being presented at the Kitchen Art Gallery in Chelsea and at the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, which is also showing "WTC: Uncut."

Museum of the City Of New York
"The Day Our World Changed: Children's Art of 9/11," which opens today at the Museum of the City of New York, counters the unflinching scrutiny pervading the shows at the New-York Historical Society with works infused with exaggeration, poetry and even joy. An exhibition of art by New York City schoolchildren, solicited by the New York University Child Study Center, the show includes watercolors, drawings, collages and murals.
Judging from the book that accompanies the exhibition, there was a lot to choose from, because many of the works look superb. The art of children can give horrific events a beguiling, comedic air while also revealing primal feelings with inspired intensity. 
In addition, the museum has organized a powerful photography exhibition of its own. In the lobby of 195 Broadway in Lower Manhattan, it will display 70 of the haunting images of ground zero taken by Joel Meyerowitz.

American Folk Art Museum
Like other New York art museums, the American Folk Art Museum has turned to its permanent collection and is observing the 9/11 anniversary with a display of Edward Hicks's "Peaceable Kingdom" at its building on West 53rd Street. But the museum's Eva and Morris Feld Gallery at Lincoln Square has something more specific: "The National Tribute Quilt," a 33-foot-long mural quilt assembled by four women who work in the Pittsburgh steel industry and call themselves the Steel Quilters of Pittsburgh.
This shimmering, mosaiclike expanse depicts the skyline of Manhattan with the towers sheathed in gold. Up close, its more than 3,100 3-by-3-inch squares come into focus. Made by more than 1,000 quilters in the United States and abroad, they are individually inscribed or embroidered with the names of the people known to have died in New York, at the Pentagon and aboard the four hijacked airplanes.

Deutsche Bank
An excellent exhibition in the lobby of the Deutsche Bank, also on West 53rd Street, steps back in time. "Americus: Selections From the New York City Fire Museum" celebrates the collective spirit, pageantry and courage of the city's fire companies over several generations.
Its beautiful, unpretentious mix of objects and images includes prints, photographs, models and toys, among them a spectacular model of a horse-drawn aerial ladder truck. Among the 19th-century material are leather buckets and fire hoses, wood water mains, brass speaking trumpets and elaborately decorated leather presentation shields. 
This exhibition dovetails with what promises to be a simple but heart-rending display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art: the chalkboards on which the firefighters on duty at Engine Company 22 and Ladder Company 13 in Manhattan signed out on Sept. 11. Damaged when distraught firefighters removed them from the wall for safekeeping, the boards were restored by the Met's conservation department and placed in hermetically sealed frames. Before being returned to the companies, they will be shown in the museum's Charles Engelhard Court for six days, beginning Tuesday. 

Municipal Art Society
The idiosyncratic display at the Municipal Art Society is less an exhibition than a collective work of late Conceptual art orchestrated by the small staff of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. The council had offices in the World Trade Center and in cooperation with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey sponsored a studio program on the 91st and 92nd floors of the North Tower, which was overseen by Moukhtar Kocache, the council's director of visual and media arts. (Michael Richards, one of the participants last year, died in the collapse of the building.) 
Invited to present a show at the Municipal Art Society, Mr. Kocache, in turn, invited the former participants in the program (about 140 artists) to send not art but photographs taken in and around the building during their residencies. The result, organized by Christopher K. Ho and Stephan Apicella-Hitchcock, is "Microviews: Artists' Documents of the World Trade Center," an austere presentation of more than 400 photographs, arranged in folders in a 20-foot-long line of black file drawers and also displayed on a video monitor.
This strangely affecting show returns to the fact of the buildings themselves but avoids their status as icons of urban and economic might, placing the emphasis on randomness and minutiae. It tours the anonymous hallways and cluttered out-of-the-way spaces, subbasements included, and occasionally shows someone in a studio, staring at a blank canvas. It includes views from windows, close-ups of ceilings and blurred images of bustling lunchtime crowds.
The images are numbered, cross-referenced by subject and organized in a strictly formal manner, which creates a dizzying array of shifting perspectives. For example, a view of objects on a desktop is followed by one of building roofs viewed from above, because their compositions are both strongly diagonal. 
Yet "Microviews," which Mr. Kocache intends to expand, is also as cumulative as a street shrine and almost as touchingly intimate. It measures the loss of the World Trade Center in fractions of time, space and material, in glimpses of lives being lived, and finds that it is as enormous as ever.

HEADLINE: Canadian Union Picks G.M. for First Talks 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
The union representing 46,000 Canadian auto workers today chose General Motors as its target -- the company that it will negotiate a new labor contract with first, to set a pattern for contracts with the others. But the union indicated that its most serious issues were with Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler, not G.M.
 Announcing the choice to cheering union officials at a Toronto hotel, Buzz Hargrove, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers Union, said job security remained the union's top concern even though car and truck sales are strong. "Restructuring, job losses, layoffs and closures are still threats that we're having to face in our bargaining," Mr. Hargrove said. The union will also seek "substantial" wage increases, he said. 
 The American and Canadian operations of the Big Three automakers are closely integrated, with assembly lines in each country producing vehicles for the entire North American market. 
Still, for the first time in many years, bargaining on new labor contracts will not take place simultaneously in the United States and Canada. The current contracts in Canada are for three years, and expire at midnight on Sept. 17; the United Auto Workers' contracts in the United States are for four years and expire in 2003.
Next year's talks in the United States are expected to be centered less on job security and more on pension and health care costs, analysts said.
In both countries, the auto workers generally negotiate first with the company from whom, in Mr. Hargrove's words, "we believe we can get the best agreement with the least amount of sacrifice." 
Relations between the Canadian union and G.M. have improved markedly in recent years, Mr. Hargrove said, though the 20,000 G.M. workers he represents will nonetheless strike immediately if there is no new contract in place when the old one expires.
Few analysts expect that to happen. "There's going to be a lot of noise, but it will be settled amicably," said Dennis DesRosiers, an industry consultant in Toronto. "General Motors is in a position where they are very profitable, and have good labor relations."
For its part, G.M. is "confident that we'll be able to come to an agreement that meets the needs of employees, the C.A.W. and the competitive environment in the industry," said Richard James, a company spokesman. The Canadian Auto Workers last chose G.M. as its negotiating target in 1984.
By contrast, "Ford and DaimlerChrysler are in a very defensive mode right now," said Richard Cooper, executive director of J. D. Power & Associates, automotive consultants in Toronto.
All three manufacturers have recently announced plant closings in Canada. Last month, G.M. shut down a plant at Ste. Therese, Quebec, that built Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird sports cars, eliminating 1,400 jobs.
But the union agreed to the closing of the plant, in part because G.M. was expanding elsewhere in Canada, adding a shift at its Oshawa plant east of Toronto to build more Buick Impalas and announcing plans to invest $191 million there to start making a new midsize Pontiac model.
Ford has said it will close a pickup truck assembly line at Oakville, west of Toronto, next year, a bigger concern for the union. But "Ford is not in a position to be overly generous right now," said Mr. Cooper of J. D. Powers.
The Big Three broke sales records in both the United States and Canada in August, with the help of generous discounts and interest-free financing deals. In the United States, sales in August ran at an annual rate of 18.7 million vehicles, up 13.5 percent from August 2001. G.M. did even better, posting an 18.2 percent rise and gaining eight-tenths of a percentage point in market share. Ford and DaimlerChrysler lost share. 
In Canada, General Motors' sales rose 13.4 percent in August, far ahead of Ford's 2.9 percent and DaimlerChrysler's 2.3 percent.
Industry executives say that the torrid sales pace is unlikely to last through the fall and that intense competition will erode profit margins.
Noting that General Motors had extended its incentives to 2003 model vehicles now arriving in dealer showrooms, Mr. Hargrove said, "They could meet our proposals and still lower the cost of their vehicles."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Buzz Hargrove, right, president of the Canadian Auto Workers Union, will bargain with Al Green, vice president for personnel at General Motors Canada, which the union set as its first bargaining target yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: D.C.'s Fiscal House 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Tarnish Anew From Race for Mayor" (news article, Sept. 3) quotes Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, as saying that the District of Columbia's economic prosperity is "guaranteed by massive, endless subsidies from the federal government" and that the locally elected government "can indulge their fantasies because there's no accountability." 
 Less than 29 percent of our budget comes from the federal government. 
What's more, D.C.'s budget for fiscal year 2002 represents our fifth consecutive surplus budget. We receive no state government assistance, and our tax base is severely constrained because of the enormous percentage of property that is tax-exempt (federal buildings, museums, monuments, embassies and so on). Hundreds of thousands of people work here yet pay income taxes to neighboring jurisdictions.
In short, we have what has been described as a structural imbalance that presents a fiscal challenge that is unique to D.C. Nevertheless, we have put our fiscal house in order. As for accountability -- every dollar of our government spending, even locally raised revenue, is subject to Congressional review and approval. 

ANTHONY A. WILLIAMS
Mayor, District of Columbia
Washington, Sept. 3, 2002

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
First, the Zoning Change; Next, the Apartments

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
One of the first results of a recent change in zoning in downtown Brooklyn is beginning to take shape at 53 Boerum Place, where construction began last month on an 11-story building that will have 99 market-rate rental apartments. 
 The nine-block area affected by the rezoning is on the edge of downtown Brooklyn and connects it to the Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill historic districts. Bounded roughly by Livingston, Smith and Court Streets and Atlantic Avenue, the rezoned area is dotted with parking lots, retail and commercial buildings, and a few residential buildings. 
 The new apartment building will rise in the next 16 months on a former parking lot at the northeast corner of State Street and Boerum Place. Its neighbors include the Brooklyn Criminal Court, the Brooklyn House of Detention and the Brooklyn Friends Meetinghouse. 
The developers of the new building said they were attracted to the project both by its proximity to transit links and by the change in zoning last summer that allowed an increase in the density of residential buildings constructed in the area and set a height limit of 120 feet for new buildings. 
"Without the change, this project would not have been economically feasible," said Mario Procida, president of the Procida Realty and Construction Corporation of the Bronx. His company, with Second Development Services, a Brooklyn firm headed by Louis V. Greco, formed 53 Boerum Place L.L.C. to develop the rental. Mr. Greco said that under the old zoning, only a six-story residential building with 50 apartments could have been developed.
Financing for the $25 million project is coming from the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation and the developers' own funds. 
Regina Myer, director of the Brooklyn office of the Department of City Planning, said 53 Boerum Place was "the kind of project that was intended by the upzoning, which was meant to encourage new housing." Ms. Myer said another aim of the change, part of a larger rezoning package, was to promote commercial development and establish a transition area.
Another project that will take advantage of the rezoning is moving through the development process. At 233 Atlantic Avenue, between Court Street and Boerum Place, a mixed-use development made up of two 12-story towers on a common base, including up to 260 rental units, is planned on a city-owned site now occupied by a four-story parking garage. The project, to be developed by Two Trees Management of Brooklyn, would also include a Y.M.C.A, retail space and parking for 700 cars.
On the northwest corner of State Street and Boerum Place, Brooklyn Law School plans to build a 216-foot, 20-story, 371-bed dormitory that will replace the parking lot now on the site. The project, which has met with community opposition because of its size, is possible because of a zoning amendment that allowed the additional height. Construction is expected to start later this fall, with occupancy set for the fall of 2004.
James Whelan, director of the Downtown Brooklyn Council, an affiliate of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, said the popularity of the surrounding neighborhoods was also helping to fuel residential construction on blocks immediately east of the nine-block area that was rezoned. 
Mr. Whelan said plans were proceeding to develop a series of state-owned parking lots into buildings with 400 residences. The lots are on the northeast corner of Atlantic Avenue and Smith Street and on the south side of Schermerhorn Street between Hoyt and Smith Streets and between Hoyt and Bond Streets.
The developers of 53 Boerum Place say their building will be the first of the new residential projects to be completed. The red brick building, designed by the Stephen B. Jacobs Group of Manhattan, will have one- and two-bedroom apartments with 525 to 850 square feet each. 
Cheryl Nielsen-Saaf, a senior vice president at the Brooklyn office of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage, said that the lack of new rental apartments in the area and the surrounding neighborhoods should provide a ready market for 53 Boerum Place. 
Mr. Greco said rents at 53 Boerum Place, which will have amenities like a roof garden, a fitness center and a garage for 85 cars, were expected to be $1,600 to $3,200, or an average of $42 a square foot. Leasing of the units is scheduled for the fall of 2003, with occupancy by that December.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES 

 BODY:
 CRUDE OIL GAINS. The American Petroleum Institute reported that inventories fell close to an 18-month low, sending prices higher. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 71 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $28.98.

HEADLINE: Small Employers Severely Reduce Health Benefits 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Kathy Steever, office manager of her family's automobile repair shop in Sioux Falls, S.D., is expecting a baby in December. Her father, who also works at the shop, learned last year that he has cancer.
 Even so, their company, called Pro Tune Up, canceled health coverage for all five employees last spring. Ms. Steever said premiums jumped by two-thirds, to $2,000 a month, from $1,200 in 2001, just when demand for the shop's services was slowing in a faltering economy. 
 The cancellation of benefits at Pro Tune Up added seven adults, including two spouses, and four children to the estimated 40 million Americans without health insurance. Cutbacks at other small businesses squeezed between rising premiums and the sluggish economy are likely to add to that number.
Although most large employers still offer health benefits, fewer small companies are providing coverage. Forty-five percent of employers with three to nine workers now offer no health benefits, up three percentage points from 2001, the Kaiser Family Foundation said yesterday in its annual report on employer-based insurance.
That translates into almost 150,000 more workers and dependents without insurance.
"There has been a significant decrease in the number of small firms offering coverage," said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Foundation, adding that the surge in costs would make health care problems more difficult for policy makers in Washington and the state capitals.
Health insurance premiums across the country soared by 12.7 percent, almost eight times the 1.6 percent overall inflation rate, in the 12 months ended this spring, the Kaiser report said.
It was the largest one-year increase since 1990. Jon Gabel, who directed the Kaiser study, said all signs pointed to even higher premiums next year and beyond as costs for medical care and prescription drugs continue rising.
Small businesses had even higher premium increases: exceeding 14 percent for employers with fewer than 50 workers. That has led many small-business owners to abandon coverage, sometimes even for themselves and their family members. "Dad is just taking a chance that he's getting a clean bill of health on his cancer," said Ms. Steever, whose brother owns Pro Tune Up.
Michael Wiston, president of the Valley Marble Slate Corporation, which makes kitchen countertops in New Milford, Conn., said premiums for his seven employees had doubled since 2000, to a total of $39,600, while the services covered had been reduced.
"I have a liver problem," he said. "In another year, I'll be on a list for a transplant. What worries us is: What do they cover, and what don't they cover?"
Workers are paying more of the costs, as higher premiums, deductibles and co-payments for prescription drugs, doctor visits and hospital charges outpace wage increases.
The average share of the premium for single workers rose 27 percent, to $454 a year, and 16 percent, or $2,084, for families. But wages rose only 3 to 4 percent.
Annual premiums for preferred provider networks, or P.P.O.'s, which cover more than half of insured workers, rose to $8,037 for families, including $2,148 on average contributed by each employee. And P.P.O. deductibles rose 37 percent, to an average of $276 a year.
For a family with income of $30,000, added health care costs, including higher payments for drugs, doctor visits and hospital fees, could swallow more than half the average raise, said Mr. Gabel, a researcher at the Health Research and Educational Trust in Washington. He has tracked employer-based health costs since 1987.
"It seems like all we are working for is to pay the insurance," Ms. Steever said.
Mr. Altman of the Kaiser Foundation said, "These numbers have huge implications for the national debate about expanding health insurance coverage, regardless of whether taxes pay the costs or private insurance pays."
"Sharply rising health care costs will propel the issue to the very front of the national agenda," he said, "but they will also make it much harder to solve our big-ticket health problems -- drugs for seniors and the uninsured."
Almost all employer health plans use a type of managed care. Only 5 percent still have traditional fee-for-service coverage; 26 percent are in health maintenance organizations; 52 percent are in P.P.O.'s, which have fewer restrictive rules than H.M.O.'s; and 17 percent are in point-of-service plans, hybrids that typically combine features of H.M.O.'s and preferred provider networks.
With prescription drug costs rising 14 percent to 19 percent a year, more than half of insured workers now pay more at the pharmacy. Co-payments for typically lower-priced generic drugs are $9 on average, but the co-payment for brand-name drugs that have generic equivalents has risen 30 percent, to $26, as health plans seek to encourage people to use the generic medications.
Companies are pulling back coverage for retirees, the group that typically needs the most help paying for drugs. About one in three large companies offers retiree health benefits. Only 5 percent of smaller companies -- those with fewer than 200 workers -- provide retiree health benefits.
More than one-third of large companies have increased their retirees' share of premiums, and 17 percent have raised drug co-payments.
The Kaiser survey was based on telephone interviews with a random sample of 2,014 benefit managers at public and private employers, from January to May 2002. The margin of error was plus or minus 2.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: Reports Depict 'a Stumbling Recovery' 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
A flurry of government and private reports today showed the economic recovery moving forward but also raised concerns about its strength.
 Reports on business investment and worker productivity registered improvement, but these were balanced by a weak reading on the service sector and still quite high filing rates for jobless benefits. 
 "It's still the stumbling recovery," said Steve Ricchiuto, chief economist with ABN Amro in New York. 
Even with this wide variety of economic data, economists were looking toward the release on Friday of August unemployment figures for a more up-to-date reading on the economy. Analysts polled by Reuters said they expected unemployment to hold steady at 5.9 percent, with payrolls posting a narrow gain of 37,000 jobs.
In a weekly report, the Labor Department said today that claims for unemployment benefits fell in the week ended Aug. 31, the first decline since the week ended Aug. 3. Claims dipped to 403,000 from a revised 411,000 the week before.
Even so, claims remained for a second week above the 400,000 level, which is regarded as a sign of a weak job market -- maintaining fears that the economy is struggling to generate jobs. And the four-week moving average of jobless claims, regarded as a more reliable indicator of trends, rose to the 400,000 level for the first time since June.
Referring to the job market, Ken Mayland of ClearView Economics in Pepper Pike, Ohio, said: "The hemorrhaging has very nearly stabilized at a moderate pace, which constitutes one-half of the unemployment equation. It's the other half of the equation -- rehiring -- that has yet to show any renewed life."
There were more gloomy tidings for the economy in another private-sector report. The Institute for Supply Management said its monthly index of nonmanufacturing activity slipped to 50.9 in August from 53.1 in July -- barely positive territory.
But the data from the government was more optimistic. The Labor Department said second-quarter productivity growth slowed sharply from the first quarter, but was higher than initially thought. Output per worker hour grew at a revised annual rate of 1.5 percent, down certainly from the 8.6 percent pace in the first quarter but above the 1.1 percent originally estimated in July. A year-over-year productivity increase of 4.8 percent was the fastest since the fourth quarter of 1983.
The Commerce Department said factory orders in July surged 4.7 percent after falling 2.5 percent in July, lifted by a record increase in orders for machinery.
Shipments of nonaircraft capital goods outside military industries rose 3 percent, which economists said was a sign that businesses were starting to feel more confident about the recovery and hence more willing to replace outdated equipment.
Excluding transportation equipment, orders rose 1.8 percent after a 1.8 percent decrease.

HEADLINE: In West African Visits, Powell Seeks to Prime Oil Pumps 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell visited a group of girls orphaned by the civil war in Angola and a new rain forest preserve in Gabon today to underscore Washington's efforts to strengthen ties to two West African countries that are significant oil exporters to the United States. 
 Angola is one of the top 10 oil providers to the United States, and its ranking could rise as its offshore reserves are tapped. Those reserves could become more important if unrest in the Middle East or an American invasion of Iraq cause upheavals in the oil market. 
 For that reason, maintaining stability and improving Washington's relations with Angola have become high priorities for the State Department. As a sign of Angola's growing importance, Secretary Powell broke ground today for a new embassy in Luanda, the capital. 
Secretary Powell, on the final day of a three-nation African trip, also met privately with Angola's president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos. During most of Angola's 28-year civil war, which formally ended earlier this year, the United States supported Mr. dos Santos's chief rival, Jonas Savimbi. After the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, who had backed Mr. dos Santos, the United States ended its backing for Mr. Savimbi. In 1993 Washington established relations with Mr. dos Santos's government. 
Mr. Savimbi was killed in February, and an agreement to end the long conflict between Unita and the government was signed April 4. 
Angola, a former Portuguese colony, has one of the largest oil reserves in the world, but widespread corruption and the civil war combined to ruin its economy, as well as killing as many as one million people and displacing nearly two million more. The armistice has left 80,000 former Unita fighters and their families interned in 36 relocation camps waiting to return home.
Conditions in some of those camps are said to be poor, and American officials said they are worried that rebel soldiers will take up arms against the government again if they are not allowed to return to their homes and provided with jobs soon. 
Besides meeting with girls orphaned by the war, Secretary Powell also met with a multinational commission that is overseeing the implementation of the April accord that ended Angola's civil war. He told the commission members, which included Russian and Portuguese officials, that the United States would provide aid to help resettle rebel soldiers, and urged the two sides to foster reconciliation.
"The people of Angola have suffered enough," Secretary Powell said. 
But in an hourlong meeting with Mr. dos Santos, the secretary conveyed a sterner message, urging the Angolan president to end corruption and open the political process to Unita party members, American officials said.
According to estimates that American officials consider accurate, Angolan officials siphon off as much as $1 billion from Angola's $6 billion in oil revenues each year. Angola's oil production is expected to increase significantly, to 1.2 million barrels a day, in the next three years as new offshore reserves are tapped.
"Secretary Powell emphasized that you have to take the wealth you have and use it for your own people," a senior State Department official said.
American "petroleum security" was an important subtext to Secretary Powell's visits today, American officials said.
In Gabon, the secretary visited a new forest preserve just a few miles from Libreville, the capital, Secretary Powell praised Gabon's conservation policies as an example of what a "stable, responsible government" can achieve.
The preserve, Pongara National Park, contains elephants, hippopotamuses, crocodiles and monkeys, and is one of 13 new national parks created by Gabon's president, Omar Bongo, with aid from environmental groups, timber companies, the United States and other developed countries. The parks will contain 10,000 square miles of endangered forest, representing 10 percent of the nation's land mass.
The United States has pledged to spend more than $50 million over the next four years for such conservation programs in the six central African countries that encompass the Congo River basin forest, one of the world's largest rain forests.

HEADLINE: Edison Schools Cancels Harlem Building Plan 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Edison Schools Inc., the nation's largest private operator of public schools, said yesterday that it would abandon plans to build a $125 million national headquarters across Fifth Avenue from Central Park in Harlem, setting back one of the linchpin projects for the neighborhood's transformation.
 The chairman of the struggling company, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., said in a telephone interview that "under our current financial situation we have to focus all our energy and all our financial resources on our core business, which is managing public schools." 
 Whatever Edison's calculations involved, many New York City officials and residents of Harlem had looked to the project as an extra spark plug for the neighborhood revitalization that has already brought mainstream retailers like Old Navy and Starbucks, Bill Clinton and a Broadway-caliber show into the once-battered commercial spine of 125th Street. Ground was to be broken for the Edison complex later this year. 
"I do consider it a huge loss for the community in terms of economic development," said C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president.
Charles B. Rangel, who represents the area in Congress, was more sanguine, however, saying the site on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 110th Street was likely to entice other developers.
"You're not going to tell me that a building overlooking Central Park North is not an ideal spot in our city," Representative Rangel said.
His major concern, he said, is that Edison's decision to pull out may hurt a companion plan to relocate the Museum for African Art on an adjacent Fifth Avenue lot owned by Edison. Mr. Schmidt said at a conference with investors broadcast on the Web that Edison planned to sell the lot to maximize its capital, suggesting that the museum might not end up with it. But Elsie C. McCabe, the museum's president, said it has the first option to buy the lot, which Edison bought for $10 million.
As envisioned in headier times, Edison was to move uptown from its headquarters at Fifth Avenue and 43rd Street to a roughly 15-story building the company and a development partner would put up on a five-parcel site overlooking Central Park's Harlem Meer. Edison owns the lot fronting on Fifth Avenue, the city the other four, but Edison would have given its site to the museum in exchange for the city lots. The idea was to link the museum, now in Long Island City, Queens, to the great museums along Fifth Avenue that style themselves as Museum Mile.
On the first six floors of the headquarters, Edison planned to build a tuition-free elementary school for 650 students. Supporters predicted that the project would bring 400 corporate jobs, many of them for Harlem residents, and that visitors would spend $2 million a year at nearby restaurants and shops.
In its eight years of operation, Edison has seemed to grow exponentially and now has contracts to manage 133 schools with 84,000 students, though it has yet to show a profit. Investors who once flocked to it as a hot stock were disenchanted by questions raised about its claims to have improved academic performance and by charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had provided inaccurate information about its past revenue. 
In recent months its stock price fell to less than $1, threatening its listing on Nasdaq, and several school systems canceled or scaled back their contracts with Edison. 
In the last week, the company's founder, H. Christopher Whittle, has put his $46 million estate in East Hampton up for sale in what appears to be an effort to pay personal debts resulting from the falling stock price.

HEADLINE: Ex-Official Of Vatican Pleads Guilty In Conspiracy 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
A retired Vatican official who is an expert on Catholic canon law pleaded guilty today to a federal conspiracy charge for his role in an international insurance swindle run by Martin R. Frankel, the Greenwich financier who is now in prison. 
 In a signed statement, Msgr. Emilio Colagiovanni, 82, whose career included sitting on the board that provides legal counsel to Pope John Paul II, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud and launder money. He faces a maximum of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. 
 In the six-page statement, Monsignor Colagiovanni, an Italian citizen and a priest for 60 years, said that in 1998 and 1999 he helped Mr. Frankel defraud American insurance companies that Mr. Frankel wanted to buy. His contribution, he said, was allowing his own Rome-based foundation, the Monitor Ecclesiasticus Foundation, which publishes a journal of canon law edited by the monsignor, to siphon $50 million of Mr. Frankel's money into a second foundation. It had been created by Mr. Frankel specifically to acquire the companies, the monsignor acknowledged. 
Mr. Frankel then told the companies' executives this second foundation, the St. Francis of Assisi Foundation, had received the $50 million from "various Roman Catholic charities and tribunals at the Vatican" interested in raising money for charitable causes, according to the plea.
In return for his acquiescence in the scheme and access to Vatican-based bishops and cardinals -- whose support Mr. Frankel and the monsignor sought, according to federal prosecutors -- Mr. Frankel paid the monsignor's foundation $40,000. 
Mr. Frankel pleaded guilty in May to federal corruption charges. He has also pleaded guilty to corruption and theft charges in Tennessee and Mississippi. He is expected to be sentenced next year.
In today's plea statement, Monsignor Colagiovanni named several Vatican officials whom he said he or aides to Mr. Frankel met with to seek their support in the scheme. They include Msgr. Francis X. Salerno, secretary for the prefecture for the economic affairs of the Holy See, and Archbishop Giovanni Battista Re, in the secretariat of state office.
The document does not make clear whether these or other Vatican officials other than the monsignor helped Mr. Frankel's scheme; Mark G. Califano, the assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the case, would not comment on the matter this afternoon. 
Lieutenants working for Mr. Frankel first approached the monsignor in mid-1998, while he visited a sister, cousin and other family members in Ohio, the confession said. They told him that Mr. Frankel wanted to make a "sizable" donation to the church and help its charities, including the Mother Teresa Hospital in Albania. He was arrested in August 2001 in suburban Cleveland as his family was preparing to attend a memorial Mass for his sister.
He is due in court again on Dec. 9 for a status hearing and, possibly, his sentencing by Judge Ellen Bree Burns of Federal District Court, who also presided in court today.
