HEADLINE: Lost in the Labyrinth of Oil 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Ruta; Suzanne Ruta is the author of "Stalin in the Bronx: And Other Stories."

 BODY:
 THE DARK BRIDE
By Laura Restrepo.
Translated by Stephen A. Lytle.
358 pp. New York:
Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $24.95.
 NEARLY a million Colombians have abandoned the country in the last five years. For those who stay behind, life, in the fourth decade of civil war, is dangerous and difficult. But as a Spanish proverb has it, there's no bad but brings some good. Literature flourishes as threats and violence drive a generation of investigative journalists into what one former newsman calls "the exile of books."
Laura Restrepo made the switch from reporter to novelist a decade ago with great panache. When death threats from a mafia kingpin forced cancellation of her television mini-series in Bogota about drug cartels, she used her extensive research in a novel instead: "Leopard in the Sun" (1993) is an outrageous performance, a Garcia Marquez family saga reformatted by Quentin Tarantino. The same breezy elegance and quick wit enliven "The Angel of Galilea" (1995), which won major awards in Mexico and France. In it, a ditsy reporter for a Bogota magazine finds love and transcendence with a possibly divine denizen of the city's poorest slums. 
"The Dark Bride" is another reporter's novel, full of tantalizing repartee and details too piquant and quirky to have been invented. The setting is Colombia's oil fields -- in Restrepo's phrase, suggestively merging the worlds of George W. Bush and Jorge Luis Borges, "the oil labyrinth." As Colombia's oil output increased sharply in the 1990's, guerrilla groups attacked pipelines, while paramilitary organizations linked to the Colombian military attacked the guerrillas, and peasants were massacred in the cross-fire, or forced to run for their lives. Lately, the United States has entered the equation, since recent antiterrorism legislation sanctions broader military assistance than before. Foreign oil companies are part of the game. Occidental Petroleum, for example, provides Colombian soldiers who protect its pipeline with everything from uniforms to condoms, under the heading of "nonlethal" assistance.
While reporting on the human cost of this oil war from the heart of the country, the jungle town of Barrancabermeja, Restrepo met old-timers who told her such fantastic stories about events 50 years ago that she knew she had to put them in a novel (in fact, two novels; "La Multitud Errante" -- meaning "The Wandering Crowd" -- was published last year in Spanish and is still being translated). The title of "The Dark Bride" refers to a starving motherless Indian child, "a wild-haired, slippery, surly tadpole" who metamorphoses into a legendary beauty, the most sought-after prostitute in the oil fields beyond the mythic river town of Tora in the 40's, when the fabled Tropical Oil Company, the Troco, a branch of Standard Oil of New Jersey, had the concession to Colombia's oil. 
For girls like Sayonara (the young woman's exotic working name) -- orphaned, outcast victims of rigid race and class barriers -- prostitution was the only alternative to starvation or convent servitude. Restrepo says she found the right tone for this novel in Guy de Maupassant's story "La Maison Tellier," about a kindly, practical madam who takes a day off with her girls to attend a niece's first Communion at a church in rural Normandy where, unlike in the cities, no shame attaches to prostitution.
The story unfolds slowly, deep in the jungle, by the banks of the Magdalena, a sluggish river full of crocodiles. The novel is nearly half over before we learn what fearful atrocities far upriver marked the heroine for life. Some chapters are lovely set pieces. A riverside picnic of dark-skinned women with flowers in their hair evokes Gauguin. Every character and scene in the Maupassant tale gets its tropical equivalent.
The reporter-narrator puzzles out the meaning of her story with engaging open-mindedness. She may doubt that such a genre as "tropical tragedy" exists: "The excessive light of the tropics blurs the sharp contours of any drama . . . and finally dissolves it in forgetfulness." But she claims tragic stature for her working class heroes. Sayonara's tragedy rises from her love for an oilman, whose only loyalty is to "skinny Emilia," an old derrick shipped down from the United States to drill 3,000-foot wells. If prostitution is a lifeline of sorts for Sayonara, for the oilmen, their employment was a key to heaven: "In the middle of that vast, drifting humanity, to become a petrolero meant salvation." 
In this fragile environment there is a brief, happy symbiosis, as a veteran of the Troco recalls in the 90's: "The petrolero worked hard and earned his money. The prostituta worked hard and ended up with the petrolero's money. They say that love for money is a sin, but I say it's nothing more than the law of economy, because bread doesn't fall from the sky for anyone." 
Timely messages about globalization, the shibboleths of free trade and economic growth float through this river of a novel. The narrator looks back on the 40's as a golden age, when all men asked in Tora was the chance to dream a little. The oilmen, living for rare trysts with the demure, elegant beauties of the town, are compared to gallant troubadours, who love from a distance. This is a far cry from the Colombia of tacky billionaire drug lords and casual murder.
When the oilmen strike, their demands are not for money but for decent meals in the company canteen. The company calls in the army; there is a massacre; the prostitutes stage a sympathy strike, hiding hunted oil workers in their closets . A brief, euphoric rebellion fails. The company concludes that men with wives and children are more docile than romantic loners. The prostitutes' houses are razed, replaced by one-family bungalows, and an era of enforced respectability dawns in Colombia.
Some of this bad news -- and it still is news in Latin America -- feels predictable or coy in the telling. The mysterious Sayonara tends to vanish into her own myth. The narrator's exuberant rhetoric doesn't always convince, despite the best efforts of the translator, Stephen A. Lytle. But perhaps it's not meant to. The narrator burbles so that her ancient informants can interrupt with tart, terse, reductive quips. These old folks stranded in their backwaters, living in "impeccable poverty," embody enduring Colombian virtues: "the cordial treatment and beautiful manners . . . that despite the ravages of violence you still find everywhere in this country, even on the part of people who don't know a thing about you." The real romance in this novel -- the source of its liveliest passages -- is a reporter's love for her indomitable sources.

HEADLINE: A Nation of Travelers Hard to Pin Down 

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS; GLENN COLLINS is a reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
AS the nation edgily approaches this anniversary of terrorist horror, the mood of the American traveler could hardly be more idiosyncratic, contrary and -- face it -- harassed. 
 There have been plenty of generalizations about Americans' penchant for regional cocooning and their rampant Jetway aversion. But sweeping pronouncements do little justice to the mosaic of ironies that is now the country's travel agenda. 
 Even seemingly benign backwaters of tourism are confronting anomalies. Consider, for example, cruise lock at the Hubbard Glacier. "It was hurry up and turn around," said Sanford Teller, a passenger from New York who for years had anticipated a leisurely cruise past the Alaskan natural wonder. Stellar views -- and not personal security -- were on his mind when he booked the cabin with his wife, Roberta Dougherty. 
But Mr. Teller did not reckon on the unprecedented pod of about 25 cruise ships plying those waters during his voyage in July. Many ships had been moved from the Mediterranean and Baltic because skittish tourists assumed Alaska was safely remote.
And so, he and some 1,900 other eager passengers on the Sea Princess trained their cameras on the legendary glacier as it hove into sight -- and then helplessly watched it retreat as the liner made way for the assembly-line procession of the cruise megaships waiting their turn. 
These days, traditional travel certainties are as dodgy as the Dow Jones industrial average. "It has been the most complex travel season we've seen in a very long while," said David Barna, chief of communications for the National Park Service. 
In a sense, it is a wonder anyone travels at all, considering the quotidian headline crawl: Tanking retirement funds. Terrorist alerts. Suicide bombings. Indian-Pakistani nuclear posturing. Western forest fires. European floods. Airline bankruptcies. 
"There is a tremendous feeling of unease," said Malcolm M. Knapp, a hospitality and restaurant consultant in Manhattan. "Most people have exceeded their point scale for stress." 
America is venturing forth nevertheless, perhaps because travel is an attribute of a zealously guarded lifestyle for many who hold dear the fundamental freedom of the getaway and stubbornly refuse to let terrorists dictate their vacation itineraries. 
Despite the gnawing economic downturn, leisure travel -- which dried up after Sept. 11 -- has rebounded. Volume (measured by the number of person-trips by Americans) increased about 3.1 percent in 2001 and is expected to increase again this year, by another 1.3 percent, according to the Travel Industry Association of America. 
"But travel spending levels were down 9 percent this summer," said Cathy Keefe, the association's manager of media relations, who projected a drop of a few percentage points for 2002. This, after domestic travelers spent $27 billion less on travel in 2001 and foreign visitors to the United States spent $9.7 billion less. 
Through the year, travelers' reactions have been highly diverse. About 15 percent expressed only cautionary concerns about future trips, seeing the terrorist attacks as an aberration, said Douglas K. Shifflet, president of D. K. Shifflet & Associates, a travel industry market researcher who has surveyed thousands of travelers. 
A much larger group -- about 35 percent of male and female travelers on the East and West Coasts -- "were fairly cowed by the events of last fall," Mr. Shifflet said, "and are traveling at about half the rate they used to."
Only 5 percent of travelers said that they were prepared to take severe action against other passengers who posed a threat. About 10 percent of travelers, mostly in the Midwest, said they didn't pay that much attention to the news and didn't feel seriously threatened themselves. 
Of course, there was also a carpe diem group -- about 15 percent, largely moderate-income females -- who took the terrorist attacks as a signal to travel more, Mr. Shifflet said. "They were glad to have survived, and vowed to travel more in the future -- even going into debt to have the experience," he said.
Nowhere is the new touristic dichotomy more apparent than at the nation's 385 national parks, seashores and memorials, which drew 280 million visitors in 2001, 5 million fewer than in 2000, Mr. Barna said. 
Attendance at such iconic national-park destinations as Yosemite and the South Rim of the Grand Canyon is down 15 percent this year, he said, due to economic worries and a decrease in foreign visitors. Formerly some 40 million strong, they used to amount to about 15 percent of park tourists.
Yet such places as Civil War battlefields, presidents' homes and the Liberty Bell have been mobbed because "they tend to be local destinations in a time when people are traveling locally," Mr. Barna said, "and the events of Sept. 11 have given many Americans a renewed sense of patriotism." 
In the end, uncertainty reigns and the park service "doesn't know if we're going to be down in 2002 -- due to the loss of international visitation -- or up because of the interest in patriotic sites," Mr. Barna said. 
The patriotic travel impulse -- and perhaps a yearning for the good old days -- has enriched not just parks but also many regional institutions, such as the Mariners' Museum in Newport News, Va. Since the summer travel season kickoff in May, the museum has gotten 1,500 visitors a week instead of 1,000, according to its president, John B. Hightower. 
The patriot bonus has not, however, gone very far to offset the deficit at big-city museums caused by the steep slump in air travel, which is down 7 percent for the year; tourist air-travel destinations as utterly disparate as the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Hawaii have been affected. 
Millions of air travelers have overcome their fears after Sept. 11 and resigned themselves to unprecedented delays, schedule cutbacks and root-canalish security checks. But for others, the indignity of being patted down in questionable airport security rituals is hard to accept. 
Ida R. Chamberlin of Newfane, Vt., said she couldn't believe she was the only one chosen for scrutiny in a line of 30 travelers at Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina last month. 
"I look like the little old lady from Dubuque with the tennis shoes," said Ms. Chamberlin, who is 70 and was, in fact, wearing tennis shoes. 
Her purse was checked, she was wanded, and then she had to remove said tennis shoes in front of the entire line of travelers. "It was humiliating enough to be seen as a risk to one's nation, without having everyone else invited to watch," she said. "Couldn't they screen me off?" 
When Ms. Chamberlin politely told security personnel that she felt embarrassed, they suggested she take the train. "I'm not a big traveler," she said, "but I don't know if I'll be flying domestically again soon." Delta Air Lines has estimated that airlines will lose $3.8 billion in 2002 thanks to passenger annoyance about security and other air-travel inconveniences. 
Conversely, other fliers embrace the most stringent scrutiny. "Even security in Morocco was much better than that in the United States," said Jane Green, who owns an insurance agency in Indianapolis and took an adventure trip to Morocco in October. "At J.F.K., it was so cursory," she said. 
For many reasons, even very frequent international fliers are taking a pass. "I was never afraid of flying and I'm not afraid now," said Jean Tarbel, a 75-year-old retired law librarian in Denver who used to fly to Europe and Asia several times a year. "It's the money situation. The way the market has been, it is not the time to be spending frivolously." 
Europe -- the destination for half of all Americans making an overseas trip -- lost 1 percentage point of market share to other regions in 2001, and this summer Americans spent nearly $2 billion less in Europe than they did last summer, according to Einar Gustavsson, United States chairman for the European Travel Commission in Manhattan, a trade group for 33 nations. He said that by the end of this month more than five million Americans will have flown to European destinations this year, down 15 percent over the same period last year.
France has seen a 10 to 12 percent decline in American tourists since the beginning of the year, said Patrick Goyet, director of the French Government Tourist Office in the United States. 
Preliminary reports suggest that Britain is doing better than expected, but Spain and Italy have lost tourists because of cuts in airline seating capacity, said Neil S. Martin, marketing consultant for the commission. 
In general, the Caribbean is doing well, and Latin America has also benefited from the shift in tourist destinations. Travelers are understandably averse to what they perceive as troubled areas, said Harriet F. Friedlander, chairwoman of Academic Arrangements Abroad, which is offering 125 high-end museum tours this year. Her company has removed Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Morocco, Tunisia and Syria as destinations. 
Educational and museum-oriented trips are holding up very well, Ms. Friedlander said. The company's business was off 45 percent immediately after Sept. 11, but the company now projects that it will be down 5 percent this year. 
And adventure travel is making a comeback, after a serious slump. Nicholas Ballard, marketing director for San Francisco-based Geographic Expeditions, said that high-end adventure travel at his company is down 25 percent over last year. Geographic organizes travel for 4,500 people a year on small group tours to exotic destinations, costing $2,600 to $6,800; individual private clients may spend more than $200,000. "Our regular clients are coming back," Mr. Ballard said, "but there aren't as many new clients now." 
The cruise industry had 6.9 million travelers from North America in 2001, up 1 percent over the previous year. Bob Sharak, executive director of the Cruise Lines International Association, predicts 7.4 million passengers by the end of the year, a 7.3 percent increase over 2001. Partly because of tighter budgets or a desire not to be away from home too long, two- to five-day cruises are now more popular.
Cruise travel has also saved the day for some destinations like the Bahamas, where 85 percent of tourists come from the United States. The number of visitors has been running about the same as last year thanks to sea arrivals, which were up 5.3 percent; air arrivals were down 8.7 percent. 
"Our ships are going out full," Mr. Sharak said, "but the scary part is that the booking curves have changed. People used to book six months in advance. Now it's six weeks. We're chewing our nails." About 20 percent of American travelers now plan trips within two weeks of taking them, and about half of travelers one month before, according to the Travel Industry Association of America. 
"You don't have to plan as far in advance when you're going to hop in the car," said Andrea Stueve, the association's director of market research. Car travel in the United States is up slightly over last year, by 1 to 2 percent, "because a lot of car trips are substituting for shorter airplane trips," said Mantill Williams, spokesman for the AAA. 
In what some think of as the new car culture, local and regional theme parks are doing well, while destination parks like Walt Disney World have suffered without air travelers to feed them, most notably international visitors. "Visitation at all our parks is off roughly 6 percent from last year," said Jacquee Polak, a spokeswoman for Walt Disney World, "and international visitation particularly is a challenge." 
Beyond this, "United States travelers are shying away from big cities, both here and abroad," said Ron Erdmann, deputy director of the Office of Travel and Tourism Industries of the United States Department of Commerce.
The age-old hotel goal of putting heads in beds has been frustrated by the decline in air travel, especially in luxury hotels, dependent as they are on high-end foreigners and business road warriors. Hotels that once welcomed air travelers have embraced drive-in patrons, who have replaced them to some extent. 
Air arrivals in San Francisco were off 16.8 percent during the first six months of the year, and hotel prices plummeted 15 percent in comparison to last year, to an average of $149.04 per room.
The imminent question for the travel industry is the national mourning and reflection this Wednesday. Many fear that the anniversary will cast a pall over the fall travel season. But they may underestimate the contrariness of the new American traveler. "For the diehard, this will be the best of times to travel, since there will be fewer people milling around the Pyramids," said Mr. Ballard of Geographic Expeditions. 
Looking forward, seasoned travelers are taking their chances. "The danger is that this terrorist war is going to go on and on," said Ms. Green, the adventure traveler from Indianapolis. "I don't think we are ever again going to have that feeling, in an airport, that it's open and free."

Happy campers
 Airlines, hotels, travel packagers and tour operators have indulged in bargain offers and promotions, putting up a price-cutting pinata. And the car, the recreational vehicle and the campground have become America's new fail-safe options when bargain-hunting fails. 
"In this economy everyone wants a deal," said Butch Street, a management analyst with the National Park Service. "People are waiting on Priceline, and they are waiting longer and longer to finalize. And if the price doesn't go down, then they don't go anywhere." Or they head for the van. 
Visits at Kampgrounds of America's nearly 500 branches are up about 2 percent over all, and up 4 percent in the Northeast, said Mike Gast, a KOA spokesman in Billings, Mont., and sales of trailers and motor homes are up. 
Many travelers are renewing family ties, "and a lot of them are staying with us," said Mr. Gast. Many committed budget travelers are having their reunions at the growing number of campgrounds that supply large meeting rooms, centralized kitchens and cabin units. "Our reunion business is up 30 percent over last year," he said. GLENN COLLINS

GRAPHIC: Photos: The KOA Kampground in Newburgh, N.Y., part of a nationwide chain profiting from a camping boom. A different story at Yosemite. (Photographs by Chris Ramirez for The New York Times campground and John Elk III/Lonely Planet Images Yosemite )(pg. 9); The Liberty Bell draws lots of locals; economic woes and fewer foreigners have cut Grand Canyon crowds.  Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 91

LENGTH: 2690 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/ARTIFACTS; 
Einstein's Letters, Faberge Fauna and Prewar Chic

BYLINE:  By MITCHELL OWENS (Compiled with the assistance of ANNA BAHNEY.); Mitchell Owens is the Interior Design Director of Elle Decor.

 BODY:
 September

'PICTURES, PATENTS, MONKEYS AND MORE . . . ON COLLECTING' -- O.K., it's official. Anything can be collected, but what distinguishes one man's trash from another's treasure? It's a question to ponder, as the Institute of Contemporary Art shows off four distinctly different, highly personal caches: edgy contemporary art, patent models (a dog-powered treadmill?), sock monkeys and an assortment of Egyptian figurines and amulets collected in the early 1900's by a globe-trotting Yankee socialite. Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia. Through Dec. 15. (215-898-5911) www.icaphila.org

'SCHIMMEL AND MOUNTZ: TWO PENNSYLVANIA CARVERS' -- Exotic creatures secured in pens for public exhibition may raise the ire of animal-rights activists, but who could object to a forest's worth of wildlife made of carved wood? Back in the 19th century, Wilhelm Schimmel, a German immigrant, and Aaron Mountz, a poor farmer, both wrought hundreds of fantastical eagles, bears, cranes, owls, roosters and other wildlife, some of them life-size, while others are no bigger than a handbag. Approximately two dozen pieces will be on view. Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Museum, Williamsburg, Va. Through February. (757-220-7698) www.colonialwilliamsburg.org

'FREEDOM' -- What America's celebrated freedoms really mean, through the work of artists like Arthur Dove, Peter Hurd, Larry Rivers and Jacob Lawrence and craftsmen like Paul Revere (yes, the guy who galloped round Boston). Georgia Museum of Art, Athens. Through next Sept. 22. (706-542-4662) www.uga.edu/
gamuseum

'THE QUILTS OF GEE'S BEND' -- The title of this show sounds a bit like an obscure comedy by the filmmaker Preston Sturges, but it's actually about the artistic endeavors of one of America's most isolated communities, Gee's Bend, Ala., whose black residents were trapped by a fluke of geography (and a curious lack of ferry service). Highly imaginative, marvelously modernistic quilts made by four generations of Gee's Benders will be displayed. Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Today through Nov. 10. (713-639-7300) www.mfah.org. Traveling to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Nov. 21-March 2.

'SEPTEMBER 11: ARTISTS RESPOND' -- Responding to a craft-show organizer's call to address the events of Sept. 11 in creations no larger than six inches square, more than 60 American artists went to work. Many of the pieces, which have been donated to the American Craft Museum's permanent collection, rely on the vocabulary of invasion, incorporating everything from a copper dish scarred with bullets to the teeth of a Holocaust survivor. Each is a startlingly intense expression of another day that will live in infamy. American Craft Museum, New York. Wednesday through Jan. 5. (212-956-3535) www.americancraft
museum.org

'STATE OF EMERGENCY: DISASTER RESPONSE IN CALIFORNIA' -- When mud slides threaten, fires rage and earthquakes do the shake-and-bake, who ya gonna call? Well, in California, it's the Office of Emergency Services (O.E.S). Scores of photographs by Maggie Hallahan chronicle a decade of natural disasters in the Golden State and how they were handled by relief workers, firefighters and other professionals associated with the O.E.S. Historical disasters, like the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, are surveyed as well, and displays of emergency equipment, maps and other artifacts provide evocative counterpoints. Oakland Museum of Art, Oakland, Calif. Wednesday through Mar. 30. (510-238-2200) www.museumca.org

October

'FROM THE KILNS OF DENMARK: CONTEMPORARY DANISH CERAMICS' -- Latter-day masterpieces of the potter's art is the theme of this eye-opening show, which features more than 100 ceramic creations made especially for the exhibition by Danish artists and designers who established their names in the postatomic age. American Craft Museum, New York. Oct. 1-Jan. 5. (212-956-3535) www.americancraftmuseum.org

'GOUVERNEUR MORRIS TREASURES' -- Arguably America's greatest statesmen after Thomas Jefferson, though a bit of a pompous blowhard, Morris (1752-1816), the suave, wooden-legged New Yorker, was one of this country's most celebrated people in the 18th and 19th centuries -- raconteur, collector, senator, signer of the Constitution and the presumed author of its preamble, and United States minister to France. He was also dogged by a fair bit of notoriety, thanks to his marriage to a Virginia aristocrat who may or may not have murdered her born-out-of-wedlock baby. This 250th-birthday tribute does Morris the honor that has eluded him elsewhere. Where's Ken Burns when you need him? New-York Historical Society. Oct. 1-Jan. 20. (212-873-3400) www.nyhistory.org

'ENTERPRISING WOMEN: 250 YEARS OF AMERICAN BUSINESS' -- Glass ceiling or not, influential businesswomen have long been part of America's economic fabric. Forty-odd women of industry and pluck are profiled in this groundbreaking show that spans more than two centuries, including little-known women of importance like Mary Kaatherine Goddard, the Colonial publisher who printed an important typeset version of the Declaration of Independence; the Victorian inventor Martha Coston, who developed a military flare; and Olive Beech, the aircraft executive. National Heritage Museum, Lexington, Mass. Oct. 5-Feb. 23. (781-861-6559) www.mohn.org

'THE MIRACLES OF MARY: A 17TH-CENTURY ETHIOPIAN MANUSCRIPT' -- Medieval European monks weren't the only dab hands at illumination, the art of decorating manuscripts, particularly holy ones. In the late 1600's, African artists enlivened Ethiopian Orthodox inspirational texts with luxurious calligraphy and magnificent illustrations sparkling with gold leaf and jewel-tone paints. The manuscript on view celebrates 32 miracles associated with the Virgin Mary and recognized by the Ethiopian emperor Zara Jaeqob. Viewers who want to revel in the entire book will have to be patient: only one new dazzling page will be turned every two weeks. Art Institute of Chicago. Oct. 5-March 16. (312-443-3600) www.artic.edu

'MAESTRO DE PLATA: WILLIAM SPRATLING AND THE MEXICAN SILVER RENAISSANCE' -- William Spratling, New York-born, Mexico-based architecture professor turned writer turned arts promoter changed careers yet again around 1931 when the American ambassador to Mexico brought the silver mines of Taxco, Mexico, to Spratling's attention. The rest is history. Some of the ravishing jewelry, tableware and other south-of-the-border silver objects that Spratling made a must-have in the mid-20th century form the heart of this exhibition. They include a suitably barbaric necklace that Spratling made for the temperamental cosmetics queen Helena Rubenstein. There will also be equally sensational silver items created by Latin American craftsmen and artisans, past and present, who were emboldened by the American expatriate's success. San Antonio Museum of Art. Oct. 6-Jan. 5. (210-978-8100) www.samuseum.org

'THE GOLDEN AGE OF COSTUME AND SET DESIGN FOR THE BALLET RUSSE DE MONTE CARLO, 1938 TO 1944' -- It's tutus and toe shoes galore in this tribute to the late, great touring ballet company that was a mobile emblem of creativity from World War II until the 1960's. Included will be costume and set designs by eminences like Christian Berard and Eugene Berman and drawings by Salvador Dali, as well as deep background about the choreographers and pirouetting stars who made the Ballet Russe great, from George Balanchine to Agnes de Mille. Cincinnati Art Museum. Oct.10-Jan. 12. (513-639-2995) www.cincinnatiartmuseum.org

'KAZARI DECORATION AND DISPLAY IN JAPAN, 15TH-19TH CENTURIES' -- If you are expecting a paean to Zen purity and restraint, perhaps it's best that you stay home. Here it's all high-style sizzle and no little amount of swank in an exhibition that spans shogun military uniforms to courtesans' robes, extravagant screens to a rare set of painted cedar doors created for a 17th-century empress. Each object displayed is an example of "kazari," a school of art and thought meant to engender sensory excitement rather than mental serenity. Japan Society, New York. Oct. 17-Dec. 31. (212-832-1155) www.japansociety.org

'ARTS OF THE ISLAMIC WORLD.' -- Doris Duke was American Heiress No. 1 for most of her life, hounded by paparazzi, playboys, and a variety of hangers-on, but she found some considerable peace as an astute and energetic collector of Islamic artifacts. The Middle Eastern tiles, textiles, paintings and jewels that she used to decorate her Diamond Head estate, Shangri La -- which opens its door to the public on Nov. 6 -- increase this museum's already impressive Islamic holdings. Honolulu Academy of Arts. Oct. 27, permanent. (808-532-8700) www.honoluluacademy.org

November

'BLITHE SPIRIT: THE WINDSOR SET' -- They partied; they traveled; they dazzled. The international set that added social carbonation to the decades between Armistice Day and Pearl Harbor also dressed awfully well. Inspired by a 1940 charity fashion exhibition organized by the decorator Elsie de Wolfe and the Duchess of Windsor, Andrew Bolton, Costume Institute associate curator, examines the awe-inspiring frivolity and galvanizing chic of the fete set through designer duds once owned by best-dressed luminaries like Mona Williams (a rather dim Kentucky farm girl who married very, very well) and Daisy Fellowes (a classically beautiful, thrillingly ill-tempered Singer sewing machine heiress). Metropolitan Museum of Art. Nov. 1-Feb. 9. (212-535-7710) www.metmuseum.org

'CHARLES DICKENS: A CHRISTMAS CAROL' -- If television adaptations and radio readings have somehow cheapened this classic tale for you, then get back to basics. The powers that be at the Morgan Library pull Charles Dickens's original manuscript out of storage and put it on display in a longstanding holiday tradition. Morgan Library, New York. Nov. 26-Jan. 12. (212-685-0610) www.morganlibrary.org

'EINSTEIN' -- The thoughts, life, political leanings and scientific insights of one of the greatest minds of the 20th century are traced through an exhibition chockablock with letters, manuscripts and other proofs of Albert Einstein's genius. There will also be interactive displays. Alas, however, scholars have yet to figure out how the man handled that head of hair. American Museum of Natural History, New York. Nov. 15-Aug. 10. (212-769-5100) www.amnh.org

'THE WORLD OF THEODORE ROOSEVELT' -- Writer, environmentalist, big-business buster, cowboy, soldier, arts patron and America's only seriously bodybuilding president (the man pumped iron long before the Y.M.C.A. ordered its first set of free weights), Teddy Roosevelt was easily the most vital guy ever to settle down in the Oval Office. Telling the energetic tale are family mementos, historical artifacts, clothes, photographs, letters, and, just maybe, the great man's dumbbells. Bully! Nassau County Museum of Art, Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Nov. 17-Feb. 16. (516-484-9338) www.nassaumuseum.com

'LITTLE LUXURIES: BABY RATTLES AND TEETHERS FROM THE 18TH TO THE 20TH CENTURIES' -- Just when you thought accessories for the diaper set couldn't get much more extravagant, along comes a show that will leave competitive parents stupefied. Leave Junior at home, because surely his accouterments will seem woebegone beside the objects displayed here, many of which are wrought in glamorous materials like crystal and coral. Museum of Fine Arts, St. Petersburg, Fla. Nov. 23-April 27. (727-896-2667) www.fine-arts.org

December

'CULTURE AND COSTUME: DEPICTIONS OF JEWISH DRESS ACROSS FIVE CENTURIES' -- Dozens of colorful antique prints spanning hundreds of years have been assembled, each depicting the traditional costumes -- both real and imagined -- of Jewish communities around the world. Jewish Theological Seminary, New York. Dec. 12-April 15. (212-678-8000) www.jtsa.edu

'JEWELRY: THE COLONIAL WILLIAMSBURG COLLECTION' -- What the founding mothers and daughters wore is the theme of this vest-pocket show devoted to personal adornment in the Colonies and supported by oil portraits from the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Museum. One highlight is an engraved gold ring lost by Mary Broadnax, a Williamsburg girl of the 1700's, and rediscovered on an archaeological dig behind a local tavern. DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Museum, Williamsburg, Va. Dec. 21 through December 2003.(757-220-7724) www.colonialwilliamsburg.org

January

'WILLIAM MORRIS: ELEGY' -- Inspired by the death of his mother and moved by the fatalities of Sept. 11, the eminent American glass artist William Morris has created "Cinerary Urns," a spiritually and aesthetically wondrous assortment of vessels that recall the containers traditionally used to hold cremated remains. American Craft Museum, New York. Jan. 17-April 22. (212-956-3535) www.americancraftmuseum.org

'SURF CULTURE' -- Dude, where's my board? Perhaps it's ended up here, in a salute to the surfboard and its bleached-blond lifestyle. Tracing surfing's history from early Peruvian culture to the present day, this show will also spotlight the career of Duke Paoa Kanamoku, the hunky 1930's surfer who taught the tobacco heiress Doris Duke how to hang 10. (This traveling exhibition, which opened last summer at the Laguna Museum of Art in Laguna Beach, Calif., will be adapted to emphasize Hawaii's contribution to surf culture, including an 1850's oil painting of Hawaiian surfers in Hilo Bay.) The Contemporary Museum, Honolulu. Jan. 31-Mar. 30. (808-526-1322) www.tcmhi.org

February

'FRAKTUR TREASURES FROM THE SCHWENKFELDER LIBRARY AND HERITAGE CENTER' -- Just when you thought you knew everything there was to know about Pennsylvania German religious sects in America, along come the hitherto below-the-radar Schwenkfelders and their gaily illustrated documents. Brilliantly decorated with flowers and scrolls, elaborate lettering and lacy penmanship, the group's birth certificates and other official papers make today's just-the-facts-ma'am forms and applications seem positively soulless by comparison. American Folk Art Museum. Feb. 1-May 11. (212-265-1040) www.folkartmuseum.org

'ON THE WALL' -- Wallpaper as an art form has fallen into a bit of a rut since its 19th-century heyday, when fine artists applied their talents to rolls of paper intended for home decoration. Or then again, has its demise, like reports of the death of Mark Twain, been exaggerated? Seems so, if the contemporary wallpapers exhibited here bear honest witness, executed by artists as wide-ranging as Jenny Holzer, Andy Warhol and Carrie Mae Weems. Modern wallpapers by Virgil Marti and Francesco Simeti will also be included. Rhode Island School of Design Museum, Providence. Feb. 7-April 20. (401-454-6500) www.risd.edu

'THE FABERGE MENAGERIE' -- The Russian imperial jeweler Carl Faberge made everything a fashionable St. Petersburg noble could desire, from diamond-studded tiaras to pink-enamel photograph frames. But his most cunning creations are the tiny animals his craftsmen carved from semiprecious stones and set with all manner of fabulous gems in the years before the czar-toppling revolution. More than 100 of these wee wonders are herded together for the most comprehensive look to date at this particular corner of the master's art. Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. Feb. 13-July 27.(410-547-9000) www.thewalters.org

March

'VIETNAM: JOURNEYS OF BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT' -- More than 300 items have been gathered to depict contemporary life in this ancient country, which is in the midst of a 21st-century growth spurt. Among the items are a festival canopy, rabbit lanterns, Dao-initiation masks and embroidered wedding fabrics. American Museum of Natural History, New York. March 15 through January 2004. 212-769-5100) www.amnh.org

May

'MEXICAN TREES OF LIFE' -- Towering, ornamental, mystical and utterly fantastic, handmade ceramic trees of life have become an indelible Mexican pop-culture phenomenon over the last 50 years, captivating folk artists as well as top-flight potters. This bilingual exhibition presents 85 of these arborial extravagances, all produced by family-run potteries. Fowler Museum of Cultural History at U.C.L.A. May 17-Dec. 14. (310-206-6465) www.arts.ucla.edu

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Surf-Riders, Honolulu" (about 1919-20), a woodblock print by Charles W. Bartlett, is in the exhibition "Surf Culture: The Art History of Surfing," opening Jan. 31 at the Contemporary Museum in Honolulu. (The Contemporary Museum, Honolulu, Hawaii); Votive paper vehicles, for use by the dead, in "Vietnam: Journeys of Body, Mind and Spirit" at the Museum of Natural History in March. HEADLINE: The Mongols, the Medici and Iranian Modernism 

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER (Compiled with the assistance of ANNA BAHNEY) 

 BODY:
 September

'PIERRE BONNARD: EARLY AND LATE' -- With his fruity palette and eye for domestic interiors, the work of this Proustian painter is visual comfort food of a high order. Phillips Collection, Washington. Through Jan. 19. (202-387-2151) www.phillipscollection.org. Traveling to the Denver Art Museum, March 1-May 25.

'JOHN O'REILLY: ASSEMBLIES OF MAGIC' -- The first career retrospective for an artist who for 40 years has been making exquisite photographic collages that mix art history, religion, pornography and self-portraiture. Addison Gallery of American Art, Andover, Mass. Through Dec. 22. (978-749-4015) www.andover.edu/addison

'DAMIAN ORTEGA: COSMIC THING' -- Mexico City is turning out a crop of brilliant young artists. Damian Ortega is one of them, and this is his first solo museum show in the United States. It will include a Volkswagen Beetle, a car ubiquitous in Mexico but here reduced to useless pieces, which could be Mexico's fate in the big global picture. Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia. Through Dec. 15. (215-898-5911) www.icaphila.org

'FANTASTIC! THE ART OF COMICS AND ILLUSION' -- Contemporary comics culture is the source of some of the wildest art around, as these concurrent shows indicate. "Raw, Boiled and Cooked" looks at the history of the influential publication Raw, which Art Spiegelman helped found; "Widescreen" blows anarchic, hallucinatory strips up to mural scale; "Bay Area Blast" focuses on writers and artists around San Francisco. Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco. Through Oct. 13 (415-978-2700) www.yerbabuenaarts.org

'WILLIAM POPE.L: ERACISM' -- A maverick figure in American art for more than two decades, William Pope.L is best known for his carnivalesque, endurance-test public performances addressing race, poverty and power. This career survey includes a riveting selection of documentary film clips and gallery installations made from peanut butter, Pop Tarts and Wild Irish Rose bottles. Institute of Contemporary Art, Portland, Me. Through Oct. 17. (207-879-5742) www.meca.edu Traveling to Diverseworks, Houston, Jan. 10-Feb. 22; Institute of Contemporary Art, Portland, Ore., May 7-July 28; Artists Space, New York, Jan. 17-Feb. 29, 2004; and Mason Gross Art Galleries, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J., Jan. 5-Feb. 6, 2004.

'DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF LEWIS CARROLL' -- Lewis Carroll, a k a the Rev. Charles Dodgson, was a shy mathematician who stammered, loved little girls and wrote two of the strangest, funniest books in the English language. He was also a photographer, and 75 of his extraordinary pictures, mostly of children, are in this show. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Through Nov. 10, (415-357-4000) www.sfmoma.org. Traveling to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Feb. 22-May 19.

'DO-HO SUH' -- Individuality and displacement are among the themes of this young Korean-born artist who makes wallpaper from thousands of minute portrait photographs and full-scale silk houses that float in midair. Seattle Asian Art Museum and Seattle Art Museum. Through Dec. 10. (206-654-3100) www.seattleartmuseum.org

'VINCENT FECTEAU' -- Included in the recent Whitney Biennial, the work of this young artist is a cool, tabletop-size cross between abstract sculpture and architecture, painstakingly wrought from everyday material. Berkeley Art Museum. Through Oct. 6. (510-642-0808) www.bampfa.berkeley.edu. Traveling to the Pasadena Museum of California Art, Dec. 4-Mar. 2.

'MONDRIAN: THE PATH TO ABSTRACTION, 1892-1914' -- The paintings of landscapes, figures and flowers in this show represent a Mondrian largely missing from the stately 1995 retrospective: the Romantic, the Theosophist, the artist who looked back at his youthful paintings at the end of his life and said, "For me, there is no difference between these early ones and the last ones; they are all part of the same thing." Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth. Through Dec. 8. (817-332-8451) www.kimbellart.org

'NEW WORK: ODILI DONALD ODITA' -- This Nigerian-born artist presents striking geometric abstract paintings with patterns and colors that refer to modernist painting, African textiles and the Internet. Miami Art Museum. Through Oct. 27. (305-375-3000) www.miamiartmuseum.org

'VOICE: A DECADE OF WORK BY LESLEY DILL' -- Lesley Dill's spiritually infused work includes paper dresses made from the words of Emily Dickinson's poems and choruses scored for a gospel choir. It's like a Conceptualist version of folk art and in a class by itself. C.U. Art Galleries at the University of Colorado, Boulder, through Nov. 2. (303-492-8300) www.colorado.edu/cuartgalleries. Traveling to the Contemporary Museum, Honolulu, Nov. 22-Jan. 12, and to the Scottsdale Museum of Contemporary Art, Feb. 8-May 11.

'EXPOSED: THE VICTORIAN NUDE' -- Our great-great-grandparents weren't so uptight after all. At least that's the message of this show of high art and tarted-up erotica -- it's hard to tell the difference -- by the likes of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Edward Burne-Jones and a passel of sculptors, photographers and illustrators. Brooklyn Museum of Art. Through Jan. 5 (718-638-5000) www.brooklynmuseum.org

'JO BAER: RECONCILIATION WITHHELD' -- This American abstract painter lived in Europe for much of her professional life. But the pictures in this show were done in New York between 1962 and 1975 and confirm what many people have always known: she's a major figure -- adventurous, progressive and ripe for rediscovery. Dia Center for the Arts, New York. Thur. through June 21. (212-989-5566) www.diacenter.org

'JOSE ANTONIO HERNANDEZ-DIEZ' -- This Venezuelan installation artist uses humor, commercial products and cultural cliches in a sardonic look at global economics. Palm Beach Institute of Contemporary Art, Lake Worth, Fla. Fri. through Nov. 17. (561-582-0006) www.palmbeachica.org. Traveling to Site Santa Fe, N.M., Jan. 24-April 19; and the New Museum of Contemporary Art, New York, July 3-Sept. 21.

'WINOGRAND: 1964' -- In 1964 the photographer Garry Winogrand drove across the United States to catch the face of a nation coming to grips with the assassination of a president, explosive racial unrest and the beginnings of the Vietnam War. The 150 pictures in this show, organized by the Center for Creative Photography in Arizona, are a time capsule of an era. International Center of Photography, New York. Friday through Dec. 1. (212-857-0000) www.icp.org

'GLORIA' -- A flashback to the feminist art of the 1970's with works by Hannah Wilke, Adrian Piper, Joan Jonas, Nancy Grossman, Carolee Schneemann, Yvonne Rainer and others. White Columns, New York. Friday through Oct. 20. (212-924-4212) www.whitecolumns.org. Followed by "Regarding Gloria," by younger artists inspired by these path-breaking figures. Oct. 25-Dec. 1.

'LEONARDO DA VINCI AND THE SPLENDOR OF POLAND: A HISTORY OF COLLECTING AND PATRONAGE' -- Drawn from Polish public and private collections, the exhibition contains artists unfamiliar to many of us, but also Hans Memling, Bernardo Bellotto, and -- the highlight -- Leonardo and his deeply bizarre "Lady With an Ermine (Portrait of Cecilia Gallerani)." Milwaukee Art Museum. Fri. through Nov. 24. (414-224-3200) www.milwaukee.org. Traveling to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Dec. 8-Feb. 16; and the Legion of Honor, San Francisco, March 8-May 15.

'THE NATIVE BORN: CONTEMPORARY ABORIGINAL ART FROM RAMINGINING, AUSTRALIA' -- The Asia Society had a hit in 1988 with "Dreamings: The Art of Aboriginal Australia" and may well repeat its success with this new arrival, organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney. The 200 bark paintings, weavings and wooden sculptures were created by artists in a small settlement in northern Australia. Asia Society, New York. Sept. 17-Jan. 5. (212-288-6400) www.asiasociety.org

'BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE' -- In the 1960's and 70's, when Islam was being politicized and the unrest that would lead to the 1979 Revolution was brewing, Western modernism mingled with traditional art in Iran and the artists took over the role of the poets as social commentators. This show, documenting these changes, should be fascinating. Grey Art Gallery, New York University. Sept. 18-Dec. 7. (212-998-6780) www.nyu.edu/greyart

'CHEN ZHEN: INNER BODY LANDSCAPES' -- The Chinese-born Chen Zhen (1955-2000) created sculptural installations that mixed Chinese and Western cultures in witty, often politically pointed combinations. Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston. Sept. 18-Dec. 31. (617-266-5152) www.icaboston.org. A tribute to the artist will open at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, in February.

'FACING THE MASK' -- Seventy masks from all over Africa in a museum's new temporary headquarters in Queens. Museum for African Art. Sept. 20-March 2. (212-966-1313) www.africanart.org

'BLANC-DE-CHINE: DIVINE IMAGES IN PORCELAIN' -- The white-glaze export porcelain known as Dehua ware, produced in southern China and all the rage during the Ming and early Qing dynasties, is in the spotlight here. China Institute Gallery, New York. Sept. 19-Dec. 7. (212-744-8181) www.chinainstitute.org

'JEAN FAUTRIER' -- The parallel, sometimes overlapping, paths of American and European abstraction in the 1950's and 60's is gradually mapped out in exhibitions. This one, devoted to a leading French painter, should add some valuable information. Haggerty Museum of Art, Milwaukee. Sept. 19-Dec. 29. (414-288-1669) www.marquette.edu/haggerty. Traveling to the Wallach Art Gallery, Columbia University, Jan. 28-Mar. 29; and the Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University, April 26-July 20.

'A LEGACY IN LANDSCAPES' -- Artists from Fragonard to Alex Katz are represented in a show of landscape prints from the New York Public Library's endlessly diverse holdings. New York Public Library. Sept. 20-Jan. 4 (212-869-8089) www.nypl.org

'KAY ROSEN: COLLAGES, 1999-2002' -- An artist who is known for her paintings of words as images, created collages and a wall drawing for this solo show. The Drawing Center, New York. Sept. 21-Oct. 26. (212-219-2166) www.drawingcenter.org

'THE SHAPE OF COLOR: JOAN MIRO'S PAINTED SCULPTURE' -- Whimsical 3-D work along with preparatory drawings from the prolific Surrealist. Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington. Sept. 22-Jan. 6. (202-639-1700) www.corcoran.org. Traveling to the Salvador Dali Museum, St. Petersburg, Fla., Jan. 25-April 27.

'JULIE MOOS' -- This artist's photographic double portraits reveal subliminal affinities and social tensions between the sitters. For this solo show she has produced large-format new works. Renaissance Society, University of Chicago. Sept. 22-Nov. 3. (773-702-8670) www.renaissancesociety.org

'RICHARD AVEDON: PORTRAITS' -- This celebrity photographer is seen to advantage in his stark, unflattering, often penetrating portraits. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Sept. 26-Jan. 5. (212-535-7710) www.metmuseum.org

'THE THAW COLLECTION: MASTER DRAWINGS AND OIL SKETCHES, ACQUISITIONS SINCE 1994' -- If this selection of works acquired by Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw is as gorgeous as the previous one at the Morgan Library, it will really be something to see. Morgan Library, New York. Sept. 27-Jan. 19. (212-685-0008) www.morganlibrary.org

'STRANGE MESSENGER: THE ART OF PATTI SMITH.' -- Patti Smith brought poetry and rock together with a slashing glamor. This show gives an idea of what she's been doing with photography, film and drawing. Andy Warhol Museum, Pittsburgh. Sept. 29-Jan. 5. (412-237-8300) www.warhol.org. Traveling to the Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston, March 28-May 18, and the Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia. Sept. 3-Dec. 14.

October

'COLOR AND ECSTASY: THE ART OF HYMAN BLOOM' -- This intense, idiosyncratic American artist, now in his late 70's, was highly regarded by Abstraction Expressionists in the 1940's, though he has remained a representational painter. Among his themes are Judaism, the landscape and the human body in a state of irridescent decay. National Academy of Design, New York. Oct. 2-Dec. 29. (212-369-4880) www.nationalacademy.org

'TOMOKO TAKAHASHI' -- Tokyo-born, now living in London and shortlisted for the 2000 Turner Prize, Ms. Takahashi assembles elaborately micromanaged installations from rubbish and found objects. Her material for this show will be scavenged from Hollywood studio prop archives. Hammer Museum, University of California, Los Angeles. Oct. 6-Jan. 5. (310-443-7000) www.hammer.ucla.edu

'NARI WARD' AND 'JOSEPH KOSUTH' -- For the Gardner's artist-in-residence program, the Jamaican-born Nari Ward collaborates with Boston schoolchildren on a project that will extend out of the museum and into the street. The Conceptualist Joseph Kosuth will examine aspects of the museum's fabled, staggeringly eclectic holdings. Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, Boston. Nari Ward, Oct. 6-Jan. 5; Joseph Kosuth, Jan. 24-April 6. www.gardnermuseum.org

'FROM COURT TO CARAVAN: CHINESE TOMB SCULPTURES FROM THE COLLECTION OF ANTHONY M. SOLOMON' AND 'CHINA REFIGURED: THE ART OF AH XIAN' -- These shows open simultaneously at Asia Society. The first is a truly fabulous display of ceramic guardian figures, entertainers and animals made for elite tombs from the Han to Tang dynasties. The second is a solo show of a contemporary Chinese artist who makes porcelain, lacquer and cloisonne portrait busts. Both shows Oct. 9-Feb. 9. Asia Society, New York. (212-288-6400) www.asiasociety.org

'GARY SIMMONS' -- Known in the 1990's for his fine, ghostly, half-erased drawings on racism and identity, Mr. Simmons presents new works, including photographs, video and sculptures in an exhibition organized by Thelma Golden. Studio Museum in Harlem. Oct. 9-Jan. 5. (212-864-4500) www.studiomuseum.org

'LORNA SIMPSON: PHOTOGRAPHS AND FILMS' -- Two concurrent shows at the Whitney include photographs and a film, made for the current Documenta, which tracks a month in the life of an unknown woman. Whitney Museum. Oct. 11-Jan 26. (800-944-8639) www.whitney.org. The Studio Museum in Harlem will also present a project by the artist, Oct. 9-Jan. 5.

'JUDY CHICAGO' -- A retrospective of the pioneer feminist artist will encompass her career from 1964 to the present with a focus on her 1971 work at Womanhouse and her iconic installation "The Dinner Party." National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington. Oct. 11-Jan. 5. (202-393-3235) www.nmwa.org. "The Dinner Party" will be exhibited at the Brooklyn Museum, Sept. 20-Feb. 9 and permanently installed there in 2004. (A related article is on Page 78.)

'ADOLPH GOTTLIEB: A SURVEY EXHIBITION' -- From the holdings of the Gottlieb Foundation comes a retrospective that includes seldom-seen work from the 1920's and 30's. Jewish Museum, New York. Oct. 11-Mar. 2. (212-423-3200) www.jewishmuseum.org

'ANNE VALLAYER-COSTER: PAINTER TO THE COURT OF MARIE-ANTOINETTE' -- A favored artist in pre-Revolutionary France, and one of only four women admitted to the French Academy, Vallayer-Coster specialized in paintings of lush floral still lifes. Dallas Museum of Art. Oct. 13-Jan. 5. (214-922-1200) www.dallas
museumofart.org. Traveling to the Frick Collection, New York, Jan. 21-Mar. 23.

'ROSEMARIE TROCKEL: SPLEEN' -- This always stimulating German artist will install a new suite of video projections that advance the feminist spirit that animates her art. Dia Center for the Arts, New York. Oct. 16-June 15. (212-989-5566) www.diacenter.org

'GILLIAN WEARING: MASS OBSERVATION' -- A decade's worth of films and video installations by the 1997 Turner Prize winner, who documents herself and others in moments of staged or accidental abandon. Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. Oct. 19-Jan. 19. (312-280-2660) www.mcachicago.org

'HANNELORE BARON: WORKS FROM 1969-87' -- German-born and self-taught, Ms. Baron (1926-87) was self-taught and lived and worked in the Bronx. Her small, abstract fabric-and-paper collages, ornamented with written symbols and chips of wood are like dark, time-stained messages from deep within the psyche. Macalester College Art Gallery, St. Paul, Minn. Oct. 19-Dec. 15. (651-696-6000) www.macalester.edu. Traveling to the Neuberger Museum of Art, State University of New York, Purchase, Jan. 12-March 23; Bass Museum of Art, Miami, April 5-June 1; Mennello Museum of American Folk Art, Orlando, Fla., July 5-Sept. 7.

'DEGAS AND THE DANCE' -- The ultra-urbane Degas was an habitue of the theater; dancers, offstage and on, were a recurrent theme. He painted them as a cross between night-blooming flowers and tautly designed machines with lives at once drab and magical. The show will include nearly 150 paintings, drawings and sculptures. Detroit Institute of Arts. Oct. 20-Jan. 12. (313-833-7900) www.dia.org. Traveling to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Feb. 12-May 11.

'MODIGLIANI AND THE ARTISTS OF MONTPARNASSE' -- Amedeo Modigliani lived fast, died young and left a seductive body of paintings, including female nudes of singular erotic warmth. This show places him in the context of the Parisian vie de Boheme and in the company of fellow cafe crawlers like Picasso, Rivera and Brancusi. Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalo. Oct. 22-Jan. 12. (716) 882-8700 www.albrightknox.org. Traveling to the Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, Feb. 9-May 25 and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 29-Sept. 28.

'HUNG LIU' -- This American artist's figurative paintings are based on archival photographs of China, her birthplace, but with the original images given a personal content. Laguna Art Museum, Laguna Beach, Calif. Oct. 27-Feb. 23. (949-494-8971) www.lagunaartmuseum.org. Traveling to the Crocker Art Museum, Sacramento, Calif., Mar. 7-May 4.

'FRED WILSON: OBJECTS AND INSTALLATIONS, 1985-2000' -- The role played by cultural institutions in perpetuating racist concepts is a major theme of an artist-activist having his first career retrospective. Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery, Skidmore College, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Oct. 26-Dec. 31. (518-580-8080) www.skidmore.edu/tang. Traveling to the Blaffer Gallery, the Art Museum of the University of Houston, May 3-Aug. 31.

'JAVIER TELLEZ' -- The imaginative installations created inside abandoned psychiatric hospitals by this young conceptualist have been as much about societal constraints as about mental illness. He has large thoughts and is worth keeping an eye on. Art in General, New York. Oct. 29-Dec. 21. (212-219-0473) www.artingeneral.org

'CARROLL DUNHAM' -- This New York painter's cartoon-apocalypse images have grown ever richer in form and more bitter in feeling over the last decade. He's at his peak, and this midcareer survey should pack a wallop. New Museum of Contemporary Art, New York. Oct. 31-Feb. 2. (212-219-1222) www.newmuseum.org

November

'ADVENTURES OF HAMZA' -- The Persian adventure tale known as the Hamzanama is an epic romance of heroes, monsters and bloody derring-do. It enthralled the Mughal emperor Akbar, who commissoned Hindu and Persian artists to illustrate it with some 1,400 paintings. Only a fraction of those survive. Nearly 60 will be in an eye-popping, action-packed show at the Brooklyn Museum. Nov. 1-Jan. 26. (718-638-5000) www.brooklynmuseum.org

'THE LEGACY OF GENGHIS KHAN: COURTLY ART AND CULTURE IN WESTERN ASIA, 1256-1353' -- Popular history -- i.e., Hollywood -- has cast Genghis Khan and his Mongol hordes as the bad guy of the steppes, but art offers a different perspective. His court, and those of the Ilkhanid rulers who were his heirs, both adapted and invigorated the cultures they encountered to produce an art of dynamic refinement, as the manuscripts, ceramics and textiles included in this show should demonstrate. Metropolitan Museum. Nov. 5-Feb. 16 (212-535-7710) www.metmuseum.org. Traveling to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, April 13-July 27.

'THE NEW OLD WORLD' -- Some studies say that the Taino, the indigenous people of the Caribbean at the time of Columbus's arrival, were entirely exterminated by European invaders. The photographer Marisol Villanueva argues against this "myth of extinction" in photographs documenting Taino traditions still active in Puerto Rico and Cuba. National Museum of the American Indian, New York. Nov. 7-March 30. (212-514-3700) www.nmai.si.edu

'PAINTING AS PARADOX' -- Rumors of the death of painting have always been greatly exaggerated. It's alive, and always has been. The news lies in what artists are doing with it. This salon-style show, organized by Lauri Firstenberg, assembles 50 painters to give us a notion of what's up. Artists Space, New York. Nov. 7-Dec. 21. (212-226-3970) www.artistsspace.org

'THE MEDICI, MICHELANGELO AND ART OF LATE RENAISSANCE FLORENCE' -- Florence's leading merchant dynasty had the bucks, the palazzo space and the political clout to collect the best Italian artists of the day. Prime works by some of them -- Michelangelo, Bronzino, the sociopathic Pontormo -- appear in an exhibition of 180 paintings, prints and porcelains. Art Institute of Chicago. Nov. 9-Feb. 2, (312-443-0193) www.artic.edu. Traveling to the Detroit Institute of the Arts, March 16-June 18.

'THE SENSUOUS AND THE SACRED: CHOLA BRONZES FROM SOUTH INDIA' -- From the 9th through the 13th centuries, the Chola dynasty in southern India perfected the sublime style of cast-bronze religious sculpture. The figure of the dancing god Shiva is well known, but those of lithe goddesses, skeletal ascetics and pudgy child-saints are no less enchanting. Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, Washington. Nov. 10-March 9. (202-357-2700) www.asia.si.edu. Traveling to the Dallas Museum of Art, April 6-June 15, and the Cleveland Museum of Art, July 6-Sept. 14.

'NALINI MALANI: HAMLETMACHINE' -- A leading Bombay-based artist uses traditional images and new technology in a text-and-video installation addressing the rise of Hindu fundamentalism. New Museum of Contemporary Art, New York. Nov. 13-Jan. 12. (212-219-1222) www.newmuseum.org

'CECILY BROWN' -- Willem de Kooning treated paint as a carnal substance. Ms. Brown keeps the faith with pigment-rich pictures that hide sexy bodies under abstract patterns. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Washington. Nov. 14-March 2 (202-357-2700) www.hirshhorn.si.edu

'SIGMAR POLKE: NEW WORK' -- Mural-size paintings and small-scale drawings by the most adventurous and unpindownable German artist of them all. Dallas Museum of Art. Nov. 16-March 1. (214-922-1200) www.dallasmuseumofart.org

'GENESIS: IDEAS OF ORIGIN IN AFRICAN SCULPTURE' -- Organized by Alisa LaGamma, this show will examine 17 distinctive traditions of African art that take their inspiration from concepts of how the world, human history and individual consciousness began. The centerpiece will be an array of 40 Ciwara antelope headdresses, delicate and powerful, from the Bamana people of Mali. The Met's last African show was a stunner; this one is likely to be, too. Metropolitan Museum. Nov. 19-April 13. (212-535-7710) www.metmuseum.org

'KEITH EDMIER AND FARRAH FAWCETT' -- Charlie's most sculpturally coiffed Angel actually studied sculpture in college; so did the young California artist Keith Edmier, who, as a child, was wowed by Ms. Fawcett on television. When he approached her with the idea of doing her portrait, she proposed that they make sculptures of each other. The result: a life-size double self-portrait. Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Nov. 21-Feb. 17 (323-857-6522) www.lacma.org

'GILLIAN JAGGER: SCULPTURE' -- Born in England but long a resident of the United States, Gillian Jagger does sculptures that cast a cold eye on elemental nature and make an expressive, personal thing of its raw forms. After a succession of stirring New York gallery shows, she's having a museum retrospective in Madison, Wis. Elvehjem Museum of Art. Nov. 23-Jan. 19. (608-263-2246) www.lvm.wisc.edu

'AUGUST SANDER: PEOPLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY' -- More than 200 photographs from the Sander archive in Cologne, Germany, make a lineup of the early-20th-century social "types" that the artist defined and documented. One Sander picture at a time is impressive; this many should be a revelation. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Nov. 29-Feb 23. (415-357-4000) www.sfmoma.org

December

'THE SMITHS: TONY, KIKI AND SETON' -- Work by the sculpture and painter Tony Smith (1912-80) and his artist-daughters, Kiki and Seton, are given an all-in-the-family showcase. Palm Beach Institute of Contemporary Art, Lake Worth, Fla. Dec. 1-March 23. (561-582-0006) www.palmbeachica.org

'R.S.V.P.: SARAH SZE' -- One of the most inventive of contemporary sculptors, Ms. Sze fills rooms, hallways, stairwells and odd corners with unbelievably intricate arrays of very small, everyday things held together with string, wire and thread. Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Dec. 4-Spring 2003. (617-267-9300) www.mfa.org

'JULIAN LAVERDIERE' -- Best known as a creator of the "Tribute in Light" memorial at ground zero last spring, this New York artist has also produced gloomy neo-Gothic sculptures with pulsating eletronic sound tracks. New pieces are promised for this show. Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, Fla. Dec. 4-Feb. 2. (305-893-6211) www.mocanomi.org

'GREGORY CREWDSON, TWILIGHT' -- Mr. Crewdson's photographs of spooky David Lynchian suburban tableaus are getting hokier each time out. But he has had a considerable influence on some younger artists, and that's interesting in itself. Aspen Art Museum, Colorado. Dec. 6-Feb. 2. (970-925-8050) www.aspenartmuseum.org. Traveling to Mass MOCA, North Adams, Mass., March 1-Feb. 2004.

'THE EDGE OF ENCHANTMENT' -- The "encantos," or enchantments, of the native communities of Oaxaca, Mexico, are physical spaces that mark thresholds to an unknown world. This multimedia exhibition will document some of them, as well as the histories, traditions and contemporary lives of the people of the Huatulco-Huamelula region. National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, New York. Dec. 12-Summer 2003. (212-514-3700) www.americanindian.si.edu

'LOUISE BOURGEOIS: EARLY WORK' -- Another piece in the puzzle of this artist's long but late-blooming career comes to light in a survey of paintings, sculptures and drawings from the 1940's and 50's, before she was "discovered" by the art world. Aspen Art Museum, Colorado. Dec. 13-Feb. 2. (970-925-8050) www.aspenartmuseum.org

'FIRST PHOTOGRAPHS: WILLIAM HENRY FOX TALBOT' -- Fox Talbot's early pictures (he was a 19th-century photography pioneer) of family, friends and his country home have the freshness of a sunny morning and the unreality of dreams. Organized by the San Diego Museum of Photographic Arts and the National Trust Fox Talbot Museum in Wiltshire, England, the show also includes work by several of his contemporaries. International Center of Photography, New York. Dec. 13-Feb. 16. (212-857-0000) www.icp.org. Traveling to San Diego, March-June 15.

'THE CORCORAN BIENNIAL' -- A bright young curator, Jonathan P. Binstock, is in charge of a temperature-taking show that has a reputation for being a bit snoozy. Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington. Dec. 14-March 2. (202-639-1700) www.corcoran.org

'FRENCH ART FROM THE PUSHKIN' -- This show of 72 paintings from the State Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow is one of those Poussin-to-Picasso affairs. You can't go really wrong with such an assortment, but you can't go brilliantly right either. Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Dec. 15-March 9. (713-639-7300) www.mfah.org. Traveling to the Los Angeles County Museum, July 27-Oct. 12.

January

'WANGECHI MUTU' -- A young artist recently seen at the Studio Museum in Harlem presents recent work, including figurative collages that refer to African her itage and postcolonialism. Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning, Queens. Jan. 11-March 15. (718-658-7400) www.jcal.org

'MARDSEN HARTLEY: AMERICAN MODERNIST' -- The first Hartley retrospective in 20 years considers all phases of his knotty, often audacious painting and may offer new perspectives on his aesethetic thinking and enigmatic personality. Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, Hartford. Jan. 17-April 20. (860-278-2670) www.wadsworthatheneum.org

'ROYAL ART LODGE' -- The first museum show for the collaborative team of six young Canadian artists, among them Marcel Dzama, who call themselves Royal Art Lodge, produce cool, zany drawings, as well as sculptures and videos. The Drawing Center, New York. Jan. 18-March 8. (212-219-2166) www.drawingcenter.org

'ELLSWORTH KELLY: RED GREEN BLUE' -- Like a classical poet, Mr. Kelly thrives on the formal strictures he sets for himself. In this selection of post-Paris paintings and studies from the late 1950's to the early 1960's he does miraculous things with shape, line and a palette of three colors. Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego. (858-454-3541) www.mcasd.org. Traveling to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (April-July), and the Whitney Museum (Aug.-Nov.).

'EDOUARD VUILLARD' -- Vuillard's dense, closed-up paintings of his family's Paris apartment are all puce and violet, light and shadow, infantile anxiety and adult objectivity. They make you want to dash outside for a breath of air, but they also keep pulling you back. This international retrospective, which also includes the artist's landscapes, portraits and theater designs, opens in Washington and moves on to Montreal, Paris and London. National Gallery of Art, Washington. Jan. 19-April 20. (202-737-4215) www.nga.gov

'LEONARDO DA VINCI, MASTER DRAFTSMAN' -- Sure to be a big draw, this show, organized by the Metropolitan Museum and the Louvre, assembles some 120 drawings made by this prodigious artist, demonstrating his interests in art, science and architecture. Loans from the fabled Windsor Castle and Vatican holdings will be there, including an unfinished painting with traces of the artist's fingerprints. Metropolitan Museum. Jan. 22-March 30 (212-535-7710) www.metmuseum.org.

'DEBATING AMERICAN MODERNISM: STIEGLITZ, DUCHAMP AND THE NEW YORK AVANT-GARDE' -- In early-20th-century New York, Alfred Stieglitz and his circle -- which included Arthur Dove and Georgia O'Keeffe -- looked to nature as the source of a new American modernism. Marcel Duchamp and his followers looked to machines, theories and Dada culture. The two titans duke it out in this show organized by Debra Bricker Balken. Georgia O'Keeffe Museum, Santa Fe, N.M. Jan. 24-April 20. (505-946-1000) www.okeeffemuseum.org. Traveling to the Des Moines Art Center, Iowa, May 9-Aug. 1.

'BILL VIOLA: THE PASSIONS' -- In images inspired by medieval and Renaissance devotional painting, the video artist explored how slowly changing facial expression and body language express emotional states. J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. Jan. 28-April 27. (310-440-7360) www.getty.edu

'THE CHALLENGE OF THE MODERN: AFRICAN-AMERICAN ARTISTS, 1925-1945' -- Lowery Stokes Sims organizes a show documenting the approaches used by early-20th-century African-American artists to establish themselves in the world of modern art without relinquishing or compromising the subjects that were important to them. Studio Museum in Harlem, New York. Jan. 29-March 30. (212-864-4500) www.studiomuseum.org

'JASPER JOHNS: DRAWINGS' -- Anything from the parsimonious output of this cryptic artist is an event, and several of the 35 works on paper seen here are from his personal collection. Menil Collection, Houston. Jan. 31-May 4. (713-525-9400) www.menil.org

February

'FRANK MOORE: GREEN THUMB IN A DARK EDEN' -- This artist, who died of complications from AIDS earlier this year, spent much of his spare time gardening at his home in rural upstate New York. His allegorical narratives combine memories of childhood with adult concerns about a fragile natural environment under siege. Albright Knox Gallery, Buffalo, N.Y. Feb. 1-April 20. (716-882-8700) www.albrightknox.org

'MONTIEN BOONMA' -- In the 1990's at the Asia Society, this Thai artist, who died two years, presented a walk-in abstract sculpture made of medicinal herbs and spices; other pieces have suggested temples and altars. His subject was the blending of art and Buddhist philosophy. This eagerly awaited look at his career will include soil drawings, candle and perfume paintings, metal sculptures of lungs and cosmological charts. Asia Society. Feb. 5-May 11. (212-288-6400) www.asiasociety.org

'NAYLAND BLAKE: SOME KIND OF LOVE, PERFORMANCE VIDEO 1989-2002' -- Large-scale environments, objects and videos make up a survey of work by an artist who has addressed popular culture, AIDS, gay identity and and racism with biting wit. Organized by the Tang Teaching Museum and Gallery at Skidmore College, where it will appear in October 2003. Center for Art and Visual Culture, University of Maryland, Baltimore. Feb. 7-March 22. (410-455-3188) www.umbc.edu/arts

'WHISTLER AND HIS CIRCLE IN VENICE' -- Next year is the centennial of Whistler's death. Several museums have scheduled shows of his work. The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington is one of them. Feb. 8-May 5 (202-639-1800) www.corcoran.org

'A SAINT IN THE CITY: SUFI ARTS OF URBAN SENEGAL' -- The art and culture of Islamic West Africa are viewed through the dynamic popular religious movement in Senegal known as the Mouride Way, inspired by the teaching of the Sufi saint Sheikh Amadu Bamba. Mouride art is visually thrilling, the ideas embodied complex. The show promises to offer a new perspective both on Islam and on contemporary Africa itself. Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California, Los Angeles. Feb. 9-Aug. 24. (310-825-4361) www.fmch.ucla.edu

'LUCIAN FREUD' -- Imported from the Tate Britain, this retrospective of the much-praised British artist encompasses paintings, drawings and prints from a 60 year career, among them psychodramatically fleshy portraits of family, lovers and friends. Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. Feb. 9-May 25. (213-621-2766) www.moca.org

'THOMAS GAINSBOROUGH, 1727-1788' -- The Tate Britain is the source of this exhibition of an 18th-century British slacker-artist who refused to read, compulsively missed deadlines and had one of the smoothest painting hands of his time. National Gallery of Art, Washington. Feb. 9-May 11. (202-737-4215) www.nga.gov. Traveling to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, June 15-Sept. 14.

'MATISSE PICASSO' -- Call it the Two Tenors, this made-to-order blockbuster arrives in New York from London and Paris. The story it tells isn't earth-shattering -- two art titans knew each other, had mixed feelings about each other and went about their business -- but the art sure hits those high notes. Museum of Modern Art, Queens. Feb. 13-May 19. (212-708-9400) www.moma.org

'MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE' -- Postponed from last season, this exhibition features the ambitious artist-impresario's five-part film project accompanied by related sculptures, photographs and drawings. His conceptual scope is vast (mythology, biology, pathology, spirituality); his formal resources are prodigious. The films will be screened daily. Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York. Feb. 21-May 11. (212-423-3500) www.guggenheim.org

'BADA SHANREN' -- A descendent of Ming royalty, Bada Shanren (1626-1705) became a Buddhist monk after the Manchu invasion and started painting at 60. Considered insane, he was a fantastically imaginative artist, as will surely be evident in two shows. One is at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, Washington, Feb. 16-July 27; the other at the adjoining Freer Gallery, April 27-Oct. 12. Much of the Freer's work is from the collection of Wang Fangyu (1913-97), himself a notable artist and scholar who "rediscovered" Bada Shanren. (202-357-2700) www.asia.si.edu

'CONVERSION TO MODERNISM: THE EARLY WORKS OF MAN RAY" -- May Ray was Emmanuel Rudnitsky from New Jersey before becoming a multitasking member of the Dada movements in New York and Europe. This show explores his local roots with paintings, photographs and works on paper. Montclair Art Museum, New Jersey. Feb. 16-Aug. 3. (973-746-5555) www.montclairartmuseum.org. Traveling to the Georgia Museum of Art, Athens, Sept. 20-Nov. 30, 2003 and the Terra Museum of American Art, Chicago, Jan. 23-April 4, 2004.

'ST. ADOLF-GIANT-CREATION: THE ART OF ADOLF WOLFLI' -- Wolfi (1864-1930) spent most of life in a Swiss psychiatric hospital, where he turned out streams of carefully executed and colored drawings and paintings. He was among the first figures to whom the iffy term "outsider artist" attached itself. American Folk Art Museum. Feb. 25-May 18. (212-265-1040) www.folkartmuseum.org

'BRONZEVILLE: BLACK CHICAGO IN PICTURES, 1941-43' -- The photographers Russell Lee, Edwin Rosskam, Jack Delano and John Vachon documented Chicago's South Side, one of the most important centers of African-American culture in the 20th century. The art historian Maren Stange brings more than 120 of their pictures together here. International Center of Photography. Feb. 28-June 8. (212-857-0000) www.icp.org

March

'ERNST LUDWIG KIRCHNER' -- Kirchner (1880-1938), who painted spikey-haired, sallow-skinned, protopunk figures, was a leader of early-20th-century German Expressionism. This show, organized in collaboration with the Royal Academy of Arts, London, is the first full-fledged look at him in decades. National Gallery of Art, Washington, March 2-June 1 (202-737-4215) www.nga.gov

'THE HISTORY OF JAPANESE PHOTOGRAPHY' -- Can this really be the first comprehensive United States survey of Japanese photography? Yes. Traveling to the Cleveland Museum of Art, May 25-July 20.

'MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING' -- Thanks to a pushy little guy named Napoleon, a lot of 17th- and 18th-century painting moved from Spain to 19th-century Paris, where it had a big impact on French art. That's the theme of this show, which matches up Velazquez, Murillo, Ribera and El Greco with Delacroix, Courbet, Manet and Degas. Metropolitan Museum. March 4-June 8. (212) 535-7710 www.metmuseum.org

'THE LAST EXPRESSION: ART AND AUSCHWITZ' -- The 200 pieces here, by artists who were interned and in many cases died at Auschwitz and other concentration camps, were made for various reasons, including as documents, decorations and gestures of resistance. Retrieved from German archives, most of the work has not been seen before. Brooklyn Museum. March 7-June 15. (718-638-5000) www.brooklynmuseum.org

'IN MEDIA RES' -- Like video 30 years ago, new media technologies in art today take their share of critical abuse but are here to stay, and to flourish. Four curators, lead by Michele Thursz, will suggest ways in which sculpture, painting, photography, installation and photography have dramatically changed with the incorporation of techhnological tools. Exit Art, New York. March 8-May 31. (212-966-7745) www.exitart.org

'RAFAEL TUFINO, PINTOR DEL PUEBLO/PAINTER OF THE PEOPLE' -- Now 80, Mr. Tufino was born in Brooklyn but has spent most of his life in Puerto Rico. The paintings, prints and book illustrations seen in this career retrospective reflect his profound immersion in the island's social and political life. Museo del Barrio, New York. March 13-August. (212-831-7272) www.elmuseo.org

'LAURA OWENS' -- This Los Angeles painter's work plays with the borders between representation and abstraction and finds pictorial sources in English embroidery, Chinese landscape and her own photographs. Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. March 16-June 22. (213-621-2766) www.moca.org

'WHITENESS: A WAYWARD CONSTRUCTION' -- If this show about an ultra-loaded racial and social symbol is on the ball, it could be important. It's lineup of artists including Adrian Piper, Byron Kim, Enrique Chagoya, Jeff Koons and Gary Simmons. Laguna Art Museum, Laguna Beach, Calif. March 23-July 6. www.lagunaartmuseum.org

'FAITH HOPE AND IMPOSSIBILITY: THE ART OF PHILIP GUSTON' -- A comprehensive survey takes the painter from political work in the 1940's, through a fine-grained abstraction in the 50's and 60's, to a return to the figure in the 1970's that caused a collective art world gasp, secured his reputation and immeasurably extended his influence. Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth. March 23-June 8. (817-738-9215) www.mamfw.org. Traveling to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, June 28-Sept. 28.

'HIMALAYAS: AN AESTHETIC ADVENTURE' -- Pratapaditya Pal organizes a showcase of religious and secular works from the Himalayan countries, including Kashmir, Nepal and Tibet.
